('38', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. SPEECH AT MEETING OF DEPRESSED CLASS SCHOOLS, CALCUTTA 1
('38', 0, 2, 3, 101) January 2, 1927
('38', 0, 3, 4, 117) Mahatmaji in reply said that he never knew that the members of the depressed classes would present him with an address.
('38', 0, 3, 5, 237) He felt their troubles and untold miseries and he sometimes wanted to become an untouchable so that he would clearly realize their position in the country.
('38', 0, 3, 6, 393) Mahatmaji was sorry to say that the members of the Hindu community were not helping them in any way.
('38', 0, 3, 7, 494) On the other hand, they were having their service in the way of labour.
('38', 0, 3, 8, 566) The country would be ruined if that feeling prevailed in the Hindu community.
('38', 0, 3, 9, 644) Swami Shraddhanand who had sacrificed his valuable life in removing untouchability from the country had said that, if he saw that the Hindus were keeping at least one depressed class boy in their house, he would think that the Hindus were really feeling for the untouchables in the country.
('38', 0, 3, 10, 935) Before that Swamiji expected that they should give up the habit of drinking, gambling, and other vices which always kept them behind the other communities in the country.
('38', 0, 4, 11, 1106) Continuing, Mahatmaji said that Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya had issued an appeal to collect five lakhs of rupees to complete the shuddhi and sangathan movement of Swami Shraddhanand.
('38', 0, 4, 12, 1289) Malaviyaji did not expect any money from them as he knew the members of the Hindu community would fulfil his desire for their good.
('38', 0, 4, 13, 1421) Still as a mark of respect to the sacred memory of Swami [Shraddhanand] they should collect some money among themselves and approach Malaviyaji with the purse.
('38', 0, 5, 14, 1581) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 4 1 1927
('38', 0, 6, 15, 1612) 2. SPEECH AT CHITTARANJAN SEVA SADAN, CALCUTTA 2
('38', 0, 7, 16, 1661) [January 2, 1927] 3
('38', 0, 8, 17, 1681) In declaring the foundation to be well and truly laid, 4 Gandhiji emphasized what Dr. Nilratan Sarkar had described as the spiritual unity between Deshbandhu and Gandhiji which had become, if possible, more real after Deshbandhu’s death.
('38', 0, 8, 18, 1919) He had no doubt that, if Deshbandhu’s energies had not been absorbed, like all other political leaders’, by politics owing to the peculiar conditions of enslaved India, he
('38', 0, 9, 19, 2091) 1 Gandhiji was replying to an address of welcome presented by the students of sixteen depressed class schools in Calcutta and Howrah.
('38', 0, 9, 20, 2225) The meeting was held at Mirzapur Park, Calcutta.
('38', 0, 9, 21, 2274) 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 3 The date is taken from the Forward report.
('38', 0, 10, 22, 2368) 4 Two annexes for the Obstetric Ward and X Ray Block of the Seva Sadan—the Deshbandhu Memorial Hospital
('38', 1, 0, 1, 2472) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 1, 1, 2, 2512) would have entirely devoted himself to religious reform and to the service of Daridranarayana 1 .
('38', 1, 1, 3, 2610) But Deshbandhu believed, said Gandhiji, in following the lesson of the Gita—Do your immediate duty, even though other duties may seem to be superior—and if he seemed that day to be laying the foundation of an ordinary maternity home, he was sure that from the point of view of Deshbandhu it was a step forward to swaraj.
('38', 1, 1, 4, 2931) He then alluded to the suspicion expressed in some quarters that the Bengalis being of a parochial outlook, the memorial would also take a parochial character.
('38', 1, 1, 5, 3091) I would not mind the Bengalis absorbing the whole of India in Bengal, for then the old Panditji 2 from the U.P. and myself, an old Bania from Gujarat, would be left free to have some rest.
('38', 1, 1, 6, 3280) I would not mind in the least the whole of India being absorbed in Bengal that gave birth to Rabindranath, Ram Mohan Roy, Keshub Chandra Sen, Ramakrishna Paramahansa and Vivekanand, Bengal which was hallowed by the sacred feet of Chaitanya, Bengal which is sanctified by the sacred rivers the Ganges and the Brahmaputra.
('38', 1, 1, 7, 3601) But the fear is baseless, as Dr. Bidhan Roy has declared on behalf of the trustees, that Seva Sadan would be conducted on the same broad lines as [those on which] Deshbandhu served the Motherland.
('38', 1, 1, 8, 3798) The institution is a living tribute to one who had the emancipation of women at heart, those down trodden sisters of ours who are the victims of our lust and passion.
('38', 1, 1, 9, 3965) It does not belong to this or that trustee, it belongs to the nation.
('38', 1, 1, 10, 4035) Let us strive to make it worthy of Deshbandhu and let it immortalize his memory in India.
('38', 1, 1, 11, 4125) Young India, 13 1 1927
('38', 1, 2, 12, 4148) 3. SPEECH AT KEORAHTALA CREMATION GROUND, CALCUTTA 3
('38', 1, 3, 13, 4201) January 2, 1927
('38', 1, 4, 14, 4217) Mahatma Gandhi made a short speech on the occasion.
('38', 1, 4, 15, 4269) He said that he laid the
('38', 1, 5, 16, 4294) foundation of a memorial in honour of one of the greatest patriots of Bengal, nay, of
('38', 1, 6, 17, 4380) whole India.
('38', 1, 6, 18, 4393) Mahatma Gandhi thought himself very fortunate in performing the
('38', 1, 7, 19, 4457) ceremony.
('38', 1, 7, 20, 4467) He regretted that he could not come into intimate acquaintance with Aswini
('38', 1, 8, 21, 4542) When Mahatmaji was in South Africa, he used to read newspapers during the
('38', 1, 9, 22, 4616) Bengal Partition days and it was there that he got acquainted with Aswini Babu’s
('38', 1, 10, 23, 4697) 1 God in the form of the destitute 2 Madan Mohan Malaviya 3 Gandhiji was laying the foundation for a memorial to Aswini Kumar Du tt .
('38', 2, 0, 1, 4831) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 3
('38', 2, 1, 2, 4872) works through the papers.
('38', 2, 2, 3, 4898) On his return to India, Mahatmaji continued, he had the privilege to have darshan of the late Aswini Kumar Dutt and that was during his Bengal tour when he went to Barisal.
('38', 2, 2, 4, 5071) At Barisal, as soon as he got down from the steamer, he was told that Aswini Babu was lying on sick bed and hence could not come to welcome him.
('38', 2, 2, 5, 5216) So he thought it his first and foremost duty to go directly and see the great patriot on his sick bed.
('38', 2, 2, 6, 5319) He still remembered that loving look when he met Aswini Babu and he could never forget it.
('38', 2, 3, 7, 5410) Mahatmaji next recognized that the lesson we learnt from the life of Aswini Kumar was that only those could be the worshippers of the motherland who had given up all pleasures of life and sacrificed all their desires for the cause of the country.
('38', 2, 3, 8, 5657) Mahatmaji advised young Indians to learn the spirit in which Aswini Kumar led his life, and that was the lesson that every young man should learn from the life of the great men of the world.
('38', 2, 4, 9, 5848) Mahatmaji further said that many things could be heard about many people in the papers, but untill and unless one could come in contact with those men, one was not able to get the truth about them.
('38', 2, 4, 10, 6046) When Mahatmaji came in close contact with Aswini Dutt, he realized the absolute truth of what he had read in the papers.
('38', 2, 5, 11, 6167) Mahatmaji, in conclusion, appealed to young men to mix with such great men and follow in their footsteps if they wanted to serve the country, and the only true memorial that they could raise in the name of such great men was only to follow in their footsteps.
('38', 2, 5, 12, 6427) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 4 1 1927

('38', 3, 1, 2, 7286) 5. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('38', 3, 2, 3, 7316) [After January 2, 1927] 1
('38', 3, 3, 4, 7342) GANGABEHN, I find that you make mistakes in gender.
('38', 3, 3, 5, 7394) In the Kutchhi dialect there are only [two] genders—feminine and masculine.
('38', 3, 3, 6, 7470) But in Gujarati there is a third, the neuter gender.
('38', 3, 3, 7, 7523) You say ghar kevo 2, while in Gujarati we say ghar kevun 3, you say tamaro sharir 4, while in Gujarati we would say tamarun sharir 5. You will find it interesting to compare the two languages in this manner and will be able to correct your mistakes more easily.
('38', 3, 3, 8, 7785) Such mental exercise will also develop your intellect.
('38', 3, 3, 9, 7840) Blessings from BAPU From the Gujarati original: C.W. 8703. Courtesy: Gangabehn Vaidya

('38', 4, 1, 2, 8855) 7. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('38', 4, 2, 3, 8877) January 3, 1927
('38', 4, 3, 4, 8893) MIRA, I have your two letters.
('38', 4, 3, 5, 8924) I see what you are passing through and I am glad of it.
('38', 4, 3, 6, 8980) You have to love humanity in spite of itself.
('38', 4, 3, 7, 9026) The Ashram is finally not at Sabarmati but in yourself.
('38', 4, 3, 8, 9082) The vilest beings must enter there purified.
('38', 4, 3, 9, 9127) That is the meaning of treating all alike and in this universe of opposites remaining unaffected even as the lotus remains unaffected by water though immersed in it.
('38', 4, 3, 10, 9293) I understand your programme.
('38', 4, 3, 11, 9322) You may carry it out.
('38', 4, 3, 12, 9344) I continue to send you letters to Kanya Gurukul till I hear from you again.
('38', 4, 3, 13, 9420) I suppose in the circumstances related by you, you will not advice me to send anybody to the place as a pupil.
('38', 4, 3, 14, 9531) I am writing this at Sodepur, a suburb of Calcutta, where Satis Babu has built his Khadi Works.
('38', 4, 3, 15, 9627) It is a great effort.
('38', 4, 3, 16, 9649) It has cost nearly Rs. 80,000. We leave for Comilla tomorrow as per programme sent to you.
('38', 4, 3, 17, 9740) But for future guidance, it would be well to note that when in doubt send to the last address.
('38', 4, 3, 18, 9835) You will be interested in the enclosed which was handed to me by a friend.
('38', 4, 3, 19, 9910) With love.
('38', 4, 4, 20, 9921) From the original: C.W. 5194. Courtesy: Mirabehn

('38', 5, 3, 8, 10631) 9. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('38', 5, 4, 9, 10657) SODEPUR, Monday, Magsar Vad O 1, January 3, 1927
('38', 5, 5, 10, 10706) DEAR SISTERS, This time I have not yet received your weekly letter.
('38', 5, 5, 11, 10774) We have shifted today to the new buildings erected on the land purchased by the Khadi Pratishthan.
('38', 5, 5, 12, 10873) They have built many small houses here.
('38', 5, 5, 13, 10913) The houses took only nine months to build.
('38', 5, 5, 14, 10956) The processes of washing, bleaching and dyeing khaddar with the aid of machines are now carried on here.
('38', 5, 5, 15, 11061) There was a big gathering here yesterday.
('38', 5, 5, 16, 11103) Theatten dance was very good.
('38', 5, 5, 17, 11133) I thought that I should ask for a collection from the audience; I did, and got about Rs. 3,500/ .
('38', 5, 5, 18, 11231) Prayers are held here just as we hold them there.
('38', 5, 5, 19, 11281) The verses which they recite are also the same.
('38', 5, 5, 20, 11329) But their recitation is out of tune, compared to ours, and so it jars a little on the ear.
('38', 5, 5, 21, 11420) But gradually they will improve.
('38', 5, 5, 22, 11453) Perinbehn, Mithubehn and Jamnabehn are still with me.
('38', 5, 5, 23, 11507) They are carrying on their khadi work.
('38', 5, 5, 24, 11546) They have sold about half the stock they had brought with them.
('38', 5, 5, 25, 11610) It is a very good thing that your prayers are held regularly.
('38', 5, 5, 26, 11672) I note that they are also well attended.
('38', 5, 5, 27, 11713) Do not forget that spinning is yajna.
('38', 5, 5, 28, 11751) The Gita says that he who eats food without offering yajna eats stolen food.
('38', 5, 5, 29, 11828) ‘Yajna’ means work done for the good of others.
('38', 5, 5, 30, 11876) For us spinning is such public work.
('38', 5, 5, 31, 11913) Blessings from BAPU
('38', 5, 6, 32, 11933) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 3633

('38', 7, 3, 5, 13412) 3 Be you as those two streams.

('38', 7, 4, 11, 14042) 13. SPEECH AT VILLAGERS’ MEETING, COMILLA
('38', 7, 5, 12, 14084) January 5, 1927
('38', 7, 6, 13, 14100) The Mahatma with his party visited two Namsudra villages, viz., Rajapura and Muradpur, near about the Ashram and addressed the inhabitants in Hindi.
('38', 7, 6, 14, 14249) The Mahatma was received by the villagers, men, women and children with hullas 4, and the blowing of conch shells and sankirtans 5. His message to them was not to
('38', 7, 7, 15, 14412) consider themselves lower than others and not to imitate the bad habits of the so called higher classes.
('38', 7, 7, 16, 14517) He asked them to give up drinking and to lead a simple and honest life.
('38', 7, 7, 17, 14589) He specially dwelt upon the importance and utility of khaddar and exhorted them to follow the examples of the members of the Abhoy Ashram.
('38', 7, 7, 18, 14728) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 7 1 1927
('38', 7, 8, 19, 14759) 1 Institution run by Dr. Suresh Chandra Bannerji.
('38', 7, 8, 20, 14809) The Ashram conducted seven schools for untouchables and also ran a khadi store.
('38', 7, 8, 21, 14889) Only the concluding remarks of a long talk at the prayer are available.
('38', 7, 8, 22, 14961) 2 The report is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” where no date has been assigned to it, but it is placed before the report of the public meeting, which took place on January 5. 3 The reference is to the Khadi Pratishthan and the Abhoy Ashram.

('38', 8, 1, 2, 15365) 14. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, COMILLA 1
('38', 8, 2, 3, 15405) January 5, 1927 You have been so kind to me in giving me permission to speak in Hindi.
('38', 8, 2, 4, 15492) If only because I want to show you my appreciation of your kindness, I propose to say a few words to you in English.
('38', 8, 2, 5, 15609) Every time that I am obliged to speak in the English language before an audience of my countrymen, I feel humiliated and ashamed.
('38', 8, 2, 6, 15739) I have urged upon Bengali audiences several times not to put an undue strain upon my loyalty, not to put an undue strain upon Bharatamata herself.
('38', 8, 2, 7, 15886) It is the easiest thing possible for every Indian north of the Vindhya range to pick up Hindi inside of a month.
('38', 8, 2, 8, 15999) Try it and tell me if what I say is not true.
('38', 8, 2, 9, 16045) Let us not say that our mother tongue is only Bengali or Gujarati or Punjabi, as the case may be.
('38', 8, 2, 10, 16143) These are provincial languages.
('38', 8, 2, 11, 16175) When we sing that ode to the Motherland—Bande Mataram, we sing it to the whole of India.
('38', 8, 2, 12, 16264) When Bankim 2 wrote the inspired song he said sapt akoti bhujaih 3. But you and others deliberately said dwi trimshatkoti bhujaih 4 and it was proper.
('38', 8, 2, 13, 16415) It was proper and dignified on your part to sing of dwi trimshatkoti bhujaih, and it was proper and dignified for the whole of India to accept that magnificent ode.
('38', 8, 2, 14, 16580) Shall we not then live up to it and sing with all our hearts and say we are sons of Mother India, not merely sons of Bengal?
('38', 8, 2, 15, 16705) I ask you, therefore, next time I happen to come here or you invite me to come, to insist upon my speaking to you in Hindi and Hindi alone.
('38', 8, 2, 16, 16845) That is one thing.
('38', 8, 2, 17, 16864) We have seen the last of the last session of the Congress.
('38', 8, 2, 18, 16923) On the sacred banks of the Brahmaputra, in the midst of that magnificent foliage and scenery almost unrivalled in the world, our leaders deliberated.
('38', 8, 2, 19, 17073) They have evolved a Council programme.
('38', 8, 2, 20, 17112) But how many of us can take a direct part in the working of that programme?
('38', 8, 2, 21, 17188) How many of us can enter Councils and the Legislative Assembly?
('38', 8, 2, 22, 17252) How many of us are entitled to elect members to these legislative bodies?
('38', 8, 2, 23, 17326) Are the millions of the villagers of India enfranchised?
('38', 8, 2, 24, 17383) Is India living in her 10 or 20 cities, or is she living in her 700,000 villages?
('38', 8, 2, 25, 17465) What then is the programme that can weld together the 30 crores of people scattered on a surface 1,900 miles long and 1,500 miles broad in
('38', 8, 3, 26, 17604) 1 The meeting was held at Mahesh Prangan.
('38', 8, 3, 27, 17646) 2 Bankim Chandra Chatterji 3 Seven crore arms—a reference to the population of Bengal at the time 4 Sixty crore arms—a reference to the population of India
('38', 9, 0, 1, 17802) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 9, 1, 2, 17843) 700,000 villages?
('38', 9, 1, 3, 17861) What is it that every villager, man, woman and child, Hindu and Mussalman, can do with profit and, at the same time, uplift the whole of India?
('38', 9, 1, 4, 18005) The one and unequivocal answer is the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('38', 9, 1, 5, 18071) The message of khaddar can penetrate to remotest villages if we only will that it shall be so.
('38', 9, 1, 6, 18166) The spinning wheel can be turned by millions of the villagers of India who have been reduced to pauperism, who have been ground down to dust, not merely under the foreigner’s heels but under your heels, under my heels.
('38', 9, 1, 7, 18385) We the city dwellers are living upon the labour, upon the wealth of these millions of villagers; not like the Americans, not like the Englishmen, who live upon the exploitation of Asiatic races or the so called weaker races of the earth.
('38', 9, 1, 8, 18623) Even they would be obliged to take up the spinning wheel or any equivalent if they were not able to exploit India, China, Africa and other parts of the earth.
('38', 9, 1, 9, 18782) We do not exploit them, because it is a virtue of necessity with us.
('38', 9, 1, 10, 18851) But I hope that a time is coming when out of the fullness of our hearts, out of a wider national outlook, we shall disdain of our own free will to exploit a single nation of the earth, no matter how weak.
('38', 9, 1, 11, 19056) I hope that in your lifetime and mine that time is coming when we shall reach our freedom and having reached it, we shall say to all the nations of the earth that they need not fear us, as we have lived in perpetual fear of the so called civilized races of the earth.

('38', 15, 4, 7, 33700) SHRADDHANAND MEMORIAL
('38', 15, 5, 8, 33722) It is in the fitness of things that there should be an appeal on behalf of the Hindu Mahasabha for funds to perpetuate the memory of the late Swami Shraddhanandji.
('38', 15, 5, 9, 33886) I congratulate the Sabha on having decided upon inviting collections for carrying on the work for which the Swamiji chiefly lived after his sannyasa.
('38', 15, 5, 10, 34036) This was removal of untouchability, shuddhi and sangathan.
('38', 15, 5, 11, 34095) The appeal has been made for five lakhs for untouchability and as many for shuddhi and sanga than.
('38', 15, 5, 12, 34194) For my own part I still remain unconvinced about the necessity of the shuddhi movement, taking shuddhi in the sense it is generally understood.
('38', 15, 5, 13, 34338) Shuddhi of sinners is a perpetual inward performance.
('38', 15, 5, 14, 34392) Shuddhi of those who can be identified neither as Hindus nor as Mussalmans or who have been recently declared converts but who do not know even the meaning of conversion and who want to be known definitely as Hindus is not conversion but prayaschitta or penance.
('38', 15, 5, 15, 34655) The third aspect of shuddhi is conversion properly so called.
('38', 15, 5, 16, 34717) And I question its use in this age of growing toleration and enlightenment.
('38', 15, 5, 17, 34793) I am against conversion whether it is known as shuddhi by Hindus, tabligh by Mussalmans or proselytizing by Christians.
('38', 15, 5, 18, 34913) Conversion is a heart process known only to and by God.
('38', 15, 5, 19, 34969) It must be left to itself.
('38', 15, 5, 20, 34996) But this is no place for airing my views on conversion.
('38', 15, 5, 21, 35052) Those who believe in it have a perfect right to follow their own course without let or hindrance, so long as it is kept within proper limits, i.e., so long as there is no force or fraud or material inducement and so long as the parties are free agents and of mature age and understanding.
('38', 15, 5, 22, 35341) Those, therefore, who believe in shuddhi have a perfect right to subscribe to the appeal.
('38', 15, 5, 23, 35431) Sangathan is really a sound movement.
('38', 15, 5, 24, 35469) Every community is entitled, indeed bound, to organize itself if it is to live as a separate entity.
('38', 15, 5, 25, 35570) I have kept myself aloof from it because of my peculiar ideas
('38', 16, 0, 1, 35632) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 17
('38', 16, 1, 2, 35674) of organization.
('38', 16, 1, 3, 35691) I believe in quality rather than quantity.
('38', 16, 1, 4, 35734) The fashion nowadays is to rely upon quantity even at the cost of quality.
('38', 16, 1, 5, 35809) Quantity has its place no doubt in social and political economy.
('38', 16, 1, 6, 35874) Only I am ill fitted for organizing quantity in the way it is done at present.
('38', 16, 1, 7, 35953) There fore, for me the appeal only for funds for the removal of untouch ability has a value.
('38', 16, 1, 8, 36046) It comes with a force all its own.
('38', 16, 1, 9, 36081) For reform of Hinduism and for its real protection, removal of untouchability is the greatest thing.
('38', 16, 1, 10, 36182) It is all inclusive and, therefore, if this the blackest spot on Hinduism is removed, you have automatically all that shuddhi and sangathan can be expected to yield.
('38', 16, 1, 11, 36348) And I say this, not because of the vast number of untouchables whom every Hindu should seek to embrace as one of his own but because consciousness of having broken down a barbarous and ancient custom and consequent purity it necessarily implies gives a strength which is irresistible.
('38', 16, 1, 12, 36633) Removal of untouchability therefore is a spiritual process.
('38', 16, 1, 13, 36693) Swamiji was a living embodiment of that reformation because he had no half measures about it, because he would not compromise, he would give no quarter.
('38', 16, 1, 14, 36846) If he could have had his way, he would have made short work of untouchability in Hinduism.
('38', 16, 1, 15, 36937) He would have opened every well and every temple to every untouchable on conditions of absolute equality and he would have braved all consequences.
('38', 16, 1, 16, 37085) I can conceive no more fitting memorial to Swami Shraddhanandji than that every Hindu should henceforth purge his heart of the uncleanliness which untou chability undoubtedly in and deal with the untouchable as with his own kith and kin.
('38', 16, 1, 17, 37323) His monetary contribution to the memorial, there fore, will, in my opinion, be merely an earnest of his irrevocable reso lution to root out the evil and cast it away once and for all from Hinduism.
('38', 16, 1, 18, 37521) The 9th day of January is the day appointed for doing public and religious reverence to the memory of the Swamiji.

('38', 17, 2, 3, 38233) In selecting the Board of Studies the Council of the All India Spinners’ Association had included Dr. Profulla Chandra Ghosh’s name in the Board subject to his acceptance of the office.
('38', 17, 2, 4, 38419) But as his acceptance was not received owing to his absence from his head quarters in time for publication, the name was withdrawn at the last moment.
('38', 17, 2, 5, 38570) Dr. Ghosh has now kindly accepted the office.
('38', 17, 2, 6, 38616) The reader will be glad to learn that the Board will have the assistance of one who has made a study of and has practical experience of the science of charkha and khadi.
('38', 17, 3, 7, 38786) PRIZE ESSAY ON HAND SPINNING
('38', 17, 4, 8, 38815) The Prize Essay on Hand Spinning and Hand weaving issued by the All India Spinners’ Association and written by Professor S.V. Puntambekar and Sjt.
('38', 17, 4, 9, 38962) N. S. Varadachari is a publication which I commend to the attention both of the khadi worker and the sceptic.
('38', 17, 4, 10, 39072) The khadi worker will find many things in this volume occupying 235 pages of bold type in octavo size, which he perhaps had not known before.
('38', 17, 4, 11, 39214) It has four chapters.
('38', 17, 4, 12, 39236) The first gives the history of hand spinning and hand weaving in India before the advent of the British.
('38', 17, 4, 13, 39341) The second deals with the complete ruin of hand spinning, the great est national industry, and almost complete ruin of hand weaving, the second great national industry.
('38', 17, 4, 14, 39510) The third deals with the possibilities of hand spinning and hand weaving and incidentally sets up a compa rison between mill spinning and mill weaving and hand spinning and hand weaving.
('38', 17, 4, 15, 39697) And the fourth deals with exclusion or boycott of all foreign cloth through the spinning wheel.
('38', 17, 4, 16, 39793) The authors give facts and figures for every statement made by them.
('38', 17, 4, 17, 39862) The price of the book is one rupee.
('38', 17, 4, 18, 39898) Copies can be had from the office of the All India Spinners’ Association, Ahmedabad, or from Mr. S. Ganesan, Current Thought Press, Triplicane, Madras, by send ing one rupee and two annas to cover postage.

('38', 17, 5, 20, 40126) 17. THE CONGRESS
('38', 17, 6, 21, 40143) When, in Cawnpore, the Assam delegates gave the invitation to hold the Congress of 1926 at Gauhati and the Congress accepted the invitation I was filled with misgivings.
('38', 17, 6, 22, 40313) I felt that Assam was too far away, too unorganized and too poor to shoulder the heavy burden of
('38', 18, 0, 1, 40410) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 19
('38', 18, 1, 2, 40452) holding a Congress session.
('38', 18, 1, 3, 40480) Gauhati has a population of only 16,000. No place with such a small population has, before Gauhati, had the temerity to invite the Congress.
('38', 18, 1, 4, 40621) Gauhati, however, beat all previous records, and in an incredibly short space of time erected, in the midst of surroundings of great natural beauty on the banks of the great Brahmaputra, a city under khadi canvas.
('38', 18, 1, 5, 40835) The huge Congress pavilion itself was made of pure Assam khadi.

('38', 18, 1, 9, 41322) The construction of the cottages was incredibly simple,—Assam bamboo, Assam mud, Assam straw, Assam khadi and Assam labour were responsible for the very simple but artistic huts erected on the Brahmaputra bank.

('38', 18, 1, 11, 41948) Let not the reader however imagine for one moment that there was in any degree whatsoever less comfort in these artistic huts than in the palatial looking structure that was provided in Belgaum.

('38', 26, 3, 16, 60043) 21. COMPLICATIONS OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('38', 26, 4, 17, 60079) I publish in this issue Shri Govindji Jadavdas’s letter under the heading which he has himself given to it, viz., “The Downfall of Hinduism”.
('38', 26, 4, 18, 60221) The purport of his letter is this: If untouchability is to be removed, then why have separate schools, temples and wells for the untouchables?
('38', 26, 4, 19, 60364) This argument is certainly not pointless.
('38', 26, 4, 20, 60406) Similar pro blems have arisen and still arise in South Africa.
('38', 26, 4, 21, 60469) I had raised the argument myself, in South Africa, that setting up of separate schools for the Indians means prolonging the life of untouchability.
('38', 26, 4, 22, 60617) Only those who have themselves suffered can realize the pain of other sufferers; in the same way I can appreciate Shri Govindji’s unhappi ness.
('38', 26, 4, 23, 60761) But where I realized that it would be considered foolish on my part to ignore the existence of a thing which does exist, I did my work
('38', 26, 5, 24, 60896) 1 Belt or cord passing round the wheel and the spindle 2 Cotton thread moistened with gum
('38', 27, 0, 1, 60986) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 27, 1, 2, 61027) with full realization of the discrimination which was there.
('38', 27, 1, 3, 61088) So I accepted the proposal of having separate schools.
('38', 27, 1, 4, 61143) I had also accepted [in S. Africa] the proposal for separate first and second class compar tments in trains for Indians.
('38', 27, 1, 5, 61264) Like Govindji I too had opposed such a discrimination there.
('38', 27, 1, 6, 61325) But when the mere existence of a community was in danger, I accepted such a discrimination which would virtually lead to lightening the discrimination in spite of its continuance.
('38', 27, 1, 7, 61505) For example, the Indians could formerly travel only by the third class; as a result of the agitation an order was issued allowing them to travel in first and second class compartments.
('38', 27, 1, 8, 61690) Simultaneously it was decided to have for the Indians separate first and second class coaches.
('38', 27, 1, 9, 61785) We accepted this provision even after we had opposed discrimination.
('38', 27, 1, 10, 61854) The government authorities can make arrangements [for common coac hes] but how can others be forced to sit with us?
('38', 27, 1, 11, 61970) I yielded to this line of thinking and came to the conclusion that as long as the Antyajas are not able to make use of common temples, etc., it is better to have for them separate institutions by which they may benefit, rather than totally to deprive them of the amenity.
('38', 27, 1, 12, 62242) Theoretically, untouchability has disappeared.
('38', 27, 1, 13, 62289) Still many are not yet ready to discard it altogether in practice.
('38', 27, 1, 14, 62356) What should the friends of the untouchables do so long as such a situation persists?
('38', 27, 1, 15, 62441) How else can they prove their sincerity of purpose?
('38', 27, 1, 16, 62493) The answer should be that it can be done by constructing temples, etc., for the untouchables.
('38', 27, 1, 17, 62587) Shri Govindji says that such temples, etc., may be built, but why label them with unpleasant words, “for the untouchables only”?
('38', 27, 1, 18, 62716) No one has assigned such unpleasant labels.
('38', 27, 1, 19, 62760) The temples, etc., which are being built are used by those who have made donations towards their cost as well as by other friends of the untouchables.
('38', 27, 1, 20, 62911) From this viewpoint the institutions built for the benefit of the untouchables are in fact for the general public.
('38', 27, 1, 21, 63026) But the untouchables have the first claim upon them.
('38', 27, 1, 22, 63079) In the matter of using these institutions, the untou chables are given the first preference, and their requirements looked to first.
('38', 27, 1, 23, 63212) Though I can fully realize the unhappiness of an Antyaja like Shri Govindji, I wish him to believe that the Antyaj Directory 1 and the underlying motive to build temples, etc., is pure, laudable and in the interests of the Antyajas.

('38', 42, 1, 2, 96319) 31. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('38', 42, 2, 3, 96342) January 10, 1927
('38', 42, 3, 4, 96359) MIRA, I have your letter describing the drive with Hakimji.
('38', 42, 3, 5, 96419) I do not mind either your tasting the dishes at Brijkishen’s or the pan from Hakimji.
('38', 42, 3, 6, 96505) The latter’s tempting you with pan distresses me.
('38', 42, 3, 7, 96555) It is bad stuff and he should never have offered it to you.
('38', 42, 3, 8, 96615) But opinions differ.
('38', 42, 3, 9, 96636) He evidently considers it to be harmless.
('38', 42, 3, 10, 96678) However, the reasoning that you have employed for justifying the tasting of the dishes and the pan is in my opinion faulty.
('38', 42, 3, 11, 96802) Why should one know the taste of what one does not need or wish to take?
('38', 42, 3, 12, 96875) Do you know that this is the reasoning that has been applied to justify every form of vice?
('38', 42, 3, 13, 96967) It is the million times told story of the forbidden apple: why should I not know the taste of the thing I am asked not to take or touch?
('38', 42, 3, 14, 97104) But you must not worry.
('38', 42, 3, 15, 97128) If you do not understand my reasoning, you must argue with me patiently.
('38', 42, 3, 16, 97201) If you appreciate my reasoning, it is to serve as warning in the future.
('38', 42, 3, 17, 97274) But it must not result in self reproach.
('38', 42, 3, 18, 97315) There is no cause for it.
('38', 42, 3, 19, 97341) The incident is trivial.
('38', 42, 3, 20, 97366) But trivialities possess deadly potentia lities.
('38', 42, 3, 21, 97415) Hence the paternal warning.
('38', 42, 3, 22, 97443) Now about your analysis of the Kanya Gurukul.
('38', 42, 3, 23, 97489) I hope you have spoken about it to Vidyavati.
('38', 42, 3, 24, 97535) But you must discuss it freely with Principals Ramdev and Sethi.
('38', 42, 3, 25, 97600) Principal Ramdev is her guide and if he is convinced, immediate improvement can be made.
('38', 42, 3, 26, 97689) I propose to send him the relevant extract from your letter.
('38', 42, 3, 27, 97750) That will make your position quite clear.
('38', 42, 3, 28, 97792) The insanitation, the indiscipline must go.
('38', 42, 3, 29, 97836) The anti Muslim feeling is a more difficult proposition.
('38', 42, 3, 30, 97893) But you have to do your duty.
('38', 42, 3, 31, 97923) Little girls’ minds must not be poisoned if we can help it.
('38', 42, 3, 32, 97983) But whilst you will talk about these things, you will remember your limits.
('38', 42, 3, 33, 98059) You have gone out to learn Hindi and to observe and gain experience, not to reform or teach.
('38', 42, 3, 34, 98152) Yours will, therefore, be remarks only by the way and merely as suggestions either for acceptance or rejection.
('38', 42, 3, 35, 98264) Your own conduct is sufficient effort for reform otherwise.I am writing this on the moving train during my silence which finishes at 9 p.m.

('38', 45, 8, 11, 101571) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 11, 1927
('38', 45, 9, 12, 101617) DEAR FRIEND, I must apologize to you for the very long delay in acknow ledging your letter of 27th November, 1926. I duly received your first intimation which I thought was purely formal and as I had nothing effective to say, I did not send you a reply.
('38', 45, 9, 13, 101871) From your second letter, however, I observe that you were anxious to have my opinion.
('38', 45, 9, 14, 101957) But when I received it I was so overwhelmed with work that I had no time to collect my thoughts and give you a considered reply.
('38', 45, 9, 15, 102086) Even as it is, I am sending you this reply in the midst of my Bihar tour.

('38', 45, 9, 17, 102276) Probably now it is of no use, even so I gave myself the satisfaction of telling you that there was no discourtesy intended by me in the first instance in not replying and now in replying at a time when my reply may prove too late.
('38', 45, 9, 18, 102507) In matters of religion I am against any State interference, and the cow question is in India a mixed matter of religion and economy.

('38', 49, 0, 1, 109375) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 49, 1, 2, 109416) 39. SPEECH AT DHANBAD 1
('38', 49, 2, 3, 109440) January 12, 1927
('38', 49, 3, 4, 109457) He said that on an enquiry from Babu Rajendra Prasad about the inclement weather he had come to know that rains even in winter were not quite unusual in the province and that that was to some extent necessary too.
('38', 49, 3, 5, 109671) He was no doubt conscious of the immense difficulties the audience had to face on account of the rain; his own difficulties were no less.
('38', 49, 3, 6, 109809) But he was capable of working in the midst of all sorts of difficulties, his life had been only a prolonged story of his fight with difficulties of every description.
('38', 49, 4, 7, 109976) After announcing the meeting to be addressed by him at six next evening, he proceeded to explain the purpose of his visit.
('38', 49, 4, 8, 110099) He said that they were perhaps aware that his tour was specially intended to preach the message of the charkha and khaddar.
('38', 49, 4, 9, 110223) He admitted that there was enough field in the country for other activities with a view to the attainment of swaraj but he had taken to the charkha because he had found that that could be prescribed with equal force for all—Hindus and Muslims, males and females, men and boys, touchables and untouchables.
('38', 49, 4, 10, 110529) The charkha was the universal thing and as such it was to be taken up by all according to the capacity of each individual.
('38', 49, 4, 11, 110652) Working at the wheel was the sacred business of every Indian; everyone was required to join this universal yajna.
('38', 49, 4, 12, 110766) But if that was not possible for all, they could do one thing.
('38', 49, 4, 13, 110829) They could at least put on khaddar.
('38', 49, 5, 14, 110865) Continuing, he said that khaddar work to be conducted on a large scale throughout India demanded a large sum of money to be spent over it.
('38', 49, 5, 15, 111004) That money was to be supplied by the country.
('38', 49, 5, 16, 111050) Nearly 16 lakhs were already collected and spent and as a result, nearly 50 thousand women who had formerly nothing to do, and about 4,000 men who also formerly had alomst nothing to do, had got employment.
('38', 49, 5, 17, 111257) Weavers, many of whom were compelled to give up their profession on account of hard competition with Lancashire weavers, had once more found occupation, while large sums had already gone to the carders and ginners.
('38', 49, 5, 18, 111472) Spinning, therefore, was the saviour of the poor, while the middle class men also could derive much benefit from it.
('38', 49, 5, 19, 111589) Without humbly approaching the Government, without supplicating the rich, middle class young men could solve a good deal of their unemployment problem by taking to the charkha.
('38', 49, 5, 20, 111766) Riches were of course not to be expected from this work, but young men could very well earn an honest living by reverting to khaddar work.
('38', 49, 6, 21, 111905) Proceeding, he said that the fund, for which he was appealing for money, was called Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, started to commemorate the sacred memory of the late Deshbandhu.
('38', 49, 6, 22, 112080) Khaddar was very dear to his heart.
('38', 49, 6, 23, 112116) He had realized that the charkha was the thing for the whole of India and through that alone one could approach the masses for village reconstruction work which was the unrealized dream of his life.
('38', 49, 7, 24, 112315) 1 The meeting was held in a local hall.
('38', 50, 0, 1, 112355) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 51
('38', 50, 1, 2, 112397) few days before his death, he had expressed his wish to the speaker to accompany him (Mahatmaji) on his tour for khaddar work.
('38', 50, 1, 3, 112524) But “man proposes God disposes”.
('38', 50, 1, 4, 112557) Before he could begin to work according to his plan, he was snatched away by the cruel hand of death.
('38', 50, 1, 5, 112659) It was in order to fulfil his last wish, said Mahatmaji, that the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, to be utilized by the All India Spinners’ Association, was inaugurated.
('38', 50, 1, 6, 112833) He referred to the circumstances under which the All Bengal Deshbandhu Memorial Fund was allowed to be spent over the Hospital, while at the very time he had appealed for money for the All India Memorial Fund for khaddar work.
('38', 50, 1, 7, 113060) It was time, said the speaker, that each one of them contributed his quota to fulfil the last wishes of Deshbandhu.
('38', 50, 1, 8, 113176) By contributing to this fund the donor might serve two useful purposes at the same time; firstly they would honour the sacred memory of Deshbandhu who lived and died for them, and, secondly, they would be helping the poor with work and money.
('38', 50, 2, 9, 113419) Proceeding, Mahatmaji said that to purchase one yard of khaddar was to help the poor men of their country to the extent of about four annas, whereas spending money over foreign cloth was to send the same abroad to the untold miseries of their own people.
('38', 50, 2, 10, 113674) To purchase Indian mill made cloth did not mean helping the poor, for it was the capitalists who used to enjoy the largest amount of profit, doling out a negligible amount to the labourers, which was not sufficient for them even to keep their body and soul together.
('38', 50, 2, 11, 113941) Three fourths of the money spent over Indian mill made cloths, said the speaker, filled the already overflowing coffers of the capitalists, while the labourers who were really in need of money did not get collectively more than one fourth of the profit.
('38', 50, 2, 12, 114195) The charkha was the only effective weapon to fight the poverty of the country to a successful close.
('38', 50, 3, 13, 114296) Mahatmaji then appealed for money.
('38', 50, 3, 14, 114331) He wanted everyone present to contribute his mite for this noble work and asked them to send the money to the proper authority if they had not it with them at that time.
('38', 50, 3, 15, 114501) He exhorted the audience to solemnly promise in that hall to put on khaddar habitually for all time to come.
('38', 50, 3, 16, 114610) He said that he would ask them even to burn their foreign clothes, if they had any.
('38', 50, 3, 17, 114694) But if they could not go so far as that, they must henceforward boycott all foreign clothes without the least hesitation.
('38', 50, 3, 18, 114816) Khaddar had become the burning passion of his life because he had found that and that alone could give food to the poor.
('38', 50, 3, 19, 114937) People might call him mad, but he could not give up that work for anything.
('38', 50, 3, 20, 115013) He asked everyone present in that hall to pay what little he could.
('38', 50, 3, 21, 115081) He did not want that people should pay money out of fear or shame; he wanted every one of them to feel the nobility of the cause and then do whatever lay in his power.
('38', 50, 4, 22, 115249) Referring to untouchability, he said that that was greatest blot upon Hindu society and that should be wiped out at the soonest possible date.
('38', 50, 4, 23, 115392) Hinduism never taught one man to consider another man as untouchable.
('38', 50, 4, 24, 115462) By observing the custom of
('38', 51, 0, 1, 115489) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 51, 1, 2, 115530) untouchability, Hindus were committing a sin.
('38', 51, 1, 3, 115576) Swami Shraddhanand gave his life for the sake of the removal of untouchability.
('38', 51, 1, 4, 115656) It was their duty to take up that work of service to the poor and the untouchables.
('38', 51, 2, 5, 115740) Incidentally he referred to the Hindu Muslim tension and deplored the murder of Swamiji.
('38', 51, 2, 6, 115829) But Sawamiji’s death could be turned to good account, if both the Hindus and the Muslims cleansed their hearts with his blood.
('38', 51, 2, 7, 115956) That would be the work of purfication, that would be a real shuddhi work.
('38', 51, 2, 8, 116030) What was the duty of the Hindus?
('38', 51, 3, 9, 116063) should not seek to retaliate.
('38', 51, 3, 10, 116093) The teaching of all religions was not to return evil for evil but good for evil.
('38', 51, 3, 11, 116174) All the religions taught that the greatest conquest was the conquest of one’s own self.
('38', 51, 3, 12, 116262) The Hindus should attain that self possession.
('38', 51, 3, 13, 116309) Abdul Rashid was a poor creature; he alone was not responsible for this diabolical deed.
('38', 51, 3, 14, 116398) The bulk of the Muslim Press in Delhi and all those who had been holding up Swami Shraddhanand, Lala Lajpat Rai and Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya as the enemies of Islam collectively contributed to the murder.
('38', 51, 3, 15, 116606) The results of those things were before them.
('38', 51, 3, 16, 116652) The whole atmosphere of the country demanded purificatin.
('38', 51, 3, 17, 116710) Enthusiasm like that of 1922 was necessary for their success in the battle they had undertaken, but that could not come until the process of purification had reached its completion.
('38', 51, 3, 18, 116892) Everyone should, therefore, concentrate all his attention upon self purification.
('38', 51, 3, 19, 116974) It was wholly unwise to be inimical to the enemies, one should rather pity them.
('38', 51, 3, 20, 117055) The Searchlight, 16 1 1927
('38', 51, 4, 21, 117082) 40. INDEPENDENCE
('38', 51, 5, 22, 117099) Year after year a resolution is moved in the Congress to amend the Congress creed so as to define swaraj as complete independence and year after year happily the Congress throws out the resolution by an overwhelming majority.
('38', 51, 5, 23, 117325) The rejection of the resolution is proof of the sanity of the Congress.
('38', 51, 5, 24, 117397) The moving of the resolution betrays the impatience (pardonable in the circumstances) of some ardent Con gressmen who have lost all faith in the British intentions and who think that the British Government will never render justice to India.
('38', 51, 5, 25, 117639) The advocates of independence forget that they betray want of faith in human nature and therefore in themselves.
('38', 51, 5, 26, 117752) Why do they think that there can never be change of heart in those who are guiding the British people?
('38', 51, 5, 27, 117855) Is it not more correct and more dignified to own that there is no change of heart because we are weak?
('38', 51, 5, 28, 117958) Nature abhors weakness.
('38', 51, 5, 29, 117982) We want from the British people and the world at large not mercy but justice that is our due.
('38', 51, 5, 30, 118076) And justice will come when it is deserved by our being and feeling strong.
('38', 52, 0, 1, 118151) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 53
('38', 52, 1, 2, 118193) I am sure that the staunchest votary of independence does not mean that he will not have any British association on any terms whatsoever.
('38', 52, 1, 3, 118331) Even when he says so, he means, as one of the supporters of the resolution admitted in answer to my question, that the British people will never accept association on equal terms.
('38', 52, 1, 4, 118511) This is totally different from rejecting British association on any terms.
('38', 52, 1, 5, 118586) Indeed the word swaraj is all embracing.
('38', 52, 1, 6, 118627) It does include comp lete independence as it includes many other things.
('38', 52, 1, 7, 118700) To give it one definite meaning is to narrow the outlook, and to limit what is at present happily limitless.
('38', 52, 1, 8, 118809) Let the content of swaraj grow with the growth of national consciousness and aspirations.
('38', 52, 1, 9, 118899) We may be satisfied today with dominion status.
('38', 52, 1, 10, 118947) The future generations may not be, may want something better.
('38', 52, 1, 11, 119009) Swaraj without any qualifying clause includes that which is better than the best one can conceive or have today.
('38', 52, 1, 12, 119122) Swaraj means even under dominion status a capacity to declare independence at will.
('38', 52, 1, 13, 119206) So long as we have not achieved that capacity, we have no swaraj.
('38', 52, 1, 14, 119272) This is the least it should mean.
('38', 52, 1, 15, 119306) South Africa has achieved that status today.
('38', 52, 1, 16, 119351) It is a partnership at will of free peoples.
('38', 52, 1, 17, 119396) Between Britain and the Dominions there is a partnership at will on terms of equality and for mutual benefit.
('38', 52, 1, 18, 119506) What India will finally have is for her and her alone to determine.
('38', 52, 1, 19, 119574) This power of determination remains unfettered by the existing creed.
('38', 52, 1, 20, 119644) What therefore the creed does retain is the possibility of evolution of swaraj within the British Empire or call it the British Commonwealth.
('38', 52, 1, 21, 119786) The cryptic meaning of swaraj I have often described to be within the Empire if possible, with out if necessary.
('38', 52, 1, 22, 119899) I venture to think that it is not possible to im prove upon that conception.
('38', 52, 1, 23, 119976) It is totally consistent with national self respect and it provides for the highest growth of the nation.
('38', 52, 1, 24, 120082) After all, the real definition will be determined by our action, the means we adopt to achieve the goal.
('38', 52, 1, 25, 120187) If we would but concentrate upon the means, swaraj will take care of itself.
('38', 52, 1, 26, 120264) Our exploration should, therefore, take place in the direction of determining not the definition of an indefinable term like swaraj but in discovering the ways and means.

('38', 53, 1, 2, 120499) 41. NOTE
('38', 53, 2, 3, 120508) INDIANS IN PANAMA The Legislative Assembly of the Republic of Panama recently passed an Immigration Restriction Act prohibiting the entry of British Indians among others.
('38', 53, 2, 4, 120679) President Chiari had in a well considered message returned the Bill to the Assembly advising considerable amendments and reconsideration.
('38', 53, 2, 5, 120817) But the Assembly refused to make the amendments recommended except in matters that were inevitable.
('38', 53, 2, 6, 120917) The Assembly defended its restriction upon the liberty of British Indians on the ground of protection of the rights of posterity.
('38', 53, 2, 7, 121047) There are at present not more than perhaps thirity Sindhi Indian merchants of fancy goods.
('38', 53, 2, 8, 121138) It was acknowledged that their presence was no menace to the inhabitants of Panama.
('38', 53, 2, 9, 121222) Nevertheless the law is retrospective in its effect with the exception that those who can prove continuous previous domicile of ten years may receive exemption certificates.
('38', 53, 2, 10, 121396) I hardly think there are many settlers there who can prove continuous residence in Panama for such a long period.
('38', 53, 2, 11, 121510) If African experience is any guide, Indian settlers abroad are not in the habit of staying out of India for such a long period.
('38', 53, 2, 12, 121638) The matter is now, I understand, before the Foreign Office.
('38', 53, 2, 13, 121698) It remains to be seen how far that office is able to protect the rights of the resident Indian popu lation and of those who may choose to emigrate to Panama in search of an honest livelihood.

('38', 54, 1, 2, 122086) 43. SPEECH AT DHANBAD 1
('38', 54, 2, 3, 122110) January 13, 1927
('38', 54, 3, 4, 122127) Mahatma Gandhi in replying thanked the commissioners for the welcome addresses they had presented him.
('38', 54, 3, 5, 122230) He thanked particularly the commissioners of the Municipality for frankly confessing that khaddar and charkha were not much in use in the jurisdiction of their municipality.
('38', 54, 3, 6, 122404) He said that he used to take keen interest in municipal affairs even when he was in South Africa.
('38', 54, 3, 7, 122502) He knew that towns played a prominent part in the affairs of the country and that almost all movements in the modern world sprang from the towns.
('38', 54, 3, 8, 122648) He was aware further that sense of civic responsibility was to be awakened in their young men.
('38', 54, 3, 9, 122743) But in the peculiar condition of India, towns were at the most only of secondary importance.
('38', 54, 3, 10, 122836) India lived in villages and towns, sank into insignificance when compared with seven lakhs of villages.
('38', 54, 3, 11, 122940) This importance of village life in India was not to be lost sight of by the commissioners of the municipalities.
('38', 54, 3, 12, 123053) There was a growing tendency in this country on the part of the educated men to cut off all their connection with villages and wipe them out of their memory.
('38', 54, 3, 13, 123211) This tendency was to be checked.
('38', 54, 3, 14, 123244) In Europe the villages depended for everything upon the towns which were the centres of all sorts of activites.
('38', 54, 3, 15, 123356) But in India it was the villages which nourished the towns and as such it was the duty of every townsman to see that the healthy growth of the villagers was not interfered with in any way.
('38', 54, 3, 16, 123545) One wondered how India could be so poor in spite of her exports exceeding her imports.
('38', 54, 3, 17, 123632) The reason was that crores of rupees went out of this country to add to the prosperity of other people while the majority of their own men did not know what it was to have two full meals a day.
('38', 54, 3, 18, 123826) Whatever little money was left in this country went to the coffers of merchants and middle men.
('38', 54, 3, 19, 123922) He (Mahatmaji) did not envy their lot but the poor villages were not to be forgotten.

('38', 61, 4, 16, 144916) He said that swaraj which had ever been the dream of his life had almost come in 1921 22. The real shuddhi work, namely, the process of purification, had begun at that time.
('38', 61, 4, 17, 145090) A wave of enthusiasm had swept over the country and that was why they could come almost near their goal.
('38', 61, 4, 18, 145195) The same chapter was to be repeated again, but that could not be done till dissensions and disunions kept them hopelessly divided.
('38', 61, 5, 19, 145326) Proceeding, he said that those who entered the Councils did it with the sincere desire of doing good to the country and they might do some good work as well.
('38', 61, 5, 20, 145484) But how many could go to the Councils and how many were there who had right of voting, he asked.
('38', 61, 5, 21, 145581) Sixty lakhs of voters did not constitute the whole of India; his aim was to raise the thirty crores of Indian people.
('38', 61, 5, 22, 145699) Khaddar, he believed, might serve as a link between the rich and the poor; the spinning wheel might bring about unity and harmony among the entire population of India.
('38', 61, 5, 23, 145867) He appealed once more to the people to contribute to the funds of the All India Spinners’ Association and prayed to God to help them in doing their duty.

('38', 62, 9, 13, 146546) 49. SPEECH AT MEETING, GAYA 3
('38', 62, 10, 14, 146576) January 15, 1927
('38', 62, 11, 15, 146593) Mahatmaji, speaking in Hindi, regretted that the address presented to him on behalf of the municipality was written in English.
('38', 62, 11, 16, 146721) He said that whenever he found an opportunity he had repeatedly asked the people to present him addresses either in the vernacular of their province or in the national language of India, namely, Hindi.
('38', 62, 11, 17, 146923) He had no spite against the English language; he himself used that language on special occasions, but it was undesirable that they should use it while addressing their own men.
('38', 62, 11, 18, 147100) He requested the municipality to use Hindi whenever they presented any address, not merely to himself, but to any other Indian leader.
('38', 62, 12, 19, 147235) Continuing, he said that Gaya was really a sacred place to the Hindus, a place of pilgrimage for them.
('38', 62, 12, 20, 147338) But it pained him to see the deplorable state of the roads of that sacred city which was frequented by people from all parts of the country.
('38', 62, 12, 21, 147479) He had occasion that morning to see some of the roads in Gaya.
('38', 62, 12, 22, 147542) They surpassed in dirtiness even the roads of Ahmedabad, which was an old city and home of many poor people,
('38', 62, 13, 23, 147651) 1 Of the Munnalal Library at Gaya 2 There was no Pausa Sud 12 in this year.

('38', 63, 1, 2, 147940) which fact might be an excuse for the municipality of that place.
('38', 63, 1, 3, 148006) He regretted to say that he had never before seen such dirty roads in any part of India.
('38', 63, 1, 4, 148095) Gaya, being a place of all India interest, its municipality ought to have been an ideal one, but he was sadly disappointed.
('38', 63, 1, 5, 148219) He said that the commissioners should be up and doing in reforming the municipal arrangements of that great city.
('38', 63, 1, 6, 148333) How could they do so?
('38', 63, 1, 7, 148355) In order to achieve that end, the commissioners should themselves take up the work.
('38', 63, 1, 8, 148439) Mere dependence upon paid sweepers and scavengers would not better the situation.
('38', 63, 1, 9, 148521) He would rather request the chairman and the commissioners of the Board to take the broomsticks and buckets of water themselves and proceed to cleanse the roads and latrines of the city.
('38', 63, 1, 10, 148708) Towns were of considerable importance to the development of a country.
('38', 63, 1, 11, 148779) Growth of civic responsibilities in the people was an urgent necessity for their political emancipation.
('38', 63, 1, 12, 148884) He said that the case of Gaya was not an exception.
('38', 63, 1, 13, 148936) There were many other municipalities in India which were guilty of such bad administration.

('38', 63, 1, 15, 149112) There was nothing to be ashamed of in sweeping the streets; he himself had done it in many places; he had done it even in Bihar, in Champaran.
('38', 63, 1, 16, 149255) He was no lover of Western civilization; he would rather oppose all Western influences which tended to injure the vital interests of India.
('38', 63, 1, 17, 149395) But he would welcome all that was good in Western culture.
('38', 63, 1, 18, 149454) In respect of municipal administration, they had much to learn from the Western people.
('38', 63, 1, 19, 149542) Glasgow and Birmingham were formerly as dirty as Gaya, or perhaps even worse.
('38', 63, 1, 20, 149620) But the way in which the municipal administrators of those two places had reformed them was worthy to be imitated by the municipal commissioners of India.
('38', 63, 1, 21, 149775) He hoped that the Gaya Municipality will be prompt in reforming the state of that city.
('38', 63, 2, 22, 149863) Continuing, he regretted that the Chairman of the Municipality did not inform him in the morning that he and his colleagues could not agree on two points, namely khaddar and removal of untouchability.
('38', 63, 2, 23, 150064) In that case he might make time to try to convince them on those two points.
('38', 63, 2, 24, 150141) If they wanted to create a link between them and the villagers, the charkha and khaddar were unavoidable for them.
('38', 63, 2, 25, 150256) As regards untouchability, he did not think that there was any necessity of arguing on that point, after the death of Swami Shraddhanand.
('38', 63, 2, 26, 150394) He claimed to be sanatani Hindu.
('38', 63, 2, 27, 150427) But he had never found any of the Hindu scriptures sanctioning untouchability in the form in which it was practised by them.
('38', 63, 2, 28, 150552) If untouchability was not removed, Hindu society might altogether perish in the near future.
('38', 63, 2, 29, 150645) There were only three religions in the world, namely, Christianity, Islam and Hinduism.
('38', 63, 2, 30, 150733) He would regard Buddhism and Sikhism as branches of Hinduism, as the Hindu Mahasabha had defined it.
('38', 63, 2, 31, 150834) But the mighty Hindu society was fast disintegrating.
('38', 63, 2, 32, 150888) Christianity and Islam, in fact, the entire non Hindu population of the world, were keenly watching the movements of the Hindu society.
('38', 63, 2, 33, 151024) If they wanted to justify their existence and revive their old glory, it was their clear duty to remove that blot from Hinduism.
('38', 63, 3, 34, 151153) He had received that morning a cable from Mr. Andrews.
('38', 63, 3, 35, 151208) If they continued to tyrannize upon the so called untouchables, how could they expect to receive proper treatment at the hands of the white men in South Africa?
('38', 63, 3, 36, 151369) Gokhale had rightly said
('38', 64, 0, 1, 151394) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 65
('38', 64, 1, 2, 151436) in one of his addresses that it was but quite natural that the white people should look down upon the Indians who so inhumanly treated certain sections of their own people.
('38', 64, 1, 3, 151609) So long as the removal of untouchability was not achieved and the khaddar movement was not made to succeed, all their works would remain incomplete.
('38', 64, 1, 4, 151758) Continuing, he thanked the District Board for taking up khaddar work, although he was sorry that spinning could not be made popular with school children.
('38', 64, 1, 5, 151912) He was not surprised, for he knew the habit of children.
('38', 64, 1, 6, 151969) In order to make them spin regularly, the teachers should have to spin themselves.
('38', 64, 1, 7, 152052) The example of teachers might prompt the students to cling to the charkha as a plaything and they might create wonders while playing with the same.
('38', 64, 1, 8, 152200) He reminded the people of the good old days of their textile industry and asked them to endeavour their best to bring back those days.

('38', 64, 4, 12, 152417) He said that he was reminded by the chairman of the municipality as well as by the president of the Hindu Sabha that Gaya was a sacred place of pilgrimage, hallowed by the association of Lord Buddha.
('38', 64, 4, 13, 152617) But it pained him to see the miserable state of the latrines and the roads of Gaya dirtier than those which he had ever seen in his life.

('38', 69, 4, 6, 162306) presenting him the addresses, he said that although he would speak a few words on
('38', 69, 5, 7, 162388) other subjects also, his visit was mainly intended to preach the message of khaddar
('38', 69, 6, 8, 162472) and charkha.

('38', 69, 7, 10, 162559) evil of untouchability.

('38', 69, 8, 12, 162649) Hindu society.

('38', 69, 9, 14, 162733) to say that unless one untouchable was kept as family member in the house of each
('38', 69, 10, 15, 162815) and every Indian leader, they could not say that untouchability was removed.

('38', 69, 10, 17, 162966) If the leaders kept the
('38', 69, 11, 18, 162990) untouchables in their houses, there was no reason why people should blame them.

('38', 70, 1, 2, 164271) 56. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SEWAN 1
('38', 70, 2, 3, 164309) [January 16, 1927] 2
('38', 70, 3, 4, 164330) I am glad you say that your sub division is better than other parts so far as Hindu Muslim unity is concerned.
('38', 70, 3, 5, 164441) But can you say that you are so united that your unity will stand the strain of anything happening elsewhere?
('38', 70, 3, 6, 164551) I wish there can be at least one province, one district, one sub division in this vast land which can proudly say that no power on earth can foment a Hindu Muslim quarrel there.
('38', 70, 3, 7, 164729) We may think we are living but disunited we are worse than dead.
('38', 70, 3, 8, 164794) The Hindu thinks that in quarrelling with the Mussalman he is benefiting Hindu ism, and the Mussalman thinks that in fighting a Hindu he is bene fiting Islam.
('38', 70, 3, 9, 164953) But each is ruining his faith.
('38', 70, 3, 10, 164984) And the poison has spread as among the members of the communities themselves.
('38', 70, 3, 11, 165062) And no wonder.
('38', 70, 3, 12, 165077) For one man cannot do right in one department of life whilst he is occupied in doing wrong in any other department.
('38', 70, 3, 13, 165193) Life is one indivisible whole.
('38', 70, 3, 14, 165224) I said at Comilla that the problem had passed out of human hands, and that God had taken it into His own.
('38', 70, 3, 15, 165330) Maybe the statement springs from my egotism.
('38', 70, 3, 16, 165375) But I do not think so.
('38', 70, 3, 17, 165398) I have ample reason for it.
('38', 70, 3, 18, 165426) With my hand on my breast, I can say that not a minute in my life am I forgetful of God.
('38', 70, 3, 19, 165515) For over twenty years I have been doing everything that I have done as in the presence of God.
('38', 70, 3, 20, 165610) Hindu Muslim unity I had made a mission of my life.
('38', 70, 3, 21, 165662) I worked for it in South Africa, I toiled for it here, I did penance for it, but God was not satisfied, God did not want me to take any credit for the work.
('38', 70, 3, 22, 165819) And so I have now washed my hands.
('38', 70, 3, 23, 165854) I am helpless.
('38', 70, 3, 24, 165869) I have exhausted all my effort.
('38', 70, 3, 25, 165901) But as I am a believer in God, as I never for a moment lose faith in Him, as I content myself with the joy and sorrow that He wills for me, I may feel helpless, but I never lose hope.
('38', 70, 3, 26, 166085) Something within me tells me that Hindu Muslim unity must come and will come sooner than we might dare to hope, that God will one day force it on us, in spite of ourselves.
('38', 70, 3, 27, 166258) That is why I said that it has passed into the hands of God.
('38', 70, 3, 28, 166319) This, I said, might be taken to be an arrogant utterance—arrogant inasmuch as it implies that it is not in the power of any other man to
('38', 70, 4, 29, 166456) 1 Condensed summary of a speech delivered in Hindi 2 Sewan is a sub divisional town in the district of Saran, which, according to The Searchlight, 21 1 1927, Gandhiji covered on January 16.
('38', 71, 0, 1, 166646) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 71, 1, 2, 166687) achieve the work, as if no one has worked for it more than I. But there is no arrogance in the statement.
('38', 71, 1, 3, 166793) Hundreds may have done the work with the same earnestness, love and energy, but none with more.
('38', 71, 1, 4, 166889) And I believe that all of them must be feeling as helpless as I. In 1920, I said that not even the British Empire with all the resources of its armed strength, diplomacy and organization could efface us, make us slaves, or divide Hindus from Mussalmans.
('38', 71, 1, 5, 167143) But that was because I thought we were godfearing then.
('38', 71, 1, 6, 167199) We trusted one another and we relied on one another’s strength.
('38', 71, 1, 7, 167263) But how am I to prevail upon you today to cast off all fear, hatred and distrust?
('38', 71, 1, 8, 167345) Shraddhanandji was not the enemy of Mussalmans.
('38', 71, 1, 9, 167393) He was a warrior, he had the courage of his convictions.
('38', 71, 1, 10, 167450) Assassination was not the way to fight him.
('38', 71, 1, 11, 167494) Let us Hindus and Mussalmans both wash the sins of our heart with his blood.
('38', 71, 1, 12, 167571) And what is it that we should be fighting for?
('38', 71, 1, 13, 167618) We Hindus may be idol worshippers.
('38', 71, 1, 14, 167653) We may be mistaken.
('38', 71, 1, 15, 167673) But when God gave every man the right to make mistakes, when God suffers us to live although we are idol worshippers, why should not the Mussalmans suffer us too?
('38', 71, 1, 16, 167836) And if a Mussalman thinks that he must slaughter the cow, why should a Hindu stay his hands by force?
('38', 71, 1, 17, 167938) Why should he not fall on bended knees before him and plead with him?
('38', 71, 1, 18, 168008) But we will do no such thing.
('38', 71, 1, 19, 168038) Well then, God will one day make the Mussalman and the Hindu do what we will not do today.
('38', 71, 1, 20, 168129) If you are believers, I beseech you to retire into yourselves and pray to the In dweller to stay your hands from wrong and to make them do the right thing.
('38', 71, 1, 21, 168285) Let that be our prayer every morning and evening.
('38', 71, 1, 22, 168335) There is no other way.

('38', 75, 1, 2, 174554) 60. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('38', 75, 2, 3, 174581) Silence Day, Pausa Sud 14 [January 17, 1927]
('38', 75, 3, 4, 174626) DEAR SISTERS, I have your letter.
('38', 75, 3, 5, 174660) I always write to you on Mondays; but as I keep moving from town to town, the day on which you receive my letters may vary.
('38', 75, 3, 6, 174784) Till now I was to the south of the Ganga.
('38', 75, 3, 7, 174826) Yesterday I came over to the north, crossing the river.
('38', 75, 3, 8, 174882) From Patna we crossed over to the other side by means of a boat.
('38', 75, 3, 9, 174947) A car awaited us there and took us to Sonepur.
('38', 75, 3, 10, 174994) Soil here is not sticky like mud; it has a mixture of sand in it.
('38', 75, 3, 11, 175060) It, therefore, feels soft to the feet like velvet.
('38', 75, 3, 12, 175111) Ba and I walked for about a mile.
('38', 75, 3, 13, 175145) We were not wearing sandals.
('38', 75, 3, 14, 175174) We liked to walk on the sand very much indeed.
('38', 75, 3, 15, 175221) Mother Ganga prepares new soil every year in this part of the country.
('38', 75, 3, 16, 175292) For hundreds of miles she carries mud and silt with her and, depositing them here, she runs along to the sea as though she wanted to avoid feeling embarrassed by being told by anyone of the great good she was doing to the land.
('38', 75, 3, 17, 175520) Today we are in Rajendra Babu’s village.
('38', 75, 3, 18, 175561) Rajbansi Devi is here.
('38', 75, 3, 19, 175584) Chandramukhi and Vidyavati are at present in Chhapra, the town where he (i.e., Rajendra Babu) lives.
('38', 75, 3, 20, 175685) We met them in Chhapra.
('38', 75, 3, 21, 175709) Both are in relatively good health—Chandramukhi slightly worse than she was in the Ashram and Vidyavati slightly better.
('38', 75, 3, 22, 175830) In a women’s meeting yesterday I started educating them on a new subject.
('38', 75, 3, 23, 175904) The women here wear heavy silver ornaments; they keep their children dirty and do not comb their hair.
('38', 75, 3, 24, 176007) I, therefore, criticized their habit of wearing ornaments.
('38', 75, 3, 25, 176066) The result was that some of them gave away their anklets, necklaces and so on to me, and promised that they would neither buy nor wear others in future.
('38', 75, 3, 26, 176219) While doing this, I thought of all of you.
('38', 75, 3, 27, 176262) Ba is giving me great help in this work, but that is because she agrees with me in this.
('38', 75, 3, 28, 176351) You can do work of this kind better than I. But that requires self sacrifice, enthusiasm, and opportunities.
('38', 75, 3, 29, 176460) All this you can have there.
('38', 75, 3, 30, 176489) Do we not sing atmavatsa rvabhuteshu 1?
('38', 75, 3, 31, 176529) We should regard all as ourselves.
('38', 75, 3, 32, 176564) Then, on finding somebody’s children dirty, we would feel as if our own children were
('38', 75, 4, 33, 176650) 1 ( He sees rightly who) in all things sees himself.
('38', 76, 0, 1, 176703) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 77
('38', 76, 1, 2, 176745) dirty and so would feel ashamed; on finding someone else suffer would ourselves suffer and seek a remedy for the suffering.

('38', 76, 1, 4, 176899) Much as I like to exceed, I feel nervous when I look at the pile of correspondence lying before me.
