('38', 77, 0, 1, 178173) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 77, 1, 2, 178214) 62. KHADI IN BIHAR
('38', 77, 2, 3, 178233) Rajendra Prasad has sent me the report on the work of the Bihar branch of the A.I.S.A. for the year ending September 1926. It is a record of steady progress.
('38', 77, 2, 4, 178391) After mentioning the vicissitudes the organization had to pass through in the early stages, the report says: 1
('38', 77, 3, 5, 178502) There are 8 production and sale centres and 11 sale depots.
('38', 77, 3, 6, 178562) Besides these there are sale agencies at 6 places and more are being established.
('38', 77, 3, 7, 178644) The agency has 65 wholetime workers including two honorary workers.
('38', 77, 3, 8, 178712) Their average earnings are Rs. 25 per month.
('38', 77, 3, 9, 178757) During the year under review 2,698 spinners earned Rs. 29,519; 489 weavers, Rs. 36,862; 6 tailors, Rs. 230 during two months; 8 dyers and printers Rs. 2,273 during six months including the cost of dyes; and 40 washermen Rs. 1,951 during six months.
('38', 77, 3, 10, 179006) It goes without saying that the spinners and weavers too were not wholetime workers.
('38', 77, 3, 11, 179091) They worked only during their spare time and irregularly.
('38', 77, 3, 12, 179149) The report then says:
('38', 77, 4, 13, 179171) The progress that has been made is not only in regard to increased production and sale but also in regard to the quality of khaddar and reduction in its price.
('38', 77, 4, 14, 179331) The average price in 1923 was Rs. 1 0 5 per yard of fine cloth.
('38', 77, 4, 15, 179395) It was reduced to As.
('38', 77, 4, 16, 179417) 13 in 1926. When the yarn was very weak the weaving charge was 3 annas 3 pies per yard of 45 inches width.
('38', 77, 4, 17, 179524) On account of the improvement in the yarn, it has now been reduced to 2 annas 3 pies per yard of the same width.
('38', 77, 4, 18, 179637) Nor is there any difficulty about getting sufficient weavers to weave hand spun yarn.
('38', 77, 4, 19, 179723) Some of these weavers weave even up to 72 inches width and the variety of weaving includes twills, coatings of various designs, etc.
('38', 77, 4, 20, 179856) Dyeing and printing is being developed under the special care of a graduate of the Bihar Vidyapith.
('38', 77, 4, 21, 179956) The report, after mentioning the work in different branches of the organization, says:
('38', 77, 5, 22, 180043) If we could dispose of our present stock, it is expected that we shall be
('38', 77, 6, 23, 180117) able to reduce our prices still further by about 10 p.c.
('38', 77, 7, 24, 180174) 1 The statement, which gave figures of the production and sale of khaddar, is not reproduced here.
('38', 78, 0, 1, 180273) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 79
('38', 78, 1, 2, 180315) It naturally dwells upon the successful peripatetic exhibitions that were held during the year, of which a detailed account has appeared from time to time in these pages.
('38', 78, 1, 3, 180486) The interesting report contains the following pregnant reflections:
('38', 78, 2, 4, 180554) The province of Bihar is particularly suited for khaddar work.
('38', 78, 2, 5, 180617) The population is agricultural; there is no industry in the province worth the name, outside the coalfields of Chhotanagpur and apart from the great Tata Iron and Steel Works at Jamshedpur.
('38', 78, 2, 6, 180807) The tradition of spinning is still extant in most parts of it and the number of weavers and looms is large enough to supply almost the entire requirement of cloth of the province.
('38', 78, 2, 7, 180987) Cotton, though of an inferior quality, is also produced in many parts of it.
('38', 78, 2, 8, 181064) The work of production of khaddar is, therefore, not very difficult, although it requires organization and technical skill to improve its quality.
('38', 78, 2, 9, 181211) It can be extended almost indefinitely, if sufficient capital and organizing and technical skill are forthcoming.
('38', 78, 3, 10, 181325) The above narrative will show the progress made in reviving the ancient but practically all but dead industry of spinning in Bihar.
('38', 78, 3, 11, 181457) We have succeeded in touching but the merest fringe of the vast area in which spinning can be revived and made to furnish a much needed occupation for the idle hours of our great agricultural population.
('38', 78, 3, 12, 181661) That its possibilities are vast can hardly be denied.
('38', 78, 3, 13, 181715) That some supplementary occupation, not to speak of income, is necessary for the population will be apparent from the fact that the average quantity of land actually cultivated with food and non food crops is less than three quarters of an acre per head.
('38', 78, 3, 14, 181970) It is the yield of this small quantity of land, nearly four fifths of which are unirrigated and depend upon the freaks of the monsoon, that is expected not only to keep the body and soul together of every individual but also to supply him with cloth and other necessaries of life and to meet among others all demands of the zamindar, the society and the State.
('38', 78, 3, 15, 182331) Looked at from this point of view the admittedly scanty earning of 7 pies per day by charkha is not after all so small and does afford, as experience has shown, substantial relief to a class of people who need such relief but cannot get it through forced unemployment.
('38', 78, 3, 16, 182600) It is believed that agriculture does not require more than a hundred days’ labour in the year but the work is so distributed that the agriculturist cannot leave his farm and seek work elsewhere at a distance.
('38', 78, 3, 17, 182809) In fact, the nature of the work is such that it allows plenty of leisure but at short intervals and a supplementary industry, which is not capable of being taken up and put aside to be resumed later at the stage at which it was left, cannot be usefully taken up.
('38', 78, 3, 18, 183072) Experience has shown that the charkha alone can serve the purpose.
('38', 78, 3, 19, 183139) It is hoped that the appeal made in the report to the public for the purchase of khaddar will meet with the liberal response it deserves.
('38', 78, 3, 20, 183277) Young India, 20 1 1927
('38', 79, 0, 1, 183300) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 79, 1, 2, 183341) 63. HINDI V. ENGLISH
('38', 79, 2, 3, 183362) Organizers of meetings seem to require constant reminders that not English but Hindi or Hindustani is the common medium of expression among the masses.
('38', 79, 2, 4, 183514) I have observed that unlike as in 1921 the addresses hitherto presented to me during the tour have been in most cases in English.
('38', 79, 2, 5, 183644) The absurdity became patent when an address in English on behalf of the employees of Jharia collieries was sought to be read to me and that, at a big mass meeting attended by thousands, hardly fifty of whom could possibly understand English.
('38', 79, 2, 6, 183886) The vast majority could have easily followed Hindi and a very large number could have understood Bengali.
('38', 79, 2, 7, 183992) The officers of the associ ation were from Bengal.
('38', 79, 2, 8, 184043) If the English drafting was meant for me, it was wholly unnecessary.
('38', 79, 2, 9, 184112) They might have written the address in Bengali and given me a translation in Hindi or even in English.
('38', 79, 2, 10, 184215) But to inflict English on that big audience would have been an insult to them.
('38', 79, 2, 11, 184294) I hope that the time is coming when, if the proceedings are conducted in a language the majority cannot understand, they would leave such meetings.
('38', 79, 2, 12, 184442) Be it said to the credit of the chairman at this meeting that he saw the absurdity as soon as I drew his attention to it and very courteously allowed the address to be taken as read.
('38', 79, 2, 13, 184625) May the incident serve as a warning to all the organizers but more especially those in the Andhradesh, Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Karnatak.
('38', 79, 2, 14, 184761) I know their difficulty.
('38', 79, 2, 15, 184786) But they have had now for six years in their midst an efficient organization for the spread of Hindi.
('38', 79, 2, 16, 184888) Their addresses should be in the vernaculars of their respective provinces with a Hindi translation for my benefit.
('38', 79, 2, 17, 185004) I have always made an exception in Dravida land and delivered my speeches in English wherever they have so desired.
('38', 79, 2, 18, 185120) But I do think that the time has come when they should dispense with English for big public meetings.
('38', 79, 2, 19, 185222) Really it is the English speaking leaders who are blocking the way to our rapid progress among the masses by their refusal to learn Hindi which can be easily picked up inside of three months even in Dravida land, if the learners will give three hours per day.
('38', 79, 2, 20, 185482) Let those who doubt give a trial to the Hindi Prachar Karyalaya conducted in Madras under the aegis of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, Prayag.
('38', 79, 2, 21, 185621) They will find at the head office in Triplicane and the branches in Andhradesh and elsewhere books and teachers that will satisfy them.
('38', 79, 2, 22, 185757) There is no excuse save
('38', 80, 0, 1, 185781) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 81
('38', 80, 1, 2, 185823) idleness or disinclination for not knowing Hindi which is understood by over twenty crores of the people of Hindustan.
('38', 80, 1, 3, 185942) Young India, 20 1 1927 64. NOTES
('38', 80, 2, 4, 185975) ALL INDIA DESHBANDHU MEMORIAL
('38', 80, 3, 5, 186005) I hope the readers of Young India have not forgotten the All India Deshbandhu Memorial.
('38', 80, 3, 6, 186093) When I suspended touring after the Cawnpore Congress for one year, I knew that the collection of funds for the All India Deshbandhu Memorial to which I had pledged myself would be suspended.
('38', 80, 3, 7, 186284) But it was inevitable.
('38', 80, 3, 8, 186307) At the time of suspension I had stated that, if God willed it, at the end of the year I would resume my tour for the collection.
('38', 80, 3, 9, 186436) I resumed it at Calcutta and all the collections that I am now making will be for the All India Deshbandhu Memorial except where the donors otherwise specify the object of their donations.
('38', 80, 3, 10, 186625) And since the object of the All India Deshbandhu Memorial is village organization and that through the spinning movement, all these collections automatically become part of the All India Spinners’ Association which is the agency through which the Memorial collections are to be utilized for the purpose.
('38', 80, 3, 11, 186929) A resolution to this effect was passed by the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Committee at Cawnpore in 1925. I trust, therefore, that those who are in charge of the organization of meetings in connection with my tour will take good care to inform those who may attend meetings of the object of the tour.
('38', 80, 3, 12, 187231) There should be no desire to spring a surprise upon those who attend meetings by asking for subscription.
('38', 80, 3, 13, 187337) The honest course is to let them know beforehand that they will be asked to pay.
('38', 80, 3, 14, 187418) No one need pay unless he believes in the Memorial and its object.
('38', 80, 3, 15, 187485) I know, too, that a man may revere the memory of Deshbandhu and still not believe in the spinning movement.
('38', 80, 3, 16, 187593) But I would venture to remind such people of what were Deshbandhu’s last wishes expressed to his wife, his sister and his trusted lieutenants and Satis Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan and to me almost exactly 7 days before his death.
('38', 80, 3, 17, 187834) He said that as soon as he descended from Darjeeling, he would throw himself heart and soul into the spinning movement.
('38', 80, 3, 18, 187954) He could see that that was the greatest constructive movement we could undertake and that it was the most effective method of village organization and village reconstruction.
('38', 80, 3, 19, 188129) It was for that reason that he had asked me to send for Satis Babu with
('38', 81, 0, 1, 188201) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 81, 1, 2, 188242) whom he had discussed the plan of working the spinning movement and it was for the spinning movement that he had intended to spend the largest part of the money that had been collected for village reconstruction.
('38', 81, 1, 3, 188455) The Spinners’ Association, therefore, is the natural outcome, if I may say so, of Deshbandhu’s wishes.
('38', 81, 2, 4, 188558) TO ORGANIZERS
('38', 81, 3, 5, 188572) If all goes well, I hope during the year to cover, besides Bihar, part of Maharashtra, Madras Presidency including Karnatak, U.P., Bengal and Orissa.
('38', 81, 3, 6, 188722) I should love to visit the other provinces also if time and health permit and if they intend to subscribe to the Memo rial, that is, khadi work.
('38', 81, 3, 7, 188867) To Orissa I have promised to go and pass there, so far as it is humanly possible, the month of November, not because I expect to make large collections but because it is to my mind an epitome of our distressful condition.
('38', 81, 3, 8, 189089) Orissa regenerate is to me the regeneration for the whole of India.
('38', 81, 3, 9, 189157) It is a land which need not be the poorest in the country.
('38', 81, 3, 10, 189216) Its people are in no way inferior to those of the other parts of India.
('38', 81, 3, 11, 189288) They have a fine history all their own.
('38', 81, 3, 12, 189328) They have magnificent temples.
('38', 81, 3, 13, 189359) They have the Lord of the Universe in their midst who knows no distinction between his creatures.
('38', 81, 3, 14, 189457) And yet, sad to relate, under the very shadow of the mighty temple people die of hunger in their thousands.
('38', 81, 3, 15, 189565) It is a land of chronic poverty, chronic famine, and chronic disease.
('38', 81, 3, 16, 189635) Nowhere have I seen in the eyes of people so much blankness, so much despair, so much lifelessness as in Orissa.
('38', 81, 3, 17, 189748) I therefore look forward to my stay in November with sad pleasure.
('38', 81, 3, 18, 189815) It is a province that can be, ought to be, easily organized for spinning, because the people have no work.
('38', 81, 3, 19, 189922) The whole of Orissa cannot be transplanted to the factories of Bengal or the factories of all India put together.
('38', 81, 3, 20, 190036) It would be wrong even if it was possible.
('38', 81, 3, 21, 190079) Happily it is not possible.
('38', 81, 3, 22, 190107) The people must live on their own land and learn to be resourceful, industrious, and learn even to be happy.
('38', 81, 3, 23, 190216) They have forgotten what happiness can be.
('38', 81, 3, 24, 190259) Let the workers in Orissa, therefore, understand their responsibility.
('38', 81, 3, 25, 190330) I expect them to throw themselves heart and soul into the spinning movement.
('38', 81, 3, 26, 190407) Let them not think of the whole of Orissa.
('38', 81, 3, 27, 190450) Let them think of single villages where they will establish themselves, and where they may, by prayerful and persistent effort, lift the people out of the Slough of Despond into which they have stuck.
('38', 82, 0, 1, 190651) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 83
('38', 82, 1, 2, 190693) And though, as I have said, I do not expect to make large collections, I shall welcome the only pies of the people who will attend meetings, even as I welcomed them when I travelled in 1921. The sight of old people with their trembling fingers untying the knots which firmly held their pies and willingly surrendering them to me is never to be forgotten.
('38', 82, 1, 3, 191048) I want to see it again and renew, if a renewal is necessary, the determination that this winter of despair is to be changed into the summer of hope and happiness within a measurable distance of time.
('38', 82, 1, 4, 191248) May I ask the organizers also to bear in mind that the tour is to be almost incessant and that I must do my editing and attend to my correspondence during the hours they may leave for me and in the trains?
('38', 82, 1, 5, 191454) Besides Mondays, at least three hours should be left for me in addition to the time required for ablutions and meals.
('38', 82, 1, 6, 191572) All night demonstrations must be avoided.
('38', 82, 1, 7, 191614) It is impossible after a strenuous day’s work to stand the strain of disturbance during sleeping hours.
('38', 82, 1, 8, 191718) And as this is to be a purely business tour, the meetings should be so arranged and the audiences should be so seated as to leave passages for collectors to pass to and fro.
('38', 82, 1, 9, 191892) All shoutings and noises should be avoided.
('38', 82, 1, 10, 191936) I have observed that where management is effi cient, collections mount up.
('38', 82, 1, 11, 192011) The audiences have invariably been found by me to be responsive.
('38', 82, 1, 12, 192076) Though the thousands of the rich are welcome, I know that it is the coppers and the single rupees of the poor people that bless the movement.
('38', 82, 1, 13, 192218) It is theirs and let them freely contribute to it their mite.
('38', 82, 2, 14, 192280) Young India, 20 1 1927
('38', 82, 3, 15, 192303) 65. THE CENTRAL FACT
('38', 82, 4, 16, 192324) During my tour in so far as it has progressed up to now, I have observed that spinning organizations have not an accurate register of spinners and that the figures supplied and published by me from time to time in these pages were based upon the deductions drawn from the actual wages paid to the spinners.
('38', 82, 4, 17, 192631) For statistical information the calculation is sound enough because it must err on the right side, i.e., of understatement.
('38', 82, 4, 18, 192755) But it is not good enough for the movement itself.
('38', 82, 4, 19, 192806) The spinning movement depends for its permanence upon a vital and direct contact being established between the workers and the spinners; for then and then only shall we be able to understand the wants,
('38', 83, 0, 1, 193008) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 83, 1, 2, 193049) aspirations and limitations of the spinners.
('38', 83, 1, 3, 193094) The object is to penetrate the remotest Indian homes in the innumerable villages of India and to introduce a ray of hope and light into these homes.
('38', 83, 1, 4, 193243) This we shall never do, if we do not establish a living touch with the spinners.
('38', 83, 1, 5, 193324) We cannot, therefore, be satisfied with the work of middlemen whom we may not and do not know.
('38', 83, 1, 6, 193419) We must be able to trace the course of every pie till it is safely deposited in the hands of the spinners.
('38', 83, 1, 7, 193526) And let it be remembered that spinning is the central fact of the movement, not weaving, not dyeing, not printing, not even carding and ginning, anterior though the last two processes are to spinning.
('38', 83, 1, 8, 193727) For the economic solution depends upon a supplementary employment being found for the largest number of the semi starved millions.
('38', 83, 1, 9, 193858) That employment by far the best is spinning and that alone, as will be seen by a study of the figures for the various provinces given in these pages.
('38', 83, 1, 10, 194008) The Bihar figures reproduced in this issue show 489 weavers against 2,698 spinners.
('38', 83, 1, 11, 194092) My own observation is that ten spinners are required to feed one weaver both working for the same amount of time.
('38', 83, 1, 12, 194206) The ultimate ambition is to teach the spinners carding and ginning so as to enable them to increase their earnings as spinners without much effort and without much training.
('38', 83, 1, 13, 194380) This is being done on a fairly large scale in Bihar, Bengal and the Madras Presidency.
('38', 83, 1, 14, 194467) The Spinners’ Association can justify its existence therefore only upon its achieving a progressive amelioration in the economic condition of the vast masses who can be reached in no other way in a shorter time.
('38', 83, 1, 15, 194679) The movement depends also for its increasing influence and vitality upon this fact of its tender care for the millions of whom it has as yet only touched but a small part.
('38', 83, 1, 16, 194851) Workers have suggested to me that, if an accurate register is to be kept of every spinner, it would involve extra cost.
('38', 83, 1, 17, 194971) Possibly, it will.
('38', 83, 1, 18, 194990) Not being in charge of a single centre, I am unable fully to under stand the difficulty of keeping such registers.
('38', 83, 1, 19, 195105) But I can say without any fear of challenge that, whatever the cost may be, a complete register of spinners is an absolute necessity until spinning has become an automatically working movement beyond risk of destruction.
('38', 83, 1, 20, 195326) The extra cost that the keeping of such a register may involve will be worth undertaking if we are to put the movement on a stable foundation.
('38', 83, 1, 21, 195469) What an accurate and simultaneous entry of every pie received and spent in a banking corporation is to its honest existence and steady
('38', 84, 0, 1, 195604) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 85
('38', 84, 1, 2, 195646) growth, an accurate register of spinners is to the honest existence and steady growth of the spinning movement.
('38', 84, 1, 3, 195758) I hope therefore that every spinning organization will without any loss of time set about keeping a full and up to date register of its spinners.
('38', 84, 1, 4, 195904) Needless to say that the workers who will be incharge of the registers and who will come in contact with the spinners must be men—and how nice if they were women?—of unimpeachable character and purity.
('38', 84, 1, 5, 196106) The discovery of this flaw in the movement was made by me through the hypersen sitiveness of the workers of Bengal.
('38', 84, 1, 6, 196222) In my notice of the Abhoy Ashram report, 1 I made an incidental observation that our statements of figures must not contain “abouts” and “nearlies” and then I made a general observation about the necessity of purity of character.
('38', 84, 1, 7, 196452) I had in making that observation no one in particular in mind but owing to the juxtaposition of the general remark to the mention of the work of the Abhoy Ashram some of its inmates suspected that my remarks were aimed at them.
('38', 84, 1, 8, 196680) I had no difficulty in disabusing their minds of the suspicion; but the conversation enabled me to under stand and convince the members of the Ashram of the necessity of keeping an accurate up to date register of spinners.
('38', 84, 1, 9, 196903) I am therefore not sorry for the paragraph that I wrote in my notice of the Abhoy Ashram, if only because it has led to the discovery of the flaw in our human account keeping.
('38', 84, 1, 10, 197079) But let me reiterate for the information of all concerned that in this spinning movement which is fraught with tremendous consequences, we cannot put too much stress upon the absolute necessity of members of our organizations being and remaining beyond suspicion, and if we are to attain this standard of purity, we will have to develop a thick skin enough to stand and take in good part well meant suggestions, criticisms and observations.

('38', 87, 4, 13, 203845) Mahatmaji in replying thanked the Boards for presenting him addresses.

('38', 87, 4, 21, 204769) He admitted that the Western system of medical treatment was very defective, but he knew this also that the Indians did not do even half of what the people of Europe were doing for the success of their medical science.
('38', 87, 4, 22, 204988) But they had great opportunity to work for the improvement of that science.

('38', 87, 4, 24, 205139) He further requested the vaidyas to make a scientific study of the system.
('38', 87, 4, 25, 205214) If there were defects in the system,
('38', 87, 5, 26, 205251) 1 At the meeting, addresses were presented to Gandhiji on behalf of the Mun icipality, the District Board, the goshalas, the Youngmen’s Debating Club and the Arya Samaj.
('38', 88, 0, 1, 205421) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 89
('38', 88, 1, 2, 205463) and defects there certainly were, they should not try to conceal them; on the contrary, every effort should be made to remove them.
('38', 88, 2, 3, 205595) Continuing, he said that he was glad to learn that the organizers of the Madhubani goshala agreed with his views on the utilization of the hides of dead cattle
('38', 88, 3, 4, 205755) for the improvement of the cattle themselves.
('38', 88, 3, 5, 205801) Goshalas, he said, had two aspects, one
('38', 88, 4, 6, 205841) economic and the other religious.
('38', 88, 4, 7, 205875) The question of cow protection was a non 
('38', 88, 5, 8, 205917) controversial matter.
('38', 88, 5, 9, 205939) He did not understand why there should be any quarrel with the Muslims on that point.
('38', 88, 5, 10, 206025) His views on kurbani, he said, remained unchanged.
('38', 88, 6, 11, 206076) Continuing, he said that the existing line of work of the goshala had also
('38', 88, 7, 12, 206151) many defects in it.
('38', 88, 7, 13, 206171) They should be maintained in the right and proper way.
('38', 88, 7, 14, 206226) The organizers of these houses should be thoroughly acquainted with the treatment of animal diseases.
('38', 88, 7, 15, 206328) They should know how to house and feed the cows, how to make milk cheaper for the poor village purchasers; in fact, the conductors of goshalas
('38', 88, 8, 16, 206471) must thoroughly study the science of cattle keeping and then alone could the purpose of goshalas be served.
('38', 88, 9, 17, 206579) Proceeding, he said that he had done all he could for the attainment of Hindu Muslim unity but had failed.
('38', 88, 9, 18, 206686) For that reason he had given up reading newspapers even.
('38', 88, 9, 19, 206743) He had no time to read them either.
('38', 88, 9, 20, 206779) His condition, he said, had become like king Janaka of Mithila who had looked indifferently when his own city was burning, for he had done all he could to prevent the fire.
('38', 88, 9, 21, 206952) Similarly his (Mahatmaji’s) attitude towards Hindu Muslim differences was that of indifference for he knew that it was not in his power to remedy it.
('38', 88, 9, 22, 207102) He said he did not know how or when Hindu Muslim unity would come.
('38', 88, 9, 23, 207169) The people of this country had gone mad; they were unhesitatingly cutting the throats of each other.
('38', 88, 9, 24, 207270) He could not be a party to it.
('38', 88, 9, 25, 207301) His religion was of non violence, his faith in non violence remained as unshaken as it was before, although attempts were made by his friends to convince him of the utility of violence on special occasions.
('38', 88, 9, 26, 207508) To him all things were not as they seemed and he believed firmly that non violence was the religion through which alone one could triumph ultimately.
('38', 88, 9, 27, 207658) For all those reasons, he said, he had stopped dealing with the subject altogether.
('38', 88, 9, 28, 207742) But he believed that the unity would certainly come one day, if not through the agency of man, through the agency of God.
('38', 88, 10, 29, 207864) Referring to khaddar, he said that he was glad that a purse was presented to him for khaddar work.
('38', 88, 10, 30, 207963) But from Madhubani he expected much more.
('38', 88, 10, 31, 208005) Madhubani, he said, was a big khaddar centre.
('38', 88, 10, 32, 208051) He saw that many poor spinners of the place came four or five miles walking on foot with their yarn to take cotton or money from the workers.
('38', 88, 10, 33, 208193) He knew that there were people who were even poorer than they.
('38', 88, 10, 34, 208256) While he was at Champaran he had heard a lady complain that she could not take her bath in the Ganges and clean her clothes because she had no additional clothes to spare.
('38', 88, 10, 35, 208428) This might have been an exaggeration but such cases were not absent.
('38', 88, 10, 36, 208497) There was no other
('38', 89, 0, 1, 208516) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 89, 1, 2, 208557) way to relieve the poverty of those people except by giving them an occupation and the best possible occupation they could give them was spinning.
('38', 89, 2, 3, 208704) Continuing, he said that he had just heard a hymn from the Isopanishad which
('38', 89, 3, 4, 208781) meant that those who did not work stole other men’s property.
('38', 89, 3, 5, 208843) What did it mean, he asked.
('38', 89, 3, 6, 208871) It did not mean that he actually stole other men’s property but it meant that he lived on the food earned by other men’s labour.
('38', 89, 3, 7, 209000) As a matter of fact, no man had any right to live, unless he worked not only for himself but for all men alike, for an individual is but a drop in the great ocean of humanity.
('38', 89, 3, 8, 209176) Similarly, the Gita taught him that no man should eat unless he had performed yajna and of the many yajnas
('38', 89, 4, 9, 209283) sanctioned by that sacred book, that of working for others was the best.
('38', 89, 4, 10, 209356) Spinning, then, was the only work which could help thousands of people; it was the universal yajna which could be performed by all.
('38', 89, 5, 11, 209488) Addressing the ladies, he said that to him all who were clad in foreign clothes were naked, for nothing but khaddar could cover the nakedness of Indians.
('38', 89, 6, 12, 209642) Mahatmaji appealed to the people to look into the affairs of the local national school and of the goshala and help them with money if they deserved it.
('38', 89, 6, 13, 209794) It was the
('38', 89, 7, 14, 209805) duty of a citizen, he said, to help his fellow beings and institutions in distress.
('38', 89, 8, 15, 209889) He concluded by appealing once more for money for khaddar work and asking people to purchase khadi which was stocked at the meeting.
('38', 89, 8, 16, 210022) The Searchlight, 26 1 1927
('38', 89, 9, 17, 210049) 68. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SAMASTIPUR
('38', 89, 10, 18, 210090) January 20, 1927
('38', 89, 11, 19, 210107) He said that he was glad to see them once more.
('38', 89, 11, 20, 210155) It was impossible for him to forget the people of Samastipur who had once brought him there in a special train with Bapu Brajkishore Prasad and others.
('38', 89, 11, 21, 210307) He had, therefore, come to Samastipur with great hope.
('38', 89, 11, 22, 210362) His tour, he said, was intended to preach the message of khaddar.
('38', 89, 11, 23, 210428) It pained him very much to see that most of the people who had come to see him had not put on khaddar.
('38', 89, 11, 24, 210531) He had preached the message of khaddar for five long years from thousands of platforms but still the people were reluctant to use khadi.
('38', 89, 11, 25, 210668) Bihar had the capacity to produce as much khaddar as could be consumed in the province and if only the people patronized that great cottage industry, thousands of their unemployed men and women—ginners, carders, spinners, weavers, and even bleachers and washermen— could be provided with food and clothing.
('38', 89, 11, 26, 210975) Every farthing that they could spend on khadi would go to the homes of their poor countrymen.
('38', 89, 11, 27, 211069) It was their religious duty, therefore, to put on khadi and khadi alone.
('38', 89, 12, 28, 211142) Continuing, he said that by purchasing mill made cloth they were helping only the rich mill owners of either Lancashire or Ahmedabad.
('38', 89, 12, 29, 211276) He was intimately acquainted
('38', 90, 0, 1, 211305) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 91
('38', 90, 1, 2, 211347) with the condition of labourers through Anasuyabehn.
('38', 90, 1, 3, 211400) He knew it definitely that the labourers were little benefited by the huge amount of money that people spent over mill made cloth.
('38', 90, 1, 4, 211531) The rich mill owners were not in need of money and they had a wide market even outside India, but the poor countrymen of theirs were dying for a bit of rough bread.
('38', 90, 1, 5, 211696) He knew how poor the people of Bihar were, for he had been in Champaran for a long time.
('38', 90, 1, 6, 211785) Would they not be kind and sympathetic to these poor people, he asked.
('38', 90, 2, 7, 211856) Proceeding, he said that money was necessary for the furtherance of khaddar work.
('38', 90, 2, 8, 211938) In order to save crores of money permanently in the country, crores of money were to be invested in the beginning.
('38', 90, 2, 9, 212053) He had come to their door to beg of them that money.
('38', 90, 2, 10, 212106) He regretted that no khaddar was stocked at the place of the meeting, although he was told on his arrival that there were khaddar shops in the town and that some khaddar would surely be stocked on the spot.
('38', 90, 2, 11, 212313) Nevertheless he requested the people to go at once to the khaddar shop and clothe themselves in khadi.
('38', 90, 3, 12, 212416) Concluding, Mahatmaji spoke a few words on the evils of untouchability and paid an eloquent tribute to Shraddhanand, the martyr, who had embraced death in his attempt to regenerate the untouchables.
('38', 90, 4, 13, 212615) An address of welcome on behalf of the Municipality was then read by Babu Giriwardhar, Chairman, to which Mahatmaji made a short reply.
('38', 90, 4, 14, 212751) He expressed his satisfaction that there was no ill feeling between the Hindu and the Mussalmans of Samastipur.
('38', 90, 4, 15, 212863) It was a great thing.
('38', 90, 4, 16, 212885) He hoped that that state of things would continue to exist.
('38', 90, 5, 17, 212945) Referring to their desire to have a khaddar producing centre at Samastipur, he said that if they sincerely desired such an organization, Rajendra Babu would surely look into the matter.
('38', 90, 5, 18, 213131) He hoped that if requisite amount of money was advanced by the people themselves, Rajendra Babu would be coming to their help with all the energy he possessed.
('38', 90, 6, 19, 213291) Referring to the national school, he regretted that it was not what it ought to have been.
('38', 90, 6, 20, 213382) He saw there certain charkhas and the students were also seen sitting by them, but it was all a mockery, a mere show.
('38', 90, 6, 21, 213500) Neither the teacher nor the students knew anything about spinning.
('38', 90, 6, 22, 213567) He had given proper instructions to the head master and he (the head master) had agreed to work according to that plan.
('38', 90, 6, 23, 213687) He hoped that they would send him a satisfactory report within a month.
('38', 90, 7, 24, 213759) Continuing, he said that the municipalities could do a good deal of work if they so desired.
('38', 90, 7, 25, 213852) They could push on the khaddar work to the great profit of not only the work but of themselves also.
('38', 90, 8, 26, 213953) A purse of Rs. 2,000 was then presented to him on which he remarked that Samastipur should not have contributed such a small amount.

('38', 97, 5, 18, 224082) 78. SPEECH AT NATIONAL SCHOOL, KHAMGAON
('38', 97, 6, 19, 224122) February 8, 1927 The reason why I have taken the trouble to carry out this examination 4 is that I have heard much praise of you, and what I am saying now is not to criticize you, but because I appreciate your effort and wish to help you.
('38', 97, 6, 20, 224361) I must inform you that I am not satisfied if this is the standard of the most brilliant boy of the school.
('38', 97, 6, 21, 224468) I am not satisfied either with his pronunciation or with the translation.
('38', 97, 6, 22, 224542) English pronunciations were also bad.
('38', 97, 6, 23, 224580) Only teachers who can teach correct pronunciation, whether of Sanskrit or English, should be employed.
('38', 97, 6, 24, 224683) If such teachers are not available, then we should stop teaching.
('38', 97, 6, 25, 224749) But we have forsaken satyagraha and so plan our work to please the people anyhow.
('38', 97, 6, 26, 224831) Let us follow truth in our system of education too.
('38', 97, 6, 27, 224883) I will now
('38', 98, 0, 1, 224894) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 99
('38', 98, 1, 2, 224936) suggest a little modification in your attitude to the charkha.
('38', 98, 2, 3, 224999) I see that the charkha has a place on your programme, but it is one out of the four or five things you teach here.
('38', 98, 2, 4, 225114) Now I want you to understand that the charkha has a place all its own, for reasons that should be obvious to you.
('38', 98, 2, 5, 225228) For charkha is not one of the professions that you teach.
('38', 98, 2, 6, 225286) A profession is for earning a livelihood, and if charkha was to be taught as a profession it should have no place on your syllabus.
('38', 98, 2, 7, 225418) But it has a special purpose.
('38', 98, 2, 8, 225448) When you put it in line with carpentry, clay modelling, etc., you are guilty of a confusion of thought.
('38', 98, 2, 9, 225552) Charkha is an instrument of service.
('38', 98, 2, 10, 225589) In a national school therefore where the nation expects us to train national servants, the scheme of studies will centre round the charkha.
('38', 98, 2, 11, 225729) It is a science in itself and it is a science which gives us a knowledge of the means of ameliorating the condition of the masses.
('38', 98, 2, 12, 225860) Devotion to a cause is no longer a strong point in our life.
('38', 98, 2, 13, 225921) A true brahmachari is one who is devoted to his ideal and single minded in his pursuit of the Brahman.
('38', 98, 2, 14, 226024) If you at all want to give a place to the charkha, then it ought to have a special place.
('38', 98, 2, 15, 226114) The distinctive quality of our national schools should be that we treat them as a great yajna and should train ourselves to run them accordingly.
('38', 98, 2, 16, 226260) You must always think how much the knowledge of English helps in the propagation of the charkha, what support the Gita gives to the charkha, and what improvement you can effect in it if you learn carpentry and smithy.
('38', 98, 3, 17, 226478) Do you know that we have not a national institution where mechanical engineering is taught and where good spindles are made?
('38', 98, 3, 18, 226603) If therefore you learn mechanics, concentrate on learning how to make a true spindle and how to mend a wrong one.
('38', 98, 3, 19, 226717) You should be able to tell the circumference of an ideal wheel, the distance between the axle and the poles, the number of revolutions of your spindle, etc.
('38', 98, 3, 20, 226874) A carpenter in a national school will not have as his ambition the making of an ideal cabinet, but of an ideal charkha.
('38', 98, 3, 21, 226994) In short, you should study the charkha scientifically and with religious zeal, i.e., with a view to making it the mightiest lever of the nation’s salvation.
('38', 98, 3, 22, 227151) Young India, 17 2 1927

('38', 99, 1, 2, 227277) 79. SPEECH ON UNTOUCHABILITY, KHAMGAON 1
('38', 99, 2, 3, 227318) February 8, 1927 If I could think of anything that is untouchable it is foreign clothes.
('38', 99, 2, 4, 227407) Anything that is prejudicial to the welfare of the nation is untouchable.
('38', 99, 2, 5, 227481) Anything that is calculated to do the nation a disservice is untouchable.
('38', 99, 2, 6, 227555) Liquor therefore is untouchable, foreign cloth is untouchable, but no human being is untouchable, and I regard it as fiendish or satanic to regard a fifth of the land as untouchable.
('38', 99, 2, 7, 227738) Young India, 17 2 1927
('38', 99, 3, 8, 227761) 80. SPEECH ON TILAK SWARAJ FUND, PACHORA
('38', 99, 4, 9, 227802) February 8, 1927
('38', 99, 5, 10, 227819) Mahatmaji addressed the meeting emphasizing the need for khaddar and the removal of untouchability.
('38', 99, 5, 11, 227919) Some questions were put to him and he answered them.
('38', 99, 5, 12, 227972) The important question was as to how the one crore of rupees collected for the Tilak Swaraj Fund had been spent.
('38', 99, 6, 13, 228085) In replying to this question at length, Mahatmaji invited the curious to study the audit accounts published by the All India Congress Committee.
('38', 99, 6, 14, 228230) Every pie had been properly accounted for.
('38', 99, 6, 15, 228273) Did they distrust the honesty of the treasurers like Seth Revashanker Jagjivan Zaveri and Seth Jamnalal Bajaj?
('38', 99, 6, 16, 228384) The fact was that some people had given their contributions specially earmarked for certain purposes and they were being spent for them.
('38', 99, 6, 17, 228521) For example, Seth Revashankerbhai had himself given Rs. 40,000 for educational purposes in Kathiawar.
('38', 99, 6, 18, 228623) A gentleman in Bombay had given two to three lakhs for the removal of untouchability and they were being properly used.
('38', 99, 6, 19, 228743) Both the treasurers as well as Mr. Shankerlal Banker, the Secretary of the All India Spinners’ Association, had given magnificent donations and it was not likely that they would be careless in the management of the funds.
('38', 99, 6, 20, 228965) Capable business man as every one of them was, he was, however, ready to admit that there were some losses in some cases, but the total could not in any case exceed Rs. 50,000. They were due to the inevitable risk that every business man has to face.
('38', 99, 6, 21, 229216) In Bihar, for instance, khadi was sold on credit to a number of people who had failed to satisfy the obligations.
('38', 99, 6, 22, 229330) In Andhra, good Konda Venkatappayya was imposed upon by certain people.
('38', 99, 6, 23, 229402) He had disbursed certain amounts, which could not be readily realized.
('38', 99, 6, 24, 229473) He had put undue trust in them and they had deceived him.
('38', 99, 6, 25, 229531) Everyone knew that he had not taken a single pie for himself.
('38', 99, 6, 26, 229593) Then there were cases of loss, which the greatest carefulness on one’s part does not always succeed in avoiding.
('38', 99, 6, 27, 229706) Recently Sjt.
('38', 99, 6, 28, 229720) Mahadev Desai, who had been in the service for ten years, now as a trusted “hamal” (coolie) lost Rs. 400 at
('38', 99, 7, 29, 229828) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('38', 100, 0, 1, 229867) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 101
('38', 100, 1, 2, 229910) Bhandara.
('38', 100, 1, 3, 229920) Could he ask him to repay the amount?
('38', 100, 1, 4, 229958) He was bound to enter it in the accounts as being lost, though Mahadev Desai himself was looking forward to make good the loss as soon as possible.
('38', 100, 2, 5, 230106) These things were bound to happen in the regular course of business and he would even warn the audience that on rare occasions there might be even frauds.
('38', 100, 2, 6, 230261) But, knowing all these things, if they thought that good work was being done, they might give whatever they could.
('38', 100, 2, 7, 230376) He for himself was bound to trust the workers, whom the people trusted.
('38', 100, 2, 8, 230448) Dastane, for instance, was their worker.
('38', 100, 2, 9, 230489) If he commanded their trust, why should Gandhiji distrust him?
('38', 100, 2, 10, 230552) Mahatmaji assured them that every pie would be credited and accounted for and every loss accurately shown.
('38', 100, 3, 11, 230659) Knowing all these things, if they wanted to subscribe to the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, which is the same as the Khaddar Fund, let them subscribe; and he assured them that whatever they gave would be carefully spent and accounted for in the best manner possible.
('38', 100, 3, 12, 230921) The Hindu, 12 2 1927
('38', 100, 4, 13, 230942) 81. BE IN TIME
('38', 100, 5, 14, 230957) The eventful month of April will be soon on us with its memories of the birth of the nation accompanied by unparalleled rejoicings in which lakhs upon lakhs of people took part and which showed the possibilities of what the nation, if it could only act with one mind, could do.
('38', 100, 5, 15, 231235) It is a month which showed also what haughty, revengeful and merciless Imperialism could do to save itself.
('38', 100, 5, 16, 231343) The 6th and the 13th of April 1 are never to be forgotten days in the life of the nation.
('38', 100, 5, 17, 231433) Since then the nation has been struggling not to return evil for evil, not to act in a spirit of retaliation, but to use for self purification the mingled crimson stream that flowed in Jallianwala.
('38', 100, 5, 18, 231631) The nation has been struggling to express itself in a non violent spirit expressed by the spinning wheel and khadi, the removal of untouchability and solidarity of the different sects and creeds.
('38', 100, 5, 19, 231827) It is clear, however, that khadi is the only thing in which the whole nation can take part.
('38', 100, 5, 20, 231919) If we want to act non violently, we must act constructively, patiently and with quiet and quenchless confidence in ourselves and in our method.
('38', 100, 5, 21, 232063) We must evolve unity, strength and iron discipline.
('38', 100, 5, 22, 232115) We must learn to give effect to our views in spite of the vast odds against us.
('38', 100, 5, 23, 232195) Let us realize that the British rule is imposed upon us because British commerce is forced upon us.
('38', 100, 5, 24, 232295) If we could but purify British commerce, we would purify the British connection.
('38', 100, 5, 25, 232376) Our commercial
('38', 101, 0, 1, 232391) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 101, 1, 2, 232433) transactions with the British as with the world should be on our terms and should therefore be mutually beneficial and absolutely voluntary.
('38', 101, 1, 3, 232574) But Lancashire cloth is a symbol of our helpless exploitation, whereas khadi is the symbol of self help, self reliance and freedom, not merely of individuals or groups, sects or clans, but of the whole nation.
('38', 101, 1, 4, 232784) It is a movement in which the prince and the pauper, men and women, boys and girls, Hindus and Mussalmans, Christians, Parsis and Jews, Englishmen, Americans and Japanese, if they wish well to India and get rid of the spirit of exploitation, can also take part.
('38', 101, 1, 5, 233046) Thus it is a unique movement.
('38', 101, 1, 6, 233076) It is good not merely for some, not merely for the vast majority, hut it is good for all.
('38', 101, 1, 7, 233166) We may do many other and many more things during the forthcoming National Week.
('38', 101, 1, 8, 233246) But let us at least organize khadi.
('38', 101, 1, 9, 233282) Here are the ways: 1. We can, every one of us, buy as much khadi as we can.
('38', 101, 1, 10, 233358) 2. We can sell as much khadi as we can.
('38', 101, 1, 11, 233398) 3. We can spin as much yarn as we can.
('38', 101, 1, 12, 233437) 4. We can give as much as we can to the All India Spinners’ Association and collect from others.
('38', 101, 1, 13, 233534) 5. Lastly, if we have the will and the opportunity, we can dedicate ourselves wholly to khadi work.
('38', 101, 1, 14, 233634) As I write this, the question arises in my own mind: ‘But what about the immediate present, what about the Bengal detenus who are pining away in their prison cells without any knowledge of charges against them, without any trial and without knowing how long they are to be detained?’ My answer however is quite clear.
('38', 101, 1, 15, 233952) If I could think of any other more expeditious method of setting them free, I would adopt it and suggest it today; but there is not.
('38', 101, 1, 16, 234085) Slow, as this may seem, it is, in my humble opinion, the surest and the quickest method.
('38', 101, 1, 17, 234174) Let those therefore who have belief in khadi or who have no belief in anything else, do their best bit during the National Week.
('38', 101, 1, 18, 234303) A true soldier does not argue as he marches how success is going to be ultimately achieved.
('38', 101, 1, 19, 234395) But he is confident that if he only plays his humble part well, somehow or other the battle will be won.
('38', 101, 1, 20, 234500) It is in that spirit that every one of us should act.
('38', 101, 1, 21, 234554) It is not given to us to know the future, But it is given to every one of us to know how to do our own part well.
('38', 101, 1, 22, 234668) Let us then do that which we know is possible for us if we only will.
('38', 101, 1, 23, 234738) Young India, 10 2 1927
('38', 102, 0, 1, 234761) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 103
('38', 102, 1, 2, 234804) 82. NATIONAL LANGUAGE
('38', 102, 2, 3, 234826) In reply to my innocent paragraph about the evil habit of using English at our public meetings, a habit happily growing less day by day, a correspondent writes: 1
('38', 102, 3, 4, 234989) The Hindu of 28th January quotes in extenso your article 2 in Young India suggesting that in your proposed tour to the Southern Presidency, any address that may be presented to you should be in the vernacular of the place.
('38', 102, 3, 5, 235212) You suggest also that a Hindi translation of the address should be supplied for your benefit.
('38', 102, 3, 6, 235306) I observe further that you think that the time has come when South India should dispense with English for large public meetings.
('38', 102, 3, 7, 235435) According to you, it is the English speaking leaders who are blocking the way to our rapid progress among the masses by their refusal to learn Hindi.
('38', 102, 3, 8, 235585) But the truth seems to be that, had it not been for this language, there would have been no active political life in India as we have it today.
('38', 102, 3, 9, 235729) .Just as you say it would be an insult to inflict English on an audience composed of colliery workmen, I contend that to inflict any other language but English on an audience composed of people collected from various parts of India will be an affront to the latter.
('38', 102, 3, 10, 235995) You will remember that the President 3 of this year’s Congress was in the first instance called upon to speak in Hindi.
('38', 102, 3, 11, 236115) It was only his rare courage and his rarer wit that saved him from what looked to be a very embarrassing situation.
('38', 102, 3, 12, 236231) Supposing the President addressed that body in his own vernacular, how many in the audience would have understood him?
('38', 102, 3, 13, 236350) Or for the matter of that, how many of the delegates assembled would have sat through the whole speech?
('38', 102, 3, 14, 236454) So long therefore as a common Indian language suitable to India and Burma is not agreed upon, English is bound to be and will be the only medium of communication among the Indian people.
('38', 102, 3, 15, 236641) Instead of therefore setting your face against the use of the English language, and until such time as a common language is evolved for India, a man situated in your position should not add to the existing difficulties of the people by calling upon them to learn altogether a different language.
('38', 102, 3, 16, 236937) You remark in your article that it would be difficult to approach the masses if English is used as the medium.
('38', 102, 3, 17, 237048) I quite agree with you there.
('38', 102, 3, 18, 237078) But the masses should in the first instance be approached by people belonging to themselves and who live in their midst.
('38', 102, 3, 19, 237199) It is, of course, understood that when approaching them their own language will be used.
('38', 102, 4, 20, 237288) I publish the letter because it reflects an attitude with which one
('38', 102, 5, 21, 237356) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('38', 102, 5, 22, 237393) 2 Vide “Hindi v.
('38', 102, 5, 23, 237410) English”, 20 1 1927.
('38', 102, 6, 24, 237431) 3 S. Srinivasa Iyengar
('38', 103, 0, 1, 237454) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 103, 1, 2, 237496) has to reckon.
('38', 103, 1, 3, 237511) The correspondent in his eagerness to defend his own laziness, for it is difficult otherwise to characterize his mentality, has missed the following fundamental facts: English is known hardly to one per cent of the population.
('38', 103, 1, 4, 237738) It will never be learnt by the masses and we have to reckon daily more and more with the masses in all our political transactions The Congress every year has delegates and visitors the majority of whom do not know and understand English, and when it becomes a thoroughly democratic body, whose delegates are scavengers, cobblers, farmers, washermen, tailors and such others, there will be very few to know English.
('38', 103, 1, 5, 238153) As against hardly one per cent of the total population knowing English, over 60 per cent of the total population of India at the present moment understand the ordinary rustic Hindustani.
('38', 103, 1, 6, 238340) For an Indian it is any day infinitely easier to learn Hindustani than English.
('38', 103, 1, 7, 238420) These are the facts, but the correspondent has overlooked them.
('38', 103, 1, 8, 238484) Moreover, in his zeal to make English the official language of the Congress, the correspondent has forgotten the agitation that has been going on in the Congress ever since its inception for a wider recognition of Hindustani as the common medium and that there is now already a resolution of the Congress making Hindustani the common medium.
('38', 103, 1, 9, 238826) The correspondent seems to think that I decry the use of even learning English, which I have never done.
('38', 103, 1, 10, 238931) That the English speaking Indians have rendered immense service to the country nobody can deny, but unfortunately it is equally undeniable that further progress is being blocked by us English speaking Indians refusing to learn the language of the masses and to work amongst them in accordance with methods best suited to them.
('38', 103, 1, 11, 239258) The instance given by the correspondent of Mr. Chen is beside the point.
('38', 103, 1, 12, 239331) I do not know what he is doing, but I do know that he is not speaking to the Chinese masses through English.
('38', 103, 1, 13, 239440) And all I have claimed is that at our mixed mass meetings where the language of the province will not be understood by all, if any other language is to be adopted, it must be Hindustani.
('38', 103, 1, 14, 239627) Surely, it is a proposition which does not admit of any challenge.
('38', 103, 1, 15, 239694) Young India, 10 2 1927

('38', 106, 5, 19, 245671) He has asked for 50 Bengali maunds presuming that transport charges up to Raxaul will be the same for 50 maunds as for 25. If it is so it appears advisable to send 50 maunds.
('38', 106, 5, 20, 245846) Now if I have left anything unsaid you should do as you think fit.

('38', 107, 6, 9, 246377) One of the special features of the tour was the auctioning of the caskets containing addresses at the meetings where they were given.
('38', 107, 6, 10, 246511) The beginning was made at Jalgaon and the process was continued until Dhulia.
('38', 107, 6, 11, 246589) Gandhiji said: You must know, friends, that excepting things which have a special artistic value and which I can hand over to Prof.
('38', 107, 6, 12, 246721) Malkani 2 who is collecting such things at the Gujarat Vidyapith, I cannot afford to carry these caskets with me.
('38', 107, 6, 13, 246835) For one thing I carry no steel trunks with me, nor have I any provision at the Ashram to keep them.

('38', 107, 6, 16, 247108) On the contrary, I propose to return the love in the best manner I can, and that is by converting the caskets into money for the work which is nearest my heart and for which you are showering your love on me.

('38', 109, 4, 6, 249395) 89. SPEECH ON KHADI, AMALNER 1
('38', 109, 5, 7, 249426) February 12, 1927
('38', 109, 6, 8, 249444) At Amalner for instance a doubt was expressed as to the utility of carrying the message of khaddar to a mill area like that place.
('38', 109, 6, 9, 249575) “There are 2,000 labourers here and they form the bulk of the population.
('38', 109, 6, 10, 249649) Do you expect them to wear khadi?
('38', 109, 6, 11, 249683) Do you expect the mill owners to wear khadi?”
('38', 109, 7, 12, 249729) Gandhiji gave a lengthy reply.
('38', 109, 7, 13, 249760) It is a question that you may well ask, and yet should not need to ask at this time of the day.
('38', 109, 7, 14, 249856) Truth has to be repeated a million times if it is not understood by all.
('38', 109, 7, 15, 249929) If only a single expression of truth was sufficient everyone should have been a believer in God by now.
('38', 109, 7, 16, 250033) The fact is that the truth that God is one has a million times been told, but the hearts of only a few have been able to receive it.
('38', 109, 7, 17, 250166) The 330 rupees that the labourers have contributed to the purse are for me worth their weight in gold.
('38', 109, 7, 18, 250269) But it is not for the first time that labourers are giving concrete expression to their sympathy.
('38', 109, 7, 19, 250367) Even the mill owners have done so and will do so in the conviction that they are helping a good cause, and the labourers are doing so because of their sympathy for a fellow labourer like myself.
('38', 109, 7, 20, 250562) But an understanding of one’s duty and the observance thereof are different things.
('38', 109, 7, 21, 250646) If they went together we should have Ramarajya.
('38', 109, 7, 22, 250694) There are for instance those who know the value of brahmacharya but who cannot observe it.
('38', 109, 7, 23, 250785) Even so there are those who appreciate the message of khadi but who are not able to conquer their love of ease and comfort and exclusively wear khadi.
('38', 109, 7, 24, 250936) Many come and tell me: ‘We value your message, but show us the way to carry it out.’ And as honest conviction is bound to be followed by practice sooner or later this attitude fills me with more hope.
('38', 109, 7, 25, 251137) You may be employing 2,000 labourers here but do not forget that you tear them from the soil, do
('38', 109, 8, 26, 251234) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('38', 110, 0, 1, 251273) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 111
('38', 110, 1, 2, 251316) not forget that your mills can provide only a handful with labour, and can never find employment for the millions who must be rooted to the soil and who want more work.
('38', 110, 1, 3, 251485) The question has been before the Royal Commission of Agriculture, the question is before the Viceroy and I challenge any one to find a better solution than the one I have placed before the country.
('38', 110, 1, 4, 251683) Dr. Roy 1 could not carry his chemical works to the famine areas in Bogra and Khulna; he had to fall back on the spinn ing wheels.
('38', 110, 1, 5, 251814) Let not your ambition be to concentrate thousands of spindles in a mill, but to convert every home into a spinning mill.
('38', 110, 1, 6, 251935) ‘Do I seek to destroy the mill industry?’ I have often been asked.
('38', 110, 1, 7, 252002) If I did I should not have pressed for the abolition of the excise duty.
('38', 110, 1, 8, 252075) I want the mill industry to prosper—only I do not want it to prosper at the expense of the country.
('38', 110, 1, 9, 252175) On the contrary if the interests of the country demand that the industry should go, I should let it go without the slightest compunction.
('38', 110, 1, 10, 252313) The mill owners who support me understand my attitude and many want this movement to prosper, even if its prosperity should mean their loss.
('38', 110, 1, 11, 252454) And you ask how those who produce mill cloth may wear anything else.
('38', 110, 1, 12, 252523) Do you know that in Manchester the manufacturers do not wear their own products?
('38', 110, 1, 13, 252604) You need not mind your inability to use cloth produced by your own mills.
('38', 110, 1, 14, 252678) The good Duchess of Sutherland saw the miserable plight of the poor islanders of Hebrides and placed spinning wheels and looms at their disposal.
('38', 110, 1, 15, 252824) The citizens of Man chester, including mill owners, do wear the hand spun stuffs prepared by the Hebrides people, even at three times the cost of the mill stuff.
('38', 110, 1, 16, 252986) Do not hanker after cheapness and fineness.
('38', 110, 1, 17, 253030) If you want cheap and fine stuffs you must spin fine yarn as the late Jogesh Chatterji did or you must spend more money for it.
('38', 110, 1, 18, 253158) Those who talk of swaraj can not have both cheapness and fineness.
('38', 110, 1, 19, 253225) Think of the sacrifices all fighters have to make.
('38', 110, 1, 20, 253276) In Queen Elizabeth’s time heavy duties were imposed on foreign stuffs and heavy penalties were prescribed for the purchase of Holland laces.
('38', 110, 1, 21, 253417) Am I asking for much when I ask you to remember your poor and to purchase their khadi?
('38', 110, 1, 22, 253504) Do not say you will maintain the poor on charity.
('38', 110, 1, 23, 253554) Only two classes of people are entitled to charity and no one else—the Brahmin who possesses not hing and whose business it is to spread holy learning, and the cripple

('38', 113, 3, 9, 256905) 92. LETTER TO B. F. MADON
('38', 113, 4, 10, 256931) DHULIA, February 13, 1927
('38', 113, 5, 11, 256957) DEAR FRIEND, I have your illuminating letter.
('38', 113, 5, 12, 257003) Everything coming from you commands my attention because I like your straightforward and popular exposition of a subject which has been [made] unnecessarily abstruse by economists.
('38', 113, 5, 13, 257184) I am taking the liberty in anticipation of your permission of sending your letter to Prof.
('38', 113, 5, 14, 257275) Wadia so that he may understand and appreciate your viewpoint.
('38', 113, 5, 15, 257338) I would love to constitute myself a bridge over the gulf that, without cause as it seems to me, separates economists and that makes it difficult for a layman to study this very important subject.
('38', 113, 5, 16, 257534) If all the principal economists of our country will agree on the fundamentals and issue a brief, reasoned joint statement, it will prove very useful to students like me who have opportunities of educating the popular mind.
('38', 113, 5, 17, 257757) What is this thunderbolt that Mr. Shroff has hurled in our midst?
('38', 113, 5, 18, 257823) It is occasionally that I get a peep at the newspapers.
('38', 113, 5, 19, 257879) Whenever there fore you get a moment and have anything to pass on to a busy man like me, please do not hesitate.
('38', 113, 5, 20, 257992) For, though I am saying nothing in the Press, I am watching everything with an absolutely open mind.

('38', 116, 4, 16, 262293) 96. SPEECHES AT DHULIA 1
('38', 116, 5, 17, 262318) February 13, 1927
('38', 116, 6, 18, 262336) The programme at Dhulia was heavy, but everything was so ordered and quiet that Gandhiji could address six meetings during the day, spinning on his charkha throughout the speeches!
('38', 116, 6, 19, 262517) He said: You will not regard me as impertinent if I go on spinning whilst I address you.
('38', 116, 6, 20, 262606) I do so because of the wonderful stillness here, and because I think I can best respond to your affection by giving you an object lesson in the thing I most believe in.

('38', 117, 3, 10, 263601) During my wanderings throughout the land I have not yet come across a single local body which has been fanctioning of its own independent initiative and which I could point to as an ideal body.
('38', 117, 3, 11, 263795) Mr. Lionel Curtis remarking on the contrast between an Indian village and an English village said that whereas the one gives you an impression of general untidiness and reminds you of a village built on a dunghill, the other gives an impression of cleanliness and health and beauty all around.
('38', 117, 3, 12, 264089) Of course he knew nothing of the condition of the Indian villager, he did not know that his daily income was five per cent of that of the English villager.
('38', 117, 3, 13, 264245) But let us not ignore one substratum truth in his remark.
('38', 117, 3, 14, 264303) There is no gainsaying the fact that our villager betrays a woeful ignorance of even the rudiments of village sanitation.
('38', 117, 3, 15, 264425) One could deplore the race prejudice amongst the South African Europeans, but their attempts to keep their towns healthy and sanitary were heroic and worthy of imitation.

('38', 117, 3, 17, 264686) It is a lame excuse.
('38', 117, 3, 18, 264707) The capacity to look after the village and town sanitation is included in our capacity for swaraj and when we demonstrate it, nothing on earth can stand between us and swaraj.
('38', 117, 3, 19, 264883) You may be sure that we shall be able to retain only as much as our capacity has won for us.
('38', 117, 3, 20, 264976) Some of our local bodies keep only those roads clean as are likely to be used by Government officials, but they have no regard for the roads which are used day and night by poor villagers and their bullocks, and which are always and everywhere ill kept.

('38', 117, 4, 23, 265529) And in his reply they got more than they had bargained for.

('38', 118, 1, 2, 265632) As I said at Jalpaiguri in 1925 1, it is not the Brahmins, nor the Kshatriyas nor the Sudras that lost India; it is the Vaisyas who lost India, and it is the Vaisyas alone who can regain it.
('38', 118, 1, 3, 265823) Indian history is replete with instances of Banias who helped and served the English shopkeeper to the prejudice of India.

('38', 130, 4, 9, 285321) 111. SPEECH AT NASIK 1
('38', 130, 5, 10, 285344) February 16, 1927 Some youths handed over to me several questions as soon as I arrived here; my replies to them will be my speech today.
('38', 130, 6, 11, 285481) [1.] Don’t you think as a Hindu you should concentrate on collecting for the Shraddhanand Fund rather than for any other fund?
('38', 130, 6, 12, 285608) I am an imperfect mortal and my capacities are limited.
('38', 130, 6, 13, 285664) I know the theory and practice of economy, and whilst all my time and energy are given to the country, I am not vain enough to think that I should do all things myself.
('38', 130, 6, 14, 285833) The work you refer to is engaging the attention and energies of men like Malaviyaji and Lalaji and there is no reason why I should also put in my oar.
('38', 130, 6, 15, 285984) At the first meeting held in Calcutta 2 to collect funds for raising a fitting memorial to Shradd hanandji, I was asked to be present by Pandit Malaviyaji and I did so.
('38', 130, 6, 16, 286153) I do not think he expects more from me.
('38', 130, 6, 17, 286193) I claim to follow in daily life the teachings of the Gita and I know that, humble as is the work that I am doing, it is better for me than much other work which may be quite as good and even better but which is not my work.
('38', 130, 7, 18, 286417) [2.] The collections you make today are only for khadi, are they not so?
('38', 130, 7, 19, 286490) If they are, how will you utilize them?
('38', 130, 7, 20, 286530) Yes, of course, this fund is only for khadi because it is being collected for the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('38', 130, 8, 21, 286648) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('38', 130, 8, 22, 286688) The introductory paragraph, questions 2, 5 and 6, and their answers are from Navajivan, 27 2 1927.
('38', 130, 9, 23, 286787) 2 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Calcutta”, 31 12 1926.
('38', 131, 0, 1, 286844) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 131, 1, 2, 286886) Deshbandhu’s name has been associated with this fund because hehad drawn up, a few days before his death, a scheme for the organization of villages through khadi.
('38', 131, 1, 3, 287049) Khadi work was dear to him.
('38', 131, 1, 4, 287077) The All India Spinners’ Association has been set up only to collect funds for khadi and use them to organize work.
('38', 131, 1, 5, 287192) Accounts of its funds are being maintained to a pie and everyone has a right to inspect them.
('38', 131, 1, 6, 287286) The Association has an executive committee, auditors and inspectors.
('38', 131, 1, 7, 287355) This Association has now placed before the country a scheme for an organization of khadi service.
('38', 131, 1, 8, 287453) You will ask what effective work this association can do, paying as it will be only thirty rupees a month to each worker.
('38', 131, 1, 9, 287575) Of course, ours is a poor Association, for it has been established with money collected from the poorest of the poor.
('38', 131, 1, 10, 287693) It is not another Indian Civil Service, so that it can afford to pay salaries of thousands of rupees.
('38', 131, 1, 11, 287795) The Indian Civil Service is maintained with taxes paid by the people and is meant to rule the people; our poor little association is meant to serve them.
('38', 131, 2, 12, 287949) [3.] Are you partial to the Mussalmans?
('38', 131, 2, 13, 287989) Why don’t you answer the charges some of the Mussalman leaders level against you?
('38', 131, 2, 14, 288071) I can do justice to people of other faiths by appearing to be partial to them, and I know that I am protecting my own faith by showing if you will a reasoned partiality for other faiths.
('38', 131, 2, 15, 288258) I do not, I cannot, wish to harm the Hindu religion, for I am after all a drop in the ocean of Hinduism.
('38', 131, 2, 16, 288363) If Mussalmans call me kaffir, what then?
('38', 131, 2, 17, 288404) What can be the answer to it?
('38', 131, 2, 18, 288434) In South Africa, a nephew of mine was staying with me.
('38', 131, 2, 19, 288489) It was only when people said that I was partial to him that he realized, and I realized, that I was only just to him.
('38', 131, 2, 20, 288607) The fact that the Mussalmans are finding fault with me possibly suggests that I am not yet sufficiently partial to them to convince them that I am just to them.
('38', 131, 2, 21, 288768) Why should I answer their charges?
('38', 131, 2, 22, 288803) All my twenty four hours are consecrated to the service of Lord Krishna who is ever with me, who guides my footsteps, and whom I always pray to do whatever is needed for me.
('38', 131, 2, 23, 288977) He will answer for me, if there be any need.
('38', 131, 3, 24, 289022) [4.] If you fought for the Khilafat, why do you not fight for the Hindu sangathan 1 today?
('38', 131, 3, 25, 289113) The question is well asked.
('38', 131, 3, 26, 289141) I had pledged myself to lay down my life for the Khilafat and I knew that I was indirectly helping thereby the cause of the cow.
('38', 131, 3, 27, 289270) ‘How much cow protection have you
('38', 131, 4, 28, 289304) 1 Movement for unity
('38', 132, 0, 1, 289325) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 133
('38', 132, 1, 2, 289368) achieved?’—you will ask.
('38', 132, 1, 3, 289393) Very little, I admit.
('38', 132, 1, 4, 289415) But what does that matter to me?
('38', 132, 1, 5, 289448) “To work you have the right and duty and not to fruit thereof,” says the Gita.
('38', 132, 1, 6, 289527) 1 It was at the bidding of the Lord that I offered my co operation to the Ali Brothers and rendered whatever help I could.
('38', 132, 1, 7, 289650) I have never had reason to regret it.
('38', 132, 1, 8, 289688) I would do the same thing should another occasion arise.
('38', 132, 1, 9, 289745) That is the teaching of all our religious books.
('38', 132, 1, 10, 289794) Let the people rail at me, insult me if they like.
('38', 132, 1, 11, 289845) I am not going to pay them back in their coin.
('38', 132, 1, 12, 289892) Mine is the religion of tapascharya, the way of penance taught by the scriptures and by Tulsidas.
('38', 132, 1, 13, 289990) That is the law of my being and I cannot do otherwise.
('38', 132, 1, 14, 290045) “The whole creation,” says the Gita, “follows the law of its being.
('38', 132, 1, 15, 290113) How will restraint then avail?” 2 My joy is in the fulfilment of my duty and the confidence that when some day the Mussalmans join hands with the Hindus in protecting the cow, everyone will say that the good result is due to the efforts of that mad Gandhi who died working for the cause.
('38', 132, 1, 16, 290401) In my opinion, there is no sanction in Hinduism, Islam or Christianity for the shuddhi, tabligh or proselytizing (respectively) as it is going on today.
('38', 132, 1, 17, 290554) How then can I take part in the shuddhi?
('38', 132, 1, 18, 290595) The Gita and the Tulsi Ramayana teach me to resort to self purification whenever I or my religion is in danger.
('38', 132, 1, 19, 290707) And what is true for me is true for all.
('38', 132, 1, 20, 290748) That process of self purification I am going through all the twenty four hours of my day.
('38', 132, 1, 21, 290838) Parvati, Narada had foretold, would have an ominous looking husband.
('38', 132, 1, 22, 290907) She knew that only Siva was as blissful as he was ominous looking and she performed penance for winning Siva and won him.
('38', 132, 1, 23, 291029) So the lesson of penance and self purifi cation is writ large everywhere in our scriptures and the Himalayas are the living witness to it—the Himalayas where countless rishis ground their bodies to dust for self purification The Vedas, to me, are not the texts writ on paper, but my very conscience and the In dweller.
('38', 132, 1, 24, 291348) They tell me to observe yama and niyama (the cardinal and the causal virtues) and trust everything to Lord Krishna.
('38', 132, 1, 25, 291464) In all humility I claim that all my work is conducive to the service of Hinduism.
('38', 132, 1, 26, 291546) As a Hindu, I could do nothing else.
('38', 132, 1, 27, 291583) The way of doing it is of course my own.
('38', 132, 2, 28, 291624) [5.] Do you know that most of the donors of the money that will be presented to you today are dealers in foreign cloth, and they give you money for the love they bear you, not for the love of khadi?
('38', 132, 3, 29, 291823) 47 2 III.
('38', 133, 0, 1, 291833) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 133, 1, 2, 291875) I do not want a single pice offered through love for me; I want people to appreciate my mission and help it with money.
('38', 133, 1, 3, 291995) Through love you can give me another thing.
('38', 133, 1, 4, 292039) Through it you can give me your foreign clothes, but not money.
('38', 133, 1, 5, 292103) The truth is that business men give me money in the belief that, if my business thrives, it will harm neither them nor the country.
('38', 133, 1, 6, 292235) They know that ultimately they will have to deal in khadi.
('38', 133, 1, 7, 292294) They understand the position correctly but today they lack strength of will.
('38', 133, 1, 8, 292371) They ask me to pray to God that He may grant them that strength.
('38', 133, 1, 9, 292436) Meanwhile, they donate money and help this movement.
('38', 133, 1, 10, 292489) They do not give me money in order to deceive me.
('38', 133, 2, 11, 292539) [6.] Why do you confine yourself to khadi work alone and neglect other important or even more important political activities?
('38', 133, 2, 12, 292665) I have already said that the sphere of my work is limited.
('38', 133, 2, 13, 292724) Duryodhana described how his warriors had taken up their due positions on the battle field.
('38', 133, 2, 14, 292816) He had asked everyone to remain in his place and protect Bhishma.
('38', 133, 2, 15, 292882) The varnashrama dharma taught in the Gita also says the same thing.
('38', 133, 2, 16, 292950) It asks everyone to know his own sphere of work.
('38', 133, 2, 17, 292999) If India wants me to serve it, it must understand my limita tions.
('38', 133, 2, 18, 293066) Although it is possible that 1 can do other jobs well, there are people doing them.
('38', 133, 2, 19, 293150) As I believe that no one else can do khadi work as well as I can and since I regard khadi work as my supreme duty, I have confined myself to that work.
('38', 133, 2, 20, 293302) I favour satyagraha, I want to start it, but I want to create a suitable atmosphere for it through khadi.
('38', 133, 2, 21, 293408) Satyagraha is like my very breath, but I regard it as impossible without khadi.
('38', 133, 3, 22, 293488) [7.] What is the extent of the help you are getting from the Mussalmans during this tour?
('38', 133, 3, 23, 293578) I admit that for my khadi work I have been having not much help from them.
('38', 133, 3, 24, 293653) But what does that matter?
('38', 133, 3, 25, 293680) I do not bargain with my brother or wife in my domestic affairs.
('38', 133, 3, 26, 293745) I do my duty and leave the rest to do theirs.
('38', 133, 3, 27, 293791) In the same way I will not bargain with the Mussalmans, as I will not with Pandit Motilalji or Kelkar.
('38', 133, 3, 28, 293894) Why should we fear the Mussalmans?
('38', 133, 3, 29, 293929) We need fear only God and no man.
('38', 133, 3, 30, 293963) Even if men should play you false, do not be deterred from doing your duty, in the confidence that God will take care of you.
('38', 133, 4, 31, 294089) Young India, 3 3 1927
