('38', 134, 7, 18, 295132) 113. OUT OF NOTHING
('38', 134, 8, 19, 295152) When one thinks of the immense possibility of the charkha it is surprising that its simple message is taking so long to become universal.
('38', 134, 8, 20, 295290) “Nothing comes out of nothing,” says a Latin proverb.
('38', 134, 8, 21, 295344) But the charkha would seem to falsify at least the letter of the proverb.
('38', 134, 8, 22, 295418) For without destroying or replacing anything useful, it seeks to utilize the waste and idle hours of the nation.
('38', 134, 8, 23, 295531) This idleness, whether it be regarded as enforced or voluntary, is
('38', 134, 9, 24, 295598) 1 From the tour programme
('38', 135, 0, 1, 295624) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 135, 1, 2, 295666) killing the very soul of the nation.
('38', 135, 1, 3, 295703) The more I penetrate the villages, the greater is the shock delivered as I perceive the blank stare in the eyes of the villagers I meet.
('38', 135, 1, 4, 295840) Having nothing else to do but to work as labourers side by side with their bullocks, they have become almost like them.
('38', 135, 1, 5, 295960) It is a tragedy of the first magnitude that millions have ceased to use their hands as hands.
('38', 135, 1, 6, 296054) Nature is revenging herself upon us with terrible effect for this criminal waste of the gift she has bestowed upon us human beings.
('38', 135, 1, 7, 296186) We refuse to make full use of the gift.
('38', 135, 1, 8, 296226) And it is the exquisite mechanism of the hands that among a few other things separates us from the beast.
('38', 135, 1, 9, 296332) Millions of us use them merely as feet.
('38', 135, 1, 10, 296372) The result is that she starves both the body and the mind.
('38', 135, 1, 11, 296431) The spinning wheel alone can stop this reckless waste.
('38', 135, 1, 12, 296486) It can do that now and without any extraordinary outlay of money or intelli gence.
('38', 135, 1, 13, 296569) Owing to this waste, we are living in a state almost of suspended animation.
('38', 135, 1, 14, 296646) It can be revived if only every home is again turned into a spinning mill and every village into a weaving mill.
('38', 135, 1, 15, 296759) With it will at once revive the ancient rustic art and the rustic song.
('38', 135, 1, 16, 296831) A semi starved nation can have neither religion nor art nor organization.
('38', 135, 1, 17, 296905) The only objection that has been urged by its critics is that the wheel does not pay.
('38', 135, 1, 18, 296991) But even if it pays only one pice per day, it does pay when we remember that our average income is six pice per day against the fourteen rupees and six rupees per day respectively of the average American and the average Englishman.
('38', 135, 1, 19, 297223) The spinning wheel is an attempt to produce something out of nothing.
('38', 135, 1, 20, 297293) If we save sixty crores of rupees to the nation through the spinning wheel, as we certainly can, we add that vast amount to the national income.
('38', 135, 1, 21, 297438) In the process we automatically organize our villages.
('38', 135, 1, 22, 297493) And as almost the whole of the amount must be distributed amongst the poorest of the land, it becomes a scheme of just and nearly equal distribution of so much wealth.
('38', 135, 1, 23, 297661) Add to this the immense moral value of such distribution, and the case for the charkha becomes irresistible.
('38', 135, 1, 24, 297770) Young India, 17 2 1927
('38', 135, 2, 25, 297793) 114. A GREAT SPINNER
('38', 135, 3, 26, 297814) When at the end of the Bihar tour and on my way to the Central Provinces, I heard at Calcutta of the death of Babu Jogeshwar Chatter jee whom I had the privilege of knowing as a spinner who gave
('38', 136, 0, 1, 298009) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 137
('38', 136, 1, 2, 298052) promise of being able to revive the old Dacca shubnum—the night dew muslin—I at once sent a message 1 to Kshitish Babu of Khadi Pratishthan to supply me with details of the deceased’s life.
('38', 136, 1, 3, 298242) These have been now received and I share them with the reader: 2
('38', 136, 2, 4, 298307) Jogeshwar Chatterjee, son of Sjt.
('38', 136, 2, 5, 298341) Jatileshwar Chatterjee of village Panpur in the district of 24 Parganas .
('38', 136, 2, 6, 298415) died on Sunday, the 30th January morning.
('38', 136, 2, 7, 298457) He left behind him his wife, a daughter aged one year, a younger brother and aged father.
('38', 136, 3, 8, 298547) Jogeshwar Babu read up to B.A., and was a teacher for some time.
('38', 136, 3, 9, 298612) He then took service in the E.B.R., and served it for seven years.
('38', 136, 3, 10, 298679) He was aged 35 at the time of death.
('38', 136, 4, 11, 298716) He took to spinning during the Non co operation days, and was an ardent spinner.
('38', 136, 4, 12, 298797) At the Gauhati Exhibition a muslin of 200 counts was exhibited by the Pratishthan, the yarn of which was spun by Jogeshwar Babu.
('38', 136, 4, 13, 298926) During one year—Cawnpore Exhibition to Gauhati Exhibition—he spun 200 count yarn for the above muslin, and sufficient yarn of 100 count, out of which two dhotis are made.
('38', 136, 4, 14, 299097) Of the last two dhotis, one was for Acharya P. C. Ray and the other for his father.
('38', 136, 5, 15, 299181) He was all along spinning on the Pratishthan’s box charkha.
('38', 136, 5, 16, 299241) He was out and out a khadi man, who used to spin during leisure hours, and made such a rapid progress in spinning.
('38', 136, 5, 17, 299356) I tender my condolences to the family of the deceased and hope that the attempt to reproduce the ancient art will not die with Jogesh Babu’s death.
('38', 136, 5, 18, 299504) Let it be remembered that Jogesh Babu’s was a labour of patriotic love.
('38', 136, 5, 19, 299576) And it is only voluntary spinners who can follow up Jogesh Babu’s grand effort.
('38', 136, 6, 20, 299656) Young India, 17 2 1927

('38', 138, 1, 2, 300683) 117. SPEECH AT AHMEDNAGAR 1
('38', 138, 2, 3, 300711) February 18, 1927 I have just been to the Rashtriya Pathshala.
('38', 138, 2, 4, 300774) I have inspected for nearly an hour like a strict inspector all the management and working of the institution and found it to my satisfaction.
('38', 138, 2, 5, 300917) I have thoroughly examined the boys in a lively heart to heart talk and found them sharp in intellect and prompt in answers.
('38', 138, 2, 6, 301042) In short, I see in Ahmed nagar Rashtriya Pathshala a lovely little oasis in the midst of such a vast desert of darkness.
('38', 138, 3, 7, 301163) [Continuing,] Mr. Gandhi said that, if Ahmednagar district was poor, the rest of India was poorer still.
('38', 138, 3, 8, 301268) Hundreds of thousands of men and women were without any kind of employment and almost starving.
('38', 138, 3, 9, 301364) He had not the slightest doubt in his mind that khadi work alone could give these people some employment and bread.
('38', 138, 3, 10, 301480) He appealed to all present to give their mite to him for his great work.
('38', 138, 3, 11, 301553) The Hindu, 19 2 1927

('38', 140, 6, 9, 304176) 122. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA [After February 19, 1927] 1
('38', 140, 7, 10, 304243) DEAR SATIS BABU, I have your pathetic letter which I see you wrote to lighten your burden.
('38', 140, 7, 11, 304334) Gods, it is said, take away those they love most.
('38', 140, 7, 12, 304384) The human mind has devised many methods of assuaging grief.
('38', 140, 7, 13, 304444) But the real fact is not to feel the grief.
('38', 140, 7, 14, 304488) But that is almost superhuman especially in Hindu society.
('38', 140, 7, 15, 304547) Please tell Hemaprabha Devi not to think of what Anil would have done, if he had lived.
('38', 140, 7, 16, 304635) His work in that body was finished.
('38', 140, 7, 17, 304671) A rare soul such as Anil’s had much higher work to do and he left the body.
('38', 140, 7, 18, 304747) Let us not grieve over our loss which may be the world’s gain.
('38', 140, 7, 19, 304810) It is as well that we do not know the mysteries of life and death.
('38', 140, 7, 20, 304877) I want you both now to get rid of your weakness.
('38', 140, 7, 21, 304926) Pray do not think of stirring till you have fully recuperated yourself.
('38', 140, 7, 22, 304998) With love,
('38', 140, 8, 23, 305009) Yours, BAPU

('38', 142, 5, 11, 307139) 126. SPEECH AT SHOLAPUR 2
('38', 142, 6, 12, 307165) February 20, 1927
('38', 142, 7, 13, 307183) As at Nasik, 3 the speech at Sholapur was a reply to questions and criticisms made in an open letter addressed to Gandhiji by some people from the town.
('38', 142, 7, 14, 307336) Their first criticism was that those who appeared in khadi on the occasion of Gandhiji’s visit were hypocrites inasmuch as they would shelve it the day he left.
('38', 142, 7, 15, 307497) Did that indicate the progress of khadi?
('38', 142, 7, 16, 307538) Gandhiji said: Well, I do not know.
('38', 142, 7, 17, 307574) I know that I am selling khadi wherever I go, and there ends my work.
('38', 142, 7, 18, 307644) Supposing you purchase from me millions of rupees worth of khadi and sink it into the sea, the sale is not vitiated.
('38', 142, 7, 19, 307761) But the criticism is unfair.
('38', 142, 7, 20, 307790) I know that some wear khadi for the occasion, but they do not disguise the fact.
('38', 142, 7, 21, 307871) They appreciate the message of khadi, but they say they cannot exclusively wear it for a number of reasons.
('38', 142, 7, 22, 307979) Am I to tell them, ‘You are no good.
('38', 142, 7, 23, 308016) I can do without your khadi?’ No, no.
('38', 142, 7, 24, 308054) My duty is to define our dharma in its fulness.
('38', 142, 7, 25, 308102) Their duty is to follow it as much as they can.
('38', 142, 7, 26, 308150) People deceive me, you say.
('38', 142, 7, 27, 308178) I do not understand how they can harm me even if they do.
('38', 142, 7, 28, 308236) I am but a self appointed agent of Daridranarayana and I shall take from you only what you can give me.
('38', 142, 8, 29, 308340) 1 Written by Mahadev Desai to Gandhiji’s dictation 2 This was published under the title, “Two Speeches”.
('38', 142, 8, 30, 308445) 3 Vide “Speech at Nasik”, 16 2 1927.
('38', 143, 0, 1, 308482) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 143, 1, 2, 308524) “You are good enough,” they say, “but your work has ruined the country.” I am but an erring mortal and like any one of you I am full of shortcomings; therefore I beseech you to reject them and simply make the best of my capacity for service.
('38', 143, 1, 3, 308766) Turn my good points to account and reject the bad ones.
('38', 143, 1, 4, 308822) If you do not pick and choose and simply reject me wholesale, what will the world say to you?
('38', 143, 1, 5, 308916) Will you regret the service of a man as a carrier because he is blind?
('38', 143, 1, 6, 308987) As I said at Nasik, I fail to understand the shuddhi, tabligh and proselytization as they are carried on today.
('38', 143, 1, 7, 309099) I cannot understand a man changing the religion of his forefathers at the instance of another.
('38', 143, 1, 8, 309194) But that is my personal conviction.
('38', 143, 1, 9, 309230) No one need stop shuddhi, tabligh or proselytization at my instance.
('38', 143, 1, 10, 309299) My own duty is clear.
('38', 143, 1, 11, 309321) I must go on purifying myself and hoping that only thereby would I react on my surroundings.
('38', 143, 1, 12, 309414) It is my unshakable conviction that penance and self purification are the only means for the protection of Hinduism.
('38', 143, 1, 13, 309531) Do any amount of sangathan, only let not that sangathan be of the evil forces, let it be only of the forces of good.
('38', 143, 1, 14, 309648) You say I am partial to the Mussalmans.
('38', 143, 1, 15, 309688) So be it, though the Mussalmans do not admit it.
('38', 143, 1, 16, 309737) But my religion will not suffer by even an iota by reason of my partiality.
('38', 143, 1, 17, 309813) I shall have to answer my God and my Maker if I give anyone less than his due, but I am sure that He will bless me if He knows that I gave someone more than his due.
('38', 143, 1, 18, 309979) I ask you to understand me.
('38', 143, 1, 19, 310007) If my hand or heart has done anything more than was anyone’s due, you should be proud of it, rather than deplore it.
('38', 143, 1, 20, 310124) It should be a matter of pride to you as Hindus to think that there was amongst you at least one mad Gandhi who was not only just to the Mussalmans, but even went out of his way in giving them more than their due.
('38', 143, 1, 21, 310338) Hinduism is replete with instances of tolerance, sacrifice and forgiveness.
('38', 143, 1, 22, 310414) Think of the sacrifice of the Pandavas, think of the forgiveness of Yudhishthira.
('38', 143, 1, 23, 310496) Should it be a matter for sorrow for you, that there is at least one man who has tried to carry out the precept of Hinduism to the letter?
('38', 143, 1, 24, 310635) If there is anything in the charge that you are wearing khadi just to please me, and for show, I say for God’s sake do not do so.
('38', 143, 1, 25, 310765) I am not a Mahatma.
('38', 143, 1, 26, 310785) If I am one, the Mahatmaship is but the expression of some shakti 1. Pray do nothing for my sake.
('38', 143, 1, 27, 310883) I shuddered when
('38', 143, 2, 28, 310900) 1 Power
('38', 144, 0, 1, 310908) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 145
('38', 144, 1, 2, 310951) someone proposed that though I was silent I should exhibit myself for darshan 1. I assure you the words ‘darshan’ and ‘Mahatma’ stink in my nostrils.
('38', 144, 1, 3, 311101) I am unworthy of giving darshan.
('38', 144, 1, 4, 311134) Even like you I am a vessel of clay, liable to all the affections and passions that flesh is heir to.
('38', 144, 1, 5, 311236) How can I be fit to give you darshan?
('38', 144, 1, 6, 311274) One and only one darshan is necessary, viz., that of the nameless, formless, indefinable Absolute.
('38', 144, 1, 7, 311373) Try, if you can, to see Him everywhere, in a poor man’s hut as in a palace, in a latrine as well as in a temple.
('38', 144, 1, 8, 311486) Have, if you will, the darshan of khadi and visualize its immense potentialities.
('38', 144, 1, 9, 311568) Dismiss the mortal frame called Gandhi from your mind.
('38', 144, 1, 10, 311623) Its darshan will be of no avail.

('38', 144, 2, 12, 311679) 127. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('38', 144, 3, 13, 311713) [Before February 21, 1927] 2
('38', 144, 4, 14, 311742) Haste is waste.
('38', 144, 4, 15, 311758) Let me do a few places thoroughly rather than many places indifferently.
('38', 144, 4, 16, 311831) You will have to remember that I have to do continuous travelling throughout the year.
('38', 144, 4, 17, 311918) My capacity and energy are limited.
('38', 144, 4, 18, 311954) I must therefore have three forty five minutes for three meals, one forty five minutes for bath, etc., and two forty five minutes for a quiet walk in the morning and evening.
('38', 144, 4, 19, 312129) I must be made to retire at 9 p.m., and I must have three hours for attending to correspon dence and editing, and I must have half an hour for sleep during day.
('38', 144, 4, 20, 312290) If you can give me these hours, I fancy that I shall not only bear the strain of travelling but go on almost indefinitely and shall improve in health.

('38', 145, 5, 16, 313608) 129. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('38', 145, 6, 17, 313638) Monday [February 21, 1927] 1
('38', 145, 7, 18, 313667) MANILAL, I have your letter.
('38', 145, 7, 19, 313696) I do not want Sushila to make a resolve; I do not know her that well.
('38', 145, 7, 20, 313766) But you should acquaint yourself with her people.
('38', 145, 7, 21, 313816) They are a cultured family.
('38', 145, 7, 22, 313844) All of them wear khadi.
('38', 145, 7, 23, 313868) I agree it is difficult for you to wear khadi.
('38', 145, 7, 24, 313915) It will not be difficult for Sushila as long as she keeps up her Indian style with sari and other things.

('38', 145, 8, 27, 314154) 1 From the reference to Manilal’s wedding and the message to Panditji in this and the succeeding two letters, it appears that all the three were written on the same date.
('38', 146, 0, 1, 314325) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 147
('38', 146, 1, 2, 314368) It is not my attempt to make recluses of you or Sushila, but I certainly intend to make you disciplined householders.
('38', 146, 1, 3, 314486) If I wanted to make you monks I would not have bothered about getting you married.
('38', 146, 1, 4, 314569) I would not disapprove if you sought your pleasure within limits.
('38', 146, 1, 5, 314635) In spite of all this you are free and should act as you please; I do not want to exercise the least pressure.
('38', 146, 1, 6, 314745) Jamnalalji has not turned a recluse, only he has given up a number of pleasures.
('38', 146, 1, 7, 314826) You are quite grown up and I do not look upon you as a child.

('38', 148, 4, 27, 319506) 132. LETTER TO ASHRAM MEMBERS
('38', 148, 5, 28, 319536) Silence Day, February 21, 1927 I see from the letters I get that attendance at the prayer is irregu lar and thin.
('38', 148, 5, 29, 319650) A general slackness is also creeping into the spinning.
('38', 148, 5, 30, 319706) Spinning and prayer are the two beacons for us.
('38', 148, 5, 31, 319754) If we do not keep an eye on them, we will be able to do no credit either to the Ashram or to ourselves.
('38', 148, 5, 32, 319858) It is one thing not to do them after deciding right from the beginning that we would not engage in either of them, and another to omit doing them after undertaking them.
('38', 148, 5, 33, 320028) In my opinion, he who approves of neither can achieve nothing at the
('38', 149, 0, 1, 320097) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 149, 1, 2, 320139) Ashram, since we regard them both as essential religious activities.
('38', 149, 1, 3, 320208) Those who, while approving of them, grow lax in their practice will develop a general laxity.
('38', 149, 1, 4, 320302) If we wish to learn to insist on truth and to experience the strength it gives, we must never omit to perform the two aforesaid rites.
('38', 149, 1, 5, 320437) Both require faith on our part.
('38', 149, 1, 6, 320469) To a certain extent we can adduce rational arguments in support of both, but in the last resort faith alone can satisfy us.
('38', 149, 1, 7, 320593) One sometimes feels that nothing is gained by attendance at prayers, that one is unable to concentrate attention, one feels a sense of lethargy, and so on.
('38', 149, 1, 8, 320749) These things cannot be reasoned out; they can be dispelled only by faith.
('38', 149, 1, 9, 320823) The Gita recommends faith alone when it speaks of dispassionate action.
('38', 149, 1, 10, 320895) An effort is never wasted.
('38', 149, 1, 11, 320922) It is an act of faith to believe in the ultimate triumph of truth in the face of failures, and to follow truth dispassionately.
('38', 149, 1, 12, 321050) We should have the same attitude to spinning as to prayer.
('38', 149, 1, 13, 321109) It is not for me to calculate how this much spinning would benefit me or the country.
('38', 149, 1, 14, 321195) One may not see any immediate benefit from spinning but one must stick to one’s belief that it is going to bring some benefit.
('38', 149, 1, 15, 321322) The point is to learn to stick to our resolve.
('38', 149, 1, 16, 321369) The two external and common activities of prayer and spinning are likely to develop this tenacity.
('38', 149, 1, 17, 321468) If we are lax in these activities, when shall we learn to stand firm on truth?
('38', 149, 1, 18, 321547) I therefore appeal to all, young and old, not to neglect these two activities.
('38', 149, 2, 19, 321626) Blessings from BAPU
('38', 149, 3, 20, 321646) From a copy of the Gujarati: C.W. 8053. Courtesy: Raojibhai N. Patel

('38', 153, 5, 9, 327031) I have been studying the question carefully and carrying on an active correspondence with experts chiefly Messrs Madon and Wadia.

('38', 156, 3, 6, 331494) 142. SPEECH AT GULBARGA 1
('38', 156, 4, 7, 331520) February 22, 1927
('38', 156, 5, 8, 331538) [Addressing] both the Hindus and Mussalmans gathered in the vast courtyard of the famous Sharana Basappa Temple which still bore the marks of the mob fury of 1924 2, Gandhiji said: My heart burns with agony when I see young men, dressed in foreign caps and clothes.
('38', 156, 5, 9, 331804) It is surprising that they do not see that, whilst the rupees that they spend on foreign caps are wasted, the annas that they need spend on khadi caps all go to the pockets of the poor.
('38', 156, 5, 10, 331990) The man who shuts his eyes to the poor of his land and seeks to befriend the poor of the world must be mad indeed.
('38', 156, 5, 11, 332105) God will find him guilty of arrogating to himself His function.
('38', 156, 5, 12, 332169) The Hindu who recites his Gayatri regularly and the Mussalman who says his namaz five times a day are doing so in vain, if they have no corner in their hearts for the poor of their land.
('38', 156, 5, 13, 332356) This is the message I would leave with the Hindus and Mussalmans of this place.
('38', 156, 5, 14, 332436) Much as I would like to pour out my agony before you, I know that it will be a cry in the wilderness.
('38', 156, 5, 15, 332538) I therefore daily send out my prayer to God: ‘Lord, do somehow deliver us from this confla gration.’ But I should be untrue to my creed if as a believing and satyagrahi Hindu I disguised from you the feelings within me.

('38', 158, 8, 10, 335552) [February 23, 1927] 2
('38', 158, 9, 11, 335574) At Pandharpur the people in charge of the temple had somehow got the report that Gandhiji was going there with a European friend and they were terribly exercised as to what they should do if Gandhiji insisted on entering the temple with the friend as he did at Banaras.
('38', 158, 9, 12, 335844) They must have been relieved to find that there was no such friend in our party.
('38', 158, 9, 13, 335925) But Gandhiji made a pointed reference to this matter in his speech.
('38', 158, 9, 14, 335993) He said: I am sorry that neither the Buddhist friend who was with me at Banaras nor the ‘untouchable’ girl I have adopted is with me.
('38', 158, 9, 15, 336127) But you may be sure that I should not have visited the temple without them if they had been with me.
('38', 158, 9, 16, 336228) Had I left them out, I should have been guilty of insulting Vithoba Himself.
('38', 158, 9, 17, 336305) I would not mind even an atheist entering our temple, for I know that God can take care of Himself.
('38', 158, 9, 18, 336405) Who is there in the world who can insult the God in the image?

('38', 159, 2, 10, 337442) 145. HONOURABLE COMPROMISE
('38', 159, 3, 11, 337469) Sir Mahomed Habibullah and his colleagues are to be congratulated upon having secured a settlement that is honourable to both parties.
('38', 159, 3, 12, 337604) It is not the best that could be conceived, but it is the best that was possible.
('38', 159, 3, 13, 337686) I doubt if any other deputation could have done more.
('38', 159, 3, 14, 337740) The Class Areas Bill, which brought about the Conference and round which the battle raged, is dead and gone.
('38', 159, 3, 15, 337849) The Right Hon.
('38', 159, 3, 16, 337864) Srinivasa Sastri, who when the deputation sailed for South Africa was of all members the most communicative and had warned us not to expect much, did not conceal at the end of the labours of the Conference his satisfaction at the result.
('38', 159, 3, 17, 338102) A perusal of the settlement warrants the satisfaction.
('38', 159, 3, 18, 338157) But like all compromises this one is not without its danger points.
('38', 159, 3, 19, 338225) The dropping of the Class Areas Bill is balanced by repatria tion, re emerging as re emigration.
('38', 159, 3, 20, 338322) If the name is more dignified, it is also more dangerous.
('38', 159, 3, 21, 338380) Repatriation could only be to India.
('38', 159, 3, 22, 338417) Re emigra tion can be to any country.
('38', 159, 3, 23, 338455) The following sentence in the settlement clearly points to that interpretation:“The Union Government there fore will organize a scheme of assisted emigration to India or other countries where Western standards are not required.” This assisted emigration to other countries I hold to be dangerous, for there is no knowing what may happen to the poor ignorant men going to an unknown land, where they would be utter strangers.
('38', 159, 3, 24, 338880) Such countries as would take them would only be either Fiji or British Guiana.
('38', 159, 3, 25, 338959) Neither
('38', 160, 0, 1, 338967) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 161
('38', 160, 1, 2, 339010) has a good name in India.
('38', 160, 1, 3, 339036) It is decidedly a disadvantage to have been party to assisted emigration to any other part of the world.
('38', 160, 1, 4, 339141) The good point about this assisted emigration is that whereas before the settlement the repatriates lost their domicile, the re emi grants now retain it and lose it only if they absent themselves so long as to warrant the inference that there is no intention on their part to return to South Africa.
('38', 160, 1, 5, 339441) How many assisted emigrants can hope to refund the assistance in money they might have received or how many can hope to return with their families is a different question.
('38', 160, 1, 6, 339613) The non forfeiture clause is clearly designed not so much to guarantee a substantial right as not to hurt national self respect.
('38', 160, 1, 7, 339742) The annexure, containing a summary of “conclusions reached by the Round Table Conference on the Indian question in South Africa”, is a remarkable document betraying in every paragraph a heroic attempt to reconcile conflicting interests and sentiments.
('38', 160, 1, 8, 339994) The industrious reader will have no difficulty in discovering hopeful paragraphs.
('38', 160, 1, 9, 340076) I shall therefore content myself with drawing attention to a paragraph that is fraught with grave danger.
('38', 160, 1, 10, 340182) The Union Government is “to take special steps under the Public Health Act for an investigation into the sanitary and housing conditions in and around Durban, which will include the question of the limitation of sale of municipal lands subject to restrictive conditions”.
('38', 160, 1, 11, 340454) I do not know what is aimed at in this paragraph, but my suspecting mind—and my suspicion is based upon previous bitter experience of interpretations, warranted and unwarranted, that a strong party places upon agree ments with a weak party to the latter’s disadvantage—conjures up all kinds of frightful consequences arising from this proposed committee and limitation.
('38', 160, 1, 12, 340824) Already the Durban Corporation has been invested with powers which it has utilized for the suppression of its Indian citizens.
('38', 160, 1, 13, 340951) So far as I know a committee can bring to light nothing that is not known to the Corporation or the Government.
('38', 160, 1, 14, 341063) The appointment of an advisory committee of Indians may be simple padding.
('38', 160, 1, 15, 341138) The Health Committee may bring in a hysterical report, as a previous committee to my knowledge has done, and limitations may be put upon the purchase of municipal lands by Indians which may cramp the Indian community residing in Durban.
('38', 160, 1, 16, 341375) Nor do I like the paragraph which seems to imply that provincial Governments are at liberty to take any action they might against the Indian settlers without
('38', 161, 0, 1, 341533) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 161, 1, 2, 341575) reference to the Central Government.
('38', 161, 1, 3, 341612) But the compromise is acceptable in spite of the dangers referred to by me, not so much for what has been actually achieved as for the almost sudden transformation of the atmosphere in South Africa from one of remorseless hostility towards Indians to that of a generous toleration and from complete social ostracism to that of admission of Indians to social functions.
('38', 161, 1, 4, 341981) Mr. Andrews sends me a glowing account of the utmost cordiality with which the Indian members of the Deputation were received alike by the Government and the people, how local Indians were able to gain entry to the most fashionable hotel in Cape Town without any let or hindrance and how the Europeans in South Africa were flocking to him to know all about the Indian Deputation and the Indian question.
('38', 161, 1, 5, 342385) If this atmosphere of goodwill and sociability is kept up and encouraged, the settlement can be used as a solid foundation for erecting a beautiful temple of freedom for the Indian settlers in South Africa.
('38', 161, 1, 6, 342592) But the success of the settlement very largely depends upon the selection of the Consul or the Commissioner who will be selected to represent the Government of India.
('38', 161, 1, 7, 342759) He must be a person of eminence, great ability and great strength of character, and in my opinion, he must be an Indian.
('38', 161, 1, 8, 342880) They very fact of his being an Indian will strike the imagination of the European population and raise the Indian settlers in European estimation.
('38', 161, 1, 9, 343027) He will reach the heart of Indians in a way no Englishman, not even perhaps Mr. Andrews, can, and if a man can be selected who will command the equal esteem of the Union Government we need not fear the future.
('38', 161, 1, 10, 343237) Such a man in my humble opinion is Mr. Srinivasa Sastri.
('38', 161, 1, 11, 343294) I cannot conclude this hasty survey of the settlement without placing on record my deepest conviction that the happy result is predominantly due to the ceaseless and prayerful labours of that godly self effacing Englishman, Charlie Andrews.

('38', 161, 3, 13, 343558) 146. NOTES
('38', 161, 4, 14, 343569) A SIMPLE SUGGESTION During my tour I observe that at some of the meetings volunteers thoughtlessly begin distribution of papers, such as copies of address, etc., just after the guest has arrived and the address has begun to be read.
('38', 161, 4, 15, 343802) They do not realize that this creates a fresh disturbance in already noisy and restless meetings.
('38', 161, 4, 16, 343900) If papers are to be distributed, they should be distributed before the proceedings
('38', 162, 0, 1, 343983) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 163
('38', 162, 1, 2, 344026) commence.
('38', 162, 1, 3, 344036) It is not even realized that if papers are distributed, they should be distributed to all who want them.
('38', 162, 1, 4, 344141) In mass meetings such distribution is impossible unless thousands of copies are available.
('38', 162, 1, 5, 344232) In my opinion this would mean an utterly useless waste of public money.
('38', 162, 1, 6, 344304) Whatever is absolutely necessary will surely be printed by local papers and the public should be satisfied with what the papers give.
('38', 162, 1, 7, 344438) If they are unable to follow the proceedings without the papers it would not be a bad plan to sell such papers when there would be no question of favouritism.
('38', 162, 1, 8, 344597) All those who wish to possess copies can have them for a trifling charge to cover printing expenses and a small addition so as to form a contribution, however small, to the expense of organizing meetings.
('38', 162, 2, 9, 344802) STEWARDS OF THE NATION
('38', 162, 3, 10, 344825) Much trouble, time and money can be saved by a little forethought.
('38', 162, 3, 11, 344892) As it is, I often notice a reckless waste of public funds in connection with these meetings.
('38', 162, 3, 12, 344985) Let organizers of all meetings, but especially of khadi meetings, realize that we are the poorest country in the world, millions of whom are semi starved, if only because their earnings are less even than three pice per day.
('38', 162, 3, 13, 345210) Let organizers therefore understand, as stewards for the nation, it is their duty to spend public funds like misers and never to spend a pie without thought and without necessity.
('38', 162, 3, 14, 345390) Organizers of khadi meetings should further realize that every pice collected is a pice meant for the starving millions and so one pice means often a day’s earning for a widow.
('38', 162, 3, 15, 345567) They must not therefore spend where they need not.
('38', 162, 3, 16, 345618) For instance, they spend money on paper decorations.
('38', 162, 3, 17, 345671) This is no time for decora tions.
('38', 162, 3, 18, 345705) Let them save as much as they can by avoiding all decorations save only those which may be required to attract people’s attention.
('38', 162, 3, 19, 345836) In that case they can think of several artistic things which cost nothing or very little.
('38', 162, 3, 20, 345926) Thus they can have flags and buntings out of waste khaddar.
('38', 162, 3, 21, 345986) We are now going in for extensive tailoring in connection with khaddar sales.
('38', 162, 3, 22, 346064) There is always much waste material in a tailor’s shop which he throws away.
('38', 162, 3, 23, 346141) Now every part of this waste can be used for buntings which unlike paper buntings can be preserved for further use.
('38', 163, 0, 1, 346257) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 163, 1, 2, 346299) WRITE YOUR ADDRESSES Flowers may be avoided altogether and yarn garlands may be presented.
('38', 163, 1, 3, 346390) Yarn must not be damaged by being tied into knots.
('38', 163, 1, 4, 346441) It can be presented in its natural condition so that it can be subsequently used for weaving or any similar purpose.
('38', 163, 1, 5, 346558) Money can also be saved by avoiding the printing of addresses.
('38', 163, 1, 6, 346621) The best calligraphist among the organizers can write out the address on simple handmade paper and the paper can be nicely sewn on to a piece of khaddar, or if a little volunteer boy or girl would embroider the letters on a piece of khaddar it would be still better, the thread for embroidery, too, being hand spun.
('38', 163, 1, 7, 346937) Such work will be at once artistic and even valuable.
('38', 163, 1, 8, 346991) I have stolen the idea from the remarkable way in which Babu Mahendra Prasad’s daughter Rama had embroidered for her father the address presented by the Chapra Municipality of which he is Chairman.
('38', 163, 1, 9, 347189) It cost the Municipality nothing and I have become possessor of a work of art which will adorn the museum which Adhya pak Malkani has brought into being in the Gujarat National College.
('38', 163, 1, 10, 347375) AVOID SILVER CASKETS Expensive caskets are not required, for I have no use for them nor have I any room to keep them in.
('38', 163, 1, 11, 347496) Latterly I have been putting to auction every expensive casket received by me and handing the proceeds to the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('38', 163, 1, 12, 347642) Although these auctions have invariably proved profitable in that they have fetched much more than their intrinsic value it will not be proper to present caskets for the purpose of securing fancy prices.
('38', 163, 1, 13, 347846) It will be a good exercise for organizers if they must give their khaddar addresses in caskets to find out something cheap, local and artistic.
('38', 163, 1, 14, 347990) NOT A PLEASURE TRIP Well has Gangadharrao said that mine is not a pleasure trip, but a business tour during which I expect to do substantial business for my principal Daridranarayana.
('38', 163, 1, 15, 348174) Every function therefore should be in fitting with that setting.
('38', 163, 1, 16, 348239) I have observed that often more local men travel with me than are necessary for the purpose of the mission and that motor cars are hired without due regard to economy.
('38', 163, 1, 17, 348407) Every item of expenditure should be previously and carefully thought out.
('38', 163, 1, 18, 348481) Unless we do so we shall not raise into being an efficient, economical organization calculated to serve the starving millions and we shall be guilty of the same charge, no matter on however small a scale, of
('38', 164, 0, 1, 348689) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 165
('38', 164, 1, 2, 348732) extravagance that we legitimately bring against the Government.
('38', 164, 1, 3, 348796) Kitson burners should be avoided whenever possible.
('38', 164, 1, 4, 348848) I notice, too, a lavish expenditure on feeding.
('38', 164, 1, 5, 348896) Those who travel with me do not do so to be entertained.
('38', 164, 1, 6, 348953) It is enough to provide clean lodging and clean food.
('38', 164, 1, 7, 349007) Indeed I often feel like copying for the whole of my company the excellent example of Mr. Bharucha who always insists on carrying his own food with him.
('38', 164, 1, 8, 349160) We spend much too much money and time upon food.
('38', 164, 1, 9, 349209) It grieves me to see people sending for parcels of fruit from Bombay or Calcutta.
('38', 164, 1, 10, 349291) Much of this expense is wholly unnecessary.
('38', 164, 1, 11, 349335) Some fruit is no doubt an essential part of my dietary and unless obtainable locally, something has no doubt to be imported.
('38', 164, 1, 12, 349460) But I am sure that the expense incurred in bringing fruit can at least he reduced by 75 per cent.
('38', 164, 1, 13, 349558) ‘But,’ argue over zealous friends, ‘why should not people who love you express their regard in some such loving acts of service?
('38', 164, 1, 14, 349687) They will not spend money otherwise, nor will they give you all the money that they spend for your personal comfort.
('38', 164, 1, 15, 349804) Let them therefore have the joy of spending some little money for you.’ The argument is no doubt flattering, but wholly unconvincing.
('38', 164, 1, 16, 349938) TRANSMUTATION INTO SERVICE If those who love cannot transfer their love to the thing for which I stand, their love is blind and of little value.
('38', 164, 1, 17, 350083) I do not know if one should live to provide mere enjoyment for friends.
('38', 164, 1, 18, 350155) Friendship means loving mutual service, and sometimes it is a positive disservice to indulge one’s friends and to expose them to temptations.
('38', 164, 1, 19, 350297) And if there are friends who would spend lavishly for providing luxuries for me, but would not spend for the cause I espouse, it is my clear duty to resist such luxuries.
('38', 164, 1, 20, 350468) Friends to be friends must first provide me with necessaries of life before they think of indulging me with luxuries; and khaddar work is a vital necessary of life for me, more vital than food.

('38', 164, 1, 22, 350696) AUCTION OF GARLANDS
('38', 164, 2, 23, 350716) The foregoing paragraphs were written, or rather dictated at the halts before we reached Ahmednagar at which latter place, there was an imposing meeting where there were several addresses presented, the Municipal address being in a beautiful silver cylinder.
('38', 164, 2, 24, 350975) The represen tatives of each body brought also expensive flower garlands.
('38', 164, 2, 25, 351049) Mr. Firodia who presented the inevitable purse excused himself for its
('38', 165, 0, 1, 351120) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 165, 1, 2, 351162) smallness by saying that Ahmednagar was a famine ridden tract.
('38', 165, 1, 3, 351225) When therefore I began my reply 1 I could not help noticing the contrast between the palatial surroundings, the expensive ceremonial and the statement of famine conditions.
('38', 165, 1, 4, 351398) I told the audience that what was true of Ahmednagar was true of the whole of India.
('38', 165, 1, 5, 351483) Was not India a famine ridden land?
('38', 165, 1, 6, 351519) But the fact did not prevent accumulation of wealth on the part of a few.
('38', 165, 1, 7, 351593) We the city dwellers lived upon the exploitation of the famine stricken villagers and the Khaddar movement was in tended somewhat to redress the wrong and to make some slight return to the millions whom we were exploiting.
('38', 165, 1, 8, 351816) I therefore suggested that the acknowledgment of the fact that Ahmed nagar was a famine area made it doubly the duty of its well to do citizens to give more rather than less.
('38', 165, 1, 9, 351991) I told them also that it would ill become me to accept for myself such caskets and rich floral tributes.
('38', 165, 1, 10, 352096) I told them further that believing as I did that plants were as much endowed with life as we were ourselves, I did not like the unnecessary plucking of a single flower.
('38', 165, 1, 11, 352265) But in a place like Ahmed nagar my dislike was heightened by the reminder that I was a self chosen representative of the very famine stricken millions whom Mr. Firodia had mentioned.
('38', 165, 1, 12, 352448) Every rupee spent upon unnecessary things meant a deprivation of the livelihood of 16 famishing women and I therefore suggested that they should auction the silver casket as also the flowers, and if my remarks went home they would pay not the market value of the casket and the flowers but they would pay for the sentiment that the things would carry with them.
('38', 165, 1, 13, 352810) The auctioning was entrusted naturally to the Chairman of the Municipality, Khan Bahadur Dorab seth.
('38', 165, 1, 14, 352911) The casket was knocked down to Sheth Magniramji the local philanthropist for Rs. 1,001 and the garlands and the bouquets were auctioned separately under the same able management and they fetched in all Rs. 502. The result of my appeal went beyond the meeting and the citizens seemed to catch the spirit of my address to them, and the purse of Rs. 1,700 for which Mr. Firodia had apolo gized went up to nearly Rs. 6,000 apart from a brisk sale of khadi at the meeting.
('38', 165, 1, 15, 353379) Future organizers beware!
('38', 165, 1, 16, 353405) I warn them that they need not present me with flowers and rich caskets, but if they do I shall assume

('38', 166, 1, 2, 353593) that they are presented for the purpose of being auctioned and in order that their contribution to the poor people’s fund may be substantially increased.
('38', 166, 1, 3, 353747) TILAK SWARAJ FUND During the Maharashtra tour at one or two meetings I was asked what had become of the crore collected for Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('38', 166, 1, 4, 353890) 1 The questioners had every right to put this question even though they might not have contributed a pie to the Fund.
('38', 166, 1, 5, 354008) A public fund becomes public property and therefore every member of the public is entitled to know in detail the administration of such funds.
('38', 166, 1, 6, 354151) I therefore answered the question fairly exhaustively.
('38', 166, 1, 7, 354206) The gist of my answer will bear repetition although the question has been answered in these pages already.
('38', 166, 1, 8, 354313) The accounts have been published regularly by the All India Congress Committee.
('38', 166, 1, 9, 354393) Copies of the audited accounts can be had at any time from the Congress Secretaries or the Treasurers.
('38', 166, 1, 10, 354496) Every pie has been accounted for.
('38', 166, 1, 11, 354530) There is no doubt that in some instances those to whom funds were entrusted were not faithful to the trust, but that is as much as to say that the Congress like all human institutions is an imperfect body having in its fold all sorts of men.
('38', 166, 1, 12, 354772) I know of no institution in the world which does not have dishonest agents.
('38', 166, 1, 13, 354848) The Congress is no exception.
('38', 166, 1, 14, 354878) But I can say this that no loss has been sustained beyond what a most careful merchant suffers.
('38', 166, 1, 15, 354974) The little loss that had been sustained is due not to negligence, but has occurred inspite of vigilant inspection and auditing.
('38', 166, 1, 16, 355102) It should be further borne in mind that the Congress has had in Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and in Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj an incorruptible working Secretary and an incorruptible working Treasurer respectively.
('38', 166, 1, 17, 355306) Moreover 75 per cent of the funds were administered locally by local representatives who had assisted in raising the funds and who were trusted by the people.
('38', 166, 1, 18, 355465) Lastly, the largest amounts were mostly earmarked and controlled by the donors, subject no doubt to the conditions that they were to be used only for purposes coming within the programme of non co operation and the accounts were to be open to inspection by Congress agents.
('38', 166, 1, 19, 355739) Personally, I have absolutely no regret about having raised the Fund and my conscience is clear as to its administration.

('38', 169, 8, 15, 360044) 151. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('38', 169, 9, 16, 360068) MALVAN, February, 28 1927
('38', 169, 10, 17, 360094) MIRA, I have two letters from you.
('38', 169, 10, 18, 360129) I have no doubt in my mind that a vow is like a rudder—a life regulator.
('38', 169, 10, 19, 360202) And just as a rudderless ship is lost, so is a life without a vow a lost life.
('38', 169, 10, 20, 360281) For after all a vow means a religious determination to carry out a decision for self restraint even at the cost of one’s life.
('38', 169, 10, 21, 360408) I should therefore welcome your desire to take what is perhaps the supremest vow for a man or a woman.
('38', 169, 10, 22, 360511) But if it is taken let it be taken after the maturest deliberation.
('38', 169, 10, 23, 360579) It would be wrong on my part to
('38', 170, 0, 1, 360611) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 171
('38', 170, 1, 2, 360654) prevent you from taking the vow, if you are clear about the necessity of taking it.
('38', 170, 1, 3, 360738) Not to take the vow is to trust one’s little self.
('38', 170, 1, 4, 360789) To take it is to distrust oneself and to trust only God.
('38', 170, 1, 5, 360846) I know where I should have been if I had not taken the vows I have.
('38', 170, 1, 6, 360914) But there is the other side, i.e., Andrews’s.
('38', 170, 1, 7, 360960) He says: “I do not know that the voice within is always the voice of God.
('38', 170, 1, 8, 361034) What I may hold to be right today may be found to be wrong tomorrow.
('38', 170, 1, 9, 361103) I must therefore hold myself free to do the will of God as I discover it from moment to moment.” This attitude has answered his purpose.
('38', 170, 1, 10, 361240) I should be undone.
('38', 170, 1, 11, 361260) I see a fallacy behind A’s argument.
('38', 170, 1, 12, 361297) He does not.
('38', 170, 1, 13, 361310) So it sustains him.
('38', 170, 1, 14, 361330) Fallacy, error and the like are relative terms.
('38', 170, 1, 15, 361378) What is good for one may not be good for all even though Truth is one for all time.
('38', 170, 1, 16, 361462) The difficulty lies in our hopeless ignorance of Truth.
('38', 170, 1, 17, 361518) Cruel God has enabled us to see that Truth is one and nothing else is; but He has disabled us for knowing its content.
('38', 170, 1, 18, 361637) If therefore you feel the call within to take the vow and if you feel it will make you feel freer, you shall take it.
('38', 170, 1, 19, 361755) Nothing need be done in haste.
('38', 170, 1, 20, 361786) You must keep your health.
('38', 170, 1, 21, 361813) Of course you will always starve when you feel the slightest touch of fullness or indigestion.
('38', 170, 1, 22, 361908) Even weakness is preferable to apparent strength if it is accompanied by indigestion or even a feeling of fullness.
('38', 170, 1, 23, 362024) You must not worry about your Hindi.
('38', 170, 1, 24, 362061) You are doing all you can.
('38', 170, 1, 25, 362088) The rest must lie in the hands of God.
('38', 170, 1, 26, 362127) A change may be necessary after we meet.
('38', 170, 1, 27, 362168) The fact evidently is that you must not combine two things—learning Hindi and teaching charkha.
('38', 170, 1, 28, 362264) It evidently exhausts you.
('38', 170, 1, 29, 362291) And you have not been helped to the extent you needed.

('38', 174, 5, 12, 368953) People are now totally oblivious of the fact that marriage is not a license, it is a discipline.
('38', 174, 5, 13, 369050) A person—man or woman—has recourse to marriage to regulate, to circumscribe the desire one feels.
('38', 174, 5, 14, 369148) This is the distinction between man and beast.
('38', 174, 5, 15, 369195) Thus though pursuit of pleasure results from marriage, the Shastras suggest that the couple should gradually shake off its hold over them.
('38', 174, 5, 16, 369334) Even those relationships which are formed for pleasure, the Shastras try to use for the attainment of moksha.
('38', 174, 5, 17, 369444) They enjoin them to this end.
('38', 174, 5, 18, 369474) So much so that seekers have described the relationship between the individual self and the Supreme Self on the analogy of marital union.
('38', 174, 5, 19, 369612) The concept of purity underlies conjugal love just as much as the communion of an individual with God.
('38', 174, 5, 20, 369715) Thus marriage can become a great help in rendering social service.
('38', 174, 5, 21, 369782) May your marriage prove so.

('38', 175, 6, 10, 370677) 158. SPEECH AT RATNAGIRI 3
('38', 175, 7, 11, 370704) [March 1, 1927] 4
('38', 175, 8, 12, 370722) After describing Ratnagiri as a place of pilgrimage for the whole of India, as it was Lokamanya’s birth place, and after a feeling reference to Sjt.
('38', 175, 8, 13, 370871) V. D. Savarkar, Gandhiji said: You know Lokamanya’s swaraj mantra.
('38', 175, 8, 14, 370938) I do not think there has been any follower of Lokamanya who has tried to carry out the mantra more than I. There may be many whose efforts are equal to mine, but no one can claim to have put forth greater effort.
('38', 175, 8, 15, 371151) For I know that not only is swaraj our birthright, but that it is our sacred duty to win it.
('38', 175, 8, 16, 371244) For in so far as we are removed from swaraj we are removed from manhood.
('38', 175, 8, 17, 371317) A proper manifestation of all our powers is impossible without swaraj.
('38', 175, 8, 18, 371388) And the swaraj that Lokamanya had in view was not the swaraj for Ratnagiri people or for Maharashtrians, but for the whole of India, poor as well as rich, and swaraj has no meaning for

('38', 176, 1, 2, 371788) the poor unless they have enough to eat.
('38', 176, 1, 3, 371829) Why should we not serve our mills, you ask.
('38', 176, 1, 4, 371873) Sheth Narottam Morarji, the owner of the Sholapur mills is a friend of mine, and I was the guest of his son 1 who showered his affection on me.
('38', 176, 1, 5, 372017) But does that mean that I must use cloth from the Sholapur mills and serve that “poor” Sheth Narottam and his son?

('38', 176, 1, 9, 372318) You say that poor people from your parts go to Bombay and earn a living there.
('38', 176, 1, 10, 372397) Do you know the price that they have to pay for that living?
('38', 176, 1, 11, 372458) They live in hovels without light and air, a few feet by a few feet, where several men and women are huddled together without regard for their bodily cleanliness or decency.
('38', 176, 1, 12, 372632) Are you ready to send your mothers and sisters to live under such conditions?
('38', 176, 1, 13, 372710) Do you not agree that the women that go to the Bombay mills are your mothers and sisters and the men your brothers?
('38', 176, 1, 14, 372826) Are you prepared to see your brothers and sisters take to a life of drunkenness and shame and return home and spread the infection of their vices?
('38', 176, 1, 15, 372973) Is it worth while paying this terrible price for the eight annas they manage to earn there?
('38', 176, 2, 16, 373065) Our cattle are destroyed because we do not know true cow protection and our villages are ruined because we do not know true economics and sociology.
('38', 176, 2, 17, 373214) The charkha can stop that ruinous process.
('38', 176, 2, 18, 373257) Do you know the daily income per head of our country?
('38', 176, 2, 19, 373311) Our economists say that it is one anna and six pies, though even that is misleading.
('38', 176, 2, 20, 373396) If someone were to work out the average depth of a river as four feet from the fact that the river was six feet deep in certain places and two feet in others, and proceeded to ford it, would he not be drowned?
('38', 176, 2, 21, 373606) That is how statistics mislead.
('38', 176, 2, 22, 373638) The average income is worked out from the figures of the income of the poor man as also of the Viceroy and the millionaires.
('38', 176, 2, 23, 373763) The actual income will therefore be hardly three pice per head.
('38', 176, 2, 24, 373827) Now if I supplement that income by even three pice with the help of the charkha, am I not right in calling the charkha my cow of plenty?
('38', 176, 2, 25, 373964) Some people attribute superhuman powers to me, some say I have an extraordinary character.
('38', 176, 2, 26, 374055) God alone knows what I am.
('38', 176, 2, 27, 374082) It is also possible to disagree about the efficacy of
('38', 176, 3, 28, 374136) 1 Shantikumar; vide “Letter to Ashram Women”, 21 2 1927.

('38', 177, 1, 2, 374235) satyagraha, but I do not think there is any reason for disagreement on these obvious facts about the charkha.
('38', 177, 1, 3, 374345) If someone convinces me today that there is no poverty in India, that there are few in India who starve for want of even a few pice a day, I shall own myself to have been mistaken and shall destroy the spinning wheel.
('38', 177, 1, 4, 374563) I ask you therefore to bear in mind what you mean when you say that Konkan is poor.
('38', 177, 1, 5, 374647) If you are really poor there is nothing like the wheel which can cure your impoverishment and which is a safeguard for the honour of your women.
('38', 177, 1, 6, 374792) Seek ye first the charkha and its concomitants and everything else will be added unto you.
('38', 177, 1, 7, 374883) How can you disregard a thing which is of such a national and universal character?
('38', 177, 1, 8, 374966) Does it behove the followers of Lokamanya to deride or reject the wheel?
('38', 177, 1, 9, 375039) But you will ask, as a youth who sought to heckle me asked, “If Lokamanya liked this thing, why did he not ask the country to take it up?” Well, I cannot be taken in by your question.
('38', 177, 1, 10, 375223) Whether or not Lokamanya had khadi in mind when he defined swadeshi, surely his swadeshi cannot but include khadi.
('38', 177, 1, 11, 375338) I am but the heir of Lokamanya, and if I do not add to the patrimony he has left me, I would not be a worthy son of a worthy father.
('38', 177, 1, 12, 375471) I pondered well over Lokamanya’s message, applied my many years experience to it and came to the conclusion that Lokamanya’s message must mean khadi.
('38', 177, 1, 13, 375621) Do you know what he used to do?
('38', 177, 1, 14, 375653) I am telling you of an incident that happened a short time before his death.
('38', 177, 1, 15, 375730) When Maulana Shaukat Ali approached him as regards the Khilafat question, Lokamanya said to him: “I shall put my signature to whatever Gandhi signs, for I trust to his better knowledge in this matter.” Supposing therefore Lokamanya had not khadi in mind when he advised swadeshi, what does it matter?
('38', 177, 1, 16, 376031) Supposing we were manufacturing spectacles here and someone were to say, “We cannot use them, Lokamanya did not advise the use thereof”, would it be proper?
('38', 177, 1, 17, 376188) We would dismiss him as a literalist, Vedavadarata as the Gita would describe him.
('38', 177, 1, 18, 376271) As the literalist interpreter of the Vedas does not grasp the infinite meaning of the Vedas, even so these literalist interpreters of Lokamanya’s message miss its infinite power.
('38', 177, 1, 19, 376450) But someone comes and says, “When Mussalmans are conver ting us who is going to listen to your khadi?” Have you, I ask, become so impotent that you will be Mussalmans because someone compels you to embrace Islam?
('38', 177, 1, 20, 376663) If you have true dharma in you, no
('38', 178, 0, 1, 376698) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 179
('38', 178, 1, 2, 376741) one dare violate it.
('38', 178, 1, 3, 376762) But I want to protect even our dharma by means of khadi.
('38', 178, 1, 4, 376819) For khadi means the service not only of Hindu but of Mussalman women.
('38', 178, 1, 5, 376889) A Maulvi in Bengal went and asked some of those women not to spin, on the ground that the khadi movement was a Hindu movement.
('38', 178, 1, 6, 377016) They listened to him for a couple of days, but the third day they came asking for cotton.
('38', 178, 1, 7, 377106) For what could they do?
('38', 178, 1, 8, 377130) They could not go on starving and the Maulvi had no food to offer them.
('38', 178, 1, 9, 377202) The learned author of the Mahabharata has described Vishvamitra, the sage, as ready to eat what was forbidden to him and even to steal, when he was oppressed by the pangs of hunger.
('38', 178, 1, 10, 377384) One cannot say what a hungry man or woman would not stoop to.
('38', 178, 1, 11, 377446) I therefore tell you that you must take to khadi if only to alleviate the poverty and safeguard the honour of your women.

('38', 178, 1, 15, 377844) Purity of character and salvation depend on the purity of heart.
('38', 178, 1, 16, 377909) I therefore say to the Hindus, “Do whatever you like, but don’t ask a man like me, who has come to his conclusions after the maturest thinking, to take up what he cannot.” Man’s capacity is after all limited.

('38', 178, 1, 18, 378175) I cannot do a hundred or even half a dozen things at a time.
('38', 178, 1, 19, 378236) I would think myself blessed even if I can do one thing well at a time.
('38', 178, 1, 20, 378308) If you agree with me that the charkha is the best sangathan that is possible, give me as much help as you can render.

('38', 181, 1, 2, 382616) 162. IS INDIA PROHIBITIONIST?
('38', 181, 2, 3, 382646) An English friend who is anxious to undertake prohibition work for India writes: 1
('38', 181, 3, 4, 382729) I know that what everyone will say to me is that the Indians themselves have shown no overpowering desire for prohibition and that as they have not organized any movement for this, it is interference on our part to
('38', 181, 4, 5, 382944) move in the matter.
('38', 181, 4, 6, 382964) Moreover of all the Councils only one or two have declared for prohibition.
('38', 181, 4, 7, 383040) Already people are saying this to me.
('38', 181, 4, 8, 383078) I always point them to the Non co operation movement when the volunteers picketed the liquor shops.
('38', 181, 4, 9, 383178) But when they say that was five years ago and they have shown no great enthusiasm lately, what is the answer?
('38', 181, 4, 10, 383288) The puzzle the friend asks me to solve is not new.
('38', 181, 4, 11, 383339) The question is bound to occur to one who does not know the history of the total prohibition movement in India.
('38', 181, 4, 12, 383451) And a stranger coming in our midst is bound to ask himself, ‘If India wants total prohibition, why does she not agitate for it as she does for many other things?’ One observes that people do not agitate when they feel absolutely helpless.
('38', 181, 4, 13, 383690) It is our helplessness which prevents us from agitating beyond having reso lutions by temperance societies and sometimes petitions to the Legislative bodies.
('38', 181, 4, 14, 383848) The cry for swaraj came out of a realization of growing helplessness in matters of paramount importance to our well being.
('38', 181, 4, 15, 383971) Take the military expenditure.
('38', 181, 4, 16, 384002) Everyone recognizes that much of it is a criminal waste of money collected from the starving millions.
('38', 181, 4, 17, 384105) Instead of agitating for reduction in military expenditure, we agitate for swaraj, the argument being that nothing is possible without swaraj.
('38', 181, 4, 18, 384248) Who can say that there is no great deal of truth in the argument?
('38', 181, 4, 19, 384314) When in 1920 we felt that we were getting swaraj, we took the law into our own hands, we successfully picketed the liquor shops and the Government was frightened to notice an immediate fall in the liquor revenue.
('38', 181, 4, 20, 384527) Liquor dealers trembled in their shoes and for a moment it appeared as if the drink evil had gone.
('38', 181, 4, 21, 384626) Unfortunately the party of non violence had not attained sufficient control over the people.
('38', 181, 4, 22, 384719) Violence broke out.
('38', 181, 4, 23, 384739) It was discovered that pickets did not everywhere carry out the instructions to create a blockade without resort to violence or threats to use it.
('38', 181, 4, 24, 384886) The picketing had therefore to
('38', 181, 5, 25, 384917) 1 The reference is to Muriel Lester; vide “Letter to Muriel Lester”, 17 3 1927.
('38', 182, 0, 1, 384997) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 183
('38', 182, 1, 2, 385040) be suspended.
('38', 182, 1, 3, 385054) But the history of 1920 21 shows in unmistakable terms what India would do if she had the power and what she did do when she thought that she had it.
('38', 182, 1, 4, 385204) Let it be further borne in mind that millions of Indians are teetotallers by religion and by habit.
('38', 182, 1, 5, 385304) Millions therefore cannot possibly be interested in keeping up the nefarious liquor traffic.
('38', 182, 1, 6, 385397) Thus in so far as it can be said that there is no agitation in India in favour of total prohibition, absence of agitation is due not to want of desire on the part of the people to secure total prohibition, but it is due to a consciousness of helplessness and to the certain know ledge that it is an integral part of the struggle for swaraj.
('38', 182, 1, 7, 385738) The very fact that it is necessary for any Englishman to defend liquor revenue on the grounds that there is no agitation among us for total prohibition, makes out an irresistible case for swaraj.
('38', 182, 1, 8, 385934) For, it shows utter ignorance of Indian conditions where the opinion is honestly held.
('38', 182, 1, 9, 386021) There is no agitation on the part of the people against malaria and scores of other diseases.
('38', 182, 1, 10, 386115) Is that any reason for taking no measures for eradicating malaria and other diseases?
('38', 182, 1, 11, 386201) In order to deal with a known evil, no agitation should be necessary for taking prompt measures.
('38', 182, 1, 12, 386298) The drink and the drug evil is in many respects infinitely worse than the evil caused by malaria and the like; for, whilst the latter only injures the body, the former saps both body and soul.
('38', 182, 1, 13, 386491) The drink revenue, military expenditure and the Lancashire’s exploitation of India through its calico, constitute the threefold wrong done by British rule to India.
('38', 182, 1, 14, 386656) When Englishmen realize that it is sinful to trade upon the drink habit of the poor labourers of India, that it is sinful to dump down English and other foreign calico on the Indian soil when India’s starving millions can easily produce during their spare hours all the cloth needed for her requirements, and when they realize that it is sinful to impose a terrific military burden upon India under the ostensible purpose of defending her borders but in reality for the sake of holding her people under subjection against their will, it would be a complete demonstration of change of heart, and co operation on a basis of absolute equality will become a real possibility.
('38', 182, 1, 15, 387328) The only agitation therefore that India can carry on is to end the system which makes these wrongs possible, which is the same thing as saying that
('38', 183, 0, 1, 387476) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 183, 1, 2, 387518) the agitation for swaraj is the agitation for the removal of these wrongs.
('38', 183, 1, 3, 387593) This removal is the acid test, in my opinion, of English sincerity.
('38', 183, 1, 4, 387661) Young India, 3 3 1927

('38', 183, 4, 9, 387880) The empty becomes full.
('38', 183, 4, 10, 387904) The worn out becomes new.

('38', 183, 4, 15, 388125) He asserts not himself, therefore he shines.

('38', 183, 4, 17, 388217) He glorifies not himself, therefore he endures.
('38', 183, 4, 18, 388265) The Master indeed does not strive, yet no one in the world can strive against him.

('38', 186, 2, 3, 393332) [March 4, 1927]
('38', 186, 3, 4, 393348) In the morning Gandhiji performed the installation ceremony of the image of Maruti 2 as part of their gymnasium.
('38', 186, 3, 5, 393461) He said: I install this image of Maruti here, not merely because Maruti had the strength of a giant.
('38', 186, 3, 6, 393562) Even Ravana had that strength.
('38', 186, 3, 7, 393593) But Maruti had the strength of soul, and his physical strength was only a manifestation of his spiritual strength which in its turn was the direct fruit of his exclusive devotion to Rama and his brahmacharya.
('38', 186, 3, 8, 393802) May you therefore be like Maruti of matchless valour born out of your brahmacharya and may that valour be dedicated to the service of the Motherland.

('38', 190, 7, 21, 401847) 173. UNTOUCHABILITY, WOMEN AND SWARAJ
('38', 190, 8, 22, 401885) I gladly publish Suhasini Devi’s letter 3 which the reader will find in another column.
('38', 190, 8, 23, 401973) Whilst the versatile President 4 of the Congress is well able to defend himself, I am inclined to think that my fair correspondent has over generalized from her own very brief experience.
('38', 190, 8, 24, 402161) No statistics are needed to demonstrate the vast strides that the movement for the removal of untouchability has made.
('38', 190, 8, 25, 402280) The barrier is breaking down everywhere.
('38', 190, 8, 26, 402321) The higher classes are to be met
('38', 190, 9, 27, 402354) 1 Evidently written soon after Manilal’s marriage 2 As in the source 3 In this she had complained that concrete action regarding removal of untouchability was not being taken to the extent it was demanded in the Congress resolutions.
('38', 190, 9, 28, 402588) 4 S. Srinivasa Iyengar
('38', 191, 0, 1, 402611) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 191, 1, 2, 402653) with in every province ministering to the wants of the suppressed classes in the shape of conducting schools and boarding houses for their children.
('38', 191, 1, 3, 402802) It was this phenomenon that the President evidently had in mind when he made the reference in his address.
('38', 191, 1, 4, 402909) There is however infinitely more yet to be done than has been already accomplished.
('38', 191, 1, 5, 402993) The question of breaking down the feminine prejudice is most difficult.
('38', 191, 1, 6, 403065) It is in reality a question of female education.
('38', 191, 1, 7, 403114) And in this it is a question not merely of education of girls but it is one of the education of married women.
('38', 191, 1, 8, 403225) I have therefore repeatedly suggested that every patriotic husband should become the wife’s own teacher and prepare her for work among her less fortunate sisters.
('38', 191, 1, 9, 403388) I have also drawn attention to the implications of the suggestion.
('38', 191, 1, 10, 403455) One of them is for husbands to cease to treat their wives as objects of their enjoyment but to regard them as co partners in their work of nation building.
('38', 191, 1, 11, 403611) We cannot have Rama without Sita.
('38', 191, 1, 12, 403645) And Sita got her real schooling under the gentle care of her partner during those terrible years of exile and probation.
('38', 191, 1, 13, 403766) Well, we are all exiles in our own land and need to imitate Rama and Sita to the best of our abilities and opportunity.
('38', 191, 1, 14, 403886) And in this connection, I cannot help drawing Suhasini Devi’s attention to the fact that Sjt.
('38', 191, 1, 15, 403980) Iyengar has not only broken down the barrier of untou chability for himself but has carried his wife and family too with him in the reform which perhaps he himself would have thought impossi ble only ten years ago.
('38', 191, 1, 16, 404195) The question of inter dining must be kept distinct from that of untouchability.
('38', 191, 1, 17, 404275) Exclusion in culinary matters permeates the whole of Hindu society.
('38', 191, 1, 18, 404343) To confuse it with untouchability is to retard the progress of the latter movement which is aimed at removing the ban on the social service to which the so called untouchable has as much right as any other human being and on the same terms as the others receive it.
('38', 191, 1, 19, 404609) There is, too, confusion regarding swaraj.
('38', 191, 1, 20, 404652) The term swaraj has many meanings.
('38', 191, 1, 21, 404687) When Sjt.
('38', 191, 1, 22, 404697) Iyengar says that removal of untouchability has nothing to do with swaraj, I presume he means that its existence can be no hindrance to constitutional advance.
('38', 191, 1, 23, 404857) It can surely have nothing to do with diarchy or greater and effective powers being given to the legislatures.
('38', 191, 1, 24, 404968) Removal of untouchability is a social question to be handled by Hindus.
('38', 191, 1, 25, 405040) Why should it prevent the Mussalman and the Parsi in common with the Hindu from having the power to regulate the military expenditure, to determine the ratio or to achieve total prohi bition or to impose a prohibitive tariff on foreign
('38', 192, 0, 1, 405276) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 193
('38', 192, 1, 2, 405319) cloth and protecting the indigenous industries?
('38', 192, 1, 3, 405367) Real organic swaraj is a different question.
('38', 192, 1, 4, 405412) That freedom which is associated with the term swaraj in the popular mind is no doubt unattainable without not only the removal of untouchability and the promotion of heart unity between the different sections but also without removing many other social evils that can be easily named.
('38', 192, 1, 5, 405698) That inward growth which must never stop we have come to understand by the comprehensive term swaraj.
('38', 192, 1, 6, 405800) And that swaraj cannot be had so long as walls of prejudice, passion and superstition continue to stifle the growth of that stately oak.
('38', 192, 2, 7, 405937) Young India, 10 3 1927
('38', 192, 3, 8, 405960) 174. PRAVARTAK YOUNG BENGAL SANGH AND KHADI
('38', 192, 4, 9, 406004) There is no province at the present moment so sorely affected as Bengal.
('38', 192, 4, 10, 406077) Some of its best young men are rotting in jails without knowing why.
('38', 192, 4, 11, 406146) Even in the Congress camp there is division.
('38', 192, 4, 12, 406191) After Deshbandhu the Provincial Congress Committee has not been able to reconcile itself to a single leadership.
('38', 192, 4, 13, 406304) It is no wonder.
('38', 192, 4, 14, 406321) There could be only one Deshbandhu.
('38', 192, 4, 15, 406357) But in spite of all this, constructive work is going on in Bengal almost without a stop.
('38', 192, 4, 16, 406446) The number of selfless young men who are engaged in that work is daily growing.
('38', 192, 4, 17, 406526) The Pravartak Sangh of Bengal whose headquarters are in Chandranagar and which is guided by Sjt.
('38', 192, 4, 18, 406623) Motilal Roy has been steadily increasing its activity in the production and sale of khadi.
('38', 192, 4, 19, 406714) But hitherto khadi in the Sangh has been a subsidiary activity—a little one among big ones.
('38', 192, 4, 20, 406806) But Moti Babu is now determined to make it the centre of his system.
('38', 192, 4, 21, 406875) I had a long talk about it myself with him when he said that the conviction was being forced upon him that it was not possible to render true service to the masses except through the spinning wheel as the centre piece.
('38', 192, 4, 22, 407094) Messrs Banker and Lakshmidas visited Chandranagar after me and they gave me a glowing account of the enthusiasm of the Sangh, about the wheel and its work at Kutubdia.
('38', 192, 4, 23, 407262) They told me too how eager Moti Babu was to learn the latest improvements in carding and spinning.
('38', 192, 4, 24, 407361) The Sangh is a comparatively old institution.
('38', 192, 4, 25, 407407) Its original inspiration is derived from the recluse of Pondichery and has a number of selfless devoted workers in Bengal.
('38', 193, 0, 1, 407530) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 193, 1, 2, 407572) From their khadi figures before me for January, I find that at their production centre they manufactured over Rs. 700 worth of khadi and their sales amounted to over Rs. 3,400 during that month.
('38', 193, 1, 3, 407767) If the Sangh could concentrate its energies on khadi production, it could soon rival Khadi Pratishthan and Abhoy Ashram without in any way interfering with either.
('38', 193, 1, 4, 407931) For the field for both production and sale is unlimited provided that each new organization explores and takes up a new field.
('38', 193, 1, 5, 408058) It is impossible for any single organization to cope with a mighty province like Bengal.
('38', 193, 2, 6, 408147) Young India, 10 3 1927
('38', 193, 3, 7, 408170) 175. WANTED WORKERS
('38', 193, 4, 8, 408190) One hears loose talk about village organization, about work in the villages.
('38', 193, 4, 9, 408267) Paper schemes also for village organization are now and again presented to the country and sometimes elegantly printed and often indifferently written.
('38', 193, 4, 10, 408419) When questioned the authors tell us frankly that they have not tried their schemes, they have not got the resources, or the time or the inclination; but they think that any idea that occurs to them they are in duty bound to put before the country, however ill digested or impracticable it might be.
('38', 193, 4, 11, 408718) Some of the authors get angry when they find that their schemes do not even get a start.
('38', 193, 4, 12, 408807) But there is one scheme which has been now before the country for some years and which its authors have tried to work first individually, then collectively and which is now being worked through an ever growing organization called the All India Spinners’ Association.
('38', 193, 4, 13, 409074) The spinning programme which has been demonstrated to be comparatively a success can be indefinitely extended if workers of the right type can be had.
('38', 193, 4, 14, 409225) During the Maharashtra tour, I have been taken to villages where there is almost continuous famine and where people are supposed to be without enough work and without enough to eat.
('38', 193, 4, 15, 409407) Some of the villages are deserted for six or eight months during the year.
('38', 193, 4, 16, 409482) The villagers go to Bombay, work under unhealthy and often immoral conditions, then return to their villages during the rainy season bringing with them corruption, drunkenness and disease.
('38', 193, 4, 17, 409671) If the righttype of workers go to these villages with the message of the wheel and with a patience that will not be exhausted and a faith that will not be moved, not one of the villagers need leave their homes.
('38', 193, 4, 18, 409882) For it is not
('38', 194, 0, 1, 409896) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 195
('38', 194, 1, 2, 409939) merely the wages earned by the spinners that are to be counted but it is the whole reconstruction that follows in the wake of the spinning wheel.
('38', 194, 1, 3, 410085) The village weaver, the village dyer, the village washerman, the village blacksmith, the village carpenter, all and many others will then find themselves reinstated in their ancient dignity, as is already happ ening wherever the spinning wheel has gained a footing.
('38', 194, 1, 4, 410351) Who then can become a village worker?
('38', 194, 1, 5, 410389) For the work that is required of him each worker should have a thorough knowledge both theoretical and practical of the science of spinning; he should there fore know the different varieties of cotton; he should know the method of picking cotton suitable for hand spinning.
('38', 194, 1, 6, 410663) For mill spin ning cotton is picked anyhow.
('38', 194, 1, 7, 410707) For hand spinning if cotton is properly picked it will save an immense amount of labour and the yarn also will be stronger.
('38', 194, 1, 8, 410831) He should know how to gin and should know the varieties of hand gins used in Indian villages.
('38', 194, 1, 9, 410925) He should know carding and he should know the different carding bows in use.
('38', 194, 1, 10, 411002) He should be able to tell the different staples of cotton and should be able to spin a given number of counts.
('38', 194, 1, 11, 411113) He should be able to test the strength and evenness and counts of yarn.
('38', 194, 1, 12, 411185) He should know a good charkha from a bad one and should be able to put dilapidated charkhas under repair.
('38', 194, 1, 13, 411291) He should be able to straighten an incorrect spindle.
('38', 194, 1, 14, 411345) If the worker is to live a model life in his village, he must know also the laws of civic sanitation and provide an object lesson in sanitation to the villagers.
('38', 194, 1, 15, 411507) He should know the domestic treatment of diseases of daily occurrence.
('38', 194, 1, 16, 411578) He should know simple accountancy.
('38', 194, 1, 17, 411613) Above all he must lead a pure and chaste life, if he is to make his mark amongst the villagers and gain their confidence.
('38', 194, 1, 18, 411735) Naturally a village worker must find happiness in a simple and frugal life.
('38', 194, 1, 19, 411811) Let no one think that I have sketched what is an impossible requirement.
('38', 194, 1, 20, 411884) I have not.
('38', 194, 1, 21, 411896) The technique though it reads formidable is by no means so for a patient student.
('38', 194, 1, 22, 411978) Purity of character must be a foregone conclusion in any of this work.
('38', 194, 1, 23, 412049) And no village worker can help falling a prey to some disease or other if he does not know and observe in his own person the laws of sanitation and does not know domestic treatment of simple diseases.
('38', 194, 1, 24, 412250) The spinning organization is capable of accommodating any number of workers who can satisfy the simple test laid down above.
('38', 194, 1, 25, 412375) Young India, 10 3 1927
