('38', 195, 3, 5, 412630) 177. BURMA AND CEYLON
('38', 195, 4, 6, 412652) A correspondent whose studious habits are evidenced by his letter itself writes thus:
('38', 195, 5, 7, 412738) Some of the following may strike you as idle academic questions, but the mention of India and Burma in the letter of your correspondent, who objects to Hindustani being our inter provincial language, published in Young India of 10 2 1927, along with your reply 2 (in which however you do not refer to Burma), gives me the excuse to put you these questions which I have long been thinking of doing:
('38', 195, 6, 8, 413136) 1. Do you believe that Burma can properly be a partner with India in the future swaraj, or do you think it better that Burma should have a separate nationality ?
('38', 195, 6, 9, 413298) (As Burmese opinion itself is divided on the question, yours may guide both it and the Indian.) 2. Have you ever been to Burma in the course of your many past tours of your country?
('38', 195, 6, 10, 413480) If not, do you intend paying a visit to Burma in the future and when ?
('38', 195, 7, 11, 413551) 3. Don’t you think it fit that Ceylon should be a partner with India in a future Swarajic Federation on account of their closer racial, linguistic and religious ties that exist between India and Burma—provided of course that the Ceylonese are willing to it (and they seem very likely) ?
('38', 195, 8, 12, 413838) 4. Do you think that Hindustani has any appreciable vogue in Burma, though it has been a Congress province now for some years (since 1908?), or that Hindustani will be acceptable to the Burmese?
('38', 195, 9, 13, 414033) 5. Ditto of Ceylon and the Ceylonese.
('38', 195, 10, 14, 414071) Well, these questions coming from me who have never been to Burma or Ceylon myself and can boast of no personal connections there may surprise you, but my interest in them is that of a cosmopolitan, which I take you also to be.
('38', 195, 10, 15, 414299) I therefore hope you will answer them at your early convenience, especially as I know that many Burmese and Ceylonese as well as Indians are
('38', 195, 11, 16, 414440) 1 Not reproduced here.
('38', 195, 11, 17, 414463) The correspondent had expressed satisfaction over the settlement, but pointed out that owing to the “bitter experience of the way such agreements have fared in the past one is apt to view it with the gravest suspicion.” 2 Vide “National Language”, 10 2 1927.
('38', 196, 0, 1, 414722) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 197
('38', 196, 1, 2, 414765) greatly interested in them, and are curious to know your views I have been to Burma and know that part of the world suffici ently to enable me to answer with confidence the question put by the correspondent.
('38', 196, 1, 3, 414973) I cannot say the same thing of Ceylon, which in spite of my desire, I have not yet been able to visit.
('38', 196, 1, 4, 415076) I have no doubt in my mind that Burma cannot form part of India under swaraj.
('38', 196, 1, 5, 415154) British India is an artificial description reminding us of foreign, that is, British domination and therefore its boundary is contracted or expanded at the will of those who hold us in bondage.
('38', 196, 1, 6, 415348) Free India will be an orga nic whole and will include those only who desire to remain as its free citizens.
('38', 196, 1, 7, 415456) Therefore free India will have its geographical, ethnic and cultural limits.
('38', 196, 1, 8, 415533) A free India will therefore recognize the differences in race and culture of the Burmese, and while it will extend the hand of fellowship and help to the Burmese nation, it will recognize its right to complete independence and help it to regain and retain it in so far as it lies in India’s power.
('38', 196, 1, 9, 415831) Needless to say that therefore in my scheme there is no demand upon the Burmese to learn Hindi or Hindustani.
('38', 196, 1, 10, 415941) I expect those who are within the real Indian border to learn Hindustani because they are the children of a common land and heirs to a common culture and are bound together by various other considera tions and their provincial dialects contain so many common words.
('38', 196, 1, 11, 416207) About Ceylon I cannot speak with equal confidence.
('38', 196, 1, 12, 416258) Although we have a common culture with Ceylon and although it is predomin antly inhabited by Indians from the South, it is a separate entity.
('38', 196, 1, 13, 416400) And as I have no imperial aspirations for India of my imagination, I should be content to regard Ceylon as an absolutely independent State; but I should not hesitate to accept Ceylon as part of free India if the Islanders express their wish to be so in an unmistakable language.
('38', 196, 1, 14, 416679) Young India, 10 3 1927

('38', 203, 0, 1, 424782) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 203, 1, 2, 424824) 190. SPEECH AT MADHI, MANDVI TALUK
('38', 203, 2, 3, 424859) March 15, 1927 Many thoughts occur to me on entering this taluk.
('38', 203, 2, 4, 424924) I forget my misery by poking fun at you, but it is a sign of my pain that I resort to that.
('38', 203, 2, 5, 425016) There was a day when not only Gujarat but the whole of India respected Surat district, and its contribution to the swaraj effort was considered to be the best, from the point of view of monetary help, silent work as soldiers’ and work in the field of education and for the service of Antyajas.
('38', 203, 2, 6, 425310) There was a friendly competition between two districts.
('38', 203, 2, 7, 425366) Even now I have memories of that friendly strife in which Bardoli had excelled itself, What a contrast between that day when Bardoli had become famous in the world, and today?
('38', 203, 2, 8, 425542) If we go to Bardoli today, we would see only a few white caps and a few Antyajas.
('38', 203, 2, 9, 425624) We would be reminded of the tragic events in Sarbhan and wonder if we would ever get swaraj.
('38', 203, 2, 10, 425717) And how can I ever forget the pledge we had taken, the oath the forty eight men had taken with God as their witness and, relying on their word, the ultimatum I had sent to the Viceroy?
('38', 203, 2, 11, 425902) And now I have to come here to inaugurate this Ashram, The lesson we should draw from this is that we should not lose heart, should not lose faith till death and should not retreat—that is the significance of the starting of this Ashram.
('38', 203, 2, 12, 426140) It is not a matter of pride that we have started it with money from the Gujarat Provincial Committee.
('38', 203, 2, 13, 426242) If you wish that an Ashram should be established here, then you should not be reluctant to give the necessary money.
('38', 203, 2, 14, 426359) You should raise the money and then ask me for men.
('38', 203, 2, 15, 426411) It is a wrong procedure to get money from the Provincial Committee for work here.
('38', 203, 2, 16, 426493) Anyone who depends only on the blood in his brain for his work is bound to fail.
('38', 203, 2, 17, 426574) One should rely on the blood in every part of one’s body.
('38', 203, 2, 18, 426632) Instead of functioning as our brain, the Provincial Committee has become our feet, and we let ourselves be dragged behind it.
('38', 203, 2, 19, 426758) This is an unhappy state of affairs.
('38', 203, 2, 20, 426795) When I see national schools and depressed communities in any place, I am reminded of Gujarat.
('38', 203, 2, 21, 426889) I wonder, then, if Gujarat is not out of the competition.
('38', 203, 2, 22, 426947) But I am an optimist, and see rays of hope even in the face of countless disappointments.
('38', 203, 2, 23, 427037) One such ray, of course, is this modest Ashram, for there are still earnest workers to run it.
('38', 203, 2, 24, 427132) May it prosper, and may Bardoli, broken in spirit, and Surat in ruins, shine again and shed lustre on Gujarat and the country.
('38', 203, 3, 25, 427259) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 20 3 1927
('38', 204, 0, 1, 427296) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 205

('38', 206, 2, 8, 431790) 194. NO AND YES
('38', 206, 3, 9, 431806) “Comrade” Saklatwala is dreadfully in earnest.
('38', 206, 3, 10, 431853) His sincerity is transparent.
('38', 206, 3, 11, 431883) His sacrifices are great.
('38', 206, 3, 12, 431909) His passion for the poor is unquestioned.
('38', 206, 3, 13, 431951) I have therefore given his fervent open appeal 1 to me that close attention which that of a sincere patriot and humanitarian must command.
('38', 206, 3, 14, 432090) But in spite of all my desire to say ‘Yes’ to his appeal, I must say ‘No’ if I am to return sincerity for sincerity or if I am to act according to my faith.
('38', 206, 3, 15, 432247) But I can say ‘Yes’ to his appeal after my own fashion.
('38', 206, 3, 16, 432303) For underneath his intense desire that I should co operate with him on his terms, there is the emphatic implied condition that I must say ‘Yes’ only if his argument satisfies my head and heart.
('38', 206, 3, 17, 432497) A ‘No’ uttered from deepest conviction is better and greater than a ‘Yes’ merely uttered to please, or what is worse, to avoide trouble.
('38', 206, 3, 18, 432634) In spite of all the desire to offer hearty co operation, I find myself against a blind wall.
('38', 206, 3, 19, 432727) His facts are fiction and his deductions based upon fiction are necessarily baseless.
('38', 206, 3, 20, 432813) And where these facts are true, my whole energy is concentrated upon nullifying their (to me) poisonous results.
('38', 206, 3, 21, 432926) I am sorry, but we do stand at opposite poles.
('38', 206, 3, 22, 432973) There is however one great thing in common between us.
('38', 206, 3, 23, 433028) Both claim to have the good of the country and humanity as our only goal.
('38', 206, 3, 24, 433102) Though therefore we may for the moment seem to be going in opposite directions, I expect we shall meet some day.
('38', 206, 3, 25, 433215) I promise to make ample amends when I discover my error.
('38', 206, 3, 26, 433272) Meanwhile however, my error, since I do not recognize it as such, must be my shield and my solace.

('38', 207, 1, 6, 434191) I distrust its schemes of amelioration of the lot of the poor, I distrust its currency reform, I distrust its army and navy.
('38', 207, 1, 7, 434316) In the name of civili zation and its own safety this Government has continuously bled the masses, it has enslaved the people, it has bribed the powerful with distinctions and riches and it has sought to crush under the weight of its despotic regulations the liberty loving patriots who would not be won over either by flattery or riches.
('38', 207, 1, 8, 434654) I would destroy that system today, if I had the power.

('38', 207, 1, 12, 435104) They do not know the root of the evil.

('38', 219, 6, 11, 458067) 208. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
('38', 219, 7, 12, 458093) [March 21, 1927] 2
('38', 219, 8, 13, 458112) [QUESTION:] 1. Do you feel it unbearable to live under the present political thraldom or not?
('38', 219, 8, 14, 458206) [ANSWER :] I do.
('38', 219, 9, 15, 458223) 2. If so, are you yourself individually prepared to get rid of it and gain political freedom or not?
('38', 219, 10, 16, 458324) 3. Is there any objection to suppose that "your being prepared" means that
('38', 219, 11, 17, 458399) you have acquired two spiritual qualities, viz., soul force and love of freedom ?
('38', 219, 11, 18, 458481) You may suppose so.
('38', 219, 12, 19, 458501) 4. Does not "preparation for the attainment of freedom" mean making the Indians endowed with the qualities and power necessary for such attainment which you respectively have acquired?
('38', 219, 12, 20, 458686) It does mean.
('38', 219, 13, 21, 458700) 5. Is not intellectual and moral education necessary for acquiring such
('38', 219, 14, 22, 458772) qualities?
('38', 219, 15, 23, 458783) 1 ‘Roguery towards a rogue’ 2 Vide the succeeding item.
('38', 220, 0, 1, 458839) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 221
('38', 220, 1, 2, 458882) 6. If so, what are the ways of educating the whole nation and how much time will it take to do it?
('38', 220, 1, 3, 458981) Through spinning.
('38', 220, 2, 4, 458999) 7. Is not the creation of a feeling of thorough disgust for political subjection extremely necessary?
('38', 220, 3, 5, 459101) 8. If so, what may be in your opinion the percentage of people having such a feeling among the three hundred millions of Indians?
('38', 220, 3, 6, 459231) Difficult to estimate.
('38', 220, 4, 7, 459254) 9. To create the consciousness of bondage is it not necessary to have the knowledge of the past glory of the motherland and to feel real restlessness on account of the present painful condition?
('38', 220, 5, 8, 459449) 10. Is it possible to create soul force in the absence of the said knowledge or the said restlessness ?
('38', 220, 5, 9, 459553) Hardly.
('38', 220, 6, 10, 459561) 11. Do acquisition of soul force and the possession of the power to suffer any pains boldly and calmly constitute the chief pillars of your spiritual activities or not?
('38', 220, 6, 11, 459730) To an extent, yes.
('38', 220, 7, 12, 459749) 12. Where, under what circumstances and how are the people to make use of their soul force for wresting power from the rulers ?
('38', 220, 7, 13, 459877) Throughout the country by non violent non co operation.
('38', 220, 8, 14, 459933) 13. What kind of intellectual, moral and physical preparation is necessary on the part of the people for the accomplishment of these two objects, viz., civil disobedience and refusal to pay Government taxes?
('38', 220, 8, 15, 460141) Hand spinning gives them an idea of non violence and self confidence.
('38', 220, 9, 16, 460211) 14. If our preparedness be looked upon as being complete, i.e., 16 annas, what proportion of the preparedness in terms of annas is necessary, in your opinion, on the part of your followers or the general public to bring about the attainment of freedom?
('38', 220, 9, 17, 460464) Eight annas one pie.
('38', 220, 10, 18, 460485) 15. Is the public so prepared today?
('38', 220, 10, 19, 460522) If not how much time do you think, it will take to be so prepared?
('38', 220, 10, 20, 460589) Not yet; unable to prophesy.
('38', 220, 11, 21, 460618) 16. What percentage of people in the country knows the fact that there is a unique personality like Mahatma Gandhi in India?
('38', 220, 11, 22, 460743) I have no idea.
('38', 221, 0, 1, 460759) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 221, 1, 2, 460801) 17. If it is taken for granted that one among a thousand may know it, how many persons per hundred thousand may have, in your opinion, the knowledge of Mahatmaji's ideas of freedom and his activities?
('38', 221, 1, 3, 461002) 1/1000th of those that know.
('38', 221, 2, 4, 461031) 18. It seems that there is complete darkness with respect to such knowledge; if the darkness is to be dispelled, how long will it have to be done?
('38', 221, 2, 5, 461178) As long as is necessary.
('38', 221, 3, 6, 461203) 19. Do you say that it is impossible to attain swaraj even if, in the absence of unity between the Hindus and Muslims, people of both communities should feel the miseries of political bondage to be unbearable and should struggle to be free from it, and even if a feeling should arise in both the communities that life without freedom is worse than death?
('38', 221, 3, 7, 461558) I do not, if both feel as you suggest.
('38', 221, 4, 8, 461597) 20. Do you say that a painful consciousness of the unbearable political condition has not the power to bring into being the union of the communities belonging to two different cultures ?
('38', 221, 4, 9, 461784) It has the power.
('38', 221, 5, 10, 461802) 21. The religious persecution of the Hindus by the Mohammedans was the principal cause which contributed to the attainment of freedom in the days of Shivaji and people belonging to different castes became united to free themselves from religious persecutions.
('38', 221, 5, 11, 462062) Readers of history do know the fact that the establishment of maths by Ramdas proved very useful in this respect.
('38', 221, 5, 12, 462176) Is it not the fact that the freedom which the people want today is for freeing themselves from the political, industrial and commercial oppression?
('38', 221, 5, 13, 462324) Yes; indeed.
('38', 221, 6, 14, 462337) 22. Whether untouchability goes away or not, whether the Hindu Moham medan disunion disappears or not, if, in spite of the existence of these two things, we could have two thousand persons maddened with the desire for freedom and endowed with soul force, will you say that these men will not be able to gain the freedom of the country?
('38', 221, 6, 15, 462673) These two thousands will sweep away disunion and untou chability and bring swaraj.
('38', 221, 7, 16, 462756) 23. If 1,400 civilians can hold such a vast country like India under subjugation will you say that the said two thousand persons endowed with the said qualities will not be able to take back India?
('38', 221, 7, 17, 462954) Vide answer 22.
('38', 221, 8, 18, 462970) 24. In short, do you say that it is not possible to attain swaraj even if the one emotion of feeling a strong disgust for bondage and regarding life without liberty to be unbearable, pervades the whole of India?
('38', 221, 8, 19, 463182) Mere emotion will never bring swaraj.
('38', 222, 0, 1, 463220) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 223
('38', 222, 1, 2, 463263) 25. If it is seen that the said emotion is quite indispensable and that it would lead to the attainment of swaraj, can it be created by your present lectures on khaddar?
('38', 222, 1, 3, 463433) My lectures on khaddar are converting that emotion into energy.

('38', 224, 4, 11, 467062) 212. SPEECH AT SANTA CRUZ, BOMBAY 1
('38', 224, 5, 12, 467098) March 23, 1927
('38', 224, 6, 13, 467113) Replying, Gandhiji began to address the gathering in Gujarati when he was requested to speak in Hindi as there was a large section of Madrasis and others, who could not understand Gujarati.
('38', 224, 6, 14, 467303) Gandhiji, however, took votes and according to the majority began to speak in Gujarati but assured the minority that their claim would not be neglected.
('38', 224, 6, 15, 467456) He said: The fear entertained by Mr. J. K. Mehta is well founded and I am really going to hit as hard as a man with non violence as his creed can do for the wide difference between the amount given at Santa Cruz six years ago and the one 2 given today.
('38', 224, 6, 16, 467709) It was only on account of the pressing invitation of Mr. Mehta that I agreed to come here instead of going to Rewari as was originally fixed.
('38', 224, 6, 17, 467851) You perhaps know that though I am not neglecting the cities I have been going to the villages very often these days because India resides not in her handful of towns but in villages.
('38', 224, 6, 18, 468034) Even there it is not difficult to collect Rs. 3,000. You will perhaps be surprised to learn that the villages in Maharashtra and Bihar contributed a lakh and a quarter each during my last tour there.
('38', 224, 6, 19, 468234) And khaddar too is spreading fast and wide in villages.
('38', 224, 6, 20, 468290) I shall quote figures which will prove, in spite of all the odd
('38', 224, 7, 21, 468354) 1 In reply to a welcome address by Jaisukhlal K. Mehta, Chairman, Bombay Suburban District Congress Committee 2 Rs. 3,000; against 52,000, six years earlier
('38', 225, 0, 1, 468511) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 225, 1, 2, 468553) rumours that khaddar is extinct, that khaddar is produced 20 times more than it was being manufactured in 1920, i.e., in the beginning of the movement.
('38', 225, 1, 3, 468705) In 1926, khaddar worth at least Rs. 20 lakhs was manufactured and at least 50,000 women scattered in 1,500 different villages of the country were given work of spinning for which they were paid over Rs. 9 lakhs.
('38', 225, 1, 4, 468917) But this position is not at all satisfactory.
('38', 225, 1, 5, 468963) It does not satisfy me.
('38', 225, 1, 6, 468987) I have found that khaddar is rarely seen in Bombay and other cities.
('38', 225, 1, 7, 469056) In Bombay in 1921, the case was quite different.

('38', 228, 2, 4, 475386) That the first edition was sold out practically within a week of its publication is a matter of joy to me.
('38', 228, 2, 5, 475493) The correspondence that the series of articles collected in this volume has given rise to shows the need for such a publication.
('38', 228, 2, 6, 475622) May those who have not made self indul gence a religion, but who are struggling to regain lost self control, which should under normal conditions be our natural state, find some help from a perusal of these pages.
('38', 228, 2, 7, 475836) For their guidance the following instructions may prove useful: 1. Remember if you are married that your wife is your friend, companion and co worker, not an instrument of sexual enjoyment.
('38', 228, 2, 8, 476026) 2. Self control is the law of your being.
('38', 228, 2, 9, 476068) Therefore the sexual act can be performed only when both desire it and that too subject to rules which in their lucidity both may have agreed upon.
('38', 228, 2, 10, 476216) 3. If you are unmarried you owe it to yourself, to society and to your future partner to keep yourself pure.

('38', 228, 2, 12, 476430) 4. Think always of that unseen Power which though we may never see we all feel within watching and noting every impure thought and you will find that Power ever helping you.
('38', 228, 2, 13, 476604) 5. Laws governing a life of self restraint must be necessary different from a life of self indulgence.
('38', 228, 2, 14, 476707) Therefore you will regulate your society, your reading, your haunts of recreation and your food.
('38', 228, 2, 15, 476804) You will seek the society of the good and the pure.
('38', 228, 2, 16, 476856) You will resolutely refrain from reading passion breeding novels and magazines and read the works that sustain humanity.
('38', 228, 2, 17, 476977) You will make one book your constant companion for referen ces and guidance.
('38', 228, 2, 18, 477054) You will avoid theatres and cinemas.

('38', 235, 0, 1, 491105) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 235, 1, 2, 491147) 223. SPEECH TO CHRISTIANS, KOLHAPUR 1
('38', 235, 2, 3, 491185) March 25, 1927
('38', 235, 3, 4, 491200) At Negala, Mahatmaji was given a cordial welcome by the Christian community.
('38', 235, 3, 5, 491277) The Principal of the Girls’ Christian High School in his welcome address assured Mahatmaji that the Christian community was one with him in all his activities.
('38', 235, 3, 6, 491437) In his reply, Mahatmaji said: 2
('38', 235, 4, 7, 491469) My experience tells me that the Kingdom of God is within us, and that we can realize it not by saying “Lord, Lord,” but by doing His will and His work.
('38', 235, 4, 8, 491621) If therefore we wait for the Kingdom to come as something coming from outside, we shall be sadly mistaken.
('38', 235, 4, 9, 491728) I am glad you are with me in my programme.
('38', 235, 4, 10, 491771) I may assure you then that whatever I do is done with the object of that realization.
('38', 235, 4, 11, 491857) Untouch ability, you say, you would like to see removed as much as I. Well, then, I may tell you that you cannot remove untouchability without whole heartedly taking up khadi work, for that work includes removal of untouchability, and goes beyond it.
('38', 235, 4, 12, 492108) Do you know that there are thousands of villages where people are starving and which are on the brink of ruin?
('38', 235, 4, 13, 492219) If we would listen to the voice of God, I assure you we would hear Him say that we are taking His name in vain if we do not think of the poor and help them.
('38', 235, 4, 14, 492376) Mr. Sam Higginbottom, a Christian missionary friend, came to see me the other day to discuss this very thing.
('38', 235, 4, 15, 492486) Fortunately he met me just in that area where the spinning wheel and khadi had done their work.
('38', 235, 4, 16, 492582) I ask you to go and visit such parts, and if you cannot do so, to take my word for it, that there is no better subsidiary occupation for the poor than khadi.
('38', 235, 4, 17, 492740) If you cannot render the little help that they need, it is no use talking of service of God and service of the poor.
('38', 235, 4, 18, 492857) Please go to the exhibition 3 and see things for yourselves, and try to identify yourselves with the poor by actually helping them.
('38', 235, 4, 19, 492989) Young India, 31 3 1927
('38', 235, 5, 20, 493012) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('38', 235, 5, 21, 493052) 2 This paragraph is from The Bombay Chronicle, 29 3 1927
('38', 235, 6, 22, 493109) 3 Khadi Exhibition; Gandhiji had inaugurated it earlier during the day.

('38', 236, 1, 2, 493224) 224. SPEECH AT KOLHAPUR 1
('38', 236, 2, 3, 493250) March 25, 1927
('38', 236, 3, 4, 493265) The Diwan saw him during the day, and he had a long talk with him.
('38', 236, 3, 5, 493332) Gandhiji asked him if there was anything like a ban on khadi in Kolhapur State.
('38', 236, 3, 6, 493412) There may have been something like it, he said, but there was nothing now.
('38', 236, 3, 7, 493487) Have I your permission then to say to the people at the public meeting in your name that people may go to the palace and all State offices and attend functions dressed in khadi?
('38', 236, 4, 8, 493665) The Diwan had no objection, and Gandhiji declared the thing at the public meeting and thanked him for the assurance.
('38', 236, 4, 9, 493782) He said: Do not have any illusion about khadi.
('38', 236, 4, 10, 493829) It is not that khadi invests the wearer with any sort of saintliness.
('38', 236, 4, 11, 493899) It is the duty of everyone who has the good of the poor at heart to wear it.
('38', 236, 4, 12, 493976) Even an adulterer and a prostitute may wear it.
('38', 236, 4, 13, 494024) This is how I would approach them.
('38', 236, 4, 14, 494059) ‘As to our conduct,’ I would say to them, ‘you are answerable to God.
('38', 236, 4, 15, 494129) But whe ther you are able to mend your ways or no, you can certainly wear khadi and do some service to the poor.
('38', 236, 4, 16, 494242) He who wastes money on liquor is a sinner.
('38', 236, 4, 17, 494285) He who wastes money on tobacco is a smaller sinner, if you will.
('38', 236, 4, 18, 494350) The one who wastes money on foreign cloth is as great a sinner as the second if not the first, and the one who uses Indian mill cloth has neither virtue nor vice to his credit or debit.
('38', 236, 4, 19, 494536) But the khadi wearer has distinctly something to his credit inasmuch as he serves both the poor and his country.
('38', 236, 4, 20, 494649) Khadi immediately takes him up from a lower level and makes him the friend of the poor.’ Young India, 31 3 1927

('38', 237, 4, 10, 495571) 226. DISCUSSION WITH DR.
('38', 237, 4, 11, 495596) WANLESS 1
('38', 237, 5, 12, 495606) [March 26, 1927] 2
('38', 237, 6, 13, 495625) That is an instance where the doctors fortunately succeeded in prevailing upon Gandhiji.
('38', 237, 6, 14, 495714) There have been instances in which they have failed.
('38', 237, 6, 15, 495767) For Gandhiji, who in many respects is an ideal patient, as many doctors have certified, also at times becomes the despair of his doctors.
('38', 237, 6, 16, 495905) The doctor immediately after the collapse prescribed undis turbed bodily rest, including cessation from spinning.
('38', 237, 7, 17, 496019) Well, then, take my blood pressure, before spinning and after spinning, and if you can convince me that after spinning it hasgone up to an alarming extent, I shall accept your advice.
('38', 237, 7, 18, 496203) On the contrary, I assure you spinning is a positive relaxation, it soothes the nerves.
('38', 237, 7, 19, 496291) And then, doctor, you must know that mine is a code of life far different from yours.
('38', 237, 7, 20, 496377) For instance, you would prescribe all sorts of medicines.
('38', 237, 7, 21, 496435) Now I have laid down a course of life, which, in certain respects, I may not change.
('38', 237, 7, 22, 496520) So if you give me a medicine which is composed of five ingredients I would take it, provided you agree to my forgoing my meal which may under no circumstances exceed five articles a day.
('38', 237, 7, 23, 496707) So you must either convince me that the medicine is more essential for my health than the diet, or must reconcile yourself to administering no medicine.
('38', 237, 7, 24, 496860) Then there is another thing.
('38', 237, 7, 25, 496889) Spinning is a thing l cannot live without.
('38', 237, 7, 26, 496932) If I must eat and live I must spin.
('38', 237, 7, 27, 496968) And what a glorious death it would be if you came and found me spinning and collapsing in the midst of it.
('38', 237, 7, 28, 497075) You would abuse those about me to your heart’s content, if you insisted on your discipline as a doctor, but if you are
('38', 237, 8, 29, 497194) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 28 3 1927 and Young India, 31 3 1927
('38', 237, 9, 30, 497299) 3 For the medical opinions, vide Appendix “Medical Opinions”, 29 3 1927.

('38', 238, 1, 2, 497415) good you will say it has been a welcome death.
('38', 238, 1, 3, 497462) You must know that I would be conscience stricken and make myself most miserable if I continued to live on and was not able to spin.
('38', 238, 1, 4, 497595) Yes, I may stop reading, writing and even spinning, provided I stop feeding too.
('38', 238, 1, 5, 497676) Will you permit me that?
('38', 238, 1, 6, 497701) No, doctor, I may not implicitly obey you, unless you can claim infallibility.
('38', 238, 2, 7, 497780) “If we could claim it,” rejoined the doctor with justice, “we should not be administering drugs, but be oracles sitting in temples.”
('38', 238, 3, 8, 497913) No wonder Dr. Wanless frankly said that no treatment was necessary excepting rest for an indefinite period.

('38', 238, 4, 10, 498044) 227. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA

('38', 238, 6, 12, 498108) DEAR SATIS BABU,
('38', 238, 7, 13, 498125) Well, it is not much use inquiring about you now that I am myself in the mire.
('38', 238, 7, 14, 498204) I am trying to pull myself out.
('38', 238, 7, 15, 498236) But if God wills otherwise what is my trial worth?
('38', 238, 7, 16, 498287) Anyway I do not expect to go beyond 13th April, 1928. I have nothing new to say or give.
('38', 238, 7, 17, 498376) I may collect more, give a little more guidance and patch here and patch there.
('38', 238, 7, 18, 498456) But really the clock has struck for me.
('38', 238, 7, 19, 498496) To reduce the message to execution is left for you.
('38', 238, 7, 20, 498548) You have therefore to live and work.
('38', 238, 7, 21, 498585) If I survive I shall not be of much use for active work evidently.
('38', 238, 7, 22, 498652) Let us see: “Thy will be done, not ours, oh Lord!” What is the use then even of peeping into the future?
('38', 238, 7, 23, 498757) Just for the moment I appear to be as fit as a fiddle.
('38', 238, 7, 24, 498812) And so I amuse myself by sending love messages to friends I can think of and have no time to talk to.
('38', 238, 7, 25, 498914) My love to you and Hemaprabha Devi.

('38', 239, 6, 15, 499572) 229. NATIONAL WEEK AND GUJARAT
('38', 239, 7, 16, 499603) I hope that Gujaratis will heartily respond to the appeal made by Shri Vallabhbhai Patel on behalf of the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee in connection with the National Week.
('38', 239, 7, 17, 499785) One can say that collecting a sum of Rs. 1 lakh is child’s play for Gujarat.
('38', 239, 7, 18, 499862) This amo unt, moreover, is required for work among the suppressed classes, which include Antyajas and the Raniparaj community.
('38', 239, 7, 19, 499989) From now on, we will describe Antyajas too as dalit.
('38', 239, 7, 20, 500042) The term was first used by Swami Shraddhanand.
('38', 239, 7, 21, 500089) Swami Vivekananda chose an English word having the same meaning.
('38', 239, 7, 22, 500154) He described the untouchables not as “depressed” 2 but as “suppressed” 3 and quite rightly.
('38', 239, 7, 23, 500246) They became, and remain, what they are because they were suppressed by the so called upper classes.
('38', 239, 7, 24, 500346) The Hindi word for this is dalit.
('38', 239, 7, 25, 500380) Among all the suppressed classes, the untouchables are the most suppressed.
('38', 239, 7, 26, 500456) The Rani (Kali) paraj community is also suppressed, and so are other communities, like Oghra, etc..
('38', 239, 7, 27, 500556) It is the object of the Provincial Com mittee to serve all these communities to the best of its resources.
('38', 239, 8, 28, 500663) 1 From the reference to Sanskrit, spinning, carding and khadi; vide “Letter to Manibehn Patel”, 28 3 1927. 2 The source has these words in English.

('38', 240, 6, 11, 501720) 231. CONDITIONS OF COW PROTECTION2
('38', 240, 7, 12, 501755) It has been a matter of sorrow for me to have taken up the burden of cow protection during the ending years of my life.
('38', 240, 7, 13, 501875) But there need be no sorrow when burdens come not of one’s seeking but when they seek one irresistibly.
('38', 240, 7, 14, 501979) And so has been for me the case with cow protection.
('38', 240, 7, 15, 502032) Recently at Ghatkopar, Bombay, I had the occasion to visit the institution 3 of the humanitarian society ably managed by its secretary Sjt.
('38', 240, 7, 16, 502172) Nagindas.
('38', 240, 7, 17, 502182) It is now conducting an experiment in dairying with the laudable object ultimately of replacing the illmanaged and disease breeding private dairies of Bombay which are situated in the heart of the city and where there is no exercise ground for the cattle, and where the best cattle are prematurely given to the butcher’s knife.
('38', 240, 8, 18, 502510) 1 Not translated here 2 This was written on or before March 28, 1927; vide “Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, 28 3 1927. 3 Vide “Speech at Sarvajanik Jivadaya Khata, Ghatkopar”, 24 3 1927.
('38', 241, 0, 1, 502693) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 241, 1, 2, 502735) But though the institution is ably managed, it has some inherent defects to which upon its invitation I had to draw the Society’s atten tion.
('38', 241, 1, 3, 502877) Incidentally I ventured to lay down the conditions of cow pro tection which are well worth repeating: 1. Every such institution should be situated out in the open where it is possible to have plenty, i.e., thousands of acres, of open ground capable of growing fodder and giving exercise to the cattle.
('38', 241, 1, 4, 503179) If I had the management of all the goshalas, I should sell the majority of the present ones at handsome profits and buy suitable plots in the vicinity except where the existing places may be needed for mere receiving depots.
('38', 241, 1, 5, 503404) 2. Every goshala should be turned into a model dairy and a model tannery.
('38', 241, 1, 6, 503478) Every single head of dead cattle should be retained and scientifically treated and the hide, bones, entrails, etc., should be used to the best advantage.
('38', 241, 1, 7, 503632) I should regard the hide of dead cattle to be sacred and usable as distinguished from the hide and other parts of slaughtered cattle, which should be deemed to be unfit for human use or at least for Hindu use.
('38', 241, 1, 8, 503842) 3. Urine and dung in many goshalas are thrown away.
('38', 241, 1, 9, 503894) This I regard as criminal waste.
('38', 241, 1, 10, 503927) 4. All goshalas should he managed under scientific supervision and guidance.
('38', 241, 1, 11, 504004) 5. Properly managed every goshala should be and can be made self supporting, donations being used for its extension.
('38', 241, 1, 12, 504121) The idea is never to make these institutions profit making concerns, all profits being utilized towards buying maimed and disabled cattle and buying in the open market all cattle destined for the slaughterhouse.
('38', 241, 1, 13, 504333) 6. This consummation is impossible if the goshalas take in buffaloes, goats, etc.
('38', 241, 1, 14, 504415) So far as I can see, much as I would like it to be otherwise.
('38', 241, 1, 15, 504477) not until the whole of India becomes vegetarian, can goats and sheep be saved from the butcher’s knife.
('38', 241, 1, 16, 504581) Buffaloes can be saved if we will not insist upon buffalo’s milk and religiously avoid it in preference to cow’s milk.
('38', 241, 1, 17, 504700) In Bombay on the other hand, the practice is to take bufffalo’s milk instead of cow’s milk.
('38', 241, 1, 18, 504792) Physicians unani mously declare that cow’s milk is medically superior to buffalo’s milk and it is the opinion of dairy experts that cow’s milk can by judicious management be made much richer than it is at present found to be.
('38', 241, 1, 19, 505018) I hold that it is impossible to save both the buffalo and the cow.
('38', 241, 1, 20, 505085) The cow can be saved only if buffalo breeding is given up.
('38', 242, 0, 1, 505144) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 243
('38', 242, 1, 2, 505187) The buffalo cannot be used for agricultural purposes on a wide scale.
('38', 242, 1, 3, 505257) It is just possible to save the existing stock, if we will cease to breed it any further.
('38', 242, 1, 4, 505347) It is no part of religion to breed buffaloes or for that matter cows.
('38', 242, 1, 5, 505417) We breed for our own uses.
('38', 242, 1, 6, 505444) It is cruelty to the cow as well as to the buffalo to breed the latter.
('38', 242, 1, 7, 505516) Humanitarians should know that Hindu shepherds even at the present moment mercilessly kill young male buffaloes as they cannot profitably feed them.
('38', 242, 1, 8, 505665) To save the cow and her progeny—and that only is a feasible proposition—the Hindus will forgo profits from the trade concerning the cow and her products, but never otherwise.
('38', 242, 1, 9, 505840) Religion to be true must satisfy what may be termed humanitarian economics, i.e., where the income and the expenditure balance each other.
('38', 242, 1, 10, 505979) The attainment of such economies is just possible with the cow and the cow only with the assistance of donations for some years from pious Hindus.
('38', 242, 1, 11, 506126) It should be remembered that this great humanitarian attempt is being made in the face of a beef eating world.
('38', 242, 1, 12, 506237) Not till the whole world turns predomi nantly vegetarian is it possible to make any advance upon the limita tions I have sought to describe.
('38', 242, 1, 13, 506378) To succeed to that extent is to open the way, for future generations, to further efforts.
('38', 242, 1, 14, 506468) To overstep the limitation is to consign the cow for ever to the slaughter house in addition to the buffalo and the other animals.
('38', 242, 1, 15, 506599) Hindus and the humanitarian societies in charge of goshalas and pinjrapoles, if they are wisely religious, will bear the foregoing condi tions of cow protection in mind and proceed immediately to give effect to them.
('38', 242, 2, 16, 506816) Young India, 31 3 1927

('38', 243, 6, 8, 507590) NIPANI, Silence Day [March 28, 1927] 2
('38', 243, 7, 9, 507629) MAGANLAL, You must not be alarmed at my illness.
('38', 243, 7, 10, 507678) You should remove the inconveniences to Bhai Bomanji and do nothing more.
('38', 243, 7, 11, 507752) He needs the commode and other things upstairs.
('38', 243, 7, 12, 507800) Mrityunjaya promised to observe discipline, relying on which I suggested that Vidyavati and Prabhavati may he accommodated within the Ashram precincts.
('38', 243, 7, 13, 507952) Do we not ourselves live there?
('38', 243, 7, 14, 507984) I trust Mrityunjaya’s word as much as I trust other persons’.
('38', 243, 7, 15, 508046) He is a very polite and truthful boy.
('38', 243, 7, 16, 508084) He has all of Rajendra Babu’s qualities.
('38', 243, 7, 17, 508125) But you may, of course, accommodate him somewhere else if you want to.
('38', 243, 7, 18, 508196) Why is the Vijapur case hanging fire?

('38', 243, 7, 24, 508393) Write what you can about cow pro tection.
('38', 243, 7, 25, 508435) Let us add no more buffaloes to our stock.
('38', 243, 7, 26, 508478) Read my article 3 in Young India.
('38', 243, 7, 27, 508512) Purushottamdas has expressed an altogether different opinion about the Ramachandra lift.
('38', 243, 7, 28, 508601) Please consider his arguments with patience.
('38', 243, 7, 29, 508646) I hope you have arranged for the spindle and have written to Apte.

('38', 253, 6, 11, 522689) 250. LETTER TO AMRITLAL V. THAKKAR
('38', 253, 7, 12, 522724) AMBOLI, Friday, April 1, 1927
('38', 253, 8, 13, 522754) HIGH PRIEST OF THE LOWLY, My health has tied me down to the bed; yesterday therefore I could go through your [draft] speech from one end to the other.
('38', 253, 8, 14, 522905) A person like me could learn a little from it but it is my humble opinion that as a presidential address it will not do.
('38', 253, 8, 15, 523026) I do not write this in exercise of any right of “veto” that you have conferred on me.
('38', 253, 8, 16, 523112) I am only arguing with you as a friend.
('38', 253, 8, 17, 523152) The speech gives no evidence of a sense of proportion.
('38', 253, 8, 18, 523207) We seem to have lost it.
('38', 253, 8, 19, 523232) Another reason is that it violates the implicit under standing with the Rana Saheb.
('38', 253, 8, 20, 523316) A third reason is that the speech does not suit the kind of audience we are going to muster.
('38', 253, 8, 21, 523409) I say there is no sense of proportion because this speech does not take into account the past convention.
('38', 253, 8, 22, 523515) There is a breach of our implicit understanding with the Rana Saheb that there should be no personal criticism, etc.
('38', 253, 8, 23, 523632) And the speech will be neither appreciated nor read by the sections whom we are at the moment trying to rouse.
('38', 253, 8, 24, 523743) If you follow Gulliver’s Travels and conceive an imaginary country in which to apply your correctives, you could say all that you have said; or if you emulate Aesop you could have a bird of your choice
('38', 254, 0, 1, 523945) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 255
('38', 254, 1, 2, 523988) perched on every tree in Saurashtra to expound your doctrines through their chatter.

('38', 261, 1, 2, 536427) 260. LETTER TO S. D. SATAVALEKAR
('38', 261, 2, 3, 536460) AMBOLI, SAVANTWADI STATE, April 6, 1927
('38', 261, 3, 4, 536500) BHAI SATAVALEKAR, I am confined to a sick bed.
('38', 261, 3, 5, 536547) I could therefore easily get the time to read your book on brahmacharya.
('38', 261, 3, 6, 536620) I liked the book.
('38', 261, 3, 7, 536638) For years I have regarded you as a devotee of truth; hence this letter.
('38', 261, 3, 8, 536710) 1. Do you regard the asanas [postures] as an infallible means to brahmacharya?
('38', 261, 3, 9, 536789) 2. If this is true does it not mean that a man who practises asanas retains his vital fluid under all circumstances?
('38', 261, 3, 10, 536906) Does it also mean that such an aspirant becomes free from passion ?
('38', 261, 3, 11, 536974) You are perhaps aware of a certain process in Western medicine by which a man can retain the fluid but is not freed from passion.
('38', 261, 3, 12, 537104) This method is followed by those who propose to enjoy sex without losing the fluid.
('38', 261, 3, 13, 537188) Do our systems mean this thing when they speak of becoming urdhvareta?
('38', 261, 3, 14, 537259) If it were so, the state of the urdhvareta would be detrimental to pure brahmacharya.
('38', 261, 3, 15, 537345) And then there would be a lurking danger of harm in retaining semen with the help of the asanas.
('38', 261, 3, 16, 537442) A friend from Delhi writes to me saying that with the help of asanas he has attained brahmacharya to such an extent that he can take any kind or quantity of food and enjoy almost all pleasures without losing his vital fluid.
('38', 261, 3, 17, 537667) I did not continue further correspondence with him as I was not impressed by his letter.
('38', 261, 3, 18, 537756) Another friend writes to say that with the help of pranayama 1, asanas and the like the final stage of brahmacharya can be attained within six months.
('38', 261, 3, 19, 537907) Him I know.
('38', 261, 3, 20, 537919) He is a simple straightforward man with no guile.
('38', 261, 3, 21, 537969) And he goes on insisting that I should practise asanas and the like.
('38', 261, 3, 22, 538038) I have not yet acted on his advice but your book has moved me.
('38', 261, 3, 23, 538101) I came in contact with many students and I cannot satisfy them all by my own experiments.
('38', 261, 3, 24, 538191) Besides restrictions of diet, etc., all my experiments are purely psychological.
('38', 261, 3, 25, 538272) I write this as it appears to me that a section of the student community has fallen so low that asanas and the like can [alone] be of any help to them.
('38', 261, 4, 26, 538424) 1 Breath control
('38', 262, 0, 1, 538441) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 263

('38', 262, 1, 4, 538673) I have refuted their arguments with the help of my little experience and by the exercise of whatever talents I have.

('38', 265, 7, 16, 543738) 264. WHAT SHALL I DO?
('38', 265, 8, 17, 543760) The Satyagraha Week has come again.
('38', 265, 8, 18, 543796) By the time this appears in print, one day of the precious week will have gone.
('38', 265, 8, 19, 543876) I would urge the reader not to fritter away the week by asking the question, ‘What shall we do?’, but to make the best possible use of it by asking, ‘What shall I do?’ There was a time when we could usefully ask and did ask the other question.
('38', 265, 8, 20, 544120) And if each one will do his or her duty to the fullest measure possible, we shall soon be able to ask, ‘What shall we do next?’ The foundation of satyagraha as of nation building is undou btedly self purification, self dedication, selflessness.
('38', 265, 8, 21, 544365) Let each one ask oneself: ‘How then can I purify myself in terms of the nation?’ Rectitude of private character is surely the beginning of the structure.
('38', 265, 8, 22, 544519) If my private character is foul, I am like “a sounding brass and tinkling cymbal”.
('38', 265, 8, 23, 544602) If then I am not right inside, I must this very instant purge myself and be a fit vessel for dedication.
('38', 265, 8, 24, 544707) Government cannot
('38', 265, 9, 25, 544725) 1 The addressee’s daughter Mama was ill and passed away in 1927. Vide “Letter to Damodar Lakshmidas” and “Letter to Gangabehn Vaidya”, 10 4 1927.
('38', 266, 0, 1, 544871) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 267
('38', 266, 1, 2, 544914) help me or interfere with me here.
('38', 266, 1, 3, 544949) I must be the sole author of my making or unmaking.
('38', 266, 1, 4, 545001) Having ensured a pure personal character I must ask the next question, what shall I do as a national servant?
('38', 266, 1, 5, 545111) If a Hindu, I hate the Mussalman or a person of another faith, I must at once make an honourable peace with him.
('38', 266, 1, 6, 545224) If I regard any single person as an untouchable, I must blot the sin from my heart and hug the one whom I have hitherto in my arrogance or ignorance regarded as untouchable and as a token I must render him some personal service, be it only going to his quarters and calling the children together and playing with them.
('38', 266, 1, 7, 545543) In these things again, I need no support from the Government and yet in doing these things whole heartedly I have surely brought swaraj nearer for the effort and rendered myself fitter for joint service whenever the occasion arises.
('38', 266, 1, 8, 545776) Is there a drink shop near me?
('38', 266, 1, 9, 545807) I must try to wean an erring brother from going to the house of his own destruction.
('38', 266, 1, 10, 545892) We began this work gloriously in 1921. Our violence brought it to an inglorious end.
('38', 266, 1, 11, 545977) Individual effort in this matter is still possible even though the atmosphere for wholesale mass action is for the moment wanting.
('38', 266, 1, 12, 546108) And last but not least, I must do my share of spinning, if I have but faith in its capacity to serve the poorest, so graphically described in Markham’s words reproduced 1 in last week’s Young India.
('38', 266, 1, 13, 546307) I must hawk Khadi.
('38', 266, 1, 14, 546326) If I have the power, I must induce my neighbour to spin for the sake of Daridranarayana and if he or she wears foreign cloth, I must induce him or her to discard it.
('38', 266, 1, 15, 546492) Shri Vallabhbhai has approached, during this National Week, the Gujaratis living in Kathiawar, Gujarat and in foreign countries for donations for the benefit of the suppressed classes in Gujarat.
('38', 266, 1, 16, 546688) His appeal is for one lakh of rupees to support the activities being carried on at present for the uplift of the depressed classes in Gujarat.
('38', 266, 1, 17, 546831) I would like to enrol myself as Vallabhbhai’s volunteer and move from house to house, begging bowl in hand, to plead with my dear friends to fill it, and also persuade them to enrol themselves as volunteers for the collection, and persuade also school going girls and young women to do likewise, with the permission of their parents, and help in swelling the contents of Vallabhbhai’s purse.
('38', 266, 2, 18, 547223) 1 Under the title, “Whom Khadi Stands for”; vide Appendix ibid, 31 3 1927.
('38', 266, 3, 19, 547298) 2 This paragraph is taken from Navajivan, 10 4 1927.
('38', 267, 0, 1, 547351) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 267, 1, 2, 547393) This is by no means an exhaustive list.
('38', 267, 1, 3, 547433) I have simply given an indication of the enormous possibilities of individual effort.
('38', 267, 1, 4, 547519) Let each one find out for himself or herself the best way of service during this week of privilege.
('38', 267, 1, 5, 547619) The seeker will be amazed to discover in the search after individual action, the immense possibilities of silent, sustained and fruitful common action.
('38', 267, 1, 6, 547771) Let not the immensity of a common programme daze or paralyse us.
('38', 267, 1, 7, 547836) What is true of the individual will be tomorrow true of the whole nation if individuals will but refuse to lose heart and hope.
('38', 267, 2, 8, 547964) Young India, 7 4 1927

('38', 269, 1, 2, 550844) 269. LETTER TO AMRITLAL
('38', 269, 2, 3, 550868) April 8, 1927
('38', 269, 3, 4, 550882) BHAISHRI AMRITLAL, You must have seen my letter 1 to Amritlal Bapa.
('38', 269, 3, 5, 550950) I want you to look into it.
('38', 269, 3, 6, 550978) After all, his speech has been drafted by you.
('38', 269, 3, 7, 551025) I want this matter to be settled purely on the basis of principle.
('38', 269, 3, 8, 551092) We must not let my personal feelings interfere with it.
('38', 269, 3, 9, 551148) And if it is a question of my feelings I am all for what suits the atmosphere in Kathiawar and is ultimately good for its people.
('38', 269, 3, 10, 551278) I am for khadi because I see advantage in it; but how could it prove beneficial if the climate is against it?
('38', 269, 3, 11, 551388) Oxygen is vital for our breathing but what is it to the trees?
('38', 269, 3, 12, 551451) And you all are the life of Kathiawar.
('38', 269, 3, 13, 551490) If I cannot convince you all about a thing, either I should not do it at all or do it in a different way.
('38', 269, 3, 14, 551596) I am aware of your ability.
('38', 269, 3, 15, 551624) I very much appreciate some of the things you do.
('38', 269, 3, 16, 551674) I count you among those serving the motherland.
('38', 269, 3, 17, 551722) You have courage which you should exercise to encourage others and contend with me, if you have to, without hesitation.
('38', 269, 3, 18, 551842) Do what you want to do, not what I want you to.
('38', 269, 3, 19, 551890) That alone will be the right thing.
('38', 269, 3, 20, 551926) Surely we cannot shine in borrowed feathers.
('38', 269, 3, 21, 551971) At the moment I can take no interest in activities other than khadi or similar constructive work.
('38', 269, 3, 22, 552069) Being thus engaged, if I have any more to live, it might some day occur to me to offer battle within the limits of satyagraha and if the struggle does not come off in my own lifetime it will be taken up by such of my successors as can do it.
('38', 269, 3, 23, 552311) Bloody revolutions just do not appeal to me.
('38', 269, 3, 24, 552356) I never wish to kill even a venomous snake, not to speak of a venomous man.
('38', 269, 3, 25, 552432) I know the world has gone in for bloody revolution too for winning freedom.
('38', 269, 3, 26, 552508) I wish to spend all my life trying to prove its futility.
('38', 269, 3, 27, 552566) I take delight in this only and so I never lose patience.
('38', 269, 3, 28, 552624) All the ways that occur to me are but ways of peace.
('38', 269, 3, 29, 552677) That for me is the straight and therefore the shortest path.
('38', 269, 3, 30, 552738) You should lend me your support only if it appeals to you and to those who look to you for guidance; otherwise, it is best to leave me alone as it has been said: “One’s own dharma is superior to” 2, etc.
('38', 269, 3, 31, 552942) Lying in a sick bed, I get more time to think and therefore I am trying to clarify our views and my own.
('38', 269, 4, 32, 553047) BAPU [From Gujarati]

('38', 271, 3, 10, 555120) Does this amount also include the expenditure incurred on our work amongst the Raniparaj community?
('38', 271, 3, 11, 555220) The answer to this question should be that at this stage the work on khadi includes awakening and educating the masses.
('38', 271, 3, 12, 555340) If this is really so, it is part of our policy; and so long as this policy is followed sincerely we should bear with it as an experiment.
('38', 271, 3, 13, 555478) But this is only my view.
('38', 271, 3, 14, 555504) If you enlighten me on this point I shall discuss it with Lakshmidas in case he meets me sooner or when all three of us meet.

('38', 271, 3, 16, 555760) I, therefore, think that we should entrust it to the Charkha Sangh and carry on such work as can be done subject to its rules and regulations.

('38', 271, 3, 19, 555983) Perhaps it had better be merged with the work in Gujarat.
('38', 271, 3, 20, 556041) As it is, I only see this much, that it cannot be carried on as an independent unit.

('38', 271, 3, 22, 556229) In the meanwhile you may look after and promote the work in Kathiawar according to facilities available in the Ashram and keep me informed.
('38', 271, 3, 23, 556369) We should be careful and see that whatever work has been or is being done is not undone.

('38', 271, 3, 25, 556546) Figures of production, at any rate, ought to appear.

('38', 274, 1, 2, 558447) 275. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA Sunday [April 10, 1927] 1
('38', 274, 2, 3, 558505) GANGABEHN, I am not unhappy at Chi.

('38', 279, 5, 11, 567681) 282. FAITH v.
('38', 279, 6, 12, 567695) An M.B.B.S. from Mandalay sends a string of questions of which the first is:
('38', 279, 7, 13, 567772) You once expressed your opinion in the pages of Young India that faith begins
('38', 279, 8, 14, 567850) where reason ends.
('38', 279, 8, 15, 567869) Then I expect you will call it faith, if a person believes in a thing for which he can give no reasons.
('38', 279, 8, 16, 567973) Is it not then clear that faith is believing unreasonably?
('38', 279, 8, 17, 568032) Do you think it is truth or justice if anybody believed in anything unreasonable?
('38', 279, 8, 18, 568114) I think it is folly to believc in that way.
('38', 279, 8, 19, 568158) I do not know what your barrister mind will call it.
('38', 279, 8, 20, 568211) If you think like me I hope you will call faith as nothing but folly.
('38', 279, 8, 21, 568281) If the worthy doctor will excuse my saying so, there is in his question a clear failure to understand my meaning.
('38', 279, 8, 22, 568395) That which is beyond reason is surely not unreasonable.
('38', 279, 8, 23, 568451) Unreasonable belief is blind faith and is often superstition.
('38', 279, 8, 24, 568513) To ask anybody to believe without proof what is capable of proof would be unreasonable, as for instance asking an intelligent person to believe without proof that the sum of the angles of a triangle is equal to two right angles.
('38', 279, 8, 25, 568742) But for an experienced person to ask another to believe without being able to prove that there is God is humbly to confess his limitations and to ask another to accept in faith the statement of his experience.
('38', 279, 8, 26, 568952) It is merely a question of that person’s credibility.
('38', 279, 8, 27, 569006) In ordinary matters of life we accept in faith the word of persons on whom we choose to rely although we are often cheated.
('38', 279, 8, 28, 569130) Why may we not then in matters of life and death accept the testimony of sages all the world over that there is God and that He is to be seen by following Truth and Innocence (non violence)?
('38', 279, 8, 29, 569321) It is at least as reasonable for me to ask my correspondent to have that faith in this universal testimony as it would
('38', 280, 0, 1, 569440) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 281
('38', 280, 1, 2, 569483) be for him to ask me to take his medicine in faith even though many a medicine man might have failed me.
('38', 280, 1, 3, 569588) I make bold to say that without faith this world would come to naught in a moment.
('38', 280, 1, 4, 569671) True faith is appropriation of the reasoned experience of people whom we believe to have lived a life purified by prayer and penance.
('38', 280, 1, 5, 569805) Belief therefore in prophets or incarnations who have lived in remote ages is not an idle superstition but a satisfaction of an inmost, spiritual want.
('38', 280, 1, 6, 569957) The formula therefore I have humbly suggested for guidance is rejection of every demand for faith where a matter is capable of present proof unquestioned acceptance on faith of that which is itself incapable of proof except through personal experience.
('38', 280, 1, 7, 570210) The correspondent’s next question is: 1
('38', 280, 2, 8, 570250) In Young India of December 9, 1926, 2 there appeared a press cutting that one Doctor Harold Blazer, who chloroformed his daughter because he felt that his own end was near and there was no one to care for her when he was gone, was fully acquitted.
('38', 280, 2, 9, 570498) Dr. Blazer’s counsel, Mr. Howry declared: “Blazer did a right and moral thing by keeping the poor girl [for whom he had cared for thirty two years] from becoming a charge on others.” To this you expressed your opinion that Dr. Blazer was wrong in taking the life of his daughter because it betrayed want of faith in the humanity of those round him and that there was no warrant for him to suppose that the daughter would not have been cared for by others....
('38', 280, 2, 10, 570957) I would request you to think over it again, for I think this is not an ordinary matter.
('38', 280, 2, 11, 571045) For it is evident that you have got no scruples to put a useless burden on society simply because you have got enough faith in the society to shoulder the burden.
('38', 280, 2, 12, 571208) For God’s sake please excuse us from believing in that useless, nay, extremely harmful, faith.
('38', 280, 2, 13, 571303) Such a faith of yours, I sincerely believe, is very harmful to the best interests of India....
('38', 280, 2, 14, 571398) If after many more years of faithful service of India, you become .
('38', 280, 2, 15, 571466) absolutely useless to society, will you like the society to feed you because you have got still life left in you or because you served so well?
('38', 280, 2, 16, 571610) I do believe that whilst the jury was right in acquitting Dr. Blazer, considered from the strictly moral point of view Dr. Blazer was wrong.
('38', 280, 2, 17, 571751) My correspondent in his utilitarian zeal has overlooked the frightful consequences and implications of the doctrine he lays down.
('38', 280, 2, 18, 571881) Indeed his doctrine would belie his own profession.
('38', 280, 2, 19, 571933) What would he say if a young practitioner chloroformed to death a patient whom he, the junior practitioner, considered to be incurable and therefore a useless burden to society and whom another as a senior subsequently found to be a case quite capable of cure ?
('38', 280, 2, 20, 572195) Is it not the boast of
('38', 280, 3, 21, 572218) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('38', 280, 3, 22, 572255) 2 Vide “The Greatest Good of All”, 9 12 1926.
('38', 281, 0, 1, 572301) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 281, 1, 2, 572343) medical science to treat no case as finally incurable?
('38', 281, 1, 3, 572398) As for myself, well, I do expect my countrymen to support me when I become a useless and burdensome article, assuming of course that I shall still want to live.
('38', 281, 1, 4, 572559) What is more, I have full faith in my countrymen suppor ting me if that event comes to pass.
('38', 281, 1, 5, 572652) I wonder whether my corres pondent will have all the lepers, the blind, the deaf, one fine night to be chloroformed to sweet, everlasting sleep.
('38', 281, 1, 6, 572797) And yet Damien was a leper and Milton was a blind poet.
('38', 281, 1, 7, 572853) Man is not all body but he is something infinitely higher.
('38', 281, 1, 8, 572912) The correspondent’s third question is: 1
('38', 281, 2, 9, 572953) In the same article, i.e., “The Greatest Good of all”, you wrote that a votary of ahimsa cannot subscribe to the utilitarian formula.
('38', 281, 2, 10, 573087) He will strive for the greatest good of all and die in the attempt to realize the ideal .
('38', 281, 2, 11, 573177) May I conclude then that you will prefer to be bitten by a poisonous snake and die rather than kill the same in trying to save yourself?
('38', 281, 2, 12, 573314) If I am right in my conclusion, .
('38', 281, 2, 13, 573348) that way you will be doing the greatest possible harm to India by trying to save a harmful living creature and by dying willingly in trying to realize the ideal of your so called greatest good of all .
('38', 281, 2, 14, 573550) You admit that you are an imperfect mortal.
('38', 281, 2, 15, 573594) So it is impossible for you to benefit the whole world.
('38', 281, 2, 16, 573650) It is even impossible for you to benefit the whole of India in all possible ways.
('38', 281, 2, 17, 573732) Therefore it is quite reasonable to be contented with the greatest good of the greatest number rather than pretend to do the greatest good to all without exception the good and the wicked, the useful and the useless, man, animal, etc., etc.
('38', 281, 2, 18, 573973) This is a question I would fain avoid answering, not because of want of faith but because of want of courage.
('38', 281, 2, 19, 574083) But I must not conceal my faith even though I may not have the courage to act up to it when it is put on its trial.
('38', 281, 2, 20, 574199) Here then is my answer.
('38', 281, 2, 21, 574223) I do not want to live at the cost of the life even of a snake.
('38', 281, 2, 22, 574286) I should let him bite me to death rather than kill him.
('38', 281, 2, 23, 574342) But it is likely that if God puts me to that cruel test and permits a snake to assault me, I may not have the courage to die, but that the beast in me may assert itself and I may seek to kill the snake in defending this perishable body.
('38', 281, 2, 24, 574579) I admit that my belief has not yet become so incarnate in me as to warrant my stating emphatically that I have shed all fear of snakes so as to befriend them as I would like to be able to.
('38', 281, 2, 25, 574768) It is my implicit belief that snakes, tigers, etc., are God’s answer to the poisonous, wicked, evil thoughts that we harbour.
('38', 281, 2, 26, 574894) Anna Kingsford saw in the streets of Paris tigers in men already taking shape.
('38', 281, 2, 27, 574973) I believe that all life is one.
('38', 281, 2, 28, 575005) Thoughts take definite forms.
('38', 281, 2, 29, 575035) Tigers and snakes have kinship with us.
('38', 281, 2, 30, 575075) They are a
('38', 281, 3, 31, 575086) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('38', 282, 0, 1, 575123) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 283
('38', 282, 1, 2, 575166) warning to us to avoid harbouring evil, wicked, lustful thoughts.
('38', 282, 1, 3, 575232) If I want to rid the earth of venomous beasts and reptiles, I must rid myself of all venomous thoughts.
('38', 282, 1, 4, 575336) I shall not do so if in my impatient ignorance and in my desire to prolong the existence of the body I seek to kill the so called venomous beasts and reptiles.
('38', 282, 1, 5, 575496) If in not seeking to defend myself against such noxious animals I die, I should die to rise again a better and a fuller man.
('38', 282, 1, 6, 575621) With that faith in me how should I seek to kill a fellow being in a snake?
('38', 282, 1, 7, 575696) But this is philosophy.
('38', 282, 1, 8, 575720) Let me pray and let my readers join in the prayer to God that He may give me the strength to live up to that philosophy.
('38', 282, 1, 9, 575841) For philosophy without life corresponding is like a body without life.
('38', 282, 1, 10, 575912) I know that in this land of ours we have enouh phiosophy and but little life.
('38', 282, 1, 11, 575990) But I know also that the laws governing the conduct of man have still to be explored and the condition of exploration is imperative and unalterable.
('38', 282, 1, 12, 576139) We shall explore them only by dying, never by killing.
('38', 282, 1, 13, 576194) We must become living embodiments of Truth and Love, for God is Truth and Love.
('38', 282, 2, 14, 576274) Young India, 14 4 1927
('38', 282, 3, 15, 576297) 283. CIVILIZATION AND CULTURE
('38', 282, 4, 16, 576327) Dr. Martin Hurlimann, a Sanskrit scholar of Zurich, sends the following instructive translation of selections 1 from the writings of Heinrich Pestalozzi who died just a century ago and was according to Dr. Hurlimann “one of Europe’s greatest educationists as also one of the greatest among fighters for Menschlichkeit and Menschenwurde, i.e., humanity and dignity of man but not understood on the Continent and almost unknown to the rest of the world”.

('38', 283, 1, 2, 576867) 284. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('38', 283, 2, 3, 576905) AMBOLI, April 14, 1927
('38', 283, 3, 4, 576928) DEAR BROTHER, Your letter has given me boundless joy.
('38', 283, 3, 5, 576982) The news will cheer our people and Andrews.
('38', 283, 3, 6, 577026) And Europeans will be glad to have to do with one whom they have come to know and respect.
('38', 283, 3, 7, 577117) For me your letter is a great relief.
('38', 283, 3, 8, 577155) And for your health God will take care of it.
('38', 283, 3, 9, 577201) Freedom from the turmoil into which our country has landed itself will refresh your tired nerves whilst at the same time you will be doing inestimable service to the country.
('38', 283, 3, 10, 577376) The present confusion does not admit of much hurry and calculated interference.
('38', 283, 3, 11, 577456) It will settle itself in due time.
('38', 283, 3, 12, 577491) Mrs. Sastri will be of great help to you in South Africa and her presence will mean much to our dumb sisters there.
('38', 283, 3, 13, 577607) I expect to reach Nandi Hills on Wednesday next.
('38', 283, 3, 14, 577656) You will please come whenever you can and like.
('38', 283, 4, 15, 577704) Yours sincerely,
('38', 283, 5, 16, 577721) M. K. GANDHI
('38', 283, 6, 17, 577734) V. S. Srinivasa Sastri Papers (Correspondence No.
('38', 283, 6, 18, 577784) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('38', 283, 7, 19, 577821) 285. LETTER TO S. D. SATAVALEKAR
('38', 283, 8, 20, 577854) AMBOLI, April 14, 1927
('38', 283, 9, 21, 577877) BHAI SATAVALEKAR, I thank you for your prompt reply.
('38', 283, 9, 22, 577930) I shall try and send you a good student.
('38', 283, 9, 23, 577971) From the consideration you have been showing me I see that you are treating me as a fellow seeker.
('38', 283, 9, 24, 578070) I shall certainly try to become one.
('38', 283, 9, 25, 578107) I read your book on the Isopanishad and was extremely pleased.
('38', 283, 9, 26, 578170) I shall write to Bhai Bapulal 1 in connection with Brahmacharya and Suryabhedan Vyayam.
('38', 283, 9, 27, 578258) He must not suffer any financial loss.
('38', 283, 10, 28, 578297) 1 Bapulal Kuberdas Patel of the Arya Samaj, Anand, Kheda District, publisher of the addressee’s books
('38', 284, 0, 1, 578399) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 285
('38', 284, 1, 2, 578442) I am acquainted with Kuvalayanandji.
('38', 284, 1, 3, 578479) I had sent a young boy to him who being weak was not taught pranayama and other disciplines but was instead treated with medicines.
('38', 284, 1, 4, 578611) Despite the prevailing climate I have not lost hope regarding the practice of brahmacharya, etc.
('38', 284, 1, 5, 578708) There will rise from our midst a true aspirant who will clear the prevailing atmosphere.
('38', 284, 1, 6, 578797) As yet I have come across no such aspirant.
('38', 284, 1, 7, 578841) My own tapascharya is hopelessly imperfect.
('38', 284, 1, 8, 578885) I have been observing external, physical brahmacharya for nearly 30 years.
('38', 284, 1, 9, 578960) I have, however, not freed myself from passion; I am trying to.
('38', 284, 1, 10, 579024) I think complete control of all the five sense organs is essential for the observance of perfect brahmacharya.
('38', 284, 1, 11, 579135) It will not suffice to have control over the six fold passion 1; it has to be rooted out.
('38', 284, 1, 12, 579225) I believe in every word of the verse: “The yearning too departs when he beholds the Supreme.” 2 The world is prone to hero worship.
('38', 284, 1, 13, 579357) The unhealthy climate prevailing around will soon clear when such a person emerges.
('38', 284, 1, 14, 579441) Let us work with all our faith for the advent of such a person amidst us.
('38', 284, 1, 15, 579515) And have not you yourself said that if the message of the Upanishads, etc., is eternally true—and so it is —even today we can come across Uma, Hemavati and Yaksha and, God willing, we shall.
('38', 284, 1, 16, 579706) I too have read about rubbing in semen and consuming it.
('38', 284, 1, 17, 579763) 3 I regard this as a demoniac practice.
('38', 284, 1, 18, 579803) There may be some truth in it but the experiment deserves no consideration, because we want the brahmacharis to master their senses.
('38', 284, 1, 19, 579936) Preserving and retaining the vital fluid is a means to an end and not an end in itself.
('38', 284, 1, 20, 580024) Consuming semen does not bring about freedom from passion; it might to some extent remove the debility consequent upon ejaculation.
('38', 284, 1, 21, 580156) This is what the Western method achieves.
('38', 284, 1, 22, 580198) ‘The root cause of seminal discharge lies in the rising of passion, [And] we aim at annihilating all passion.
('38', 284, 1, 23, 580308) That is why I enquired about the asanas, etc, Now I understand that asanas, etc., are a stage on the way [to brahmacharya] and it may be deemed necessary for the aspirant to pass through them.
('38', 284, 1, 24, 580501) Have I made myself clear ?
('38', 284, 1, 25, 580528) I have understood what you say in your book about the asanas for retaining semen.
('38', 284, 1, 26, 580610) Your cautions put one on guard.
('38', 284, 1, 27, 580642) Even for a
('38', 284, 2, 28, 580653) 1 Desire, anger, avarice, delusion, pride, envy 2 Bhagavad Gita, II.
('38', 284, 3, 29, 580722) 3 The addressee had referred to an ancient Sanskrit text which says that semen from involuntary ejaculation should be rubbed between the breasts or the brows, or consumed orally.
('38', 285, 0, 1, 580901) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 285, 1, 2, 580943) married man I see no harm in the siddha and other asanas.
('38', 285, 1, 3, 581001) With the help of siddhasana a married man’s semen may possibly be retained, the secretion however does not stop.
('38', 285, 1, 4, 581114) How many men can we come across today who go to their wives purely for the sake of progeny?
('38', 285, 1, 5, 581206) If the term ‘calming down’ can be used of passion etc., a married man may calm down his passion with the help of siddha and other asanas.
('38', 285, 1, 6, 581344) But then it is another thing if his aim is absolute eradication of desire.
('38', 285, 1, 7, 581419) I was relieved to find that you do not reject the Puranas.
('38', 285, 1, 8, 581478) I was afraid you would be disdainful of the ancient Puranas.
('38', 285, 1, 9, 581539) Indeed I am convinced that at a time when people were growing sceptical the authors of the Puranas aroused in them a love for dharma with their rich poetic appeal, Our Shastras need to be re interpreted as you are doing, in the light of modern knowledge and for the young people of today.
('38', 285, 1, 10, 581828) When I am settled somewhere I would like to give you the trouble of coming over to me so that we can compare notes.
('38', 285, 1, 11, 581944) I am now reading the Kenopanishad after which I shall take up your Mahabharata Samalochana 1.

('38', 287, 12, 18, 585078) [April 17, 1927] 3
('38', 287, 13, 19, 585097) His Highness and the Rani came to see Gandhiji on the day before we left Amboli.
('38', 287, 13, 20, 585178) They were as usual very nice and asked if it was not too late to persuade Gandhiji to stay a little longer at Amboli.
('38', 287, 13, 21, 585296) Gandhiji said he wished very much he could continue his stay in that scented spot surrounded by picturesque scenery, in fact, he was distressed to leave it, but he could not help it as he wanted to combine rest with work.
('38', 287, 13, 22, 585518) And then Gandhiji proceeded to ask the questions I had not asked the other day.

('38', 288, 8, 26, 587573) The furniture in her room was as severely simple as could be.
('38', 288, 8, 27, 587635) I was introduced to the young Maharaja whom it was difficult to recognize as such.
('38', 288, 8, 28, 587718) But there the comparison ends.
('38', 288, 8, 29, 587749) They do not live on paltry wages like you.
('38', 288, 9, 30, 587792) The Rani smiled thankfully, whilst Gandhiji continued: And I was not surprised at the small quantity of khadi that you purchased, knowing as I did that your means were limited and that you must live within your income.

('38', 289, 3, 7, 588619) 291. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('38', 289, 4, 8, 588643) April 18, 1927
('38', 289, 5, 9, 588658) MIRA, I have your letters.
('38', 289, 5, 10, 588685) You must not put yourself under over strain.
('38', 289, 5, 11, 588730) If the teaching overtaxes you, it must be reduced and so the learning.
('38', 289, 5, 12, 588801) You may make it clear to the people about you as to your physical capacity.
('38', 289, 5, 13, 588877) On no account must you lose your health.
('38', 289, 5, 14, 588918) Do you get proper fruit and milk?
('38', 289, 5, 15, 588952) I am getting on famously.
('38', 289, 5, 16, 588978) For the last two days I have been taking walks both morning and evening without suffering any harm., As you know I have replaced one fruit with a vegetable and am taking bhakhari.
('38', 289, 5, 17, 589158) We leave Amboli today and leave Belgaum tomorrow if all goes well.
('38', 289, 5, 18, 589225) Nandi Hills, Mysore, will be the address for the next two months.
('38', 289, 5, 19, 589291) I shall not leave this place without much regret.
('38', 289, 5, 20, 589341) The spot itself is delightful.
('38', 289, 5, 21, 589372) But what has attached me to this place is the exceptional character of the Chief.
('38', 289, 5, 22, 589454) From all the accounts received by me he appears to be an ideal Chief.
('38', 289, 5, 23, 589524) He draws a fixed sum from the State revenue for his personal expenses.
('38', 289, 5, 24, 589595) He mixes freely with his people.
('38', 289, 5, 25, 589628) He has visited every one of his 125 villages.
('38', 289, 5, 26, 589674) He lives an abstemious life and his wife is worthy of him.
('38', 289, 5, 27, 589733) I have met him often and his frank and easy manners have pleased me.
('38', 289, 5, 28, 589802) Hence it is that I like this place so much.
('38', 289, 5, 29, 589846) But we can’t do always the things we like.
('38', 289, 5, 30, 589889) We shall be leaving inside of a few hours.
('38', 289, 5, 31, 589932) I expect a report of the new charkha.
('38', 289, 5, 32, 589970) They seem to have worked wonders at the Ashram.
('38', 289, 5, 33, 590018) Keshu having spun over 15,000 yards in 24 hours.
('38', 289, 5, 34, 590067) With love,

('38', 291, 5, 13, 592550) 294. LETTER TO KUVALAYANAND
('38', 291, 6, 14, 592578) NANDI HILLS, MYSORE, April 19,1927
('38', 291, 7, 15, 592613) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter to Baba Saheb Soman offering to come to Mysore at once if necessary and in any case after 26th if required.
('38', 291, 7, 16, 592762) I would like you to come to Nandi Hills as soon as possible after 26th.
('38', 291, 7, 17, 592834) If you will kindly send a wire, arrangements will be made to bring you to Nandi Hills from the nearest station.
('38', 291, 7, 18, 592946) The growing self abuse among the students has, as you know, attracted me to the yogic asanas, as possible cure of the evil habit.
('38', 291, 7, 19, 593076) In the course of my reading I saw that asanas were recommended as a remedy for the cure of many other ills.
('38', 291, 7, 20, 593184) During my illness I read Pandit Satavalekar’s writings.
('38', 291, 7, 21, 593240) And I thought that I would experiment with myself.
('38', 291, 7, 22, 593291) Copious laudatory notices of shirshasana drew me to it.
('38', 291, 7, 23, 593347) And for the last five days I have been trying shirshasana for a few seconds each time.
('38', 291, 7, 24, 593434) I do it in the morning before the meal twice at intervals of two minutes.
('38', 291, 7, 25, 593508) The practice is preceded by neti, cleansing the nostrils by means of strips of thin cloth.
('38', 291, 7, 26, 593599) I remain absolutely passive during the practice of the asana.
('38', 291, 7, 27, 593661) Gunaji assists to lift the body and sustain it on the head.

('38', 291, 7, 29, 593758) before retiring.
