('38', 294, 4, 9, 598841) 297. TRUTH IS ONE
('38', 294, 5, 10, 598859) A Polish Professor writes:
('38', 294, 6, 11, 598886) I am reading with intense joy your fascinating articles in Young India and wish to impress upon you the truth that they are the source of power not only for your own country but for the world.
('38', 294, 6, 12, 599079) And as you have such a wide spiritual experience, may I ask you one question to be answered if possible in Young India?
('38', 294, 6, 13, 599199) It is a very important fundamental question to which an answer from you would have a great value.
('38', 294, 6, 14, 599297) Do you admit that there is in human thought some absolute certainty, as for instance as to God and prayer, where we might be said to have reached perfect unchangeable truth ?
('38', 294, 6, 15, 599472) Do you also confess that some particular experience led you to change your first opinion, for instance, as to the right of killing certain dangerous animals?
('38', 294, 6, 16, 599630) Now my fundamental question is, on what particular points do you change your opinion?
('38', 294, 6, 17, 599716) And what guarantee can these changes leave as to the unshaken truth of what remains certain ?
('38', 294, 6, 18, 599810) How can we distinguish opportunistic change of opinion from the permanence of an absolute certainty in essentials?
('38', 294, 6, 19, 599925) Can you define in what things we may change and what kind of things remain unchangeable?
('38', 294, 6, 20, 600014) Is independence of each country or people one of those absolute truths, or is there some innate incapacity in some nations for self government and in others an innate capacity for governing such incapable nations, as the Ger mans profess to have a capacity for governing other nations and thus justify their ruling ambition?
('38', 294, 6, 21, 600339) I have taken the liberty of altering a word here and there in this letter for the purpose of making the writer’s meaning clearer than it appears to be to me in the original.
('38', 294, 6, 22, 600513) Without in any shape or form endorsing the claim to the powers that the writer ascribes to me, I
('38', 294, 7, 23, 600610) 1 What follows is from Navajivan, 24 4 1927.
('38', 295, 0, 1, 600655) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 295, 1, 2, 600697) would in all humility endeavour to answer his questions.
('38', 295, 1, 3, 600754) My own conscious claim is very simple and emphatic.
('38', 295, 1, 4, 600806) I am a humble but very earnest seeker after truth.
('38', 295, 1, 5, 600857) And in my search, I take all fellow seekers in uttermost confidence so that I may know my mistakes and correct them.
('38', 295, 1, 6, 600974) I confess that I have often erred in my estimates and judgments.
('38', 295, 1, 7, 601039) As for instance, whereas I thought from insufficient data that the people of Kheda were ready for civil disobedience, I suddenly discovered that I had committed a Himalayan miscalculation and saw that they could not offer civil disobedience inasmuch as they had not known what it was to tender willing obedience to laws which might be even considered irksome but not immoral.
('38', 295, 1, 8, 601415) Immediately I made the discovery, I retraced my steps.
('38', 295, 1, 9, 601470) A similar error of judgment was committed by me when I presented what has been described as the Bardoli ultimatum.
('38', 295, 1, 10, 601585) 1 I had then believed that the country, that is the people, had been awakened and touched by the movement, had understood the utility of nonviolence.
('38', 295, 1, 11, 601735) I discovered my error within twenty four hours of the delivery of the ultimatum and retraced my steps.
('38', 295, 1, 12, 601838) And inasmuch as in every case I retraced my steps, no permanent harm was done.
('38', 295, 1, 13, 601917) On the contrary, the fundamental truth of non violence has been made infinitely more manifest than it ever has been, and the country has in no way been permanently injured.
('38', 295, 1, 14, 602090) But I am not aware of having changed my opinion about the necessity of killing certain dangerous animals in certain circumstances specifically mentioned in my articles 2. So far as I am aware of my own opinions, I have ever held the opinion expressed by me in those articles.
('38', 295, 1, 15, 602366) That however does not mean that the opinion is unchange able.
('38', 295, 1, 16, 602428) I claim to have no infallible guidance or inspiration.
('38', 295, 1, 17, 602483) So far as my experience goes, the claim to infallibility on the part of a human being would be untenable, seeing that inspiration too can come only to one who is free from the action of pairs of opposites, and it will be difficult to judge on a given occasion whether the claim to freedom from pairs of opposites is justified.
('38', 295, 1, 18, 602810) The claim to infallibility would thus always be a most dangerous claim to make.
('38', 295, 1, 19, 602890) This however does not leave us without any guidance whatsoever.
('38', 295, 1, 20, 602954) The sum total of the experience of the sages of the world is available to us and would be for all time to come.
('38', 295, 1, 21, 603066) Moreover, there are not many fundamental truths, but there is only one fundamental truth which is Truth itself,
('38', 295, 2, 22, 603178) 1 Vide “Letter to Viceroy”, 1 2 1922.
('38', 295, 3, 23, 603216) 2 Under the caption “Is This Humanity?”.
('38', 296, 0, 1, 603257) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 297
('38', 296, 1, 2, 603300) otherwise known as Non violence.
('38', 296, 1, 3, 603333) Finite human being shall never know in its fulness Truth and Love which is in itself infinite.
('38', 296, 1, 4, 603428) But we do know enough for our guidance.
('38', 296, 1, 5, 603468) We shall err, and sometimes grievously, in our application.
('38', 296, 1, 6, 603528) But man is a self governing being, and self government necessarily includes the power as much to commit errors as to set them right as often as they are made.
('38', 296, 1, 7, 603687) I do not know whether this will satisfy my correspondent.
('38', 296, 1, 8, 603745) But whether it does or not, I have no power in me to give him a more satisfactory answer.
('38', 296, 1, 9, 603835) After all each one must be a law unto himself, the invariable condition being that he must then walk in the fear of God and therefore continually keep on purifying his heart.
('38', 296, 1, 10, 604010) A man to be a man must be twice born as Hindus would say, reborn as Christians would say.
('38', 296, 1, 11, 604100) The concluding questions of the correspondent are easily answered.
('38', 296, 1, 12, 604167) In fact, the answers can be inferred from the foregoing remarks.
('38', 296, 1, 13, 604232) I do think that independence of each country is a truth in the same sense and to the same extent that independence of each man is.
('38', 296, 1, 14, 604363) There is, therefore, no inherent incapacity for self government in any country or nation and therefore no inherent capacity for governing other nations.
('38', 296, 1, 15, 604516) No doubt my correspondent honestly thinks that Germans profess to have a God given capacity for ruling over other nations.
('38', 296, 1, 16, 604639) But if there are German imperialists, there are also humble German democrats, who are content if they can quietly govern them selves.

('38', 296, 3, 18, 604796) 298. KHADI STORES

('38', 296, 4, 23, 605375) And why should it be surprising or unthinkable to have khadi as universal as grain or ghee?

('38', 296, 5, 25, 605496) 1 Not reproduced here
('38', 297, 0, 1, 605518) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 297, 1, 2, 605560) khadi must be unthinkable, why should it be unthinkable to have, say twenty years hence, as many shops for Australian butter and American wheat as we have today for our own ghee and wheat?
('38', 297, 1, 3, 605749) If it is patriotic enough to buy foreign cloth because it is cheaper or more pleasant to the eye, why will it not be patriotic enough, when that time comes, to buy cheaper foreign butter and foreign wheat, even though our ghee manufacturers and wheat growers may become idle and starve for want of other occupations to take the place of the lost ones?
('38', 297, 1, 4, 606101) These are reflections presented for the edification of wearers of foreign cloth.
('38', 297, 1, 5, 606182) But what is the lesson these stores teach us, khadi organisers?
('38', 297, 1, 6, 606246) In my opinion, by honest and able organization, we can create a universal demand for khadi, (a) if those who are engaged in khadi production will pay attention to the manufacture of stronger and more even yarn equal at least to the mill spun yarn; (b) if they will also study the tastes of the people and produce sufficient variety of khadi; (c) if by efficiency in other directions they bring down the price of khadi; (d) if those who are engaged in the distribution of khadi will gain greater knowledge of the tastes of the people and will learn the art of selling; (e) if both the producers and the sellers will realize that they must give the maximum of efficiency with the minimum of wages and that self sacrifice is the one imperative condition of successful organiza tion of khadi on a universal basis.
('38', 297, 1, 7, 607056) I note that private depots assume names after their owners or some other name.
('38', 297, 1, 8, 607135) For greater convenience, I would suggest their having one name—simple Khadi Bhandar or Vastralaya, with A.I.S.A. or Congress or Private as the case may be in parenthesis.
('38', 297, 1, 9, 607306) Where there are more than one in the same place they may have consecutive numbers.
('38', 297, 1, 10, 607389) This is desirable so long as khadi has to be organized and nursed and so long as the various depots are either directly owned by the A.I.S.A. or are certified by and affiliated to it.

('38', 301, 1, 2, 613130) Government is not sincere, that the people have really no hand in the matter, and that the transfer of excise revenue to the elected representatives is itself proof of the Government’s insincerity.

('38', 301, 1, 5, 613475) If the accredited representatives shut up liquor shops, they must starve education or impose fresh taxation upon a people who are in no way able to bear the weight even of existing taxation.
('38', 301, 1, 6, 613666) The remedy, therefore, is, if the position stated above is correct, for the Government to keep the excise department themselves and carry the prohibition policy through and recoup themselves for the loss of revenue by cutting down the military budget.
('38', 301, 1, 7, 613918) They have as much right to raise revenue through liquor as they would have to raise revenue through legalized prostitution.
('38', 301, 1, 8, 614042) If this is your position independently of me and if you can support the position by your own study of facts, figures and other literature, your resolution would run thus: In the opinion of this meeting it is wrong for the people of this country to be party to the maintenance of the liquor traffic in India and that therefore it was wrong on the part of the Government to have made the liquor revenue of India a ‘transferred’ (provincial) subject and consequently a principal source of revenue on which the spending departments of education and development have to depend, thereby rendering it practically impossible for the Ministers responsible for these departments to undertake a policy of prohibition.
('38', 301, 1, 9, 614749) In the opinion of this meeting the Government of India should have retained the Liquor Revenue as a Central subject and carried out a policy of complete prohibition, the loss of revenue thus sustained being made up for, by retrenchment in the ever growing and largely unnecessary military expenditure.
('38', 301, 1, 10, 615051) This meeting therefore calls upon the Government to take the steps necessary to enforce the wish expressed in this resolution.
('38', 301, 1, 11, 615178) You may lick the resolution into shape in any manner you like so long as you retain the substance of it unimpaired.
('38', 301, 1, 12, 615294) I fear that you will find it difficult to carry through the resolution of this character.
('38', 301, 1, 13, 615384) But really it is the only thing worth having.
('38', 301, 1, 14, 615430) And if you find that there is no atmosphere yet in England for such a drastic resolution—and I admit that it is drastic—merely put your case before the educated public, and wait for the resolution.

('38', 308, 11, 24, 626790) 311. LETTER TO R. B. GREGG
('38', 308, 12, 25, 626817) NANDI HILLS, April 26, 1927
('38', 308, 13, 26, 626845) MY DEAR GOVIND, Do not be alarmed.
('38', 308, 13, 27, 626880) Though I reply to your letter so promptly, it is not by way of courtesy, but for pleasure; for, I do not yield to you
('38', 309, 0, 1, 626998) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 309, 1, 2, 627040) in my zeal for dietetic reform.
('38', 309, 1, 3, 627072) Only my lot having been during the last 20 years cast in a rigid mould, I have not been able to wriggle out of it in spite of my intense desire to prosecute dietetic research.
('38', 309, 1, 4, 627248) But now that nature had laid me low, the appetite which was never eradicated, but was only under suppression, has become active and I go for everything in this direction with avidity.
('38', 309, 1, 5, 627432) Now to the point.
('38', 309, 1, 6, 627450) For the last two days I have made one impor tant change prompted by a fellow crank.
('38', 309, 1, 7, 627534) He suggested my taking the juice of fresh neem leaves by mixing it with milk.
('38', 309, 1, 8, 627612) He says my case is not one of blood pressure but of flatulence.
('38', 309, 1, 9, 627676) Blood pressure there certainly is; but I am inclined to agree with this friend, that blood pressure is a temporary effect of flatulence which is the root cause, and he thinks I could deal with the latter by taking the juice of neem leaves with my meals.
('38', 309, 1, 10, 627930) These leaves are bitter.
('38', 309, 1, 11, 627955) He says they contain the necessary vitamins.
('38', 309, 1, 12, 628000) I am watching their effect now.
('38', 309, 1, 13, 628032) Your letter was received yesterday and the change I have made today is to take unboiled milk.
('38', 309, 1, 14, 628126) This was suggested by some medical friends at Amboli.
('38', 309, 1, 15, 628180) But I was not responsive.
('38', 309, 1, 16, 628206) But your letter has evoked the necessary response.
('38', 309, 1, 17, 628257) My hosts have brought some goats on to this hill and they are milked under supervision.
('38', 309, 1, 18, 628345) Milk was therefore brought this morning fresh from the udders.
('38', 309, 1, 19, 628408) It was mixed with neem leaves juice and hot raisin water was added to the milk.
('38', 309, 1, 20, 628488) This in accordance with your letter gives me the vitamins from the milk and in accor dance with that friend gives me the vitamins from the neem leaves.
('38', 309, 1, 21, 628640) I am therefore at the present moment omitting fresh vegetables because I am not yet satisfied that these vegetables are necessary especially as I am taking those bitter leaves and unboiled milk.
('38', 309, 1, 22, 628835) At what point are vitamins destroyed when you boil leafy vegetables ?
('38', 309, 1, 23, 628905) What is the virtue of vitamins?
('38', 309, 1, 24, 628937) What is the quantity of leafy vegetables one should take in order to get the required measure of vitamins?
('38', 309, 1, 25, 629044) What quantity of unboiled milk will give the vitamins required?
('38', 309, 1, 26, 629108) Is it true that mere heating the milk does not destroy vitamins?
('38', 309, 1, 27, 629173) Or they are only des troyed when milk is brought to the boiling point?
('38', 309, 1, 28, 629244) I have tried the nuts in the manner you suggest.
('38', 309, 1, 29, 629293) I had them reduced to butter.
('38', 309, 1, 30, 629323) The pulp was as fine as butter.
('38', 309, 1, 31, 629355) I had almonds turned into milk.
('38', 309, 1, 32, 629387) But I could not cope with it, no matter how far you pulverized the nuts.
('38', 309, 1, 33, 629460) They must, it appears, pass through the double process of digestion like all non flesh foods.
('38', 309, 1, 34, 629554) It is only animal food which does not tax the large intestines.
('38', 309, 1, 35, 629618) Before nuts, therefore, can
('38', 310, 0, 1, 629646) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 311
('38', 310, 1, 2, 629689) attain the digestibility of milk, the first process of digestion must be gone through outside the human system.
('38', 310, 1, 3, 629801) I was told when I was in London, that melted nuts had that effect.
('38', 310, 1, 4, 629868) I do not know how far this is true.
('38', 310, 1, 5, 629904) I want to succeed in non milk experiment because I am convinced that milk, apart from mother’s milk, is not human food, nor is cooking essential.
('38', 310, 1, 6, 630050) A perfect food therefore for human needs has yet to be found.
('38', 310, 1, 7, 630112) From the spiritual stand point, I have a horror of animal milk, and that it is goat’s milk I am taking does not lessen the horror.
('38', 310, 1, 8, 630243) It merely enables me to respect the letter of my vow, though I know that the spirit of it is hardly kept if not already broken.
('38', 310, 1, 9, 630371) I have reconciled myself to goat’s milk under the delusive belief that I must have for my work on the earth in this body and so I cling to it at the expense of my innermost conviction.
('38', 310, 1, 10, 630556) He, therefore, who can wean me from milk, will be in a way a deliverer.
('38', 310, 1, 11, 630628) There are spiritual experiences which I know have been interrupted because of my taking milk.
('38', 310, 1, 12, 630722) When I was living rigidly on sun baked fruits and sun baked nuts without using fire and this was for several years—the animal passion was not merely under conscious subjection and control, but it was, so far as my memory serves me, thoroughly absent and I believe that I had almost entirely conquered it.
('38', 310, 1, 13, 631027) All that has been changed since my return to milk diet.
('38', 310, 1, 14, 631083) I can no longer claim that immunity.
('38', 310, 1, 15, 631120) I can only say in all humility that though I am conscious of that passion, I can keep it under subjection and appear before the world a respectable human being from whose lust no woman need fear.
('38', 310, 1, 16, 631316) But it cost me all my strength to keep the brute in me under disciplined subjection and control.
('38', 310, 1, 17, 631413) I am positive that a full grown man does not need all that effort to keep his passions under check.
('38', 310, 1, 18, 631513) On the contrary, the energy that set free when the passions are kept under control can, if he wishes, be transferred into unconquerable power for the good of mankind.
('38', 310, 1, 19, 631680) But somehow or other, I fancy that I shall never attain that freedom, that personal swaraj, so long as I have to struggle against the effect of the highly exciting unnatural food; whereas, nuts are fine muscle builders without being stimulants in the sense in which I have used them.
('38', 310, 1, 20, 631964) Now you can understand why I reply to your letter so promptly.
('38', 310, 1, 21, 632027) It is a great pity that you have not yet got rid of your piles.

('38', 317, 9, 20, 644240) 318. UNTOUCHABILITY AND UNREASON
('38', 317, 10, 21, 644273) A correspondent from Mahad writes:
('38', 317, 11, 22, 644308) It gives me much sorrow to let you know that there was a riot on the 20th of March last between touchables and untouchables at Mahad.
('38', 317, 11, 23, 644442) There was held a conference of the Colaba District depressed classes on the 19th and 20th ultimo.
('38', 317, 11, 24, 644540) The meeting was quite successful.
('38', 317, 11, 25, 644574) But whilst the crowd was dispersing, Mr. A. V. Chitre of the Social Service League of Bombay told the people as they were thirsty and as the sun was very hot that they could go to the public tank and drink water.
('38', 317, 11, 26, 644787) There were some who tried to dissuade the men from going to the tank.
('38', 317, 11, 27, 644857) But Dr. Ambedkar the president decided to march the men to the tank.
('38', 317, 11, 28, 644926) Even the police inspector could not feel the gravity of the situation, and instead of stopping the crowd from proceeding to the tank, went with them.
('38', 317, 11, 29, 645076) The tank is situated in the midst of the Brahmin locality.
('38', 317, 11, 30, 645135) As however no
('38', 317, 12, 31, 645149) 1 From the reference to the statistics about cows and buffaloes printed in Navajivan, 8 5 1927

('38', 319, 3, 16, 649550) 319. SASTRI AS FIRST AMBASSADOR
('38', 319, 4, 17, 649582) Very considerable relief will be felt by the Indian settlers in South Africa over the announcement that the Right Hon’ble V. S. Srinivasa Sastri has consented to become India’s first Agent general in that sub continent, if the post is finally offered to him by the Government of India.
('38', 319, 4, 18, 649868) It is a great sacrifice that Sastri and the Servants of India Society have made.
('38', 319, 4, 19, 649949) It is an open secret that left to himself he was not inclined to undertake the responsibility and to leave his work in India.
('38', 319, 4, 20, 650075) But he has yielded to the pressure of friends, especially when it was urged upon him that he alone could successfully inaugurate the working of the Agreement in bringing about which he played not an inconsiderable part.
('38', 319, 4, 21, 650295) We know from the cables that were sent from time to time from South Africa that the Europeans were anxious that he should accept the honour.
('38', 319, 4, 22, 650436) Srinivasa Sastri had by his eloquence,
('38', 320, 0, 1, 650475) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 321
('38', 320, 1, 2, 650518) transparent sincerity, sweet reasonableness, and extreme earnestness won the esteem and respect of the Union Government and the Europeans in South Africa during the short time that he was there as a member of the Habibullah Deputation.
('38', 320, 1, 3, 650754) I know how nervously anxious our countrymen in South Africa were that he should become the first Agent.
('38', 320, 1, 4, 650858) It was impossible for Sjt.
('38', 320, 1, 5, 650885) Srinivasa Sastri whom God has endowed with a generous nature not to respond to such a unanimous call from South Africa.
('38', 320, 1, 6, 651005) It is almost a foregone conclusion that the appointment will be duly made and very shortly announced.
('38', 320, 1, 7, 651107) The first Agent general will have his work cut out for him.
('38', 320, 1, 8, 651167) Both the Union Government and our countrymen have no doubt high expectations of India’s first ambassador.
('38', 320, 1, 9, 651273) The Union Government no doubt think that being an Indian and a person of great distinction he will make their path smooth with the Indian community in connection with any measures that they may take.
('38', 320, 1, 10, 651473) In other words, they will expect him to be their sympathetic interpreter both to the Indian community and to the Government of India.
('38', 320, 1, 11, 651607) Our countrymen equally surely expect him to insist upon an honourable and even a liberal inter pretation and fulfilment of the Agreement.
('38', 320, 1, 12, 651745) It is any time a delicate task to please rival claimants, more so now in South Africa where the clash of conflicting interests is simply bewildering.
('38', 320, 1, 13, 651895) But I know that if anybody can hold the scales absolutely even and thus give satisfaction to all parties concerned, Sjt.
('38', 320, 1, 14, 652016) Srinivas Sastri is certainly the one to be able to do so.
('38', 320, 1, 15, 652074) I feel certain that the Union Ministers do not expect the new Agent to surrender an inch of what is justly due to the Indian community.
('38', 320, 1, 16, 652210) All he can be expected to do is to persuade the Indian settlers not to go behind and travel beyond the Settlement 1 of 1914, for some time to come at any rate, until they have proved themselves entitled, by exemplary self restraint and behaviour, to an enlargement of the position attained by the Agreement of 1914. Our countrymen in South Africa, if they intend to make the Agent’s position fairly easy and their own position secure, will not expect him to work wonders.
('38', 320, 1, 17, 652682) It will be wrong to look forward to a complete transfor mation of the old position, because an honourable Agreement has been arrived at and because a great countryman is going to South Africa to see to the fulfilment of that Agreement.
('38', 320, 1, 18, 652918) They must remem ber that the Rt.

('38', 321, 1, 4, 653303) He goes there to safeguard the rights and liberty of the general body of Indian settlers.
('38', 321, 1, 5, 653393) He will be there to see that no fresh restrictive legislation is embarked upon by the Union Government and that the existing restrictive laws are administered liberally and with due regard to the vested rights.
('38', 321, 1, 6, 653604) Any individual grievance therefore that he might be called upon to tackle will have to be in terms of the position I have set forth, that is to say, it will have to be illustrative of some general principle of wide application.
('38', 321, 1, 7, 653832) Unless therefore the Indian community exercises prudential restraint upon themselves in approaching him for redress of their individual grievances, they will make the Agent’s position intolerable and even useless for the high purpose for which it is intended.

('38', 321, 4, 19, 655048) A friend having for the first time seen New Delhi and the Assembly Hall in March last writes: 1
('38', 321, 5, 20, 655144) I was the other day for the first time in the Assembly Hall and it was for
('38', 321, 6, 21, 655219) the first time then that I saw New Delhi also.
('38', 321, 6, 22, 655266) I could see how millions must
('38', 321, 7, 23, 655296) have been poured into the construction of New Delhi to make it so imposing.
('38', 321, 8, 24, 655372) The Assembly Hall too presents an equally imposing appearance.
('38', 321, 8, 25, 655435) But as I
('38', 321, 9, 26, 655444) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.

('38', 322, 1, 2, 655524) came out of the Assembly Hall, I saw dilapidated huts which turned out to be
('38', 322, 2, 3, 655601) the labour camp where I thought must be living the coolies working at the
('38', 322, 3, 4, 655675) construction of New Delhi....
('38', 322, 4, 5, 655705) The contrast between the palaces built in New Delhi for wealthy people
('38', 322, 5, 6, 655776) and the miserable huts allotted to the people whose labour was responsible for
('38', 322, 6, 7, 655855) the palaces was too terrible for contemplation....
('38', 322, 7, 8, 655906) How, I thought to myself, could the members of the Assembly day after day miss the horrible contrast which I could see even during the few moments that I was in New Delhi?
('38', 322, 8, 9, 656078) I have said nothing to any of the members.
('38', 322, 8, 10, 656121) But could you not do
('38', 322, 9, 11, 656142) anything in this matter?

('38', 322, 12, 17, 656365) disburdening myself to you.
('38', 322, 12, 18, 656393) I have summarized the main contents of the letter which my fair correspondent has written in Hindi.
('38', 322, 12, 19, 656493) The criminal disparity that exists between the condition of labour and that of capital is no new thing in modern times.
('38', 322, 12, 20, 656613) The discovery made by the friend reminds one of the discovery said to have been made centuries ago by Gautama Buddha.
('38', 322, 12, 21, 656731) It was no new thing he saw.
('38', 322, 12, 22, 656759) But the shock received by the sight of old age, disease and other miseries of life transformed his life and materially affected the fortunes of the world.
('38', 322, 12, 23, 656914) It is well that this lady has received her first shock.
('38', 322, 12, 24, 656970) If she and the other cultured women of India, who have received their education at the expense of the very poor people of whom the correspondent writes so pathetically, will dive deeper and make some slight return to these poor people by making common cause with them, some alleviation in their distressful condition will not be long in coming.
('38', 322, 12, 25, 657315) Every palace that one sees in India is a demonstration not of her riches but of the insolence of power that riches give to the few, who owe them to the miserably requitted labours of the millions of the paupers of India.
('38', 322, 12, 26, 657536) We have a Government which is based upon and which only exists by the exploitation of the toiling millions.
('38', 322, 12, 27, 657644) A friend sent me the other day a cutting from an English newspaper which considered Rs. 1,500 for an Englishman to be not enough for his wants in India, and it warned Englishmen from venturing out to India if they could get not more than Rs. 1,500 per month.
('38', 322, 12, 28, 657903) There is no need to quarrel with that standard.
('38', 322, 12, 29, 657951) From the writer’s own standpoint, Rs. 1,500 per month is demonstrably
('38', 323, 0, 1, 658021) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 323, 1, 2, 658063) inadequate because he regards club life, a motor car, migration to a hill station during the hot months, education of children in England to be the necessary minimum.
('38', 323, 1, 3, 658230) All one can say and one must say about this standard is, that if it is the indispensable minimum, it is a standard too expensive for India to afford; and however beneficial in the abstract may the services of English officials be demonstrated to be, if the toiling millions are to live, they must get along without these beneficial services for the simple reason that the benefit is beyond the reach of their pockets.
('38', 323, 1, 4, 658648) I suppose it is possible to demonstrate that if the millions of India could be translated to some bracing Himalayan plateau, they would be able to double the length of their days on earth.
('38', 323, 1, 5, 658837) But it is a proposition which they will laugh out of court as beyond their reach.
('38', 323, 1, 6, 658919) What the lady observed in New Delhi is but a tiny symptom of an ever growing and deep seated disease which is daily destroying the lives of thousands of people.
('38', 323, 1, 7, 659080) It is quite possible to imagine that if an energetic member of the Assembly moved a resolution calling upon the Government to provide better housing accommodation for the labourers, the resolution would be carried, that it would not be vetoed and that the Government would gladly give effect to it at the expense of millions poorer still than these labourers.
('38', 323, 1, 8, 659440) I am sure that this is not what the fair friend really desires.
('38', 323, 1, 9, 659504) What she desires in common with every Indian who knows anything of the country is a radical change in the system of government which is top heavy and which under its intolerable weight is crushing day after day the poor inhabitants of this country who are groaning at the bottom.
('38', 323, 1, 10, 659784) I have pointed the way out of this difficult situation times without number.
('38', 323, 1, 11, 659861) I do not know another.

('38', 323, 4, 14, 659918) KHADDAR AND PREM MAHAVIDYALAYA
('38', 323, 5, 15, 659949) Acharya Gidwani has been slowly but surely revolutionizing the mentality of the boys learning in Prem Mahavidyalaya at Brindaban.
('38', 323, 5, 16, 660079) In the course of a letter he says:
('38', 323, 6, 17, 660114) I do not boast of my khaddar work in this Mahavidyalaya; but I can safely assure you that you will not be disappointed when you see it.
('38', 323, 6, 18, 660250) Beginning with gentle pressure I have arrived at a stage when every teacher and student
('38', 324, 0, 1, 660338) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 325
('38', 324, 1, 2, 660381) wears khaddar without grudging and everyone spins on takli for 45 minutes daily.
('38', 324, 1, 3, 660462) Carding is done by turns and weaving is taught to select students.
('38', 324, 1, 4, 660529) Dyeing has been started.
('38', 324, 1, 5, 660554) About Rs. 2,000 worth of khaddar has been sold through the Prem Mahavidyalaya during the session, and everyone in Muttra and the neighbourhood looks upon the Prem Mahavidyalaya as a stronghold of shuddha khaddar.
('38', 324, 1, 6, 660767) Two tailors have been busy sewing exclusively khaddar for months in the Mahavidyalaya and will continue doing so.
('38', 324, 1, 7, 660881) I congratulate Acharya Gidwani and his staff and students.
('38', 324, 1, 8, 660940) His performance reminds me of a similar performance reported in these columns with reference to the Jamia Millia of Delhi.
('38', 324, 1, 9, 661063) These two instances and more can be quoted to show that where there are earnestness and faith there is no difficulty about response from students.
('38', 324, 1, 10, 661210) I have said repeatedly that it is the easiest thing to popularize khaddar and hand spinning in schools if the teachers have faith combined with knowledge and perseverance.
('38', 324, 1, 11, 661382) I know of no school where these three conditions being fulfilled there has been failure.

('38', 324, 2, 14, 661513) M. A. ANSARI
('38', 324, 3, 15, 661526) NANDI HILLS, April 28, 1927
('38', 324, 4, 16, 661554) DEAR DR.
('38', 324, 4, 17, 661563) ANSARI, It was a treat to receive your letter.
('38', 324, 4, 18, 661610) But you will remember that you owe me a medical visit—can’t call it professional because a professional visit will carry with it Rs. 1,000 per day if not more, now that you have been twice to Europe since the promise of a visit.
('38', 324, 4, 19, 661839) And, is not each European visit supposed to add to the capacity of doctors and lawyers and therefore also their daily fees?
('38', 324, 4, 20, 661963) Meanwhile, I shall bear your instructions in my mind.
('38', 324, 4, 21, 662017) My chief difficulty is how to control the mind and not to let it think, unless I develop dementia.
('38', 324, 4, 22, 662116) If you say I may not reduce my thoughts to writing or not even give utterance by speech even in the shape of conversation, I can somewhat understand; but I do not know how I can prevent the doings of Hindus and Mussalmans from making me think furiously.
('38', 324, 4, 23, 662370) Nor do I know how to prevent the growing starvation of millions acting upon my mind.
('38', 324, 4, 24, 662455) I do not need to read papers and get information to make me continuously think of these things.
('38', 324, 4, 25, 662551) The ony way to prevent me from thinking of these things is for Hindus and Mussalmans to behave like human beings rather than sub human animals and for all of us
('38', 325, 0, 1, 662712) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 325, 1, 2, 662754) who get more than our share of our daily bread to think of the vast majority of the teeming millions and for their sakes to discard foreign cloth and for their encouragement to spin during every idle moment.
('38', 325, 1, 3, 662962) If it is really a fact that high blood pressure is due to an over wrought brain, I seriously contend that the only way to remove this tension would be to prescribe a starvation cure.
('38', 325, 1, 4, 663145) Deep down in me I do feel that a prolonged fast is the only radical cure because during the 21 days fast 1, I could see that after 10 days I has ceased even to think of the outside world.
('38', 325, 1, 5, 663333) The starvation had created that temporary mental adjustment.
('38', 325, 1, 6, 663394) Whilst I am eating even if it was possible the mind refuses not to think.
('38', 325, 1, 7, 663468) But under starvation the mind will co operate in ceasing to think and worry.
('38', 325, 1, 8, 663545) And, if in spite of the care that I am myself taking and in spite of the army of medical friends who see me and examine me, in spite of the quacks whose opinion I voluntarily seek and in spite of the undivided attention of devoted nurses, blood pressure refuses to yield and weakness persists, I shall certainly risk causing temporary pain to many friends and impose a fast upon myself either to end or to mend this vegetating and vexing state.
('38', 325, 1, 9, 663990) But there is no cause for any alarm.
('38', 325, 1, 10, 664027) It seems that the pressure will go down.
('38', 325, 1, 11, 664068) For the last two days I am feeling stronger than when I came to Nandi.
('38', 325, 1, 12, 664139) The highest pressure during last week was 188. On Tuesday last it was found to be 180. This was the first decline yet noticed after the collapse.
('38', 325, 1, 13, 664285) This hill is 4,850 feet, therefore, not so high as Ooty nor so cold; but it is cool enough and Doctor Mehta considers that I should not [go] to a higher altitude.

('38', 330, 7, 27, 672849) April 30, 1927 In my article 3 about buffaloes I have said nothing about destroying them; on the contrary an attempt should be made to raise their breed.
('38', 330, 7, 28, 673003) Where the need for a thing is real it will surely be

('38', 331, 1, 2, 673174) protected.
('38', 331, 1, 3, 673185) What I mean is that cow protection alone can be part of dharma.
('38', 331, 1, 4, 673249) It includes compassion for other animals.
('38', 331, 1, 5, 673291) But these are not being destroyed.
('38', 331, 1, 6, 673326) There is no need to take up the stupendous task of stopping their destruction.
('38', 331, 1, 7, 673405) And if we are able to protect the cow, all else that needs to be done will be accomplished automatically.

('38', 331, 1, 9, 673570) I only indicate the limit of our ability.
('38', 331, 1, 10, 673612) Even the villages ought to have something in the nature of a tannery, a dairy.
('38', 331, 1, 11, 673691) In other words, the tanning process in the villages needs to be improved.

('38', 331, 1, 13, 673830) There should be some expert experi menting with regard to the cow; there has to be knowledge of the methods of increasing their yield.
('38', 331, 1, 14, 673965) It is our misfortune that today we can only carry this knowledge from the town to the country.
('38', 331, 1, 15, 674060) At the moment we are not even aware of this science.
('38', 331, 1, 16, 674113) I mean, we shall be able to do nothing before those who have learnt it in the West evolve it anew with an appreciation of the local environment and in an assimilable form.
('38', 331, 1, 17, 674285) So, for the time being, we shall only be experi menting, the point being that an industry which is today handled mainly by ignorant men for earning a livelihood should be taken up by the educated class, keeping in view our country’s welfare, as is being done in the case of spinning and weaving.

('38', 338, 9, 21, 685124) SISTERS, I have now received plenty of hand made paper.

('38', 339, 1, 2, 685855) that those of you who can, may learn thereby how to keep accounts.
('38', 339, 1, 3, 685922) I find your progress in another direction also praiseworthy.
('38', 339, 1, 4, 685983) Last week I raised the problem of protecting yourselves against thieves.
('38', 339, 2, 5, 686056) Do not lightly brush it aside.
('38', 339, 2, 6, 686087) I wish you to falsify the epithets ‘weak’, ‘timid’ and so on that are specially used about women.
('38', 339, 2, 7, 686185) They do not apply to all women of course.
('38', 339, 2, 8, 686227) Who would say the women of Raniparaj are ‘timid’?
('38', 339, 2, 9, 686277) How can you call them weak?
('38', 339, 2, 10, 686305) The women of the West, of course, take part these days in everything.
('38', 339, 2, 11, 686375) I do not mean to say that they should be imitated; but at least they have been falsifying many of the assumptions of men.

('38', 339, 2, 18, 686895) Now the soul is neither male nor female; neither young nor old.

('38', 339, 2, 20, 687060) The same soul pervades you and me.
('38', 339, 2, 21, 687095) How then can I protect you ?

('38', 341, 5, 29, 690417) 345. MAN’S INHUMANITY TO MAN
('38', 341, 6, 30, 690446) In another column will be seen an extract from Navajivan of a most disgraceful case of calculated inhumanity of a medical man towards the dying wife of a member of the suppressed class in Kathiawar village.
('38', 341, 6, 31, 690653) Amritlal Thakkar who is responsible for giving the details of the case has withheld the names of the place and parties for fear of the poor suppressed class schoolmaster being further molested by the medical man.
('38', 341, 6, 32, 690866) I wish, however, that the names will be disclosed.
('38', 341, 6, 33, 690917) Time must come when the suppressed class people will have
('38', 342, 0, 1, 690975) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 343
('38', 342, 1, 2, 691018) to be encouraged by us to dare to suffer further hardships and tyranny.
('38', 342, 1, 3, 691090) Their sufferings are already too great for any further sufferings to be really felt.
('38', 342, 1, 4, 691175) Public opinion cannot be roused over grievances that cannot be verified and traced to their sources.
('38', 342, 1, 5, 691276) I do not know the rules of the Medical Council in Bombay.
('38', 342, 1, 6, 691334) I know that in other places a medical practitioner, who refused to attend before his fees were paid, would be answerable to the Council and would be liable to have his name removed from the Council’s list and be otherwise subject to disciplinary action.
('38', 342, 1, 7, 691588) Fees are no doubt exactable; but proper attendance upon patients is the first duty of a medical practitioner.
('38', 342, 1, 8, 691698) The real inhumanity, however, if the facts stated are true, consists in the practitioner refusing to enter the untouchable’s quarters, refusing himself to see the patient, and refusing himself to apply the thermometer.
('38', 342, 1, 9, 691917) And if the doctrine of untouchability can ever be applied in any circumstances, it is certainly applicable to this member of the profession which he has disgraced.
('38', 342, 1, 10, 692081) But I am hoping that there is some exaggeration in the statement made by Sjt.
('38', 342, 1, 11, 692159) Thakkar’s correspondent and, if there is none, that the medical practitioner will himself come forth and make ample amends to the society which he has so outraged by his inhuman conduct.

('38', 345, 11, 14, 695647) 352. LETTER TO HONORARY SECRETARY, AYURVEDIC CONFERENCE 1
('38', 345, 12, 15, 695705) [Before May 7, 1927]
('38', 345, 13, 16, 695726) DEAR FRIEND, Owing to my sudden illness, I have not been able to reply earlier to your letter of the 17th ultimo.
('38', 345, 13, 17, 695840) The remarks quoted by you and ascribed to me in the Minority Report 2, which of course I have not seen, are substantially correct but they have been torn from their context.
('38', 345, 13, 18, 696014) In the speech, the report of which I have not read, from which I suppose the remarks quoted by you have been taken, I was drawing a distinction between Ayurveda and Ayurvedic physicians of today and I do hold the opinion that they do not do justice to the profession they seek to represent.
('38', 345, 13, 19, 696305) But these remarks should not be used in support of any proposition designed to prevent Government’s assistance being given for Ayurveda research.
('38', 345, 13, 20, 696451) I believe that Ayurveda is a field for much research work.
('38', 345, 13, 21, 696510) For want of research scholars, unlike Western medicine, it has practically come to a standstill.
('38', 345, 14, 22, 696607) 1 In Ceylon 2 Of the Commission on Ayurvedic medicine
('38', 346, 0, 1, 696661) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 347
('38', 346, 1, 2, 696704) Therefore, I should not discountenance aid being given to Ayurveda research under given circumstances and to honest and industrious men who love research work and who have the necessary qualifi cations.
('38', 346, 1, 3, 696907) I should add that the remarks attributed to me were made at the ceremony of laying the foundation of an Ayurvedic College.
('38', 346, 1, 4, 697030) Had I been averse to any aid being given to Ayurvedic work, I should certainly have declined to lay the foundation of an Ayurvedic College at Calcutta, to open the Tibbia College in Delhi and very recently, to open an Ayurvedic Hospital at Ahmednagar.
('38', 346, 2, 5, 697282) Yours sincerely,
('38', 346, 3, 6, 697299) M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 7 5 1927

('38', 348, 5, 8, 700133) 356. COW v.
('38', 348, 5, 9, 700145) BUFFALO OR COW CUM BUFFALO?
('38', 348, 6, 10, 700173) A worker in the cause of cow protection writes from Konkan:
('38', 348, 7, 11, 700233) In your recent article 2 giving the conditions of cow protection you said that the question of the protection of the cow should not be mixed up with that of the protection of the buffalo.
('38', 348, 7, 12, 700421) At the back of this suggestion seems to be the fact that the buffalo bull is not useful for agricultural purposes.
('38', 348, 7, 13, 700536) But in Konkan he is fairly useful.
('38', 348, 7, 14, 700571) It is the buffalo bull which draws the municipal refuse carts, which works water pumps and even draws the plough, especially when there is a heavy downpour disabling the bullock and most of the agriculture in Konkan is being done under monsoon conditions.
('38', 348, 7, 15, 700827) The buffalo bull has therefore his place in Konkan.
('38', 348, 8, 16, 700879) The Konkan cow does not yield more than one pound of milk, whereas the buffalo yields 5 to 10 lb.
('38', 348, 8, 17, 700977) It may be possible, after systematic breeding, to make the cow yield more and richer milk, but the buffalo needs no special culture at all.
('38', 348, 8, 18, 701117) Does not therefore the buffalo in Konkan at any rate need as much protection as the cow?
('38', 348, 8, 19, 701206) Please correct me if I am wrong.
('38', 348, 9, 20, 701239) The buffalo, I admit, has no place on the ghats where the temperature is higher, fields are bigger and water scarce.
('38', 348, 9, 21, 701356) He needs much water both to drink and bathe in.
('38', 348, 9, 22, 701404) Konkan is the place for him.
('38', 348, 10, 23, 701433) Your tannery and dairy are for cities.
('38', 348, 10, 24, 701472) For the villages you must suggest some more practical ways and means.
('38', 348, 10, 25, 701542) Let every village possess a studbull, maintain him partly from the common fund and partly from contributions from those who make use of him.
('38', 348, 10, 26, 701683) This can be done everywhere and it will improve the stock.
('38', 348, 10, 27, 701742) Could you not suggest similar other remedies?
('38', 348, 11, 28, 701788) 1 The original Gujarati was published in Navajivan, 8 5 1927. This is a translation by Mahadev Desai.
('38', 348, 11, 29, 701890) 2 Vide “Conditions of Cow protection”, pp.
('38', 349, 0, 1, 701933) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 349, 1, 2, 701975) These are appropriate questions.
('38', 349, 1, 3, 702008) My article was not intended to throw the buffalo by the board, it suggested the stopping of buffalo breeding in her own interest.
('38', 349, 1, 4, 702138) In other words it meant freedom of the buffalo from its bondage.
('38', 349, 1, 5, 702203) We have domesticated the cow for our own uses and therefore it has become part of our religion to protect her.
('38', 349, 1, 6, 702314) It was my object to show that in trying to breed the buffalo, as we do the cow, we might lose both.
('38', 349, 1, 7, 702414) The Konkan example does not affect my proposition.
('38', 349, 1, 8, 702465) We must, of course, make use of the existing stock of buffaloes, and let it be done in parts like Konkan.
('38', 349, 1, 9, 702571) But our duty is clear.
('38', 349, 1, 10, 702594) We must not increase our responsibility by breeding the buffalo where we can do with the cow alone.
('38', 349, 1, 11, 702694) We must therefore content ourselves with the use of cow’s milk only.
('38', 349, 1, 12, 702763) It should not be necessary in a city like Bombay to use buffalo’s milk in preference to cow’s milk.
('38', 349, 1, 13, 702863) An endeavour should be organized on a large scale to cheapen the supply of pure cow’s milk, and to improve the milk yield of the cow.
('38', 349, 1, 14, 702997) It is possible too to make cow’s milk richer.
('38', 349, 1, 15, 703043) All these things have been developed into a science in Europe, especially in Denmark.
('38', 349, 1, 16, 703129) Cows in those countries yield richer and more milk than our buffaloes.
('38', 349, 1, 17, 703200) I have heard from vaidyas that buffalo’s milk lacks and can never be made to have the hygenic and health giving properties that cow’s milk possesses.
('38', 349, 1, 18, 703350) Pious people have told me that cow’s milk is sattvic (possessing finer qualities) whereas buffalo’s milk is tamasic (gross).
('38', 349, 1, 19, 703475) I do not know how far this is true.
('38', 349, 1, 20, 703511) I am trying to ascertain the truth through the proper channel.
('38', 349, 1, 21, 703574) But it does seem to me, that all that the buffalo can give and even more, the cow also can or can be made to give.
('38', 349, 1, 22, 703689) If this is true, why should man, having regard to his own needs, make himself responsible for breeding the buffalo ?
('38', 349, 1, 23, 703806) And having regard to the need of the buffalo, why should we needlessly keep her in bondage ?
('38', 349, 1, 24, 703899) Or to put it more simply, why should we press her into our service?
('38', 349, 1, 25, 703967) The fact that some people make a pecuniary gain out of buffalo breeding can have no place in this religious discussion in which we have in view the good of all.
('38', 349, 1, 26, 704128) In thinking solely of the narrow interest of the self or of the moment, we have ruined ourselves, i.e., our country and our religion.
('38', 349, 1, 27, 704262) We can be a nation, only when we try to think in terms of the wider interests of the country.
('38', 349, 1, 28, 704356) If we cannot even think in those terms, it is no use talking of religion.
('38', 349, 1, 29, 704430) From the national point of view, the good of the country is the supreme consideration.
('38', 349, 1, 30, 704517) From the religious point of view the good of all living
('38', 350, 0, 1, 704573) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 351
('38', 350, 1, 2, 704616) beings from the cow down to the ant is the supreme consideration.
('38', 350, 2, 3, 704682) Let the reader now turn to the table given elsewhere in this issue.
('38', 350, 2, 4, 704750) The table relates to the income from and expenditure on the cattle maintained at the Satyagraha Ashram.
('38', 350, 2, 5, 704854) The names are those of different cows.
('38', 350, 2, 6, 704893) The manager in his covering letter says:
('38', 350, 3, 7, 704934) It is by no means the rule that the buffalo yields more than the cow.
('38', 350, 3, 8, 705004) Some of the cows in the table yield a net profit, some just pay their way and some are boarders.
('38', 350, 3, 9, 705101) These last we shall prevent from breeding and propose to take light work from them.
('38', 350, 3, 10, 705185) A sterile cow has already been trained to do some work.
('38', 350, 3, 11, 705241) The buffalo calves sell cheap, whereas some calves of the cow are worth Rs. 100 each.
('38', 350, 3, 12, 705327) Two or three have taken the place of the horse with the result that we have dispensed with our horse carriage.
('38', 350, 3, 13, 705438) The Ashram has decided to have no more buffaloes.
('38', 350, 3, 14, 705488) We may not draw large deductions from the table, but it is certainly obvious that if the cow is fed properly she compares favourably with the buffalo in her yield, she does not cost more, and her calves are much more useful.
('38', 350, 3, 15, 705713) I propose to publish in Navajivan the results of the further experiments that are being conducted in the Ashram.
('38', 350, 3, 16, 705826) The Konkan friend is not right when he says that the dairy and the tannery are useful only in and for the city, and have no place in the villages.
('38', 350, 3, 17, 705973) The cow has become a costly proposition even in the villages.
('38', 350, 3, 18, 706035) It is as essential to keep proper accounts of her yield and to improve her stock and her milk in villages as in cities.
('38', 350, 3, 19, 706155) And the skinning of dead cattle and the prompt and skilled treatment of the hides is more essential in villages than in cities, and that is the work to be done in tanneries.
('38', 350, 3, 20, 706329) It is a painful fact that in our present condition we have to cultivate the science of tanning in the cities and then take it to the villages.
('38', 350, 3, 21, 706472) For one thing it is impossible to conduct big experiments in the villages, and cattle that are slaughtered in the cities come from the villages.
('38', 350, 3, 22, 706617) If we can therefore conduct experiments in dairying and tanning from the religious and national point of view in the cities, we can easily give the benefit of them to the villages, and the cattle wealth of India which is at the present day being destroyed because of our ignorance will be saved, and man and animal will both be less unhappy than now.
('38', 350, 4, 23, 706968) Young India, 19 5 1927

('38', 351, 1, 2, 707100) 357. WHAT CAN PERSEVERANCE NOT ACHIEVE?
('38', 351, 2, 3, 707140) In the West we sometimes see a man performing club swinging continuously for twenty four hours.
('38', 351, 2, 4, 707236) These shows are held to demons trate how far a man’s endurance can go.
('38', 351, 2, 5, 707307) Thousands of spectators give money and fill the theatres to see that.
('38', 351, 2, 6, 707377) I have my own doubts whether these kinds of shows are of any use.
('38', 351, 2, 7, 707443) But readers will recall that something like this, though with a different, i.
('38', 351, 2, 8, 707521) e., religious motive was organized in the Ashram during the National Week.
('38', 351, 2, 9, 707596) Some youths insisted on plying the charkha continuously for twenty four hours, forgoing their usual sleep.
('38', 351, 2, 10, 707703) The letter written by the one who spun the largest quantity of yarn is interesting and, therefore, I give it below: 1
('38', 351, 3, 11, 707821) Those who welcome any manifestation of enthusiasm by the young or have faith in the charkha yajna will feel happy to read this letter.

('38', 351, 3, 13, 708033) It is good to have interest in games, but it is better still to have the same interest in philanthropic work.
('38', 351, 3, 14, 708143) They should also observe that such uninterrupted work is quite within the capacity of those who safeguard their health and observe brahmacharya.
('38', 351, 3, 15, 708288) It is an abuse of one’s education to use it for earning money.
('38', 351, 3, 16, 708351) Education proves its worth when used for the service of others.
('38', 351, 3, 17, 708415) Moreover, a student needs to have faith also.
('38', 351, 3, 18, 708461) Reason will certainly help a little to understand that India’s poverty can be banished through a simple thing like the charkha.
('38', 351, 3, 19, 708589) But, in the end, it is only faith which will sustain the student’s love of it.
('38', 351, 3, 20, 708668) I realize every moment, from what I see of students, that without faith education is of little use.

('38', 352, 3, 19, 710080) There are more nurses than I need here.
('38', 352, 3, 20, 710120) So if you come in the hope of doing some personal service, you would feel idle and yawning.

('38', 352, 3, 23, 710319) And then the touch comes through joint work.
('38', 352, 3, 24, 710364) You come in daily touch with me by doing my work as if it was your own.
('38', 352, 3, 25, 710436) And this can, must and will outlast the existence of this physical body of mine.
('38', 352, 3, 26, 710517) You are and will be in touch whether I am alive or dead.
('38', 352, 3, 27, 710574) And that is what I want you to be.
('38', 352, 3, 28, 710609) You have come to me not for me but for my ideals in so far as I live them.
('38', 352, 3, 29, 710684) You now know how far I live the ideals I set forth.
('38', 352, 3, 30, 710736) It is now for you to work out those ideals and practise them to greater perfection than has been given to me to do.
('38', 352, 3, 31, 710852) He or she who does that will be my first heir

('38', 358, 7, 9, 719592) DRAFT RULES
('38', 358, 8, 10, 719604) 1. Every person choosing under Article VII of the Consti tution to send the subscription in yarn shall send 2,000 yards of evenly spun yarn of his or her own spinning to the All India Spinners’ Association office, Sabarmati, to reach on or before the 28th February every year in advance for the full year.
('38', 358, 8, 11, 719910) 2. Members joining in the middle of the year shall send the full quota for the year at the time of application for admission.
('38', 358, 8, 12, 720036) No one who has failed to send his yarn subscription on or before the 28th February, or in case of members joining in the middle of the year, no one who has not paid in the full quota of 2,000 yards shall be entitled to exercise any of the privileges of membership referred to in Sec.
('38', 358, 8, 13, 720320) (iv) of Art.
('38', 358, 8, 14, 720333) 3. The yarn shall be hanked in 4 ft.
('38', 358, 8, 15, 720370) circumference and sent up at the member’s cost to the A.I.S.A. office, Sabarmati with such parti culars filled in as may be prescribed in the forms issued from that office.
('38', 358, 9, 16, 720543) 1 Of the Congress constitution; vide 1st footnote to “Speech at Congress Session, Gauhati”, 27 12 1926 and “Khadi Franchise”, 9 6 1927. Presumably this was sent for the A.I.C.C. meeting scheduled to be held in Bombay on May 15 and 16, 1927; vide “Letter to Chhaganlal Gandhi”, 19 5 1927.
('38', 359, 0, 1, 720831) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 359, 1, 2, 720873) 4. On any member being found to the satisfaction of the President of a Provincial Congress Committee to be infringing the rule of habitual wear of khaddar, he may at his discretion report him to the President of the Congress; and he shall thereupon forfeit for the rest of the year the right to vote or be elected at the election of represen tatives or delegates or any committee or sub committee of any Con gress organization whatsoever or to take part in any meeting of the Congress or Congress organization or any committee or sub committee thereof.
('38', 359, 1, 3, 721426) 5. Subject to the above rule, if at any meeting a question is raised that any member is not entitled to vote or to be elected or to take part in any proceedings thereof, on the ground that he does not habitually wear khaddar, the statement of the member himself shall, except where it is manifestly untrue to the knowledge of the Chairman, be accepted without further proof in regard to the question so far as that meeting is concerned.

('38', 360, 4, 17, 723940) So far as our ideals are concerned, we stand apart.
('38', 360, 4, 18, 723992) 2 Whilst Anasuyabai and Banker as also Gulzarilal and Desai are absolutely free agents, they have exercised their choice of accepting my guida nce in framing their labour policy and administration.
('38', 360, 4, 19, 724190) I must there fore shoulder my share of the responsibility for what is happening about labour in Ahmedabad.
('38', 360, 4, 20, 724297) I have certainly advised them to keep Ahmedabad labour aloof from the other labour movements in India so long as Ahmedabad labour chooses to remain under their guid ance.
('38', 360, 4, 21, 724468) My reason is exceedingly simple.
('38', 360, 4, 22, 724501) Labour in India is still extre mely unorganized.
('38', 360, 4, 23, 724550) The labourers have no mind of their own, when it comes to matters of national policy or even the general welfare of labour itself.
('38', 360, 4, 24, 724681) Labourers in various parts of India have no social contact and no other mutual ties.
('38', 360, 4, 25, 724766) It is provincial and even in the same city it is highly communal.
('38', 360, 4, 26, 724832) It is not everywhere wisely guided.
('38', 360, 5, 27, 724868) 1 Gulzarilal Nanda, sometime Home Minister, Government of India 2 The addressee was of the opinion that the energies of all leaders should be harnessed towards an early inauguration of labour and industrial organizations all over the country.
('38', 361, 0, 1, 725111) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 361, 1, 2, 725153) many places it is under selfish and highly unscrupulous guidance.
('38', 361, 1, 3, 725219) There is no absolute cohesion amongst provincial labour leaders, and there is little discipline among sub leaders.
('38', 361, 1, 4, 725334) The latter do not unifor mly tender obedience to their provincial chiefs.
('38', 361, 1, 5, 725408) Leaders in different provinces have no single policy to follow.
('38', 361, 1, 6, 725472) In these circumstances, an all India union can only exist on paper.
('38', 361, 1, 7, 725540) I hold it to be suicidal therefore for Ahmedabad to think of belonging to it.
('38', 361, 1, 8, 725618) My own conviction is that Ahmedabad is rendering a service to labour all over India by its abstention, or as I call it self restraint.
('38', 361, 1, 9, 725753) If it can succeed in perfecting its own organization, it is bound to serve as a model to the rest of India and its success is bound to prove highly infectious.
('38', 361, 1, 10, 725913) But I am free to confess that there is as yet no assurance of success in the near future.
('38', 361, 1, 11, 726003) The energy of the workers is sorely tried in combating disruptive forces that ever continue to crop up.
('38', 361, 1, 12, 726107) There is the Hindu Muslim tension; there is the question of touchables and untouchables in Hinduism, etc.
('38', 361, 1, 13, 726213) Add to this extreme ignorance and selfishness among the labourers themselves.
('38', 361, 1, 14, 726291) It is a marvel to me that labour in Ahmedabad has made the progress it has during the last 12 years of its corporate existence.
('38', 361, 1, 15, 726419) If then Ahmedabad remains isolated it does so not selfishly, but for the sake of labour as a whole.
('38', 361, 1, 16, 726519) One word as to the policy.
('38', 361, 1, 17, 726546) It is not anti capitalistic.
('38', 361, 1, 18, 726575) The idea is to take from capital labour's due share and no more, and this not by paralysing capital but by reform among labourers from within and by their own self consciousness; not again through the cleverness and manoeuvring of non labour leaders, but by educating labour to evolve its own leadership and its own self reliant, self existing organization.
('38', 361, 1, 19, 726933) Its direct aim is not in the least degree political.
('38', 361, 1, 20, 726986) Its direct aim is internal reform and evolution of internal strength.
('38', 361, 1, 21, 727056) The indirect result of this evolution, when, if ever it becomes complete, will naturally be tremendously political.
('38', 361, 1, 22, 727172) I have not therefore the remotest idea of exploiting labour or organizing it for any direct political end.
('38', 361, 1, 23, 727279) It will be of itself a political power of first class importance when it becomes a self existing unit.
('38', 361, 1, 24, 727382) Labour, in my opinion, must not become a pawn in the hands of the politicians on the political chess board.
('38', 361, 1, 25, 727490) It must by its sheer strength dominate the chessboard.
('38', 361, 1, 26, 727545) And that can only happen if I can retain the intelligent and voluntary co operation of the workers in Ahmedabad and if our joint effort ultimately succeeds.
('38', 361, 1, 27, 727702) This is my dream.
('38', 361, 1, 28, 727720) I hug it because it gives me all the consolation I
('38', 362, 0, 1, 727771) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 363
('38', 362, 1, 2, 727814) need; and the policy I have outlined, you will recognize, is a direct outcome of my implicit belief in and acceptance of non violence.
('38', 362, 1, 3, 727949) It may be all a delusion; but it is as much a reality with me as life itself so long as I do not see it as delusion but see it as the only life giving force.
('38', 362, 1, 4, 728107) You will now see why I cannot, even if I had the power, respond to your appeal for dividing the funds collected by me in accordance with your suggestion.
('38', 362, 1, 5, 728261) But I may tell you that I have not even the power.

('38', 365, 1, 2, 732086) 370. LETTER TO FULCHAND K. SHAH Wednesday, May 11, 1927 I have your letter.
('38', 365, 1, 3, 732162) It is not satyagraha in the true sense of the word if people outside the State of Gondal agitate against the ban on entry of newspapers into the State.
('38', 365, 1, 4, 732314) People not belonging to the Gondal State can offer satyagraha there only when the cause of Gondal subjects is common to all the States and if success in the Gondal case would mean an improvement in all the other States.
('38', 365, 1, 5, 732534) Moreover offering satyagraha against a ban on entry of journals is like killing a buffalo for the sake of a thong or like citing scriptures for eating carrots while swallowing whole camels.
('38', 365, 1, 6, 732724) Even if the satyagraha in Gondal is to be offered by the State subjects they ought to have a stronger reason.
('38', 365, 2, 7, 732834) The Wadhwan well case is slightly stronger no doubt, but before you take it up you should be prepared to bear the loss of the school.
('38', 365, 2, 8, 732968) You should try some preliminary remedies, e.g., you should carry on negotiations, bring in the good offices of intermediaries, give the matter sufficient publicity.
('38', 365, 2, 9, 733133) You ought to prove that the ban is due solely to ill will.
('38', 365, 2, 10, 733192) In short, a satyagrahi’s case has to be self proven.
('38', 365, 2, 11, 733245) If there is any scope for doubt, if the other party has anything to say, a satyagrahi should hold his patience for the nonce.
('38', 365, 2, 12, 733371) If you look at all the occasions when I had offered satyagraha you will be able to see this condition as well as others.
('38', 365, 3, 13, 733492) You have rightly laid down the limit that satyagraha cannot be offered without my permission.
('38', 365, 3, 14, 733586) Observe this limit steadfastly, and obtain my written approval before starting anything.
('38', 365, 3, 15, 733675) This will be good for you and the principle of satyagraha will not be compromised by your action.
('38', 365, 4, 16, 733773) Blessings from
('38', 365, 5, 17, 733788) BAPU [From Gujarati]

('38', 366, 1, 2, 733922) 371. NOTES
('38', 366, 2, 3, 733933) EVILS OF MACHINE MILLING Mr. Andrews, who is working himself almost to death in the interest of the Indian settlers of South Africa, cannot forget things that he has at heart in India itself.
('38', 366, 2, 4, 734125) Having read Mahadev Desai’s account of the Bihar tour, he cabled some time ago:
('38', 366, 3, 5, 734205) Tell Mahadev delighted accounts Bihar tour.
('38', 366, 3, 6, 734249) Give love Rajendraprasad.
('38', 366, 3, 7, 734275) Sug gest your emphasizing hand milling.
('38', 366, 3, 8, 734315) Have witnessed evils rice mills, inclu ding destruction of vitamins.
('38', 366, 3, 9, 734384) Warn public against unauthorized cables from South Africa.
('38', 366, 3, 10, 734443) The reader can see that the foregoing cablegram was sent in order that I may warn the public against accepting everything that comes from South Africa, unless it bears Andrews’s own hallmark.
('38', 366, 3, 11, 734635) But I hardly think that the caution is required.
('38', 366, 3, 12, 734684) Naturally the public here will discount anything sensational that may come from South Africa, unless it is duly countersigned.
('38', 366, 3, 13, 734811) But let us hope that the Rt.
('38', 366, 3, 14, 734840) Hon’ble Srinivasa Sastri will soon be on his way to South Africa, when all cause for alarm or anxiety will be set at rest.
('38', 366, 3, 15, 734963) Without, therefore, dilating upon the South African part of the cable, I return to the rice mills, whose evils have distressed him so much as to prompt the cabling of his opinion.
('38', 366, 3, 16, 735143) The reader will appreciate Andrews’s anxiety when I inform him that he has to live whilst in India in the midst of rice mills.
('38', 366, 3, 17, 735270) For whereas when he first went to Shantiniketan near Bolepur, there was no rice mill in Bolepur, at the present moment several such mills are working in that once quiet place.
('38', 366, 3, 18, 735446) He often spoke to me about the din, the dust and the smoke and the fraudulent trafficking that has been going on in Bolepur since the advent of rice mills, and spoke also of the deprivation of a useful cottage industry by reason of the installation of these mills.
('38', 366, 3, 19, 735711) There can be no doubt that hand husked rice is infinitely superior to mill husked rice.
('38', 366, 3, 20, 735799) Medical men can, however, speak on the evil with greater authority than I can.
('38', 366, 3, 21, 735878) The moral evil of those mills stares one in the face, as soon as one goes to places where these mills have found a place.
('38', 366, 3, 22, 736000) In spite, however, of my knowledge of the evil of this growing destruction of cottage industries, had I not been bed ridden, I should not have undertaken the task that Andrews out of his good nature and out of the abundance of love that he has for India suggests that I should do.
('38', 367, 0, 1, 736281) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 367, 1, 2, 736323) I regard myself as an economical worker, fully cognizant of my own limitations.
('38', 367, 1, 3, 736403) In trying to revive hand spinning I feel that I am touching the root of the evil, that it is enough to occupy all my energy, and that if that movement becomes successful, as I am daily becoming more and more convinced that it will, the undulated evils of rice mills, to which Andrews draws attention, and others which can be named will automatically disappear.
('38', 367, 1, 4, 736764) Let us not make the mistake of thinking that what has happened in India about the spinning wheel, and what is now happening about other cottage industries, such as hand milling of rice, need cause no harm to national life, because such things have happened in the West without the West having come to grief.
('38', 367, 1, 5, 737072) In the first place it is yet too early to say positively that the destruction of village life in the West has been either a benefit to it, or to mankind in general.
('38', 367, 1, 6, 737237) In the second place, and this is more pertinent, assuming that the new life that has come into being in the West is calculated to benefit mankind, let us understand that whereas in the West the villagers whose industry was destroyed readily found another occupation, and were, therefore, somehow provided, with us only an infinitesimal portion of those whom the erection of these mills deprives of their occupation is otherwise provided, and that the vast majority are left idle and penniless.
('38', 367, 1, 7, 737731) Let not the reader also rush to the conclusion that the hand spinning movement is an indiscriminate onslaught upon machinery.
('38', 367, 1, 8, 737857) This movement is intended to displace only such machinery worked by power as is harmful to the moral and material welfare of the starving millions.
('38', 367, 1, 9, 738005) The fact is that we are too much obsessed by the glamour of the West, and the ready made literature that is poured down upon us from week to week.
('38', 367, 1, 10, 738152) We forget that what may be perfectly good for certain conditions in the West is not necessarily good for certain other, and often diametrically opposite, conditions in the East.
('38', 367, 1, 11, 738330) Free Trade which may have been good enough for England would certainly have ruined Germany.
('38', 367, 1, 12, 738422) Germany prospered, only because her thinkers, instead of slavishly following England, took note of the special conditions of their own land, and devised economics suited to them.
('38', 367, 1, 13, 738601) And both England and Germany will have to revise their policy in economics immediatelythe nations that are now being exploited by them come to their own, and refuse to be exploited.
('38', 367, 1, 14, 738783) The civilization of both is based upon the exploitation of other lands.
('38', 367, 1, 15, 738855) Let us remember that even if we have desire, we have not the power to exploit any single nation on earth.
('38', 368, 0, 1, 738961) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 369
('38', 368, 1, 2, 739004) Hence if we are to live as an independent nation, we must evolve economics and conditions suited to our growth.
('38', 368, 2, 3, 739116) MOST ECONOMICAL
('38', 368, 3, 4, 739132) A friend, who fell ill about the same time as I became incapa citated, writing out of sympathy, and herself in search of it, says in her letter:
('38', 368, 4, 5, 739277) I had time to philosophize and there was one thought I was working at ever since I lost my voice.
('38', 368, 4, 6, 739375) And I have discovered that there is no necessity for living, and that Fate in giving us death early is most economical.
('38', 368, 4, 7, 739495) For thereby she economizes the power that abides in us whereas we waste it by living when living becomes manifestly unnecessary.
('38', 368, 4, 8, 739624) I spun the thought out until I felt exhausted, and I said to myself, “After all what is the good?
('38', 368, 4, 9, 739722) The call somehow or other has not come.
('38', 368, 4, 10, 739762) And so I must be wasted till there is nothing more left to be wasted.’’ 1
('38', 368, 5, 11, 739836) What a comforting thought it is to think of death, whenever it comes, as a wise plan in the economy of Nature?
('38', 368, 5, 12, 739947) If we could realize this law of our being and be prepared for death as a welcome friend and deliverer, we should cease to engage in the frantic struggle for life.
('38', 368, 5, 13, 740110) We shall cease to want to live at the cost of other lives and in contempt of all considerations of humanity.
('38', 368, 5, 14, 740219) But to philosophize, as this friend has done, is one thing; to realize at the required moment the truth of the philosophy is totally another.
('38', 368, 5, 15, 740361) Such realization is impossible without a due conception of the definite and grave limitations of the body and an abiding faith in God and His unchangeable Law of Karma.
('38', 368, 6, 16, 740530) Young India, 12 5 1927
('38', 368, 7, 17, 740553) 372. YOUNG AT 75
('38', 368, 8, 18, 740570) An English friend writes:
('38', 368, 9, 19, 740596) I want just to tell you of a letter and photographs I have had from a dear old Swiss peasant woman of over 70, who spins and weaves away up in the mountains above Villeneuve.
('38', 368, 9, 20, 740771) She writes in answer to letters that she has had of mine, and then she says (in French dialect), “We are commencing the winter and the snows are coming down to keep us company for many months.
('38', 368, 9, 21, 740964) I shall have plenty of time to occupy myself with my loom.
('38', 368, 9, 22, 741023) And I have now got an order for two pieces at 59 metres,
('38', 368, 10, 23, 741080) 1 For Gandhiji’s reply; vide “Letter to Isabel Bamlet”, 10 5 1927
('38', 369, 0, 1, 741146) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 369, 1, 2, 741188) so I shall need the time, as I get tired easily in these days” (at 75 years old!).
('38', 369, 1, 3, 741271) Her life is a perfect example of the full, yet peaceful and contented existence, which should be the lot of all peasantry.
('38', 369, 1, 4, 741394) In the summer she works in the fields, with just a few odd hours of spinning and weaving put in here and there when the days are wet, and in the winter when the land is under snow, she works away at her wheel and her loom all day.
('38', 369, 1, 5, 741625) Take this hand industry away from her, and she would be lost in complete misery.
('38', 369, 1, 6, 741706) As it is, she is the happiest and sweetest natured person on the mountainside.
('38', 369, 1, 7, 741785) Because she alone, of all the peasants in that place, has retained the old industry, and she alone has a full and true life.
('38', 369, 1, 8, 741910) I enclose you one of the little photographs which shows her sitting on a log of wood caressing one of her goats, which may give you some slight idea of her dear old face.
('38', 369, 1, 9, 742081) The younger woman is her daughter in law.
('38', 369, 1, 10, 742123) I have the beautiful photograph which I am unable to reproduce in Young India, but the imaginative reader will have no difficulty in filling in the picture.
('38', 369, 1, 11, 742280) The point of the letter however is that even in that machine ridden country, there are people who find their true peace in this, at one time universal, home industry of the wheel and the loom.
('38', 369, 1, 12, 742473) And if this old woman, who for her industry is young at 75, finds her solace, not her livelihood, in the wheel and the loom, how much greater is their need in this land where very few women reach the age of 75, where the majority needlessly are old at 50, and where millions of women need not merely the solace of an innocent cottage industry to occupy their idle hours but who need it even more to keep the wolf from the door?
('38', 369, 1, 13, 742901) ‘If that is so, why do not the millions take to the home industry, even as the dear old Swiss sister does, and find from it their solace and their food?
('38', 369, 1, 14, 743054) What is there to prevent them from doing so?,’ asks the ignorant scoffer.
('38', 369, 1, 15, 743128) But somewhat similar was the question put by a burly, rough looking Englishman to Surendranath Bannerjea in 1889 or 1890 when he was haranguing an English audience.
('38', 369, 1, 16, 743293) This worthy member of the firm of John Bull and Company asked the then uncrowned king of Bengal, if what the latter said was true that India desired freedom, what prevented her from taking it, how was it that they, members of this numerous and powerful firm, never heard of breaking of window panes, let alone heads, as they the members were wont to do when they could not get what they wanted?
('38', 369, 1, 17, 743688) So far as my memory serves me right, the papers recorded no answer from the orator.
('38', 369, 1, 18, 743772) There was only a ‘hear, hear’ from the audience.
('38', 369, 1, 19, 743821) But what the honest Englishman said to Surendranath may be safely repeated even today, and we know that such a question will be no answer to the cry

('38', 370, 1, 2, 744013) for freedom.

('38', 370, 1, 4, 744057) Knowing the way we may not have the power or the will to adopt it.
