('38', 371, 1, 15, 747480) India is unfortunately a land of almost perpetual famines, and the chief activity of the All India Spinners’ Association at the present moment is directly to deal with such causes of famine as are within the power of man to control.
('38', 371, 1, 16, 747713) Man cannot control and regulate floods beyond a certain limit.
('38', 371, 1, 17, 747776) They will take their toll in spite of the exercise of all the ingenuity that man may be capable of.
('38', 371, 1, 18, 747876) But floods always leave a legacy behind, which man can and is bound to deal with.
('38', 371, 1, 19, 747958) In a similar manner man cannot bring water beyond a certain point when the rains fail.
('38', 371, 1, 20, 748045) But man can produce conditions whereby people who are willing to work can find work enough to buy food with, when Nature leaves enough scope for transferring grain from one place to another.
('38', 371, 1, 21, 748236) It is exactly these causes that the All India Spinners’ Association is endeavouring in a humble manner to deal with through its growing army of workers.
('38', 371, 1, 22, 748389) The method adopted is to establish spinning centres in places where there is the greatest need for work during off seasons.
('38', 371, 1, 23, 748513) The largest amount of such work is being done, as is now well known, in South India.
('38', 371, 1, 24, 748598) And the letter I have reproduced is a recommendation

('38', 382, 7, 24, 767710) MOONJE, I was looking forward to a copy of your address.

('38', 382, 7, 26, 767853) Acharya Gidwani wrote to me preparing me for the receipt of your address.

('38', 382, 7, 28, 768050) And, when he told me so, I wrote to him saying that if you had done any such thing, it would not surprise me as your philosophy admitted of any means for beating an opponent with.
('38', 382, 7, 29, 768230) I have now read your address and I see that it confirms Acharya Gidwani’s opinion.
('38', 382, 7, 30, 768313) I suppose it is unnecessary to tell you that the view you ascribe to me is not mine.
('38', 382, 7, 31, 768398) For, it is conceivable to me that you did not know my repeated declarations that I do not regard untouchability as is now
('38', 383, 0, 1, 768520) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 383, 1, 2, 768562) practised as a part of Hindu religion, and that if I could persuade myself that it was, I should disown Hinduism.
('38', 383, 1, 3, 768676) But this very palpable misrepresentation of my view does not affect our friendship.
('38', 383, 1, 4, 768760) For, mistaken though I regard your philosophy to be, love of the country is good enough bond between you and me.
('38', 383, 1, 5, 768873) Some day of course I expect to convert you [to] my view that it is a good policy even to treat an opponent fairly and justly.
('38', 383, 1, 6, 768999) And my conversion of you will be my contribution to the shuddhi movement.
('38', 383, 1, 7, 769073) Of course you want to know my opinion about your address.
('38', 383, 1, 8, 769131) I congratulate you upon your frankness and fearlessness; but the substance of your address makes no appeal to me.
('38', 383, 1, 9, 769245) Your address is a powerful and eloquent plea on behalf of Islam not as its best exponents know it, but as you know it, and if I do not know better my own Hinduism, I do not know what I should do.
('38', 383, 1, 10, 769441) You have also put yourself to immense pain in demonstrating that untouchability is an integral part of Hinduism, a view which I repudiate and have always repudiated in toto.
('38', 383, 1, 11, 769615) Happily for me, my Hinduism does not bind me to every verse because it is written in Sanskrit, because it is supposed to be a part of some of our scriptures.
('38', 383, 1, 12, 769773) If your portraiture of events is true and if your view of Hinduism is also true, the outlook is only gloomy both for Hinduism and for the country.

('38', 383, 1, 14, 770056) I claim in all humility to have lived Hinduism all my life.
('38', 383, 1, 15, 770116) But I can’t convert you by argument.
('38', 383, 1, 16, 770153) And I know you will sweep me off my feet with a mere gesture if I endeavour to convert you by means of lathi blows.
('38', 383, 1, 17, 770269) I shall therefore be content with what I know to be the Hindu way and wait patiently for my opportunity.

('38', 385, 1, 2, 772465) 386. LETTER TO CHINAI
('38', 385, 2, 3, 772487) NANDI DURG, Vaishakha Sud 13 [May 14, 1927] 3
('38', 385, 3, 4, 772533) BHAISHRI CHINAI, I have your letter.
('38', 385, 3, 5, 772570) Even before this I got the news from Bhai Kalyanji and Pragjibhai.
('38', 385, 3, 6, 772637) Your letter however throws more light.
('38', 385, 3, 7, 772676) I congratulate you on the fortitude you displayed in receiving the blows without either returning them or running away.
('38', 385, 3, 8, 772796) I have no doubt that your action will bring benefit to you as well as to the people.
('38', 385, 3, 9, 772881) We should entertain no doubt about it just because we cannot ourselves see its good results.
('38', 385, 3, 10, 772974) I shall now answer your questions.
('38', 385, 3, 11, 773009) It cannot be stated categorically whether or not one may participate in the activities of the Hindu [Maha]sabha.
('38', 385, 3, 12, 773122) Those who are capable of having their own ideals implemented may surely do it, or those who are in agreement with the ideology of their local leaders will join them anyway.
('38', 385, 3, 13, 773295) I find nothing wrong with the Hindu [Maha]sabha’s aims and ideals.
('38', 385, 3, 14, 773362) There can be nothing wrong in organizing a community.
('38', 385, 3, 15, 773416) Abolition of untouchability is everyone’s dharma.
('38', 385, 3, 16, 773466) Shuddhi is a very wide term.
('38', 385, 3, 17, 773495) A part of what it connotes may be acceptable to us, some of it may be rejected.
('38', 385, 3, 18, 773575) I think their manifesto gives no rigid definition of shuddhi.
('38', 385, 3, 19, 773637) People therefore have to make their own individual choice after considering the activities carried on in their respective province or city.
('38', 385, 3, 20, 773777) As a matter of fact you have therefore to act as directed by your own inner self in view of the local situation.
('38', 385, 3, 21, 773890) There is no absolute dharma that you must attend all the meetings convened by the Mahasabha, nor are you bound by dharma to take active part in any meeting which you happen to attend.
('38', 385, 3, 22, 774074) Dharma consists in undertaking an act only if it is likely to advance what one regards as one’s dharma.
('38', 385, 3, 23, 774178) I would have no objection to taking part in a procession launched by the Hindu [Maha]sabha if it is done with a pure motive and not expressly with the intention to create trouble.
('38', 385, 3, 24, 774358) If we get news of a riot we should certainly exercise our strength, such as it is, in bringing about peace.
('38', 385, 3, 25, 774466) It is everyone’s dharma to make every pious effort to stop riots breaking out.
('38', 385, 3, 26, 774545) I employ the adjective “pious” with a purpose because in this age of cowardice men are presumed to be observing their dharma of peace by remai 
('38', 386, 0, 1, 774689) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 387
('38', 386, 1, 2, 774732) ning indifferent merely with a view to saving their own skin.
('38', 386, 1, 3, 774794) Thus by pious efforts, I mean, no one is required to check the riots at the cost of his dharma.
('38', 386, 1, 4, 774890) If there is an attack on my temple coming up and I just disappear or if I am advised to run away, neither I nor the person who counsels flight can be said to have been trying to stop the riot.
('38', 386, 1, 5, 775083) Social boycott can be justified in principle.
('38', 386, 1, 6, 775129) I have however never seen a clear reason for a social boycott of Muslims; nor is a general social boycott possible, as far as I can see.
('38', 386, 1, 7, 775266) Please do write to me if you need further elucidation.
('38', 386, 1, 8, 775321) I hope your pain has subsided; that Raiji too must be all right by now.
('38', 386, 1, 9, 775393) One of your doubts remains to be cleared.
('38', 386, 1, 10, 775435) There is absolutely no reason to believe that the Government has a hand in the functioning of the Hindu [Maha]sabha.
('38', 386, 1, 11, 775552) The Government, nonetheless, is wont to make use of every sabha or samiti with a view to consolidating their own position, as it does with the Hindu [Maha]sabha, the Muslim League and even the Congress.

('38', 389, 3, 8, 781132) 390. NOTE
('38', 389, 4, 9, 781142) RAMACHANDRA LIFT
('38', 389, 5, 10, 781159) The lift has now been in use in several parts of Gujarat since the management of it was taken over by the Satyagraha Ashram.

('38', 395, 2, 3, 791276) Vaishakha Sud Purnima [May 16, 1927] 1
('38', 395, 3, 4, 791315) SISTERS, I am very glad to know that you are not afraid.
('38', 395, 3, 5, 791372) A person who knows that God is the Protector of all, why need he fear?
('38', 395, 3, 6, 791443) By saying that God is the Protector of all, I do not mean that none would be able to rob or harm us.
('38', 395, 3, 7, 791544) If this happens, it is not a reflection on the capacity of God to protect us; it is an indication of our lack of faith in Him.
('38', 395, 3, 8, 791671) The river is ever ready to give water to all.
('38', 395, 3, 9, 791717) But if one does not approach it with a pot in which to fetch water, or avoids it thinking its water poisonous, how can that be the fault of the river?
('38', 395, 3, 10, 791868) Fear is a sign of lack of faith.
('38', 395, 3, 11, 791901) But faith cannot be developed by means of reasoning.
('38', 395, 3, 12, 791954) It comes gradually through reflection, meditation and practice.
('38', 395, 3, 13, 792018) To develop such faith, we pray to God, recite bhajans, read good books, seek the company of the good and take to sacrificial spinning at the wheel.
('38', 395, 3, 14, 792166) He who has no faith will not even touch the spinning wheel.

('38', 397, 7, 12, 794797) 401. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('38', 397, 8, 13, 794836) NANDI HILLS, May 17,1927
('38', 397, 9, 14, 794861) DEAR SATIS BABU, When my illness is fast becoming a thing of the past yours seems to be obstinate.
('38', 397, 9, 15, 794960) Whilst it remains so, you must not stir out.
('38', 397, 9, 16, 795005) But why does it persist like that?
('38', 397, 9, 17, 795040) Are you undergoing any treatment there?
('38', 397, 9, 18, 795080) What exactly is the food you are taking?
('38', 397, 9, 19, 795121) I ask this question as Mr. Gregg has sent me a book containing the latest researches on food and its relation to health.
('38', 397, 9, 20, 795242) One thing does appear to me, however apart from the book.
('38', 397, 9, 21, 795300) May it be that your vegetarian food does not agree with your body that has been built up upon flesh foods?
('38', 397, 9, 22, 795407) While the change may not have done any visible harm, may it have undermined the constitution or may it be that the change of diet does not serve for rebuilding a shattered constitution?
('38', 397, 9, 23, 795593) So it happened in my case.
('38', 397, 9, 24, 795620) I went on famously on fruit and nut alone for more than six years.
('38', 397, 9, 25, 795687) But after that severe attack of dysentery I could not rebuild the body without milk to which in some shape or other the constitution was used up to 45 years or rather 40 years.
('38', 397, 9, 26, 795864) You know my rigid predilection, bord ering on fanaticism, for vegetarianism.
('38', 397, 9, 27, 795941) But my fanaticism exhausts itself with my own person for the simple reason that it is a mater of lifelong habit and of deep religious conviction.
('38', 397, 9, 28, 796087) But religious convic 
('38', 397, 10, 29, 796109) 1 Wife of Totaram Sanadhya, a Fiji returned immigrant, an inmate of the Sabarmati Ashram
('38', 398, 0, 1, 796198) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 399
('38', 398, 1, 2, 796241) tion is a matter personal to every individual.
('38', 398, 1, 3, 796288) Therefore, even being a vegetarian, I never enforce my conviction on friends but leave them free to do as they choose, even when they are under my influence, as I did for instance for Prabhudas, Chhaganlal’s son.
('38', 398, 1, 4, 796501) I had an English friend living with me in Durban.
('38', 398, 1, 5, 796551) He had become a vegetarian under my influence.
('38', 398, 1, 6, 796598) After some time he became ill.
('38', 398, 1, 7, 796629) I could see that he could not get on well without his usual diet.
('38', 398, 1, 8, 796695) I begged of him to procure meat from outside and become well.
('38', 398, 1, 9, 796757) I could not introduce it in my own home.
('38', 398, 1, 10, 796798) I want you to seriously consider the question therefore.
('38', 398, 1, 11, 796855) You have to think not only of yourself but of Nikhil also and even Hemprabha Devi if she is still as bad as you are and Tarini if he is a vegetarian.
('38', 398, 1, 12, 797005) If you are eating pulses, they are of course a fatal thing for weak persons and those with sedentary habits.
('38', 398, 1, 13, 797114) You saw with what agitation Andrews cabled to me all the way from South Africa about milled rice.
('38', 398, 1, 14, 797212) And my concern about your food became enhanced upon reading the book sent by Mr. Gregg.
('38', 398, 2, 15, 797300) If there is any particular book on Buddhism that you require please tell me and I shall try to procure it.
('38', 398, 2, 16, 797407) The paragraph about yoga in Navajivan was unfortunate.
('38', 398, 2, 17, 797462) I did think of yoga practices, but only from two sides, their reputed helpfulness in restoring health and in aiding brahmacharya, the latter for the sake of helping the student world whose mind is cut up to pieces under dissipating practices, and the former with reference to my own health.
('38', 398, 2, 18, 797753) Having read a book on brahmacharya, during my illness and having heard copious references to use of asanas I began further research.
('38', 398, 2, 19, 797886) I do not hope to get much help for acquiring greater purity.
('38', 398, 2, 20, 797947) Not that I do not need all that I can get, but I do not feel that I shall get it through these practices.
('38', 398, 2, 21, 798053) One who considers himself proficient in yoga told me that in their final stages Raja Yoga, Hatha Yoga and Karma Yoga were one and the same and that it was only in the final stage that conquest of passions in every shape and form was at all possible; and that in Hatha Yoga the final stage was difficult of attainment and required extensive practice.
('38', 398, 2, 22, 798403) I was not surprised to hear this.
('38', 398, 2, 23, 798437) For, I knew it before I was so authoritatively told.
('38', 398, 2, 24, 798490) For that conquest therefore I have only to continue along the path I have so long followed.
('38', 398, 2, 25, 798582) But I am taking gentle exercise by way of some of these asanas and am eager to take more as I become stronger.
('38', 398, 2, 26, 798693) You need not therefore think any more about the yoga practices.
('38', 398, 2, 27, 798757) Some day in order to remove expectations and misunderstandings, I propose

('38', 402, 1, 2, 804386) 406. NAGPUR SATYAGRAHA
('38', 402, 2, 3, 804409) I see an Associated Press telegram in the papers, in which Mr. Manchershah Awari is reported to have said, that he had my consent and full sympathy for his movement of civil disobedience with regard to the Arms Act and the Explosive Substances Act, designed for the release of the Bengal detenus.
('38', 402, 2, 4, 804706) If my recollection is correct, either the Associated Press repre sentative has misunderstood Mr. Awari, or the latter has misunder stood me.
('38', 402, 2, 5, 804847) I have no recollection of having given my consent in advance to Mr. Awari’s proposed launching out on civil disobedience in any connection whatsoever.
('38', 402, 2, 6, 804998) It is really contrary to my practice to give such consent in advance.
('38', 402, 2, 7, 805068) I did discuss the theory of civil disobe dience with Mr. Awari, for whose patriotic spirit and self sacrifice I have great regard.
('38', 402, 2, 8, 805199) I drew his attention to the grave limitations of civil disobe dience.
('38', 402, 2, 9, 805269) He spoke, and rightly, with great warmth and concern about the Bengal detenus, and I remember having said, that if some move ment in the shape of civil disobedience could be conceived and successfully launched, it would be a great thing.
('38', 402, 2, 10, 805507) I hold that view even at the present moment.
('38', 402, 2, 11, 805552) For I regard the indefinite detention of the Bengal patriots without any trial of any sort as a grave injustice.
('38', 402, 2, 12, 805665) And if I have remained dumb, it is not because I do not feel the wrong as keenly as the closest friends of the detenus, but because I do not desire to make a fruitless exhibition of my powerlessness.
('38', 402, 2, 13, 805865) A public worker has to learn to endure with fortitude what he cannot cure.
('38', 402, 2, 14, 805940) And bed ridden though I am, if I could think of any feasible civil plan for securing the release of these prisoners, I should embark upon it without the slightest hesitation.
('38', 402, 2, 15, 806115) But I confess that I have none in view.
('38', 402, 2, 16, 806155) My own personal opinion is that there is no atmosphere in the country for civil disobedience.
('38', 402, 2, 17, 806249) We have fallen upon evil times.
('38', 402, 2, 18, 806281) The atmos phere today is one not of non violent disobedience but of very violent and suicidal disobedience.
('38', 402, 2, 19, 806389) I have no knowledge whatsoever of what is being done in Nagpur.
('38', 402, 2, 20, 806453) I can pronounce no judgment upon Mr. Awari’s movement.
('38', 402, 2, 21, 806508) I have given no consent for the movement.
('38', 402, 2, 22, 806550) I had intended to say not one word about the movement, and it would have been well if Mr. Awari had not dragged in my name.
('38', 402, 2, 23, 806674) If he thought that his movement had my consent, he should have laid the whole of his plan in a concrete form before me and secured it in writing.
('38', 402, 2, 24, 806820) If I had approved of it and if I could not have taken an active part myself, I would at
('38', 403, 0, 1, 806908) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 403, 1, 2, 806950) least have backed it with all the force at my command through these columns.
('38', 403, 1, 3, 807027) He must now thank himself if my disclaimer harms his movement in any way.
('38', 403, 1, 4, 807101) And let it be a warning in future to everyone concerned against using my name in connection with any movement without my pre vious consent in writing.
('38', 403, 1, 5, 807252) Indeed it is necessary for workers to become self reliant and dare to prosecute their plans if they so desire without hankering after the backing of names of persons supposed to be great and influential.
('38', 403, 1, 6, 807456) Let them rely upon the strength of their own convic tion and the cause they seek to espouse.
('38', 403, 1, 7, 807549) Mistakes there will be.
('38', 403, 1, 8, 807573) Suffering even avoidable there must be.
('38', 403, 1, 9, 807613) But nations are not easily made.
('38', 403, 1, 10, 807646) There will have to be rigid and iron discipline before we achieve anything great and enduring, and that discipline will not come by mere academic argument and appeal to reason and logic.
('38', 403, 1, 11, 807833) Discipline is learnt in the school of adversity.
('38', 403, 1, 12, 807882) And when zealous young men will train themselves to responsible work without any shield, they will learn what responsibility and discipline are.
('38', 403, 1, 13, 808027) And out of this army of candidate leaders, will arise one real leader, who will not have to plead for obedience and discipline but who will command it as a matter of course, because he will have been tried in many a skirmish and will have proved his right to undisputed leadership.
('38', 403, 2, 14, 808309) Young India, 19 5 1927
('38', 403, 3, 15, 808332) 407. HORRIBLE PRACTICES
('38', 403, 4, 16, 808356) Mr. Andrews in the course of a letter from Durban says: 1
('38', 403, 5, 17, 808414) I know the temple at Umbilo, which may really be called a suburb of Durban.
('38', 403, 5, 18, 808490) Even years ago, when the temple was erected, I had my misgivings.
('38', 403, 5, 19, 808556) Bitter experience has taught me that all temples are not houses of God.
('38', 403, 5, 20, 808628) They can be habitations of the devil.
('38', 403, 5, 21, 808666) These places of worship have no value unless the keeper is a good man of God.
('38', 403, 5, 22, 808744) Temples, mosques, churches are what man makes them to be.
('38', 403, 5, 23, 808802) I am therefore not surprised at the painful and horribly superstitious prac tices going on in this so called temple.
('38', 403, 5, 24, 808919) The origin of these practices is easy enough to trace.
('38', 403, 5, 25, 808974) There are three classes of Indians in South Africa.
('38', 403, 5, 26, 809026) The free Indian trader has nothing to do with these practices.
('38', 403, 6, 27, 809089) 1 Not reproduced here.
('38', 403, 6, 28, 809112) The correspondent had referred to the evil practices of self torture like “fire walking” festivals by Indians at Umbilo temple and to a page of pictures of such things in The Natal Advertiser.
('38', 404, 0, 1, 809305) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 405
('38', 404, 1, 2, 809348) Nor have the large number of Colonial born Indians who have received in the face of terrible odds a tolerably liberal education.
('38', 404, 1, 3, 809477) The third class is the indentured Indian, now become free.
('38', 404, 1, 4, 809536) He is drawn naturally from the poorest class here.
('38', 404, 1, 5, 809587) Nothing has ever been done by the Government or the employers or by the free Indian community to help these unfortunate men and women out of their ignorance and superstition.
('38', 404, 1, 6, 809762) The result is that they are preyed upon by superstitious and even evil minded men who pose as priests and holy men.
('38', 404, 1, 7, 809878) They mutter a few Sanskrit verses whose meaning they do not know and which they horribly mispronounce, and resort to all kinds of awe inspiring practices.
('38', 404, 1, 8, 810033) And what can be better than a temple, where simple people congregate and where every kind of superstition derives a halo from associations attributed to temples?
('38', 404, 1, 9, 810195) I think that the common law of South Africa is wide enough to deal with these prac tices if the Government desires to put them down.
('38', 404, 1, 10, 810328) The fact is, unfortunately, that the prejudice against Indians in South Africa is not ascribable to these practices, nor is it directed against the men who are victims of this barbarism.
('38', 404, 1, 11, 810515) It is directed chiefly against the free trading class who have nothing to do with these practices.
('38', 404, 1, 12, 810614) And therefore these practices have gone without any notice or comment.
('38', 404, 1, 13, 810685) And if they are now being noticed, it is in order to prejudice the European mind against the Habibullah Agreement and against what little relief is sought to be given by it to the Indian settlers.
('38', 404, 1, 14, 810882) It should also be borne in mind that these practices are by no means common amongst Indians throughout South Africa.
('38', 404, 1, 15, 810999) They are confined only to the part of the coast of Natal where indentured Indians are to be found in their largest numbers.
('38', 404, 1, 16, 811123) If therefore the Government intend to put these practices down, they can do so under the common law with ease, and they can be dealt with also through municipal bye laws.
('38', 404, 1, 17, 811294) I am sure, that if action is taken, not a voice will be raised against it in the name of religion falsely so called for sheltering these practices.
('38', 404, 1, 18, 811442) No cultured Indian will have anything to do with them, and the ignorant people who witness these tortures with awe will not dare to defend them in a court of law.
('38', 404, 1, 19, 811605) What we can do here is to encourage cultured Indians in South Africa to fight the superstition.
('38', 404, 1, 20, 811701) They should, without seeking Government intervention, work in the midst of the poor people, and wean them from these barbarisms, and advise them to help the Government, if they choose to prosecute those who take part in those practices, thus showing their desire not to reproduce in South Africa all that is bad in our life, but
('38', 405, 0, 1, 812030) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 405, 1, 2, 812072) to reproduce only that which is good in our civilization.
('38', 405, 1, 3, 812130) It is our duty to advise and encourage our countrymen in South Africa to do nothing that will give a handle to the agitation against them.

('38', 405, 3, 5, 812292) 408. LETTER TO SATCOWRIPATI RAY
('38', 405, 4, 6, 812324) NANDI HILLS (MYSORE STATE), May 19, 1927
('38', 405, 5, 7, 812365) DEAR SATCOWRI BABU, I got your letter day before yesterday after that day’s mail was closed.
('38', 405, 5, 8, 812458) I could not possibly over take your letter yesterday.
('38', 405, 5, 9, 812512) You have my deepest sympathy with you in your troubles.
('38', 405, 5, 10, 812568) But I have much fear it is out of my power to help you in the direction desired by you.
('38', 405, 5, 11, 812656) All the same please let me have a full description of your property, where it is situated, what is its extent, whether there are any buildings on it and if there are, their dimensions.
('38', 405, 5, 12, 812841) Possession of this information will be useful for me.
('38', 405, 5, 13, 812895) But your case is not out of the ordinary.
('38', 405, 5, 14, 812937) I know many who are passing through the same difficulty.
('38', 405, 5, 15, 812994) It is also one of the things we have to go through in our march towards our goal.
('38', 405, 5, 16, 813076) And I want you to bear your troubles with philoso phic calmness as I know you will do.
('38', 405, 5, 17, 813163) But why do you say insolvency is not to be thought of?
('38', 405, 5, 18, 813218) Honest insolvency is no crime if a borrower [borrows] in good faith for investing in a prosperous enterprise.
('38', 405, 5, 19, 813328) Suppose that through no fault of my own the enterprise fails and the loaner knew that I had no other means of repayment.
('38', 405, 5, 20, 813449) Surely if he is impatient, insolvency is the only honourable course left open for me even if I desired as I should to repay the loan in spite of insolvency.
('38', 405, 5, 21, 813606) For, insolvency would be the only way of my doing further business.
('38', 405, 5, 22, 813674) As a lawyer you know the genesis of insolvency law.
('38', 405, 5, 23, 813726) It was created to protect honest but unlucky enterprise and to encourage trade and enterprise.
('38', 405, 5, 24, 813821) No doubt the golden rule is not to borrow.
('38', 405, 5, 25, 813864) But so few of us follow the golden rule.
('38', 405, 5, 26, 813905) The next best therefore is not to accept a defeat but to seek the protection of the insolvency court and open a new leaf, and if successful, in the next enterprise, repay of one’s own free will the original loaner.
('38', 405, 5, 27, 814120) There are such celebrated instances of men having deliberately become insolvent and then repaid their creditors.
('38', 405, 5, 28, 814233) In my own practice, I advised
('38', 406, 0, 1, 814263) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 407
('38', 406, 1, 2, 814306) one of my nearest clients 1, who because he had taken part in the satyagraha movement, was forced into the insolvency court.
('38', 406, 1, 3, 814431) I called a meeting of the debtors.
('38', 406, 1, 4, 814466) They were unbending.
('38', 406, 1, 5, 814487) I challenged them to do their worst.
('38', 406, 1, 6, 814524) The consequence was insolvency.
('38', 406, 1, 7, 814556) But after the insol vency, the client paid the creditors in full to their agreeable astonish ment.
('38', 406, 1, 8, 814655) They apologized and they showed their sincerity by giving him afterwards unlimited credit which they had no occasion to regret.
('38', 406, 1, 9, 814783) I therefore strongly advise you to meet the creditors, place the position frankly and fearlessly before them and tell them that you will repay if you earned.
('38', 406, 1, 10, 814941) If they don’t listen, let them make you insolvent, or if the insolvency law here admits of voluntary surrender you may even surrender voluntarily.
('38', 406, 1, 11, 815088) Then you will have breathing time and then if you do not want to resume practice, you will join the Khadi Service.
('38', 406, 1, 12, 815203) Khadi Service will never give you Rs. 25,000. But if the movement goes forward with a leap, khadi will become a commercial proposition, and when it does become that, there will be a moderate amount of money in it also.
('38', 406, 1, 13, 815422) This may seem to be all far fetched; not so to me.
('38', 406, 1, 14, 815473) I regard khadi as a far sounder proposition even from a commercial standpoint than the least that can be made by our merchant princes.
('38', 406, 1, 15, 815608) After all sound commerce is of slow growth.
('38', 406, 1, 16, 815652) But my confidence in khadi is such that, though it is of slow growth, in the long run, it will prove to be the shortest route to healthy commercial prosperity of individuals as it certainly will be of the nation.
('38', 406, 1, 17, 815865) I do not want you [to] succumb therefore under the influence of false pride or [a] false sense of honour.
('38', 406, 1, 18, 815971) I want you to be a pattern for others, and therefore please follow my advice and get rid of the burden which is evidently bearing you down.
('38', 406, 1, 19, 816111) Then make a firm resolution not to borrow a single farthing henceforth.
('38', 406, 1, 20, 816183) Public workers must not borrow.
('38', 406, 1, 21, 816215) And insist upon your numerous family dependants to work for their livelihood and let them all work for khadi, and if they don’t want to do that, the male members may make their own choice; females may grumble but will submit to the inevitable.
('38', 406, 1, 22, 816459) This regulation of family obligations is also a necessary corollary to national uplift.
('38', 406, 1, 23, 816547) We must break through this family crust if we are to grow to our national height.
('38', 406, 1, 24, 816629) These falsely assumed obligations I know are hampering the progress of individuals and the nation in a way very few things are doing.
('38', 406, 1, 25, 816763) It is wrong, I almost want to say immoral, to support men and women who have some capacity for work.

('38', 413, 6, 18, 827039) MAGANLAL, I have your letter.

('38', 413, 6, 21, 827178) Do what all of you think proper.
('38', 413, 7, 22, 827211) It occurs to me that there is one thing I should write to you about.
('38', 413, 7, 23, 827280) Ramchandra and Ganesh are both good and honest persons.
('38', 413, 7, 24, 827336) Such persons should be retained if possible.
('38', 413, 7, 25, 827381) But while they are retained, we must be firm with them as well as gentle.
('38', 413, 7, 26, 827455) We should not have the slightest hesitation in pointing out their faults.
('38', 413, 7, 27, 827529) That is what I mean by firmness.
('38', 413, 7, 28, 827562) You must frankly tell Ramchandra: ‘You exaggerate.
('38', 413, 7, 29, 827613) You are hasty and hot tempered and never willing to see your own faults.
('38', 413, 7, 30, 827686) You can stay here only by recognizing those faults and overcoming them.
('38', 413, 7, 31, 827758) It is no use appealing to Gandhi, because he has delegated all powers to us.’ If he stays on even after such frank
('38', 414, 0, 1, 827873) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 415
('38', 414, 1, 2, 827916) talk, he should be allowed to stay and if he wishes to go, he should be allowed to go, whatever the inconvenience caused thereby.
('38', 414, 1, 3, 828046) You must also tell Ganesh frankly: ‘We suspect that you do not wish to teach the others the craft you know.
('38', 414, 1, 4, 828154) We can carry on only if you teach others and train them.
('38', 414, 1, 5, 828211) If not, you are free to go.
('38', 414, 1, 6, 828239) But we shall not drive you away if you should wish to continue here even after you have trained somebody.
('38', 414, 1, 7, 828345) You will continue to receive the help you are having today.
('38', 414, 1, 8, 828405) We want you to stay.
('38', 414, 1, 9, 828426) But you can stay only on our conditions.’ In other words, firmness lies in telling a person what we think about him.
('38', 414, 1, 10, 828543) We should be gentle in conveying this and it should not be an expression of hasty judgment.
('38', 414, 1, 11, 828635) Gentleness also means an effort to see whatever good may be seen in a fault.
('38', 414, 1, 12, 828712) But ultimately, we can proceed correctly and carry on our work only when we have fully expressed our view about a fault of which we are convinced.
('38', 414, 1, 13, 828859) Then alone can we consider ourselves true satyagrahis.
('38', 414, 1, 14, 828914) I see that relations among people are not smooth.
('38', 414, 1, 15, 828964) At present there is hesitation in frankly expressing our views on the faults of others which are clear to us.
('38', 414, 1, 16, 829074) If that veil of hesitation is removed, much of the work can become easy.
('38', 414, 1, 17, 829147) This is intended only by way of guidance.

('38', 415, 8, 14, 830638) 421. HE SHOULD BE DISMISSED
('38', 415, 9, 15, 830666) I have now got the name and the address of the doctor, the account of whose inhuman treatment of an Antyaja woman was given to us by Shri Amritlal Thakkar.
('38', 415, 9, 16, 830822) 1 Now an inquiry is being made into the case and in the mean time I do not see any necessity of disclosing his identity.
('38', 415, 9, 17, 830943) A well known doctor friend writes : 2
('38', 415, 10, 18, 830981) My reason for publishing this letter is that the inhuman treatment of the Antyaja woman was such as no one can possibly condone.
('38', 415, 10, 19, 831110) I do not believe that if the doctor is a private practitioner, the only alternatives before us are to grieve over the incident in helpless silence, if we wish to follow the path of non violence, or, if not, give the doctor a thrashing.
('38', 415, 10, 20, 831346) A thrashing is not likely to make the doctor change his ways.
('38', 415, 10, 21, 831408) Antyaja brethren will not benefit in any way, and we will probably fail either to do justice to the doctor or win redress for the cruel ill treatment of the woman.
('38', 415, 10, 22, 831572) One who follows non violence need not feel helpless.
('38', 415, 10, 23, 831625) The path of non violence is neither for the coward nor for the stupid.
('38', 415, 10, 24, 831696) It is for those who are ever
('38', 415, 11, 25, 831725) 1 Vide “Man’s Inhumanity to Man”, 5 5 1927.
('38', 415, 12, 26, 831769) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('38', 416, 0, 1, 831806) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 417
('38', 416, 1, 2, 831849) vigilant.
('38', 416, 1, 3, 831859) The law of violence concerns the body and its requirements, while the law of non violence appeals to the heart.
('38', 416, 1, 4, 831971) Through non violence we can arouse religious consciousness among the people, which means cultivating bold and true public opinion.
('38', 416, 1, 5, 832102) If the true spirit of compassion were alive in the village in which this incident occurred, such cruelty would never have been possible.

('38', 416, 4, 11, 832760) 422. THE COW AND THE BUFFALO
('38', 416, 5, 12, 832789) A votary of non violence writes: 1
('38', 416, 6, 13, 832824) When writing the article on the cow and the buffalo, I had assumed that no clarification was called for about the matter of swaraj to the buffalo.
('38', 416, 6, 14, 832971) When we domesticate an animal, we deprive it of its freedom, however good our intention in domesticating it may be.
('38', 416, 6, 15, 833087) Hundreds of Englishmen feel happy in the belief that they rule India with a good motive and, even if we reject that rule, they think us to be fools and do not relinquish what they consider to be their duty of ruling over us.
('38', 416, 6, 16, 833312) But if a judge were appointed between us, this state ment by us would suffice: ‘How can these self appointed protectors of ours understand our sufferings.
('38', 416, 6, 17, 833467) Only the All seeing God and we ourselves know them.
('38', 416, 6, 18, 833519) And we of course say that our good lies in being released from our bondage.’ Similarly, if the buffalo could speak and if an impartial judge were appointed between her and us and the buffalo entered a similar plea, and I do believe she would do so—the verdict would be in her favour.
('38', 416, 6, 19, 833803) And so I said that by giving up our fancy for rearing buffaloes, we would not be forsaking her,
('38', 416, 7, 20, 833899) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('38', 416, 7, 21, 833936) Referring to Gandhiji’s article “Cow V. Buffalo or Cow cum Buffalo?”, 8 5 1927, the correspondent had asked what Gandhiji had meant by granting swaraj to the buffalo.
('38', 417, 0, 1, 834103) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 417, 1, 2, 834145) that is, would not be doing her any harm, but would be granting her freedom.
('38', 417, 1, 3, 834222) There is no question in this of our disowning an accepted responsibility.
('38', 417, 1, 4, 834296) We must accept responsibility for those buffaloes which we have reared, but, if I am right in my view, no duty like that which we have accepted in regard to the cow, of adopting ways and means of increasing and improving the progeny of the cow, devolves upon us in regard to the buffalo.
('38', 417, 1, 5, 834584) Hence it is not necessary to regard the protection of the buffalo as included in our special duty of cow pro tection.
('38', 417, 1, 6, 834702) If people accept my suggestion, it will naturally be our duty to collect together all the buffaloes we have reared in regions where the cow and the bullock cannot, but only the buffalo can be maintained, and provide for the protection of her male progeny as well.
('38', 417, 1, 7, 834966) It was not my intention to suggest that there should be separate dairies and tanneries for villages, but the fact is that in the existing circumstances, it is only after making experiments in the cities that we can take to villages the science of cattle rearing, of extracting the maximum quantity of milk from the cow without torturing her, and that of tanning her hide and so on.
('38', 417, 1, 8, 835348) Such is our pitiable condition at present.
('38', 417, 1, 9, 835391) In these days, when village pasture lands have disappeared and oilcake, hay, etc., have become dear, the villagers maintain their cattle with great difficulty.
('38', 417, 1, 10, 835551) We rest content with whatever use the illiterate tanner can make of the hide.
('38', 417, 1, 11, 835629) The bones, etc., are wasted.
('38', 417, 1, 12, 835658) As a consequence, this living wealth perishes and, if the cattle do not die, they live on as skeletons, often become a burden to the owner and in the end, land in slaughter houses in Bombay and other cities.
('38', 417, 1, 13, 835866) I know that, in these circumstances, important changes need to be adopted, but I am at present unable to say how to bring them about, what methods we should adopt from the West, and so on.
('38', 417, 1, 14, 836055) This whole thing is at the moment in an experimental stage.
('38', 417, 1, 15, 836115) If I have been able to explain what needs to be done, it is for every individual worker to experiment on his own and discover how to do it.
('38', 417, 1, 16, 836255) There was a time when appropriate changes could be effected in our civilization and people accepted the need for such changes.
('38', 417, 1, 17, 836382) As long as these conditions of progress were accepted, so long, we can say, our civilization was living.
('38', 417, 1, 18, 836487) Now we believe that whatever is written in a book which is published as a Shastra and which finds its way into our hands is the Lord’s word and cannot be altered in any way.
('38', 417, 1, 19, 836661) We must get out of this horrible mental death.

('38', 433, 5, 5, 866699) 439. HIGHLY UNSATISFACTORY
('38', 433, 6, 6, 866726) I wish it was possible for me to tender the Government of Bengal congratulations upon the release of Sjt.
('38', 433, 6, 7, 866832) Subhas Chandra Bose.
('38', 433, 6, 8, 866853) The release has been granted, not because public opinion demanded it, not because Government considered the Chief Officer of the Calcutta Corporation to be guiltless, nor because they considered that he had been sufficiently punished for a crime of which neither he nor the public has any knowledge, but because their own medical officers considered the distinguished prisoner to be seriously ill, so seriously ill as to cause fear about his life.
('38', 433, 6, 9, 867301) If Sjt.
('38', 433, 6, 10, 867309) Subhas Chandra Bose is a danger to society or to the life of anybody, and if he is a man of determination as he is reputed to be and even believed by the Government to be, he is no less dangerous because he is seriously ill.
('38', 433, 6, 11, 867534) Why should the Government be afraid of his dying in their prison?
('38', 433, 6, 12, 867600) Surely it is not customary with them to release every prisoner who becomes dangerously ill.
('38', 433, 6, 13, 867692) And if it was right to discharge him for his illness, why was he not discharged when he first showed signs of tuberculosis?
('38', 433, 6, 14, 867816) Papers have been for a long time full of information about the alarming character of his disease.
('38', 433, 6, 15, 867914) His brother repeatedly warned the Government about the prisoner’s illness.
('38', 433, 6, 16, 867989) It is, I venture to suggest cowardly to fling a dying man in the face of his relatives and wash oneself of the guilt of his death.
('38', 433, 6, 17, 868120) This release brings us no nearer to the solution of the question of imprisonment or indefinite detention, without trial, of prisoners whom Government choose to suspect.
('38', 433, 6, 18, 868289) The Bengal Regulation remains where it was.
('38', 433, 6, 19, 868333) More or less healthy detenus must continue to rot, and are now deprived of the support of an agitation which was kept at a fairly high pitch because a powerful man was under detention.
('38', 433, 6, 20, 868518) No doubt some sort of agitation will still continue for the release of the other detenus.
('38', 433, 6, 21, 868608) But there is every fear of its lacking strength.
('38', 433, 6, 22, 868657) Indian nature is grateful for the smallest mercies.
('38', 433, 6, 23, 868709) It is easily satisfied.
('38', 433, 6, 24, 868733) And the public will condone the detention of the other prisoners for the release of Sjt.
('38', 433, 6, 25, 868822) Subhas Chandra Bose, forgetting that the release is due not to any
('38', 434, 0, 1, 868889) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 435
('38', 434, 1, 2, 868932) relenting on the part of the Government but due to Nature’s supreme intervention.
('38', 434, 1, 3, 869014) It may seem cruel, but I must confess that I would far rather not have any release at all than have a release on false issues, which merely complicate the main issue and make it more difficult to deal with than before; for behind the agitation for the release of the detenus is the great question of the liberty of the citizens and the question of extraordinary powers exercised over the lives of people by an utterly irresponsible Government.
('38', 434, 1, 4, 869458) The one consolation that the public can derive from this painful affair is, that Sjt.
('38', 434, 1, 5, 869544) Subhas Chandra Bose up to the very last moment manfully declined to accept the humiliating conditions from time to time proposed by the Government for his discharge.
('38', 434, 1, 6, 869710) Let us hope and pray that he will be soon restored to health and that a long life of service will be vouchsafed to him.
('38', 434, 2, 7, 869830) Young India, 26 5 1927
('38', 434, 3, 8, 869853) 440. AN APPEAL TO INDIAN HUMANITY
('38', 434, 4, 9, 869887) In another place will be found a substance of the observations made in the columns of Navajivan by Sjt.
('38', 434, 4, 10, 869991) Kishorelal Mashruwala.
('38', 434, 4, 11, 870014) He is a worker of long standing and was up to recently Registrar of the Gujarat Vidyapith, and it was only due to illness that he was obliged to relinquish the post.
('38', 434, 4, 12, 870180) He is one of the most thoughtful among the silent workers we have in India.
('38', 434, 4, 13, 870256) He weighs every word he writes or utters.
('38', 434, 4, 14, 870298) I mention these qualifications of his; for I am anxious that his reflections should not be dismissed out of consideration as so many writings nowadays have to be.
('38', 434, 4, 15, 870461) The story of the abuse of the helpless women of the Raniparaj community is a blot upon the nation.
('38', 434, 4, 16, 870560) Kishorelal Mashruwala has made his appeal to the Parsis, and from his standpoint, rightly too.
('38', 434, 4, 17, 870655) For it is the Parsis who will be better able, if anyone is, to influence the Parsi men who are said to be corrupting innocent womanhood.
('38', 434, 4, 18, 870792) But I am painfully aware of the fact that it is not the Parsis alone who hold so cheap the honour of poor sisters.
('38', 434, 4, 19, 870907) Indians belonging to the other faiths, placed in similar circumstances, have been known to behave exactly as the Parsi canteen keepers are reported to be doing.
('38', 434, 4, 20, 871068) But that is no justification whatsoever for the inhuman crimes of the latter.
('38', 434, 4, 21, 871146) The lust for money, which drives these adventurers to a trade which they know saps the manhood of the otherwise fine forest dwellers miscalled
('38', 435, 0, 1, 871289) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 435, 1, 2, 871331) Kaliparaj, i.e., black people, tempts them to the worse crime of defilement.
('38', 435, 1, 3, 871408) The British Government or rather the Government of India and the Baroda State must be held primarily responsible for the tragedy described by Sjt.
('38', 435, 1, 4, 871555) Mashruwala; for it is they, who for their wretched revenue allow liquor shops to be opened or to exist in the midst of these simple people.
('38', 435, 1, 5, 871695) These people have never asked for these shops, and even if they had, it would be still criminal to open liquor shops for them, even as it would be to allow a little child to play with fire because he desires it.
('38', 435, 1, 6, 871907) But a reformer does not stop before commencing action to philosophize or to distribute blame through golden scales.
('38', 435, 1, 7, 872023) He begins his reform wherever the opportunity offers itself.
('38', 435, 1, 8, 872084) And now that the corruption has been brought to light, it behoves Parsi reformers to go to the delinquents and appeal to their sense of honour and try to wean them from the crime of violating the womanhood of the simple, innocent and guileless Raniparaj, even if they cannot also be weaned from trafficking in liquor.
('38', 435, 1, 9, 872402) Unfortunately, there is much truth in the taunt levelled at us as a nation, that we have not sufficient regard for the honour of our women.
('38', 435, 1, 10, 872542) It is no use false patriotism seeking cover under tu quoque argument; nor must we mix up sexual immorality, in which depraved men and women of equal status indulge of their own free but unbridled will, with the instances of crime quoted by Sjt.
('38', 435, 1, 11, 872787) Kishorelal Mashruwala.
('38', 435, 1, 12, 872810) Immoralities of the first kind are bad enough and do incredible harm to mankind; but the crimes like those of the Parsi canteen kee pers are infinitely worse and have not yet, thank God, received the tacit endorsement of fashionable society.
('38', 435, 1, 13, 873052) In the instances quoted by Sjt.
('38', 435, 1, 14, 873084) Kishorelal Mashruwala, the canteen keepers are in the position of trustees, and it is insufferable that they should induce ignorant women in whose midst they are living to become instruments of their criminal lust.
('38', 435, 1, 15, 873299) It is this kind of indifference to the honour of ignorant sisters who come under the influence or protection of the so called better class men, which has been justifiably criticized, and which we must, if we want to become a self respecting and independent nation, outgrow at any cost.
('38', 435, 1, 16, 873585) The honour of the least among our sisters must be as dear to us as that of our blood sisters.
('38', 435, 2, 17, 873679) Young India, 26 5 1927

('38', 436, 1, 2, 873745) 441. NOTES
('38', 436, 2, 3, 873756) ALL INDIA SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION
('38', 436, 3, 4, 873788) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association has, owing to the necessity of prolonged rest that I must take from active and routine work, relieved me of the burden of directing the affairs of the Association and appointed Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj as officiating Chairman.
('38', 436, 3, 5, 874062) Whilst, therefore, I still nominally remain President of the Association, the whole burden of directing its affairs will now fall upon Jamnalalji, and correspondents will henceforth, whenever they find it necessary, write to him rather than to me.
('38', 436, 3, 6, 874310) The proper course certainly is to write to the working Secretary Sjt.
('38', 436, 3, 7, 874380) Shankerlal Banker to whom naturally Jamnalalji will have to refer all correspondence before coming to any decision.
('38', 436, 3, 8, 874496) This does not mean that I shall take no interest in the affairs of the Association.
('38', 436, 3, 9, 874580) On the contrary, whenever in the opinion of the Council or the officiating Chairman or the Secretary, any matter should be referred to me, it will come before me for guidance and advice.
('38', 436, 3, 10, 874767) But the Council’s decision and the arrangements I have come to with it are that I should not worry myself as hitherto over details and over every individual matter trifling or otherwise.
('38', 436, 3, 11, 874954) They have taken an undertaking from me to refrain from doing so and to throw the burden on them and leave it for them to refer to me matters which they may consider to be important enough for referring to me.
('38', 436, 3, 12, 875163) The test of a living organization is that it depends upon no single individual, however important, however able he may be.
('38', 436, 3, 13, 875286) A living organization goes on irrespective of persons.
('38', 436, 3, 14, 875341) The endeavour of the members of the Council is to make the Association a living and efficiently working organization.
('38', 436, 3, 15, 875459) I trust, therefore, that khadi workers and khadi lovers will fall in with the new arrangement and render all the help they can to the Council in working this growing organization to the fullest extent possible.
('38', 436, 4, 16, 875670) AN EXAMPLE TO COPY
('38', 436, 5, 17, 875689) The State of Jaora seems to be noted for its dyeing and printing.
('38', 436, 5, 18, 875755) I understand that His Highness the Nawab Saheb is interested in the khadi movement and, in order to make khadi more attractive by putting it through the dyeing and printing processes and thus to encourage it, he has exempted khadi from any tax.
('38', 436, 5, 19, 876000) I congratulate the State on this praiseworthy step, and hope that other States will grant favoured treatment to this great and growing national enterprise which

('38', 441, 4, 8, 882724) 446. LETTER TO R. B. GREGG
('38', 441, 5, 9, 882751) NANDI HILLS, May 27, 1927
('38', 441, 6, 10, 882777) MY DEAR GOVIND, The occasion for writing this letter is supplied by your capital letter of the 17th instant to Maganlal of which he has sent me a copy.
('38', 441, 6, 11, 882929) Your suggestions are all perfect, if the premises can be accepted by us.
('38', 441, 6, 12, 883002) Probably Maganlal has not even thought of what I am about to tell you; though I shouldn’t be surprised if he has also thought of the same thing, for I think that he has assimilated the inwardness of the spinning movement.
('38', 441, 6, 13, 883224) What I want to state is this: the movement is bound to fail if we expect to succeed by adopting the same methods, or very nearly the same methods with necessary adaptations, as the adversary, if such a term can be properly used under a plan of life which admits of no enemies.
('38', 441, 6, 14, 883501) In my opinion, we have to devise other ways of making the movement a living and universal force at least so far as India is concerned.
('38', 441, 6, 15, 883636) The adversary believes in the latest appliances and therefore is bound to adopt the methods of those who are adepts in using those appliances; but in the spinning movement, modern appliances are largely discarded and the few that are retained are used in a different way.
('38', 441, 6, 16, 883908) Typewriters, shorthand assistance and the like are taken in our movement as a temporary measure.
('38', 441, 6, 17, 884005) Immediately one goes to the villages, these become a hindrance rather than a help.
('38', 441, 6, 18, 884088) If the movement has to depend upon first class stenography, it will fail before long.
('38', 441, 6, 19, 884174) For, it cannot make any headway under those conditions beyond the cities.
('38', 441, 6, 20, 884248) It cannot succeed even if it has to depend upon the English language for its spread.
('38', 441, 6, 21, 884333) And so you find that at the Ashram, in the Association office and even here we are managing with most
('38', 442, 0, 1, 884435) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 443
('38', 442, 1, 2, 884478) indifferent stenography.
('38', 442, 1, 3, 884503) Even if we advertised, we shall probably not get the best stenographer, because he will know that there is room only for half a dozen stenographers in the movement, and then we shall have to pay not 100 or 125, which is the most I think that is being paid, but we should have to pay anything between 200 and 400 for getting the assistance such as you have in mind.
('38', 442, 1, 4, 884868) I should quite agree with you if you argue that even that salary would be economy even if only one man has to be obtained.
('38', 442, 1, 5, 884991) Experience, however, shows that it is not possible to retain the services of such a man unless you are prepared to allow him to become the master and to dictate his own terms in every respect.
('38', 442, 1, 6, 885184) Thus it would be useless to have an able stenographer who has no faith in the movement, who would disdain to wear khadi and who would require polished furniture before he will settle down to work.
('38', 442, 1, 7, 885381) The spinning movement, so far as I can see, will never afford the high wages that are demanded by good men in such a line of business.
('38', 442, 1, 8, 885516) Do you know that if in khadi service we offer high wages even to one man, there is immediately and naturally a ferment throughout the rank and file and they would all begin to compare their low wages to the high wages given even to one single man?
('38', 442, 1, 9, 885764) The proper working of the spinning movement is still being evolved.
('38', 442, 1, 10, 885832) It is in a state of flux, and it will be some time before it can be said to be stabilized.
('38', 442, 1, 11, 885923) It is a movement which has to grow from within.
('38', 442, 1, 12, 885971) It is a movement which requires a fair measure of continuous sacrifice from those who have become accustomed to city life.
('38', 442, 1, 13, 886094) The class of men and women required for the movement have got to be trained and brought up.
('38', 442, 1, 14, 886186) They cannot therefore be had by advertising.
('38', 442, 1, 15, 886231) The reason why we have not got efficient stenography is because no endeavour has been made to train stenographers.
('38', 442, 1, 16, 886346) It is quite possible for instance to make of Chhaganlal, Mahadev, Krishnadas, Pyarelal and many others whom I can name first class stenographers.
('38', 442, 1, 17, 886492) But it was considered not worth while doing so.
('38', 442, 1, 18, 886540) It would have been like throwing away a rupee for a pice, and so we are managing with fourth rate stenographers hoping that if they assimilate the spirit of the movement they will distinguish themselves in the work they have undertaken by coming up to the highest level.
('38', 442, 1, 19, 886811) I have entered into this elaborate argument—very badly expressed because it is for the first time that I am reducing to writing this thought about the movement—because I am anxious that you who are saturated with the spirit of the spinning movement should understand all that is at the back of my mind and then give me the benefit of your criticism.
('38', 442, 1, 20, 887161) If I have not expressed myself clearly, as I
('38', 443, 0, 1, 887206) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 443, 1, 2, 887248) am afraid I have not, do not please hesitate to ask me for further explanation and by an interchange of a few letters, probably, I shall be able to express myself more clearly than I have done.
('38', 443, 1, 3, 887442) But of course apart from what I have said above, there is much to be said for your view.
('38', 443, 1, 4, 887531) Young India and Navajivan are not all I want them to be.
('38', 443, 1, 5, 887588) There are reasons for it into which however I need not enter just now.
('38', 443, 1, 6, 887659) Some are avoidable and some are unavoidable.
('38', 443, 1, 7, 887704) I hope to be able to cope with those that are avoidable.
('38', 443, 1, 8, 887761) I got the book on vitamins.
('38', 443, 1, 9, 887789) I read it through as soon as I got it.
('38', 443, 1, 10, 887828) It is a good book.
('38', 443, 1, 11, 887847) But it failed to convince me.
('38', 443, 1, 12, 887877) The subject of vitamins has still, so far as I can see, to be investigated.
('38', 443, 1, 13, 887953) The author’s statement does not appear to me to be the final word.
('38', 443, 1, 14, 888020) Their ruling out all the nuts and the pulses in preference to meat foods goes against the grain and is contrary to all I have read in the vegetarian literature.
('38', 443, 1, 15, 888181) If what the authors have said be the final word about them, it is a severe blow to vegetarianism.
('38', 443, 1, 16, 888279) But the authors could not possibly have sufficient data about the effect of nuts and pulses to enable them to come to a just decision.
('38', 443, 1, 17, 888414) Accurate observation about the efficacy or the inefficacy of vegetable protein foods can only be made on an extensive scale in India, where alone one meets thousands of born vegetarians.
('38', 443, 1, 18, 888601) Their diet and their habits have to be scientifically observed and analysed before safe deductions can be drawn; and then, too, there are so many disturbing factors.
('38', 443, 1, 19, 888767) Climate, harmful customs and suchlike have to be taken into account before using the values of foods taken by them.
('38', 443, 1, 20, 888883) I am therefore taking all the statements in that book with a great deal of caution.
('38', 443, 1, 21, 888967) The late A. F. Hills was President of the Vegetarian Society in London.
('38', 443, 1, 22, 889039) He was a good man.
('38', 443, 1, 23, 889058) I do not know the extent of his scientific knowledge.
('38', 443, 1, 24, 889112) But he indulged in bold speculations about diet.
('38', 443, 1, 25, 889161) He carried on a series of experiments himself.
('38', 443, 1, 26, 889208) He wrote a number of articles on what he called “vital food”.
('38', 443, 1, 27, 889270) He divided foods into three or four divisions: one for those whose occupation was pre dominantly body labour; another for those whose occupation was predominantly intellectual; third for those whose occupation was predominantly spiritual and the fourth for those who were not in a healthy condition.
('38', 443, 1, 28, 889570) His reasoning used to appeal to me in those days.
('38', 443, 1, 29, 889620) I do not know whether it would now if I read all his writings afresh.
('38', 443, 1, 30, 889690) I followed also keenly the controversy going on in the medical profession in those days about food values, and I know that
('38', 444, 0, 1, 889813) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 445
('38', 444, 1, 2, 889856) one army of doctors defended white bread for all they were worth, and another army suggested that white bread was the staff of death and that the brown bread alone was the staff of life.
('38', 444, 1, 3, 890043) There was even a Bread Reform League with Miss Yates as its energetic Secretary.
('38', 444, 1, 4, 890124) I used to come in close contact with the lady.
('38', 444, 1, 5, 890171) But I learnt even then that either side was fanatical, either produced statistics and analysis of various types of bread.
('38', 444, 1, 6, 890293) No one had sufficient data for its absolute conclusions.
('38', 444, 1, 7, 890350) For they could not set a large number of men, who would for the sake of their observations, live purely on brown bread and water or white bread and water.
('38', 444, 1, 8, 890505) I remember one example that was given by a doctor.
('38', 444, 1, 9, 890556) I think it was Dr. Allinson.
('38', 444, 1, 10, 890585) He said he put one of his dogs upon white bread for one month and it died; and another upon brown bread for one month and it lived.
('38', 444, 1, 11, 890717) The irresistible inference was that white bread was the staff of death and brown bread was the staff of life.
('38', 444, 1, 12, 890827) He did not state whether both the dogs were kept under restraint the whole of the time, nor did he state whether both the dogs started with the same stamina.
('38', 444, 1, 13, 890985) Let me confess that in those days, that is nearly 40 years ago, I sided with Dr. Allinson and I swallowed his testimony about the dogs and used to eat nothing but brown bread, and in the brown bread variety also, largely Allinson’s brown bread; because, the worthy doctor took care to emphasize the necessity of taking Allinson’s brown bread, for that alone contained the whole wheat meal ground to the necessary fineness.
('38', 444, 1, 14, 891408) He was a good man.
('38', 444, 1, 15, 891427) I read all his writings.
('38', 444, 1, 16, 891452) Even in 1914, I consulted him when I was suffering from pleurisy when I constantly refused to take even milk.
('38', 444, 1, 17, 891562) Probably the worthy doctor is still alive.
('38', 444, 1, 18, 891605) All the same I came to discount, as experience ripened, most of the argument of the type I have mentioned.
('38', 444, 1, 19, 891712) The upshot of all this is to tell you that I have not made many changes in my food beyond what I reported to you.
('38', 444, 1, 20, 891826) I still take unboiled milk.
('38', 444, 1, 21, 891854) I dilute it with water.
('38', 444, 1, 22, 891878) The milk that comes fresh from the goats is poured over boiling water; that gives the necessary warmth to the milk and addition of water makes it lighter.
('38', 444, 1, 23, 892033) I am taking yet a little bread or a little bhakhari made of home ground wheat, and I am taking one green vegetable.
('38', 444, 1, 24, 892149) The authors of the book say that addition of soda destroys the vitamins in the vegetables.
('38', 444, 1, 25, 892240) But without soda, the vegetables refuse to be soft.
('38', 444, 1, 26, 892292) I have therefore decided to add soda to the vegetable.
('38', 444, 1, 27, 892347) It is difficult to digest it unless it is thoroughly cooked.
('38', 444, 1, 28, 892408) Uncooked green cabbage, my system rejects.
('38', 444, 1, 29, 892451) You will have observed that all the four vitamins are to be found in milk.
('38', 444, 1, 30, 892526) They are to be found also in the fruits I am taking and therefore I do not lose
('38', 445, 0, 1, 892606) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 445, 1, 2, 892648) much by adding soda at the time of cooking cabbage or Indian marrow.
('38', 445, 1, 3, 892717) There is no difficulty about the cooking of spinach without soda and so whenever I get spinach, soda is not added.
('38', 445, 1, 4, 892832) There is no occasion for worry about my health; for, I seem to be getting better though slowly.
('38', 445, 1, 5, 892928) No food will give me personal satisfaction unless I can revert to fruits and nuts.
('38', 445, 1, 6, 893011) But it seems to me that I shall have to close this earthly life without getting that personal satisfaction.
('38', 445, 2, 7, 893119) Yours sincerely, [PS.] Forgive me this very long letter.

('38', 446, 6, 8, 894979) NANDI HILLS, May 28, 1927
('38', 446, 7, 9, 895005) MIRA, I have your two letters as also your telegram.
('38', 446, 7, 10, 895058) In order not to delay replying for two days I am resorting to dictation.
('38', 446, 7, 11, 895131) I do not want to break the rule as far as possible of not writing letters myself except during silence.
('38', 446, 7, 12, 895235) Both your letters are precious.
('38', 446, 7, 13, 895267) I now understand the Ashram much better than I ever did before.
('38', 446, 7, 14, 895331) It is almost like having been there myself and seen it.
('38', 446, 7, 15, 895387) So characteristic is your account, and it is usefully supplemented by Valunjker’s letter.
('38', 446, 7, 16, 895477) You did well in not entering into the comparative merits of respective parties, and I do hope that you will remain unmoved even if you hear comparisons that may not please you.
('38', 446, 7, 17, 895654) Those who enter into comparisons do so honestly.
('38', 446, 7, 18, 895703) That it is improper to enter into such comparisons they do not know.
('38', 446, 7, 19, 895772) And what is the use of being ruffled by listening to an expression of views honestly held?

('38', 448, 2, 3, 899122) NANDI HALLS, May 28, 1927
('38', 448, 3, 4, 899148) MY DEAR GULZARILAL, I was delighted to hear from you.
('38', 448, 3, 5, 899202) Whilst lying on my bed, I have constantly thought of so many like you in whom I am deeply interested and from whom, I expect many large and big things if only God will give them the requisite health for the task before them.
('38', 448, 3, 6, 899427) Your description of a truly religious life is accurate.
('38', 448, 3, 7, 899483) I have not a shadow of a doubt that this blessed state of inward joy and freedom from anxiety should last in the midst of the greatest trials conceivable.
('38', 448, 3, 8, 899638) It admits of no exception whatsoever.
('38', 448, 3, 9, 899676) Naturally, it is unattainable except by the very fewest.
('38', 448, 3, 10, 899733) But that it is attainable by human beings, I have also no doubt.
('38', 448, 3, 11, 899798) That we do not find in history evidence regarding the existence of any such person merely proves to me that all the record that we have has been prepared by imperfect beings, and it is impossible for imperfect beings to give us a faithful record of perfect ones.
('38', 448, 3, 12, 900061) The same may be said of our own experiences.
('38', 448, 3, 13, 900106) We have to be very nearly perfect in order to meet perfect souls as you have described.
('38', 448, 3, 14, 900194) Nor need you think that I have laid down an absurd proposition inasmuch as it is incapable of being recorded, or being experienced by the average man.
('38', 448, 3, 15, 900345) To raise such a doubt would be begging the question, for we are here picturing to ourselves extraor dinary mortals, though mortals nevertheless, and surely extra ordinary powers are required to find out these extraordinary mortals.
('38', 448, 3, 16, 900577) This statement is true even of much lesser things, things almost ridiculous, and yet very difficult of accomplishment, such, for instance, as the discoveries of Sir J. C. Bose or the finest paintings.
('38', 448, 3, 17, 900778) Both these, we average beings will have to take on trust.
('38', 448, 3, 18, 900836) It is only the privileged few who have got the special faculty for understanding and appreciating either those discoveries, or those paintings.
('38', 448, 3, 19, 900980) These do not appear to us to be incredible and we are able to accept them on faith only because in favour of these we have the testimony of a larger number of witnesses than we can possibly have for the things of permanent value, such as human perfection of the utmost type.
('38', 448, 3, 20, 901255) Therefore the limitation that you have accepted is quite a workable thing for the time being.
('38', 448, 3, 21, 901349) For, even inside the limitation, there is ample scope for widening the field for the progress of the state of being and remaining unruffled in the face of the onslaught of sorrows and trials, which before regeneration would have paralysed us.
