('38', 456, 2, 4, 915497) 457. MEANS OF COW PROTECTION
('38', 456, 3, 5, 915526) Shri Pragji Mavji, manager of the pinjrapole in Nasik, makes the following suggestions in a letter 1 which he has written: In these suggestions there is not much that is new and has not been said in Navajivan.
('38', 456, 3, 6, 915736) But I have printed them to show how a devoted servant of mother cow and experienced manager of a pinjrapole supports the suggestions which have been made earlier in these columns.
('38', 456, 3, 7, 915916) The letter also contains some useful information.
('38', 456, 3, 8, 915966) For instance, the information about the use which contractors make of dead cattle, if these are handed over to them, is such as will shock us.
('38', 456, 3, 9, 916109) Such wicked things happen because, in the name of religion, people themselves do not make use of the dead animals but hand them over to others.
('38', 456, 3, 10, 916253) The suggestion in regard to bones needs some modification.
('38', 456, 3, 11, 916312) Burying bones as they are does not produce manure; they have to be ground into powder.
('38', 456, 3, 12, 916399) The flesh and intestines need not be buried.
('38', 456, 3, 13, 916444) Intestines are used even now for making leather strips, strings for musical instruments and catguts, and the fat obtained from flesh is used in great quantities for lubricating machinery.
('38', 456, 3, 14, 916632) So there remains very little to be buried in its natural form.
('38', 456, 3, 15, 916695) But this concerns the future.
('38', 456, 3, 16, 916725) If we accept in principle that by making in goshalas and pinjrapoles all those things against the use of which we have no religious objection, we can save the maximum number of cattle, other discoveries will follow.
('38', 456, 3, 17, 916941) The reproach to cow protection workers implied in the last suggestion deserves attention.
('38', 456, 3, 18, 917031) Every such worker should bear in mind that there is a greater need for workers who will devote themselves to active work of service and make themselves proficient in their field of work than for preachers who go round exhorting others.
('38', 456, 3, 19, 917267) But, along with this letter 2, I have before me a press cutting containing a long interrogatory addressed to me on the question of
('38', 456, 4, 20, 917398) 1 Not translated here 2 What follows is the translation as found in Young India, 3 11 1927.
('38', 457, 0, 1, 917490) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 457, 1, 2, 917532) cow protection.
('38', 457, 1, 3, 917548) The underlying suggestion obviously seems to be that the methods of cow protection advocated by me are not consistent with my profession of Hinduism.
('38', 457, 1, 4, 917698) For in his introductory remarks to his questions the writer has tried to make light of the basic principle of cow protection that I have formulated, viz., that what is economically wrong cannot be religiously right.
('38', 457, 1, 5, 917914) In other words, if a religion cuts at the very fundamentals of economics it is not a true religion but only a delusion.
('38', 457, 1, 6, 918034) My critic on the other hand believes that this view is opposed to the teachings of our ancient scriptures.
('38', 457, 1, 7, 918141) I, at least, am not aware of a single text in opposition to this view nor do I know of any religious institution that is being maintained in any part of the world today in antagonism to the elementary principles of economics.
('38', 457, 1, 8, 918367) As for Nature, anyone who has eyes can see, that it always observes the principle that I have stated.
('38', 457, 1, 9, 918469) For instance, if it has implanted in its creation the instinct for food it also produces enough food to satisfy that instinct from day to day.
('38', 457, 1, 10, 918612) But it does not produce a jot more.
('38', 457, 1, 11, 918648) That is Nature’s way.
('38', 457, 1, 12, 918670) But man, blinded by his selfish greed, grabs and consumes more than his requirements in defiance of Nature’s principle, in defiance of the elementary and immutable moralities of non stealing and non possession of other’s property and thus brings down no end of misery upon himself and his fellow creatures.
('38', 457, 1, 13, 918977) To turn to another illustration, our Shastras have enjoined that the Brahmin should give knowledge as charity without expecting any material reward for it for himself.
('38', 457, 1, 14, 919145) But they have at the same time conferred upon him the privilege of asking for and receiving alms and have laid upon the other sections of the community the duty of giving alms, thus uniting religion and economics in a common bond of harmony.
('38', 457, 1, 15, 919387) The reader will be able to find further instances of this kind for himself.
('38', 457, 1, 16, 919463) The religious principle requires that the debit and credit sides of one’s balance sheet should be perfectly square.
('38', 457, 1, 17, 919579) That is also the truest economics and therefore true religion.
('38', 457, 1, 18, 919642) Whenever there is any discrepancy between these two it spells bad economics and makes for unrighteousness.
('38', 457, 1, 19, 919749) That is why the illustrious author of the Gita has defined yoga as “balance” or “evenness”.
('38', 457, 1, 20, 919841) But the majority of man kind do not understand this use of economics to subserve religion; they want it only for amassing “profits” for themselves.
('38', 457, 1, 21, 919989) Humanita rian economics, on the other hand, for which I stand, rules out “profits” altogether.
('38', 457, 1, 22, 920084) But it rules out “deficit” no less for the simple reason that it is utterly impossible to safeguard a religious institution by following a policy of dead loss.
('38', 457, 1, 23, 920244) That is the reason why in spite of
('38', 458, 0, 1, 920279) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 459
('38', 458, 1, 2, 920322) our 1,500 goshalas we have not only failed to protect the cow, but its slaughter is day by day on the increase.
('38', 458, 1, 3, 920434) If in spite of this we delude ourselves into the belief that we have done our duty by the cow by establishing these homes for cattle, and remain smugly self satisfied there, whatever comfort it may give us, it won’t bring us one whit nearer the goal of cow protection, whereas it can be demonstrably shown that by adopting the policy that I have suggested we can easily realize this goal.
('38', 458, 1, 4, 920823) It does not require much effort to see that but for the fact that the cow yields us milk, the duty of cow protection would not have come into being at all.
('38', 458, 1, 5, 920979) There are a host of other innocent animals besides the cow in the world but nobody has ever thought of setting up their protection as a religious obligation, and if somebody had attempted it, it would have simply remained a dead letter.
('38', 458, 1, 6, 921216) We have use for the cow.
('38', 458, 1, 7, 921241) That is why it has become religiously incumbent on us to protect it.
('38', 458, 1, 8, 921310) To turn now to the questionnaire drawn up by my critic, I will embody the questions in my answers without reproducing them separately: 1. Every goshala or Pinjrapole should have a tannery adequate to its needs attached to it.
('38', 458, 1, 9, 921536) In other words, the manager in charge of every such institution should have a thorough knowledge of the immediate steps necessary for utilizing the remains of dead cattle.
('38', 458, 1, 10, 921708) If this is done, the question, viz., how many heads of cattle should a particular goshala contain, won’t arise at all.
('38', 458, 1, 11, 921827) 2. I do not know what the rate of mortality of cattle in goshalas is, nor is it relevant to my proposition.
('38', 458, 1, 12, 921935) So long as there is a single head of cattle in a goshala, its manager ought to know how to dispose of its remains after it is dead, just as he is expected to know how to look after it while it is alive.
('38', 458, 1, 13, 922138) 3. Such humanitarian institutions for the protection of cattle as I have described should normally take charge of the remains of the cattle that might die in the village.
('38', 458, 1, 14, 922309) Therein lies the interest of the cattle, the depressed classes and the general public alike.
('38', 458, 1, 15, 922402) In villages where there are no goshalas or the concomitant tanneries, some local person who believes in cow protection should take it upon himself to get the carcasses removed to the nearest tannery or get the preliminary processes performed upon it and send the useful parts there.
('38', 458, 1, 16, 922685) 4. The establishment of such tanneries as I have described does not require much capital outlay.
('38', 458, 1, 17, 922782) Only some initial expenditure
('38', 459, 0, 1, 922812) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 459, 1, 2, 922854) would be needed to train up workers for this work.
('38', 459, 1, 3, 922905) 5. It is true that at present the leather prepared from slaughtered hides is superior in quality to that prepared from dead hides.
('38', 459, 1, 4, 923036) But during the late War the Government of India spent enormous sums of money to improve the quality of leather from dead hides; and tannery experts have told me that dead hides can be tanned into as good leather as leather from slaughtered hides.
('38', 459, 1, 5, 923283) I myself am conducting experiments in this direction.
('38', 459, 1, 6, 923337) In Cuttack, Sjt.
('38', 459, 1, 7, 923354) Madhusudan Das has been doing the same for a number of years and with success as he tells me.
('38', 459, 1, 8, 923448) The Calcutta Government Research Tannery is also at present engaged in similar experiments.
('38', 459, 1, 9, 923540) But the tragedy of it today is that we annually export crores worth of hides to foreign countries, and by ignorantly using leather goods made from the hides of slaughtered cattle, become indirectly participators in the sin of their slaughter.
('38', 459, 1, 10, 923783) It rests in our hands entirely to prevent the export of hides of our dead cattle to foreign countries.
('38', 459, 1, 11, 923886) And this we can easily do by bringing the export trade in hides under our control through the establishment of tanneries on altruistic lines.
('38', 459, 1, 12, 924028) We cannot only save nine crores of rupees annually to our country but by employing that sum properly save a countless number of cattle.
('38', 459, 1, 13, 924164) I need hardly say that the humanitarian tanneries that I have suggested would also be utilizing the bones and other useful parts of the dead cattle.
('38', 459, 1, 14, 924313) In fact it is more necessary than ever.

('38', 460, 5, 10, 925457) NANDI HILLS, May 29, 1927 Do not compliment me on my promptness in acknowledging your letter.
('38', 460, 5, 11, 925551) Only it facilitates my work and therefore recovery if I do what little I can from day to day and have no arrears weighing upon my mind.
('38', 460, 5, 12, 925687) Letters like the one you have sent me I rarely publish.
('38', 460, 5, 13, 925743) The rule is to publish such letters when there is something in them which requires a public discussion.
('38', 460, 5, 14, 925847) The letter you have sent me is really too personal for publication and there is no warrant for printing it except to gratify my own pride.
('38', 460, 5, 15, 925986) There is therefore no question of my advertising you just yet or putting Dr. Scarpa in a false position by bringing in his name in the pages of Young India and in connection with an Italian letter.
('38', 460, 5, 16, 926184) I see that your letter is three letters rolled into one.
('38', 460, 5, 17, 926241) Please tell Perin and Khurshed that you are not there to encourage their laziness.
('38', 460, 5, 18, 926324) It will be time for them to cease to work and let you work for them when they cease to eat and let you eat for them.
('38', 460, 5, 19, 926441) There is a verse 1 in the Gita whose paraphrase is: Those who eat without working are thieves, except of course patients like myself.
('38', 460, 5, 20, 926575) For myself I have still only progress to report.
('38', 460, 5, 21, 926624) It is getting colder here day by day.

('38', 461, 1, 2, 926817) 460. LETTER TO R. B. GREGG
('38', 461, 2, 3, 926844) NANDI HILLS, May 29, 1927
('38', 461, 3, 4, 926870) MY DEAR GOVIND, I have your very important letter.
('38', 461, 3, 5, 926921) It crossed mine.
('38', 461, 3, 6, 926938) I cannot appropriate the credit you give me for gentle criticism of your hand writing.
('38', 461, 3, 7, 927025) What I wanted to say was that although I liked handwritten letter, there was no occasion for you to revert to writing your letters for my sake and that you should continue type writing as you believe in it, and as I know it does result in economy of time.
('38', 461, 3, 8, 927281) Nor do I consider your handwriting to be bad.
('38', 461, 3, 9, 927327) It might be clearer.
('38', 461, 3, 10, 927348) But fortuna tely for my friends I have my own writing as the criterion and that being so, I know very few whose writing is worse than mine, and yet because of my dislike of typewriters, if I could possibly write with my own hand, I will inflict that illegible hand in preference to having my letters typed or typing them myself.
('38', 461, 3, 11, 927677) The reason underlying is this.
('38', 461, 3, 12, 927708) If I have any concern for my friends, I should endeavour to write a better and more legible hand.
('38', 461, 3, 13, 927806) Typewriter is a cover for indifference and laziness.
('38', 461, 3, 14, 927859) Moreover I believe in the dictum —handwriting reveals the writer.
('38', 461, 3, 15, 927925) Typewriting certainly results in economy of time.
('38', 461, 3, 16, 927975) But whilst I admit that time is money, I do not admit that money is everything, and therefore I can conceive innumerable occasions when economy of time would be misplaced.
('38', 461, 3, 17, 928147) And the inroads that the typewriter is making have all but destroyed the magnificent art of calligraphy.
('38', 461, 3, 18, 928252) I wonder if you have seen old handwritten manuscripts when people used to pour forth their very soul into their work.
('38', 461, 3, 19, 928370) But I must not stray away from the subject on which I want to write.
('38', 461, 3, 20, 928439) Your suggestions about selecting a few untouchable boys and making them ideal farmers does great credit to your heart.
('38', 461, 3, 21, 928558) But it betrays your ignorance of the situation.
('38', 461, 3, 22, 928606) Even if half a dozen untouchables could be trained as you suggest, that will in no way bring us nearer the solution of the problem of untouchability.
('38', 461, 3, 23, 928756) To petrify on this matter—Hindu mind will immediately say, we shall touch every untouchable who qualified as these six men have.
('38', 461, 3, 24, 928885) You perhaps know that there have been many and many pariah saints, but their sainthood has not saved this suppressed class.
('38', 461, 3, 25, 929009) The orthodox mind again argues the pariah saint becomes so because of his past karma and he naturally commands our respect.
('38', 461, 3, 26, 929133) When the others do likewise, they will also command the same respect.
('38', 461, 3, 27, 929203) It is this immoral
('38', 462, 0, 1, 929222) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 463
('38', 462, 1, 2, 929265) deduction from the theory of karma which has got to be combated at every step and the Hindu mind has got to be educated by fierce penance and understanding that the theory of karma is not intended to kill all reform and all efforts, but that it is intended for mankind to work out all evil karma and he who does not do so is not entitled to belong to the human species.
('38', 462, 1, 3, 929635) The Hindu mind has therefore to be educated to regard intrinsically as equals the lowest, the fallen and the downtrodden and to give them a helping hand so as to make them level with the rest.
('38', 462, 1, 4, 929828) And why, apart from the question of untouc hability, should not the most promising young men be sent out to become accomplished farmers and try the experiment suggested by you?
('38', 462, 1, 5, 930005) Surely you do not wish to imply that the touchables in their pride will not care to learn farming with a view to utilizing human excreta as manure.
('38', 462, 1, 6, 930153) If that is your argument, it would be wrong to expect untouchables to handle work which others would consider as degrading.
('38', 462, 1, 7, 930277) As you know at the Ashram, we have untouchable boys.
('38', 462, 1, 8, 930330) We do not even ask them to do the sanitary work.
('38', 462, 1, 9, 930379) The initiative is taken by the so called high caste men; for, on such points the so called untouchables would be very touchy.
('38', 462, 1, 10, 930505) I am having that experience everywhere.
('38', 462, 1, 11, 930545) Underlying your suggestion, therefore, is the question not of untouchability but of improved farming methods along simple lines.
('38', 462, 1, 12, 930674) But I have simply not handled this question energetically because I believe in the doctrine of one thing at a time.
('38', 462, 1, 13, 930790) There is much scattered work here, so much laziness, so much blind imitation, so little concentration that it is necessary to hammer away at one very simple but fairly universal thing, and if that succeeds, the rest can follow.
('38', 462, 1, 14, 931018) And agriculture is an industry which can only be improved when it receives state assistance.
('38', 462, 1, 15, 931111) In an ill governed country, I think with Thoreau that the citizen who resists the evil government must ignore property rights.
('38', 462, 1, 16, 931238) And without assurance of settled ownership, it is impossible to do much in the way of agriculture.
('38', 462, 1, 17, 931337) I do not want to elaborate this thing.
('38', 462, 1, 18, 931376) I have said sufficient to enable you to fill in the rest.
('38', 462, 1, 19, 931434) Whilst your suggestion does not seem to me to be feasible so far as the untouchables are concerned and difficult of accomplishment, even as a general scheme the extract sent by you is valuable and I propose as soon as I find space to reproduce it in Young India so that those who are at all inclined in the direction might take the matter up.
('38', 462, 1, 20, 931777) I did not get the larger volume about vitamins.
('38', 462, 1, 21, 931825) What I got was Food and Health.
('38', 462, 1, 22, 931857) But that book also gives enough information about

('38', 466, 3, 4, 935948) I hope you will get from this work all the intellectual and spiritual nourishment you need.
('38', 466, 3, 5, 936040) I have no doubt that once you have mastered the elements of this science you will get thoroughly interested in it.

('38', 469, 1, 2, 939862) I must finish Madras and would really like to go through the other provinces also if I can do them gently and in a leisurely fashion leaving ample margin for rest and having no more than one meeting per day or even per two days.

('38', 469, 1, 4, 940299) I can therefore combine rest and work.

('38', 469, 1, 9, 940633) Then there are other parts of the Madras Presidency too which are quite cool.
('38', 469, 1, 10, 940711) And Karnatak is perfect after June.
('38', 469, 1, 11, 940747) You need have therefore no worry whatsoever, and, of course, I shall be taking soundings as the tour progresses.

('38', 475, 3, 10, 950977) 479. LETTER TO J. P. BHANSALI June 1, 1927 How can I put obstacles in your way or in the way of anyone else who, prompted by a religious motive, undertakes a religious effort.
('38', 475, 3, 11, 951153) But I wish to place a suggestion before you.
('38', 475, 3, 12, 951198) Fasting concerns the body.
('38', 475, 3, 13, 951225) Hence, though it has an important place in one’s spiritual develop ment, relatively it is a small thing.
('38', 475, 3, 14, 951330) It is a means and serves a useful purpose only when the mind is behind it.
('38', 475, 3, 15, 951405) I know that your mind cannot but be behind your fast, otherwise you could not have fasted for so many days.
('38', 475, 3, 16, 951513) Nevertheless please think more deeply over the matter and reconsider it.
('38', 475, 3, 17, 951586) Do you fast for some sort of self puri fication?
('38', 475, 3, 18, 951635) Do you weigh afterwards the benefits of your fasts?
('38', 475, 3, 19, 951687) Or are you indifferent towards them?
('38', 475, 3, 20, 951724) If you are, how do you justify your fasts as spontaneous acts?
('38', 475, 3, 21, 951787) The desire for fruit is implicit in describing a fast as meant for self purification.
('38', 475, 3, 22, 951873) This is not an unworthy desire; it is a worthy one.
('38', 475, 3, 23, 951925) In interpreting what is meant by the desire for fruit, one must use discrimination.
('38', 475, 3, 24, 952009) One’s duty is to be a mumukshu.
('38', 475, 3, 25, 952041) A mumukshu is one who aspires after moksha.
('38', 475, 3, 26, 952085) The true meaning of
('38', 475, 4, 27, 952105) 1 Sidelights on the Crisis in India by H. Harcourt and Chhotu Ram; Harcourt was a member of the Indian Civil Service and Deputy Commissioner of Gurdaspur and Chhotu Ram was Minister for Agriculture in the Punjab Government.

('38', 476, 1, 2, 952372) renunciation of the desire for fruit is that one who renounces it knows that the fruit does follow.

('38', 478, 5, 12, 957569) I got your letter.
('38', 478, 5, 13, 957588) Brahmacharya is to be observed in three ways— in mind, in speech and in body.
('38', 478, 5, 14, 957666) As long as the mind feels the slightest evil desire, there is always a danger of the desire for indulgence being aroused.
('38', 478, 5, 15, 957788) The evil desires of the mind are not controlled in a moment; their control, being the aim of man’s highest effort, takes ages to attain.
('38', 478, 5, 16, 957925) It is logical to believe that a person who conquers the evil desires in him in this life has succeeded in doing so by reason of the efforts in many lives rather than merely through his efforts in this life.
('38', 478, 5, 17, 958132) If in our conscious moments the body is about to violate brahmacharya, it is our duty at that time to commit suicide and destroy the body.
('38', 478, 5, 18, 958271) Hence one cannot be too vigilant towards one’s body; anyone who cannot be so vigilant has yet to learn the first lesson of brahmacharya.
('38', 478, 5, 19, 958408) Brahmacharya in speech is practically included in bodily brahmacharya, for, though it is the mind that inspires speech, in itself speech is a bodily function.
('38', 478, 5, 20, 958567) There remains the mind.
('38', 478, 5, 21, 958591) As one acquires greater control over the mind, one finds it easy to keep the body under control without having to struggle to do so, but until the mind is completely subjugated, there is a chance of involuntary emission.
('38', 478, 5, 22, 958812) We should not be frightened at such emission.
('38', 478, 5, 23, 958858) It is the mind we should fear.
('38', 478, 5, 24, 958889) Involuntary emission is Nature’s warning

('38', 479, 1, 11, 960221) We should find out where evil desires are lurking in the mind and strive harder still to banish them.

('38', 481, 3, 12, 965461) 484. CHOICE BEFORE US
('38', 481, 4, 13, 965483) A correspondent sends me a cutting from the Press giving most gruesome facts about the growing infantile crimes and illicit gratifica tion among girls in the New World.
('38', 481, 4, 14, 965652) A boy of four years is reported to have shot his mother, because she forbade him to play with matches.
('38', 481, 4, 15, 965755) When the police confronted him, he was in no way taken aback.
('38', 481, 4, 16, 965817) He threatened “to shoot them too”, and when questioned by the Coroner, he grew so impatient with him that he picked up a knife from among the exhibits lying in front of him and rushed to strike him.
('38', 481, 4, 17, 966016) It is said, that hardly a day passes in America without some crime being committed by a boy or a girl, and in most American colleges there are said to be suicide clubs or crime societies, and the more horrible part of the account shows that many girls, even of exclusive colleges, have become so lawless as to run away in pursuit of illicit adventures.
('38', 481, 4, 18, 966369) It is difficult, in an age in which newspapers, in order to provide
('38', 482, 0, 1, 966437) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 483
('38', 482, 1, 2, 966480) sensational food for their readers, invent stories when they have no facts to weave narratives from, to believe without reservation reports such as I have condensed.
('38', 482, 1, 3, 966646) But whilst one may make ample allowance for exaggeration, there is no doubt that infantile crime and lawlessness among boys and girls are sufficiently extensive in the New World to make us beware of a civilization which must be held responsible for these crimes and lawlessness.
('38', 482, 1, 4, 966925) That life in the West goes on—and it may be said progressively after a fashion—in spite of these infantile crimes, may be granted.
('38', 482, 1, 5, 967056) And it may also be granted that the wise people of the West are not only not unaware of the evil, but that they are manfully struggling to overtake it.
('38', 482, 1, 6, 967208) Nevertheless we have to decide whether we shall indiscriminately copy this civilization.
('38', 482, 1, 7, 967297) We may well pause in the face of the awful revelations that come to us from the West from time to time, and ask ourselves, whether after all it is not better to hold by our own civilization and seek, in the light of the comparative knowledge that is available to us, to reform it by removing its known excrescences.
('38', 482, 1, 8, 967613) For, there is no doubt, that if the West has its terrific problem arising out of its own civilization, we have no less grave problems of our own to deal with.
('38', 482, 1, 9, 967772) It is perhaps unnecessary, if not useless, in this connection to weigh the merits of the two civilizations.
('38', 482, 1, 10, 967880) It is likely that the West has evolved a civilization suited to its climate and surroundings, and similarly, we have a civilization suited to our conditions, and both are good in their own respective spheres.
('38', 482, 1, 11, 968089) This may be safely said that the crimes and the lawlessness described by me are almost impossible with us, and I hold that this is due to our pacific training and the restraining influence in the midst of which we are brought up.
('38', 482, 1, 12, 968319) Cowardliness which often springs from pacific training, and obsequiousness which comes from the restraint that is handed down from generation to generation, have somehow to be avoided, if the ancient civilization is not to perish before the mad modern rush.
('38', 482, 1, 13, 968577) The distinguishing characteristic of modern civilization is an indefinite multiplicity of human wants.
('38', 482, 1, 14, 968680) The characteristic of ancient civilization is an imperative restriction upon and a strict regulating of those wants.
('38', 482, 1, 15, 968797) The modern or Western insatiableness arises really from want of a living faith in a future state and therefore also in Divinity.
('38', 482, 1, 16, 968926) The restraint of ancient or Eastern civilization arises from a belief, often in spite of ourselves, in a future state and the existence of a Divine Power.

('38', 485, 4, 8, 974069) NANDI HILLS, June 2, 1927 I have your sweet little note.

('38', 485, 4, 15, 974589) You know my theory of the disease, don’t you?
('38', 485, 4, 16, 974635) I regard it as a result of some conscious or unconscious sin as I call or breaches of Nature’s laws.

('38', 492, 5, 16, 988403) 494. LETTER TO GANGUBEHN June 3, 1927 Brahmacharya, etc., can be practised only by an inner urge and by cultivating spiritual energy.
('38', 492, 5, 17, 988537) This energy again can only be cultivated by constant application.
('38', 492, 5, 18, 988603) There are two means of such application.
('38', 492, 5, 19, 988644) One, discriminating and meditative study of good books, and two, efforts to practise the noble principles one has learnt.
('38', 492, 5, 20, 988766) Learning without practice goes waste and serves only to turn one’s head.
('38', 492, 5, 21, 988839) Whatever therefore one has learnt one should immediately reduce to action.
('38', 492, 5, 22, 988914) Therefore, a woman wanting to practise brahma charya should take to non violence, truth, non possession, etc.
('38', 492, 5, 23, 989024) She should thus zealously guard herself against the slightest untruth, against violence in thought, word or deed and should strive to give up all possessions.
('38', 492, 5, 24, 989183) The scriptures tell us that courage and contentment are also to be cultivated.
('38', 492, 5, 25, 989262) Courage should mean both inward and outward courage and it should be practised as soon as its implications are
('38', 493, 0, 1, 989373) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 493, 1, 2, 989415) clearly understood.
('38', 493, 1, 3, 989435) So is the case with contentment.
('38', 493, 1, 4, 989468) We should not be upset if someone abuses us, maligns us or calls us fools.
('38', 493, 1, 5, 989543) This is a sign of contentment.
('38', 493, 1, 6, 989574) We should remain contented even if we do not get food when hungry or we do not get clothes when we shiver.
('38', 493, 1, 7, 989681) And as long as we do not practise what we have learnt we should not take a new lesson.
('38', 493, 1, 8, 989768) We must apply ourselves to a greater understanding of what we have learnt, and think of nothing else.
('38', 493, 1, 9, 989870) This also is a part of the dharma of brahmacharya because the latter is the high watermark of discipline.

('38', 493, 3, 13, 990059) 495. LETTER TO S. D. SATAVALEKAR June 3, 1927 I have almost finished reading the current issue of Vaidika Dharma.
('38', 493, 3, 14, 990173) I wish to make some comments about the article on brahmacharya in the issue.
('38', 493, 3, 15, 990250) You have interpreted brahmacharya only as preservation of the vital fluid and mentioned manly pursuits like hunting and so on in that context.
('38', 493, 3, 16, 990393) Visiting foreign lands and founding colonies have also been mentioned.
('38', 493, 3, 17, 990464) In my humble view this involves unsound logic.
('38', 493, 3, 18, 990511) The first fallacy consists of narrow definition.
('38', 493, 3, 19, 990560) The brahmacharya which you have explained by first quoting a mantra from the Atharva Veda, viz., the gods overcame death by the strength of brahmacharya, and by practising it man also can overcome death, cannot be restricted to mere preservation of the vital fluid.
('38', 493, 3, 20, 990826) The other is the fallacy of too wide definition.
('38', 493, 3, 21, 990875) Brahmacharya need not be associated with acts of valour, etc.
('38', 493, 3, 22, 990937) We see this in the world today.
('38', 493, 3, 23, 990969) If the mere preservation of semen is the object of brahmacharya, it can be attained, as I have said in one of my letters, in a few minutes by a surgical operation.
('38', 493, 3, 24, 991133) This operation does not make a man impotent; but allows him to indulge in sexual pleasures without losing his vital fluid.
('38', 493, 3, 25, 991256) Such a man does not lose by way of manly adventures either.
('38', 493, 3, 26, 991316) I am sure, however, that you will not call this brahmacharya.
('38', 493, 3, 27, 991378) The brahmacharya which you seek is attainable only by the subjugation of sexual and other desires.
('38', 493, 3, 28, 991477) The preservation of the vital fluid, although important, is only a bye product.
('38', 493, 3, 29, 991557) Its direct and primary objective is nothing less than communion with the Brahman.
('38', 493, 3, 30, 991639) This is the only desirable and legitimate adventure on the path of
('38', 494, 0, 1, 991706) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 495
('38', 494, 1, 2, 991749) brahmacharya.
('38', 494, 1, 3, 991763) Why should a man take to the uphill task of conquering desires for the sake of brahmacharya, when manly adventures like vanquishing the enemy or undertaking foreign expeditions can be achieved by thousands of people without practising brahmacharya?
('38', 494, 1, 4, 992012) And nobody does it, as I can vouchsafe from my fairly wide experience.
('38', 494, 1, 5, 992083) Where can we find braver warriors than the German and the English soldiers?
('38', 494, 1, 6, 992159) They are regularly provided with prostitutes.
('38', 494, 1, 7, 992205) Hundreds, if not thousands, of innocent girls are sacrificed to the sexual hunger of these soldiers.
('38', 494, 1, 8, 992306) No one despises these brave Kshatriyas who defend the country; on the other hand, educated and civilized men and women dote on these soldiers.
('38', 494, 1, 9, 992449) I am not employing epithets like Kshatriyas, etc., on my own or to explain my meaning.
('38', 494, 1, 10, 992536) In my view they are no warriors at all.
('38', 494, 1, 11, 992576) I do not consider them defenders of the country.
('38', 494, 1, 12, 992625) Dharma declines when we sing praises of these men.
('38', 494, 1, 13, 992676) But under modern civilization there is nothing but praise for these people.
('38', 494, 1, 14, 992752) Now let us come to the Indian scene.
('38', 494, 1, 15, 992789) Pathans, Sikhs and Gorkhas are the three acknowledged martial races.
('38', 494, 1, 16, 992858) There is a similar provision of prostitutes for them as in the case of the German and other soldiers.
('38', 494, 1, 17, 992960) They have an honoured place, you know, in the Empire.
('38', 494, 1, 18, 993014) If you look at the ancient lores, adultery has been tolerated in the case of Kshatriyas.
('38', 494, 1, 19, 993103) I write all this because I wish that the people should derive full benefit from your profound studies of the Vedas and other ancient scriptures.
('38', 494, 1, 20, 993248) This will be possible by putting the scriptures in the crucible of modern conditions, by objective observation and intense churning.
('38', 494, 1, 21, 993381) I can write a lot on this subject, but this should do to indicate to you the burden of my theme.
('38', 494, 1, 22, 993478) Another reason for my brevity is that I have little energy.
('38', 494, 1, 23, 993538) I have great respect for your learning and truthfulness, which has impelled me r`to write so much.
('38', 494, 1, 24, 993637) [From Hindi]
('38', 494, 2, 25, 993650) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('38', 495, 2, 3, 993773) APPENDIX I EXTRACTS FROM SHAPURJI SAKLATVALA’S OPEN LETTER
('38', 495, 3, 4, 993832) DEAR COMRADE GANDHI,
('38', 495, 4, 5, 993853) We are both erratic enough to permit each other to be rude in order to freely express oneself correctly instead of getting lost in artificiality of phraseology....
('38', 495, 5, 6, 994017) During my conversation with you at certain periods you did not seem to take a definite attitude with regard to the value of organization of labour and peasants.
('38', 495, 5, 7, 994178) You emphatically argued that the charkha movement was making organization.
('38', 495, 5, 8, 994253) I emphatically deny it....
('38', 495, 5, 9, 994280) For centuries together, millions of men and women in India have been boiling rice, utilizing similar quantities of rice and water and conducting cooking operations....
('38', 495, 5, 10, 994448) All these operations surely have not produced any organization and the work of spinning can never do so any more than the work of cooking....
('38', 495, 6, 11, 994590) Before 1900, leaders who .
('38', 495, 6, 12, 994617) worked to build up hopes of salvation .
('38', 495, 6, 13, 994657) were popular leaders as Gladstone was to the British, Bismarck to the Germans, or Parnell to the Irish or Dadabhai or Pherozeshah and Surendranath to the Indians.
('38', 495, 6, 14, 994820) By the year 1900 the masses of men got tired and sick and their hearts began to burn with fire.
('38', 495, 6, 15, 994916) The change came on very rapidly and universally and only such individuals as expressed the burning fire of the heart and the revolt of the suffering human beings were taken as leaders.
('38', 495, 6, 16, 995101) The first task of these was to express boldly and fearlessly the unexpressed voice of the people.
('38', 495, 6, 17, 995199) The second task of these leaders was .
('38', 495, 6, 18, 995238) to make it absolutely impossible for the old order to continue to function.
('38', 495, 6, 19, 995314) The third task was to reconstruct and arduously and slowly to build up a new life.
('38', 495, 6, 20, 995397) Ireland produced a De Valera.
('38', 495, 6, 21, 995427) He did No.
('38', 495, 6, 22, 995438) I and 2 and his people are now bravely carrying on his task No.
('38', 495, 6, 23, 995502) 3. Russia has produced Lenin.
('38', 495, 6, 24, 995532) He did No.
('38', 495, 6, 25, 995543) 1 and 2 and though his life was short, he led his people on the right path regarding No.
('38', 495, 6, 26, 995632) 3. Turkey produced Kemal.
('38', 495, 6, 27, 995658) He did No.
('38', 495, 6, 28, 995669) I and 2 and is fortunate enough to be kicking and vigorous to carry on his task No.
('38', 495, 6, 29, 995753) 3. China produced Sun Yat Sen.
('38', 495, 6, 30, 995784) He completed No.
('38', 495, 6, 31, 995801) I and 2 and after his death his well organized and well disciplined followers are carrying on task No.
('38', 495, 6, 32, 995904) 3. In Italy, though in contrary direction, Mussolini plays the same individual part, India at that moment announced to the world her leader to be Gandhi.
('38', 495, 6, 33, 996058) You performed No.
('38', 495, 6, 34, 996076) 1 but you abandoned task No.
('38', 495, 6, 35, 996105) 2 and so task No.
('38', 495, 6, 36, 996123) 3 is out of the question and we are so overwhelmed with the disastrous defect at the second stage of your struggle that our lot today is harder than before.
('38', 495, 7, 37, 996280) You have created an influence over our countrymen in the lowest strata of society wider and deeper than anybody else.
('38', 495, 7, 38, 996398) However, what is your real object?
('38', 495, 7, 39, 996433) If your purpose is to give your share in the national and political work, your approach to the people should be on terms of absolute equality and your task must be to inspire
('38', 496, 0, 1, 996608) VOL. 38 : 2 JANUARY, 1927 3 JUNE, 1927 497
('38', 496, 1, 2, 996651) confidence into them.
('38', 496, 1, 3, 996673) From this point of view you must stop allowing people to address you as a Mahatma.
('38', 496, 2, 4, 996756) Then there is one thing that I witnessed at Yeotmeal which has hurt me greatly and I had some slight evidence of it before.
('38', 496, 2, 5, 996880) Your work regarding the removal of untouchability is grand in its aspiration and is not bad in its success as it is generally carried on.
('38', 496, 2, 6, 997018) However I strongly object to your permitting my countrymen and countrywomen to touch your feet and put their fingers to their eyes.
('38', 496, 2, 7, 997150) Such touchability appears to be more damnable than untouchability.
('38', 496, 2, 8, 997217) You are ruining the mentality and the psychology of these villagers for another generation or two.
('38', 496, 2, 9, 997316) You are preparing the country not for mass civil disobedience but for servile obedience and for a belief that there are superior persons on earth and Mahatmas in this life at a time when in this country the white man’s prestige is already a dangerous obstacle in our way.
('38', 496, 2, 10, 997588) Politically this career of yours is ruinous and from a humanitarian point of view its degenerating influence appears to me to be a moral plague....
('38', 496, 3, 11, 997736) What I want of you is that you be a good old Gandhi, put an ordinary pair of khaddar trousers and coat and come out and work with us in the ordinary way.
('38', 496, 3, 12, 997890) Come and organize with us (as you alone by yourself have failed) our workers, our peasants and our youths, not with a metaphysical sentimentality but with a set purpose a clear cut and well defined object and by methods such as by experiment are making success for all human beings.
('38', 496, 4, 13, 998173) Therefore before I go, I should like you to get up one morning as from a dream and to say “Yes” and many of us can soon be put together in a good team and set about putting an end to so many deplorable conditions of life in India about which none of us has any doubt.
('38', 496, 4, 14, 998441) I remain, Yours fraternally,
('38', 496, 5, 15, 998470) SHAPURJI SAKLATVALA
('38', 496, 6, 16, 998490) The Hindustan Times, 17 3 1927

('38', 496, 8, 18, 998533) SHRADDHANAND MEMORIAL
('38', 496, 9, 19, 998555) An appeal signed by Pandit Malaviyaji and Lala Lajpat Rai says: It is decided that, except the appeal for 2_ lakhs for the Gurukul Kangri which had already been issued by the Punjab Arya Pratinidhi Sabha, only one appeal should be issued on behalf of the Hindu community as a whole for Rs. 10 lakhs, 5 1akhs of which should be kept as a permanent endowment and 5 lakhs should be used immediately as follows: 1_ lakhs for the uplift of the depressed classes (achhutoddhar); 1 _ for carrying on the work of shuddhi and 1 _ for promoting Hindu sangathan.
('38', 496, 9, 20, 999107) The Trustees shall select such agencies of the Hindu Mahasabha, Sanatan Dharma Sabha and the Arya Samaj, including the Bharatiya Shuddhi Sabha and the Dalitoddhar Sabha of Delhi to carry out the objects of the Trust as they may consider fit from time to time, subject to such general conditions for the submission and audit
('38', 497, 0, 1, 999431) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 497, 1, 2, 999473) of accounts as they may lay down; but the work of sangathan shall be carried out through the Hindu Mahasabha alone.
('38', 497, 1, 3, 999589) The interest of the five lakhs of the permanent fund will also be spent on the three objects named above in the proportion stated.
('38', 497, 1, 4, 999720) It has also been decided that at least half the total amount raised in a province shall be spent within that province, and this applies to the interest of the permanent endowment fund also.
('38', 497, 1, 5, 999910) It has been also resolved that steps be taken to acquire the house in which Swami Shraddhanandji was murdered with the object of converting it into Swami Shraddhanand Memorial Bhavan.
('38', 497, 1, 6, 1000094) Every donor is free to earmark his donation for any of the purposes named above.
('38', 497, 1, 7, 1000175) The donations will be strictly used for that purpose or purposes only for which a donor has given it.
('38', 497, 1, 8, 1000277) All donations should be remitted to the Manager, The Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi, to be credited to the Shraddhanand Memorial Fund.
('38', 497, 1, 9, 1000414) When remitting money, remitters are requested to send to the Bank a complete statement of the names and addresses of donors, and the amounts subscribed by each donor and also his instructions, if any.
('38', 497, 1, 10, 1000615) They are also requested to send a copy of such statements to the Secretary, Shraddhanand Memorial Fund, Delhi.
('38', 497, 1, 11, 1000726) To ensure that all subscriptions are duly credited to the Fund, a formal receipt for the amount subscribed will be sent to the donors by the Secretary, Shraddhanand Memorial Fund.
('38', 497, 1, 12, 1000906) If such a receipt is not received by a donor within fifteen days of payment, it is requested that the donor should inform the Secretary of the fact.
('38', 497, 1, 13, 1001055) We owe it to the memory of the revered Swamiji that the sum of ten lakhs for which the appeal has been issued by the Hindu Mahasabha, should be fully subscribed at the latest by the 30th of April next,
('38', 497, 2, 14, 1001257) We are of opinion that all efforts should be concentrated on raising the All India Memorial and that all movements for local or sectional memorials should be deferred until the All India Memorial Fund is fully subscribed.
('38', 497, 3, 15, 1001479) The division of the Fund into three parts enables everyone to make his own choice and contribute freely to the object he may have most at heart.
('38', 497, 3, 16, 1001624) It is to be hoped that the subscribers will bear in mind the date before which the memorial committee expects to finish the collections.

('38', 498, 8, 12, 1002792) ‘THE MAN WITH THE HOE’
('38', 498, 9, 13, 1002815) Bowed by the weight of centuries he leans Upon his hoe and gazes on the ground, The emptiness of ages in his face, And on his back the burden of the world.
('38', 498, 9, 14, 1002971) Who made him dead to rapture and despair, A thing that grieves not and that never hopes, Staid and stunned, a brother to the Ox?
('38', 498, 9, 15, 1003100) Who loosened and let down this brutal jaw?
('38', 498, 9, 16, 1003143) Whose was the hand that slanted back his brow, Whose breath blew out the light within his brain?
('38', 498, 10, 17, 1003240) Oh, masters, lords and rulers in all lands, Is this the handiwork you give to God, This monstrous thing distorted and soul quenched?
('38', 498, 10, 18, 1003373) How will you ever straighten up this shape, Touch it again with immortality, Give it the upward looking and the light: Rebuild in it the music and the dream?

('38', 498, 12, 21, 1003570) APPENDIX V
('38', 498, 13, 22, 1003581) FROM THE PREFACE TO “BAPU’S LETTERS TO MIRA”
('38', 498, 14, 23, 1003626) In order that the reader may have a clearer background, I will explain briefly the outline of events in my life which led me to Bapu.
('38', 498, 14, 24, 1003760) Having been brought up in an English country home, I was familiar with rural life, besides which there was, inherent in me from the beginning, a profound love of Nature.
('38', 498, 14, 25, 1003930) At the age of 15, I first
('38', 499, 0, 1, 1003956) 500 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('38', 499, 1, 2, 1003998) heard the music of Beethoven.
('38', 499, 1, 3, 1004028) Forthwith my spirit within was awakened to a living sense of the Divine Power, and prayer to God became a reality.
('38', 499, 1, 4, 1004143) Through Beethoven’s music I was led to Romain Rolland, and through Romain Rolland to Bapu.
('38', 499, 1, 5, 1004234) These were not just easy stages.
('38', 499, 1, 6, 1004267) On the contrary, turmoil, darkness, hope, despair—all had to be passed through before the pure Light of Truth broke in upon my troubled soul and led me to my destination.
('38', 499, 1, 7, 1004438) All along a power was impelling me.
('38', 499, 1, 8, 1004474) I did not understand it for a long while, but, by the time I came to know of Romain Rolland, this force was becoming apparent to me, and from the time of our first meetings at Villeneuve, an extraordinary sense of mellow happiness possessed me.
('38', 499, 1, 9, 1004719) I felt something was coming.
('38', 499, 1, 10, 1004748) I had not the slightest idea what.
('38', 499, 1, 11, 1004783) I only knew that all would be well.
('38', 499, 1, 12, 1004819) Even when Romain Rolland talked to me about Bapu, and said a little book he had written about him was in the Press, I did not realize more than that I must read the book.
('38', 499, 1, 13, 1004990) Then the day came when the book was published.
('38', 499, 1, 14, 1005037) I went to the publisher’s shop in the Latin Quarter of Paris, where I was then staying.
('38', 499, 1, 15, 1005125) The whole shop window was full of a little book with an orange coloured cover on which was printed in black ‘Mahatma Gandhi’.
('38', 499, 1, 16, 1005251) I bought a copy, took my lodging and began to read.
('38', 499, 1, 17, 1005303) I could not put it down.
('38', 499, 1, 18, 1005328) I read and read, and as I read the dawn in my heart glowed brighter and brighter, and by the time I had finished, the Sun of Truth was pouring his rays into my soul.
('38', 499, 1, 19, 1005494) From that moment I knew that my life was dedicated to Bapu.
('38', 499, 1, 20, 1005554) That for which I had been waiting had come, and it was this.
('38', 499, 1, 21, 1005615) I straightaway went to London and booked a passage to India at the P. & O. office.
('38', 499, 1, 22, 1005698) I also sought out and devoured all the literature I could; writings of Bapu, writings of Tagore, English and French translations of the Bhagavad Gita; and even the Upanishads and Vedas I peeped into.
('38', 499, 1, 23, 1005898) But very soon I began to realize that I was a fool to think that I could rush to Bapu like this.
('38', 499, 1, 24, 1005995) I was wholly unfit spiritually and physically, and I must first put myself through a severe training.
('38', 499, 1, 25, 1006097) I accordingly went back to the P. & O. office and changed my reserved berth for one a year later.
('38', 499, 2, 26, 1006195) I now set about things in a thorough and systematic way.
('38', 499, 2, 27, 1006252) First I studied the rules and regulations of the Sabarmati Ashram in every detail.
('38', 499, 2, 28, 1006335) Then I began changing my diet item by item, until I reached pure vegetarian food.
('38', 499, 2, 29, 1006417) I started sitting cross legged on the floor.
('38', 499, 2, 30, 1006462) Ten minutes at a stretch was all I could do in the beginning, but with steady practice I became perfectly at ease.
('38', 499, 2, 31, 1006577) I commenced lessons in Urdu and of course learnt carding, spinning and weaving.
('38', 499, 2, 32, 1006657) This had to be in wool, but gave me good practice.
('38', 499, 2, 33, 1006708) At the same time study of the literature continued.
('38', 499, 2, 34, 1006760) In the midst of this training news came in the papers that Bapu had gone on a 21 days’ fast for Hindu Muslim unity.
('38', 499, 2, 35, 1006876) As the days went by, the papers began saying that Bapu would probably not survive.
('38', 499, 2, 36, 1006959) I prayed to God in anguish.
('38', 499, 2, 37, 1006987) The days dragged on.
('38', 499, 2, 38, 1007008) But I never slackened in my training because, even if Bapu were to pass away in his physical form, I knew I must go to India to serve his cause.
('38', 499, 2, 39, 1007153) It seemed an eternity, but at last the 21 days were over and the news came that the fast had been safely broken.
('38', 499, 2, 40, 1007266) Up to now I had not written a word to Bapu.
('38', 499, 2, 41, 1007310) But on the successful completion of the fast, my heart was so full of thankful joy that I just had to write.
('38', 499, 3, 42, 1007419) Bapu’s Letters to Mira, pp.
